melosa: A South American herb (Madia sativa) with sticky glandular foliage; it is a source of madia oil.
Manstealer: A person who steals or kidnaps a human being or beings.
Multiformity: The quality of being multiform; diversity of forms; variety of appearances in the same thing.
Multivalent: Having a valence greater than one, as silicon.
Munificence: The quality or state of being munificent; a giving or bestowing with extraordinary liberality; generous bounty; lavish generosity.
Minimization: The act or process of minimizing.
Monorhyme: A composition in verse, in which all the lines end with the same rhyme.
Mint sauce: A sauce of vinegar and sugar flavored with spearmint leaves.
Munchausenism: An extravagant fiction embodying an account of some marvelous exploit or adventure.
maiden blue-eyed mary: A small widely branching Western wildflower (Collinsia parviflora) with tiny blue-and-white flowers; found from British Columbia to Ontaria and south to California and Colorado.
Magnesic: Pertaining to, or containing, magnesium; as, magnesic oxide.
Magnesia: A light earthy white substance, consisting of magnesium oxide (MgO), and obtained by heating magnesium hydrate or carbonate, or by burning magnesium.  It has a slightly alkaline reaction, and is used in medicine as a mild antacid laxative. See Magnesium.
&Verbar;Melada: A mixture of sugar and molasses; crude sugar as it comes from the pans without being drained.
Monsels solution: An aqueous solution of Monsel's salt, having valuable styptic properties.
&Verbar;Marimba: A musical istrument of percussion, consisting of bars yielding musical tones when struck.
Merlin: A small European falcon (Falco columbarius, syn. Falco lithofalco, or Falco æsalon).  In North America called also pigeon hawk.
Malay Peninsula: a peninsula in Southeastern Asia occupied by parts of Malaysia and Thailand and Burma.
millet: The name of several cereal and forage grasses which bear an abundance of small roundish grains. The common millets of Germany and Southern Europe are Panicum miliaceum, and Setaria Italica.
Megalethoscope: An optical apparatus in which pictures are viewed through a large lens with stereoptical effects.  It is often combined with the stereoscope.
Matthew: Saint Matthew, a disciple of Jesus; author of the first Gospel.
Marram: A coarse grass found on sandy beaches (Ammophila arundinacea). See Beach grass, under Beach.
&Verbar;Maguari: A South American stork (Euxenara maguari), having a forked tail.
misandry: Hatred of men.  Contrast misogyny and cf. misandrist.
Mucky: Filthy with muck; miry; as, a mucky road.
Measure: To make a measurement or measurements.
Merchantly: Merchantlike; suitable to the character or business of a merchant.
Mirabilary: One who, or a work which, narrates wonderful things; one who writes of wonders.
Mist: To rain in very fine drops; as, it mists.
Mohr: A West African gazelle (Gazella mohr), having horns on which are eleven or twelve very prominent rings. It is one of the species which produce bezoar.
Monamide: An amido compound with only one amido group; a monoamide.
Muconic: Of, pertaining to, or designating, an organic acid (C6H6O4, 2-4-hexadienedoic acid), obtained indirectly from mucic acid, and somewhat resembling itaconic acid.  Various other means of synthesis have been reported.
Moha: A kind of millet (Setaria Italica); German millet.
Moho: The boundary between the earth's crust and the semiliquid mantle beneath.  It varies in depth from 3 miles beneath the surface at certain points in the ocean to over 25 miles under certain parts of continents.
mMolendinaceous: Resembling the sails of a windmill.
Mannide: A white amorphous or crystalline substance, obtained by dehydration of mannite, and distinct from, but convertible into, mannitan.
Mizzenmast: the third mast from the bow in a vessel having three or more masts; the after and shorter mast of a yawl, ketch, or dandy.
monetization: The act or process of converting into money, or of establishing something (e.g. gold or silver) as the legal tender of a country; as, the monetization of silver.
Meute: A cage for hawks; a mew. See 4th Mew, 1.
Masthead: To cause to go to the masthead as a punishment.
maori hen: A flightless New Zealand rail of thievish disposition having short wings each with a spur used in fighting.
minuend: In the process of subtraction{2}, the number from which another number (the subtrahend) is to be subtracted, to find the difference.
Mantoux test: A skin test for hypersensitivity to tuberculin.  It determines whether there is or has been any infection with tubercle bacilli.
Maturate: To ripen; to become mature; specifically, to suppurate.
Mazdean: Of or pertaining to Ahura-Mazda, or Ormuzd, the beneficent deity in the Zoroastrian dualistic system; hence, Zoroastrian.
Mystery: A trade; a handicraft; hence, any business with which one is usually occupied.
Malmsey: A kind of sweet wine from Crete, the Canary Islands, etc.
macarena: a dance performed by dancers in a line, or several lines, consisting mainly of hand and arm movements; also, the name of the song to which the dance is usually performed.  It became popular in 1996.
malign: Having an evil disposition toward others; harboring violent enmity; malevolent; malicious; spiteful; -- opposed to benign.
&Verbar;Mesorchium: The fold of peritoneum which attaches the testis to the dorsal wall of the body cavity or scrotal sac.
Monotropaceae: A natural family of plants, used in some classifications for saprophytic herbs; it is sometimes included in the family Pyrolaceae, and contains the genera Monotropa and Sarcodes.
Maritime: Bordering on, or situated near, the ocean; connected with the sea by site, interest, or power; having shipping and commerce or a navy; as, maritime states.
Make-game: An object of ridicule; a butt.
Metabolite: A product of metabolism; a substance produced by metabolic action, as urea.
Monger: To deal in; to make merchandise of; to traffic in; -- used chiefly of discreditable traffic.
minimized: Reduced to the smallest possible size or amount or degree.
&Verbar;Magister: Master; sir; -- a title of the Middle Ages, given to a person in authority, or to one having a license from a university to teach philosophy and the liberal arts.
Monal: Any Asiatic pheasant of the genus Lophophorus, as the Impeyan pheasant.
Monad: An ultimate atom, or simple, unextended point; something ultimate and indivisible.
Miltonic: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, Milton, or his writings; as, Miltonic prose.
magnetic flux density: The amount of magnetic flux in a unit area perpendicular to the direction of magnetic flow.
Manubrial: Of or pertaining to a manubrium; shaped like a manubrium; handlelike.
Micromere: One of the smaller cells, or blastomeres, resulting from the complete segmentation of a telolecithal ovum.
Myoid: Composed of, or resembling, muscular fiber.
Milquetoast: a timid, unassertive man or boy fearful of confrontation and easily manipulated and dominated.
&Verbar;Majuscul\u00e6: Capital letters, as found in manuscripts of the sixth century and earlier.
Metallographist: One who writes on the subject of metals.
Mortress: A dish of meats and other ingredients, cooked together; an ollapodrida.
Meliorism: The doctrine that there is a tendency throughout nature toward improvement.
&Verbar;Miscellanea: A collection of miscellaneous matters; matters of various kinds.
&Verbar;mutandum: A thing which is to be changed; something which must be altered; -- used chiefly in the plural.
Macrodome: A dome parallel to the longer lateral axis of an orthorhombic crystal. See Dome, n., 4.
man-made: Not of natural origin; prepared or made by humans; artificial; of substances, made by chemical reaction rather than extracted from a natural source; as, man-made fibers; man-made gems.  Opposed to natural.
Mooncalf: A monster; a false conception; a mass of fleshy matter, generated in the uterus.
Mechanics: That science, or branch of applied mathematics, which treats of the action of forces on bodies.
Milling: The act or employment of grinding or passing through a mill; the process of fulling; the process of making a raised or intented edge upon coin, etc.; the process of dressing surfaces of various shapes with rotary cutters. See Mill.
mid-on: the fielding position in cricket closest to the bowler on the on side.
Margravate: The territory or jurisdiction of a margrave.
Mouse: To tear, as a cat devours a mouse.
Martyrization: Act of martyrizing, or state of being martyrized; torture.
Maplike: Having or consisting of lines resembling a map; as, the maplike figures in which certain lichens grow.
macula lutea: A yellowish central area of the retina that is rich in cones.
matinal: Relating to the morning, or to matins; matutinal.
Mistrial: A false or erroneous trial; a trial which has no result; a trial which comes to no conclusion, such as a criminal trial which does not produce a unanimous verdict of the jurors.
Melanagogue: A medicine supposed to expel black bile or choler.
Metope: The space between two triglyphs of the Doric frieze, which, among the ancients, was often adorned with carved work. See Illust. of Entablature.
Magellanic: Of or pertaining to, or named from, Ferdinand Magellan (1480-1521), the navigator.
Melampsoraceae: A natural family of rust fungi.
Mature: To advance toward maturity; to become ripe; as, wine matures by age; the judgment matures by age and experience.
Multiplicative: Tending to multiply; having the power to multiply, or incease numbers.
Minge: A small biting fly; a midge.
Maelstrom: A celebrated whirlpool on the coast of Norway.
Mercenary: One who is hired; a hireling; especially, a soldier hired into foreign service.
Mooned: Of or resembling the moon; symbolized by the moon.
Miswend: To go wrong; to go astray.
magnetic disc: A ditical memory device consisting of a flat disk covered with a magnetic coating on which information is stored; a hard disk, floppy disk, and diskette are typically magnetic disks.
Moroxite: A variety of apatite of a greenish blue color.
&Verbar;Mara: The Patagonian cavy, a hare-like rodent (Dolichotis patagonum or Dolichotis Patagonicus) of the pampas of Argentina.
Millionth: The quotient of a unit divided by one million; one of a million equal parts.
mind-boggling: intellectually or emotionally overwhelming; straining one's capacity to comprehend or cope; as, a mind-boggling display; a mind-boggling puzzle.
&Verbar;Mon\u0153cia: A Linnæan class of plants, whose stamens and pistils are in distinct flowers in the same plant.
&Verbar;Moya: Mud poured out from volcanoes during eruptions; -- so called in South America.
Modernness: The quality or state of being modern; recentness; novelty.
Midfeather: A vertical water space in a fire box or combustion chamber.
Medicamental: Of or pertaining to medicaments or healing applications; having the qualities of medicaments.
mutilated: badly injured, perhaps with amputation or permanent disfigurement; as, mutilated victims of the rocket attack.
Manducable: Such as can be chewed; fit to be eaten.
Montanic: Of or pertaining to mountains; consisting of mountains.
Multivalence: Quality, state, or degree, of a multivalent element, atom, or radical.
Mightiness: The quality of being mighty; possession of might; power; greatness; high dignity.
Molecularly: With molecules; in the manner of molecules.
Methodology: The science of method or arrangement; a treatise on method.
&Verbar;Macrocystis: An immensely long blackish seaweed of the Pacific (Macrocystis pyrifera), having numerous almond-shaped air vessels.
Megasthene: One of a group which includes the higher orders of mammals, having a large size as a typical characteristic.
Minister: To act as a servant, attendant, or agent; to attend and serve; to perform service in any office, sacred or secular.
Moghul: Of or pertaining to the Moguls{2}; as, The Taj Mahal, the most beautiful piece of Mogul architecture, was built by the Mogul emperor Shah Jehan as a mausoleum for his favorite wife.
Missionary: Of or pertaining to missions; as, a missionary meeting; a missionary fund.
matriarch: The mother and ruler of a family or of her descendants; a ruler by maternal right.
mystique: An aura of reverence or mystery stemming from  feelings of high value or interest or meaning surrounding a person or thing; as, the Kennedy mystique.
Monticulate: Furnished with monticles or little elevations.
Mammalogy: The science which relates to mammals or the Mammalia. See Mammalia.
Mahogany: A large tree of the genus Swietenia (Swietenia Mahogoni), found in tropical America.
Macerater: One who, or that which, macerates; an apparatus for converting paper or fibrous matter into pulp.
Motley-minded: Having a mind of a jester; foolish.
Magnetite: An oxide of iron (Fe3O4) occurring in isometric crystals, also massive, of a black color and metallic luster.  It is readily attracted by a magnet and sometimes possesses polarity, being then called loadstone.  It is an important iron ore.  Called also magnetic iron.
&Verbar;Metensomatosis: The assimilation by one body or organism of the elements of another.
Malacissation: The act of making soft or supple.
Molehill: A little hillock of earth thrown up by moles working under ground; hence, a very small hill, or an insignificant obstacle or difficulty; as, to make a mountain out of a molehill.
&Verbar;Manis: A genus of edentates, covered with large, hard, triangular scales, with sharp edges that overlap each other like tiles on a roof.  They inhabit the warmest parts of Asia and Africa, and feed on ants. Called also Scaly anteater. See Pangolin.
&Verbar;Mugil: A genus of fishes including the gray mullets. See Mullet.
Monopolistic: Of or pertaining to a monopolist.
menu: The details of a banquet; a list of the dishes served at a meal, whether or not one has a choice.
Mohicans: A tribe of Lenni-Lenape Indians who formerly inhabited Western Connecticut and Eastern New York.
Moringa: A genus of trees of Southern India and Northern Africa.  One species (Moringa pterygosperma) is the horse-radish tree, and its seeds, as well as those of Moringa aptera, are known in commerce as ben or ben nuts, and yield the oil called oil of ben.
Mussel: Any one of many species of marine bivalve shells of the genus Mytilus, and related genera, of the family Mytidæ.  The common mussel (Mytilus edulis; see Illust. under Byssus), and the larger, or horse, mussel (Modiola modiolus), inhabiting the shores both of Europe and America, are edible. The former is extensively used as food in Europe.
Monogoneutic: Having but one brood in a season.
&Verbar;Malacostraca: A subclass of Crustacea, including Arthrostraca and Thoracostraca, or all those higher than the Entomostraca.
manila grass: A lawn grass (Zoysia matrella) common in the Philippines; grown also in US.
Metacarpal: Of or pertaining to the metacarpus.
Mackenzie: a Canadian river; flows into the Beaufort Sea.
Monopolist: One who monopolizes; one who has a monopoly; one who favors monopoly.
Mandola: An instrument closely resembling the mandolin, but of larger size and tuned lower.
Marsh: A tract of soft wet land, commonly covered partially or wholly with water; a fen; a swamp; a morass.
Mummified: Converted into a mummy or a mummylike substance; having the appearance of a mummy; withered.
Marabou: A large black-and-white carrion-eating stork of the genus Leptoptilos (formerly Ciconia), esp. the African species (Leptoptilus crumeniferus syn. Leptoptilos crumenifer), whose downy under-wing feathers are used to trim garments; called also marabout.  The Asiatic species (Leptoptilos dubius, or Leptoptilos argala) is the adjutant. See Adjutant.
Midday: Of or pertaining to noon; meridional; as, the midday sun.
Macaca radiata: An Indian macaque with a bonnetlike tuft of hair.
Medusiform: Resembling a medusa in shape or structure.
Metagnathous: Cross-billed; -- said of certain birds, as the crossbill.
Missheathed: Sheathed by mistake; wrongly sheathed; sheathed in a wrong place.
Misappropriate: To appropriate wrongly; to use for a wrong purpose.
Mammet: An idol; a puppet; a doll.
Mechanic: Having to do with the application of the laws of motion in the art of constructing or making things; of or pertaining to mechanics; mechanical; as, the mechanic arts.
Mammea: A genus of American and Asiatic trees having edible one-seeded fruit.
Manubial: Belonging to spoils; taken in war.
Mammee: A fruit tree of tropical America, belonging to the genus Mammea (Mammea Americana); also, its fruit, called the mammee apple.  The latter is large, covered with a thick, tough ring, and contains a bright yellow pulp of a pleasant taste and fragrant scent.  It is often called mammee apple.
Malabar: A region in the western part of the Peninsula of India, between the mountains and the sea.
Millerite: A sulphide of nickel, commonly occurring in delicate capillary crystals, also in incrustations of a bronze yellow; -- sometimes called hair pyrites.
&Verbar;Mameluco: A child born of a white father and Indian mother.
metalorganic: Pertaining to, or denoting, any one of a series of compounds of certain metallic elements with organic radicals; as, zinc methyl, sodium ethyl, etc.; now usually organometallic.
&Verbar;Moniliales: The largest of the three orders into which the Fungi Imperfecti are divided, including various forms.
meaningfulness: the quality of having great meaning or value.
matte: Having a dull, lusterless surface finish; opposed to glossy or polished; as, a matte photograph; a proof coin with matte figures on a polished field.
Methol: An earlier  technical name of methyl alcohol or wood spirit, now called methanol; also, by extension, the class name of any of the series of alcohols of the methane series of which methol proper is the type. See Methyl alcohol, under Methyl.
Meditative: Disposed to meditate, or to meditation; as, a meditative man; a meditative mood.
&Verbar;Mahout: The keeper and driver of an elephant.
Method: An orderly procedure or process; regular manner of doing anything; hence, manner; way; mode; as, a method of teaching languages; a method of improving the mind.
Movement: The act of moving in space; change of place or posture; motion; as, the movement of an army in marching or maneuvering; the movement of a wheel or a machine.
Mainpernable: Capable of being admitted to give surety by mainpernors; able to be mainprised.
Mucic: Pertaining to, or derived from, gums and micilaginous substances; specif., denoting an acid obtained by the oxidation of gums, dulcite, etc., as a white crystalline substance isomeric with saccharic acid.
Malar: Of or pertaining to the region of the cheek bone, or to the malar bone; jugal.
Mahdism: Belief in the coming of the Mahdi; fanatical devotion to the cause of the Mahdi or a pretender to that title.
Morkin: A beast that has died of disease or by mischance.
Mylitta: The goddess of love and fertility and war; also called Ishtar; the counterpart of Ashtoreth and Astarte.
Malax: To soften by kneading or stirring with some thinner substance.
Malay: Of or pertaining to the Malays or their country.
Marrow: To fill with, or as with, marrow or fat; to glut.
mothball: To put into long-term storage; as, to mothball the battleships not needed after the war.
Moneyed: Supplied with money; having money; wealthy; as, moneyed men.
Mothery: Consisting of, containing, or resembling, mother (in vinegar).
Murk: The refuse of fruit, after the juice has been expressed; marc.
Moneyer: A person who deals in money; banker or broker.
Myrmecophagidae: A natural family of New World anteaters.
Moabite stone: A block of black basalt, found at Dibon in Moab by Rev. F. A. Klein, Aug. 19, 1868, which bears an inscription of thirty-four lines, dating from the 9th century b. c., and written in the Moabite alphabet, the oldest Phœnician type of the Semitic alphabet.  It records the victories of Mesha, king of Moab, esp. those over Israel (2 Kings iii. 4, 5, 27).
&Verbar;Madrina: An animal (usually an old mare), wearing a bell and acting as the leader of a troop of pack mules.
Misobserve: To observe inaccurately; to mistake in observing.
mutual savings bank: a state-chartered savings bank owned by its depositors and managed by a board of trustees.  Abbreviated MSB.
Myrtus: The type genus of the Myrtaceae.
Meiostemonous: Having fever stamens than the parts of the corolla.
Mure: To inclose in walls; to wall; to immure; to shut up.
Misprint: To print wrongly; to make a mistake in printing.
moundbird: Any of several large-footed short-winged birds of Australasia, which build mounds of decaying vegetation to incubate eggs.  Called also mound builder, mound maker, megapode, brush turkey, and scrub fowl.
magnetomotive force: The force that produces magnetic flux.
malapropism: A grotesque misuse of a word; a word so used.
&Verbar;Mouill\u00e9: Applied to certain consonants having a “liquid” or softened sound; e. g., in French, l or ll and gn (like the lli in million and ni in minion); in Italian, gl and gn; in Spanish, ll and ñ; in Portuguese, lh and nh.
myocardial: Of or pertaining to the myocardium.
Mineralogize: To study mineralogy by collecting and examining minerals.
Mill-cake: The incorporated materials for gunpowder, in the form of a dense mass or cake, ready to be subjected to the process of granulation.
Melanconiace\u00e6: A family of fungi constituting the order Melanconiales.
maximizing: Making as great as possible; increasing tothe highest degree.
Milord: Lit., my lord; hence (as used on the Continent), an English nobleman or gentleman.
Martyr: To put to death for adhering to some belief, esp. Christianity; to sacrifice on account of faith or profession.
Myochrome: A colored albuminous substance in the serum from red-colored muscles.  It is identical with hemoglobin.
Merluce: The European hake; -- called also herring hake and sea pike.
Menaccanite: An iron-black or steel-gray mineral, consisting chiefly of the oxides of iron and titanium. It is commonly massive, but occurs also in rhombohedral crystals.  Called also titanic iron ore, and ilmenite.
Medicinable: Medicinal; having the power of healing.
Matajuelo blanco: A West Indian food fish (Malacanthus plumieri) related to the tilefish.
Melancholist: One affected with melancholy or dejection.
&Verbar;Metazoa: Those animals in which the protoplasmic mass, constituting the egg, is converted into a multitude of cells, which are metamorphosed into the tissues of the body.  A central cavity is commonly developed, and the cells around it are at first arranged in two layers, -- the ectoderm and endoderm.  The group comprises nearly all animals except the Protozoa.
Mohammedanism: The religion, or doctrines and precepts, of Mohammed, contained in the Koran; Islamism; Islam.  The term Islam is preferred by most Moslems, and some find the term Mohammedanism to be offensive, as they worship Allah, not Mohammed.
Mendelian: Pert. to Mendel, or to Mendel's law; as, Mendelian inheritance.
main street: A main thoroughfare, usually one in a small town having the largest concentration of retail businesses.
Mahound: A contemptuous name for Mohammed; hence, an evil spirit; a devil.
malawi kwacha: The kwacha, the monetary unit of Malawi.
Mackerel: Any species of the genus Scomber of the family Scombridae, and of several related genera.  They are finely formed and very active oceanic fishes.  Most of them are highly prized for food.
malnutrition: Faulty or imperfect nutrition; inadequate or unbalanced food intake.
&Verbar;M\u00e6nad: A Bacchante; a priestess or votary of Bacchus.
Mummer: One who mumms, or makes diversion in disguise; a masker; a buffon.
macabre: portraying human injury or death in a way so as to inspiring shock or horror; gruesome; ghastly; as, macabre tortures conceived by madmen.
Manslayer: One who kills a human being; one who commits manslaughter.
magic spell: A verbal formula considered to have magical force.
mountaineer: To live or act as a mountaineer; to climb mountains.
&Verbar;Macropus: A genus of marsupials including the common kangaroo.
Mohammedan: A follower of Mohammed, the founder of Islam (also called Islamism or Mohammedanism); an adherent of Islam; one who professes Mohammedanism or Islamism; a Muslim; a Moslem; a Musselman; -- this term is used mostly by non-Moslems, and some Moslems find it offensive.
Motley: A combination of distinct colors; esp., the party-colored cloth, or clothing, worn by the professional fool.
Muddiness: The condition or quality of being muddy; turbidness; foulness caused by mud, dirt, or sediment; as, the muddiness of a stream.
Magistrate: A person clothed with power as a public civil officer; a public civil officer invested with the executive government, or some branch of it.
Misuse: Wrong use; misapplication; erroneous or improper use.
mantispid: Any neuropterous insect of the genus Mantispa, and allied genera.  The larvæ feed on plant lice.  Also used adjectively. See Illust. under Neuroptera.
Maintainor: One who, not being interested, maintains a cause depending between others, by furnishing money, etc., to either party.
magnesium hydroxide: A slightly alkaline chemical substance, Mg(OH)2, the active principle in the antacid milk of magnesia, also used as a laxative.
Mortgagee: The person to whom property is mortgaged, or to whom a mortgage is made or given.
Monoplastic: That has one form, or retains its primary form, as, a monoplastic element.
Molecularity: The state of consisting of molecules; the state or quality of being molecular.
Mislead: To lead into a wrong way or path; to lead astray; to guide into error; to cause to mistake; to deceive.
Mendicity: The practice of begging; the life of a beggar; mendicancy.
Maian: Any spider crab of the genus Maia, or family Maiadæ.
Macoun: A juicy, late-ripening apple similar to a McIntosh.
Manation: The act of issuing or flowing out.
&Verbar;Manta: The manta ray.  See also Cephaloptera and Sea devil.
maxwell: A cgs unit of magnetic flux, abbreviated Mx; it is equal to the magnetic flux passing through one sqaure centimeter which is normal to a magnetic field of one gauss.
Metathorax: The last or posterior segment of the thorax in insects. See Illust. of Coleoptera.
Musaceae: A natural family of treelike tropical Asian herbs including the banana tree.
Marketer: One who attends a market to buy or sell; one who carries goods to market.
Moment: A minute portion of time; a point of time; an instant; as, at that very moment.
manner of speaking: The characteristic style or manner that a person uses to express himself orally.
Murmur: To utter or give forth in low or indistinct words or sounds; as, to murmur tales.
Metronymic: Derived from the name of one's mother, or other female ancestor; as, a metronymic name or appellation.
Materialize: To appear as a material form; to take substantial shape.
Mastodon: An extinct genus of mammals closely allied to the elephant, but having less complex molar teeth, and often a pair of lower, as well as upper, tusks, which are incisor teeth.  The species were mostly larger than elephants, and their remains occur in nearly all parts of the world in deposits ranging from Miocene to late Quaternary time.
Mucosity: The quality or state of being mucous or slimy; mucousness.
Malleation: The act or process of beating into a plate, sheet, or leaf, as a metal; extension by beating.
Miswander: To wander in a wrong path; to stray; to go astray.
&Verbar;Mayoral: The conductor of a mule team; also, a head shepherd.
Marjoram: A genus of mintlike plants (Origanum) comprising about twenty-five species.  The sweet marjoram (Origanum Majorana) is pecularly aromatic and fragrant, and much used in cookery.  The wild marjoram of Europe and America is Origanum vulgare, far less fragrant than the other.
Mycology: That branch of botanical science which relates to the mushrooms and other fungi.
millennium bug: An error in the coding of certain computer programs which store the year component of the date as two digits, assuming that the first two digits are 19, rather than as a complete number of four digits; when such programs are used after January 1, 2000, the date may be misinterpreted, causing serious errors or total failure of the program; -- called also year 2000 bug, year 2000 problem and Y2K bug.
megakaryocytic: Of or pertaining to a megakaryocyte.
Metamer: Any one of several metameric forms of the same substance, or of different substances having the same composition; as, xylene has three metamers, viz., orthoxylene, metaxylene, and paraxylene; an isomer.
Metempiric: Related, or belonging, to the objects of knowledge within the province of metempirics.
Morin: A yellow crystalline substance (C15H10O7) of acid properties extracted from fustic (Chlorophora tinctoria syn. Maclura tinctoria, formerly called Morus tinctoria); -- called also moric acid and natural yellow 8.  It is used as a dye for wool, giving a color from lemon yellow through olive to olive brown, depending on the metal with which it is mordanted.
mid-sixties: the time of life between 60 and 70.
Manometer: An instrument for measuring the tension or elastic force of gases, steam, etc., constructed usually on the principle of allowing the gas to exert its elastic force in raising a column of mercury in an open tube, or in compressing a portion of air or other gas in a closed tube with mercury or other liquid intervening, or in bending a metallic or other spring so as to set in motion an index; a pressure gauge. See Pressure, and Illust. of Air pump.
magic lantern: An early form of slide projector.
Myxinoid: Like, or pertaining to, the genus Myxine.
Metacetone: A colorless liquid of an agreeable odor, C6H10O, obtained by distilling a mixture of sugar and lime; -- so called because formerly regarded as a polymeric modification of acetone.
Maundy coins: Silver coins or money of the nominal value of 1d., 2d., 3d., and 4d., struck annually for the Maundy alms.
Metathesis: Transposition, as of the letters or syllables of a word; as, pistris for pristis; meagre for meager.
Memphian: A native or resident of the city of Memphis in Tennessee.
Magnetization: The act of magnetizing, or the state of being magnetized.
Madness: The condition of being mad; insanity; lunacy.
Monocrotism: That condition of the pulse in which the pulse curve or sphygmogram shows but a single crest, the dicrotic elevation entirely disappearing.
Multiaxial: Having more than one axis; developing in more than a single line or plain; -- opposed to monoaxial.
Metatarsal: Of or pertaining to the metatarsus.
Madeira: A rich wine made on the Island of Madeira.
Masterly: With the skill of a master.
Middle-ground: That part of a picture between the foreground and the background.
Mauger: In spite of; in opposition to; notwithstanding.
morindin: A yellow dyestuff (C27H30O14) extracted from the root bark of an East Indian plant (Morinda citrifolia) or from the bark of Coprosma australis.  The substance is also found in the fruit of the Morinda citrifolia, called noni, which is touted by some merchants to have a stimulatory effect on the immune system.  It is a disaccharide derivative of anthracenedione.
&Verbar;mina: An ancient weight or denomination of money, of varying value.  The Attic mina was valued at a hundred drachmas.
Meconidine: An alkaloid found in opium, and extracted as a yellow amorphous substance which is easily decomposed.
Museless: Unregardful of the Muses; disregarding the power of poetry; unpoetical.
Monotheism: The doctrine or belief that there is but one God.
macho: Manly, especially with an assertive and domineering manner toward women.
&Verbar;Macroglossia: Enlargement or hypertrophy of the tongue.
malt liquor: An alcoholic drink made with malt.
Monologue: A speech uttered by a person alone; soliloquy; also, talk or discourse in company, in the strain of a soliloquy; as, an account in monologue.
Matronhood: The state of being a matron.
Momentary: Done in a moment; continuing only a moment; lasting a very short time; as, a momentary pang.
mudcat: A large catfish (Pylodictus olivaris, formerly Leptops olivaris) of the central U. S. having a flattened head and projecting jaw.
Muzzle-loading: Receiving its charge through the muzzle; as, a muzzle-loading rifle.
&Verbar;Macropteres: A division of birds; the Longipennes.
M1: The narrowest measure of the money supply, comprising the currency in circulation plus demand deposits or checking account balances.
M3: A broad measure of the money supply, comprising M2 plus deposits at nonbanks such as savings and loan associations.
M2: A measure of the money supply broader than M1 but narrower than M3, comprising M1 plus net time deposits (other than large certificates of deposit).
Monarch: Superior to others; preëminent; supreme; ruling.
Monophonic: Single-voiced; having but one part; as, a monophonic composition; -- opposed to polyphonic.
&Verbar;Mamelon: A rounded hillock; a rounded elevation or protuberance.
malaria mosquito: A mosquito that transmits the malaria parasite; it is most commonly the Anopheles mosquito.
meld: Any combination or score which may be declared, or melded, in pinochle.
Me: The person speaking, regarded as an object; myself; a pronoun of the first person used as the objective and dative case of the pronoum I; as, he struck me; he gave me the money, or he gave the money to me; he got me a hat, or he got a hat for me.
Muggins: In certain games, to score against, or take an advantage over (an opponent), as for an error, announcing the act by saying “muggins.”
Mo: chemical symbol for the element molybdenum.
Mi: A syllable applied to the third tone of the scale of C, i. e., to E, in European solmization, but to the third tone of any scale in the American system.
Mugging: A robbery; a taking of property by threatening (or performing) violence on the person who is robbed.  See mug, v.
Make and break: Any apparatus for making and breaking an electric circuit; a circuit breaker.
Mispoint: To point improperly; to punctuate wrongly.
My: Of or belonging to me; -- used always attributively; as, my body; my book; -- mine is used in the predicate; as, the book is mine. See Mine.
Mx: The symbol for the maxwell, a cgs unit of magnetic flux.
MO: abbreviation for modus operandi, manner of operating; -- often used to refer to the method an habitual criminal uses to perpetrate his crime.
MT: A metric ton, a unit of weight equivalent to 1000 kilograms.
Mirza: The common title of honor in Persia, prefixed to the surname of an individual.  When appended to the surname, it signifies Prince.
Malacca: A town and district upon the seacoast of the Malay Peninsula.
myxobacterium: A type of bacteria that form colonies in self-produced slime; they inhabit moist soils or decaying plant matter or animal waste.
Muride: Bromine; -- formerly so called from its being obtained from sea water.
macromolecule: A very large molecule, especially a polymer having from hundreds to many thousands of atoms, such as DNA, RNA, protein, polysaccharide, polyethylene, polycarbonate, etc.
Magistery: Mastery; powerful medical influence; renowned efficacy; a sovereign remedy.
monaural: Having or hearing with only one ear.
Mermaid: A fabled marine creature, typically represented as having the upper part like that of a woman, and the lower like a fish; a sea nymph, sea woman, or woman fish.
madagascar jasmine: A twining woody vine (Stephanotis floribunda) of Madagascar having thick dark waxy evergreen leaves and clusters of large fragrant waxy white flowers along the stems; widely cultivated in warm regions.
Marcasitic: Containing, or having the nature of, marcasite.
Mutualism: The doctrine of mutual dependence as the condition of individual and social welfare.
Mateology: A vain, unprofitable discourse or inquiry.
Maceration: The act or process of macerating.
Michaelmas: The feast of the archangel Michael, a church festival, celebrated on the  29th of September. Hence, colloquially, autumn.
Meerschaum: A fine white claylike mineral, soft, and light enough when in dry masses to float in water.  It is a hydrous silicate of magnesia, and is obtained chiefly in Asia Minor.  It is manufacturd into tobacco pipes, cigar holders, etc. Also called sepiolite.
Mammutidae: An extinct natural family of mammals, comprising the mastodons.
Mitigate: To make less severe, intense, harsh, rigorous, painful, etc.; to soften; to meliorate; to alleviate; to diminish; to lessen; as, to mitigate heat or cold; to mitigate grief.
marbles: A children's game played with marbles{3}, little balls made of a hard substance (as glass).
Monkey-pot: The fruit of two South American trees (Lecythis Ollaria, and Lecythis Zabucajo), which have for their fruit large, pot-shaped, woody capsules containing delicious nuts, and opening almost explosively by a circular lid at the top.  Vases and pots are made of this capsule.
Mortal: A being subject to death; a human being; man.
Monitor nozzle: A nozzle capable of turning completely round in a horizontal plane and having a limited play in a vertical plane, used in hydraulic mining, fire-extinguishing apparatus, etc.
Ministration: The act of ministering; service; ministry.
Mugwort: A somewhat aromatic composite weed (Artemisia vulgaris), at one time used medicinally; -- called also motherwort.
magnetic levitation: The process of supporting an object, such as a vehicle, with a magnetic field so that it does not contact the object supporting it; it is a method used for eliminating friction in moving vehicles, and is used, e.g. in high-speed rail technology where a train is suspended on a magnetic cushion above a magnetized track and so travels free of friction.
Magnificent: Doing grand things; admirable in action; displaying great power or opulence, especially in building, way of living, and munificence.
Myriarch: A captain or commander of ten thousand men.
Mugweed: A slender European weed (Galium Cruciata); -- called also crossweed.
mileometer: a meter that shows mileage traversed.
Magnoliidae: a group of families of trees and shrubs and herbs having well-developed perianths and apocarpous ovaries and generally regarded as the most primitive extant flowering plants; contains 36 families including Magnoliaceae and Ranunculaceae; sometimes classified as a superorder.
Monkey: To act or treat as a monkey does; to ape; to act in a grotesque or meddlesome manner.
Molasse: A soft Tertiary sandstone; -- applied to a rock occurring in Switzerland. See Chart of Geology.
malheur wire lettuce: A small mustardlike plant (Stephanomeria malheurensis) of Oregon, belonging to the family Cruciferae; it is a threatened species.
Melilite: A mineral occurring in small yellow crystals, found in the lavas (melilite basalt) of Vesuvius, and elsewhere.
Munch: To chew with a grinding, crunching sound, as a beast chews provender; to chew deliberately or in large mouthfuls.
Monadic: Of, pertaining to, or like, a monad, in any of its senses. See Monad, n.
Mesocoracoid: A process from the middle of the coracoid in some animals.
Mastoiditis: Inflammation in the mastoid process of the temporal bone.
Milreis: A Portuguese money of account rated in the treasury department of the United States at one dollar and eight cents; also, a Brazilian money of account rated at fifty-four cents and six mills (1913).
minelaying: The act or process of laying explosive mines in concealed places to destroy enemy personnel and equipment.
&Verbar;Montoir: A stone used in mounting a horse; a horse block.
Mourner: One who mourns or is grieved at any misfortune, as the death of a friend.
Moly: A fabulous herb of occult power, having a black root and white blossoms, said by Homer to have been given by Hermes to Ulysses to counteract the spells of Circe.
Metastasis: A spiritual change, as during baptism.
&Verbar;Markhoor: A large wild goat (Capra falconeri syn. Capra megaceros), having huge flattened spiral horns.  It inhabits the mountains of Northern India and Cashmere.
Mold: To form into a particular shape; to shape; to model; to fashion.
Mole: To form holes in, as a mole; to burrow; to excavate; as, to mole the earth.
Mawseed: The seed of the opium poppy.
Maslin: Composed of different sorts; as, maslin bread, which is made of rye mixed with a little wheat.
Meretricious: Of or pertaining to prostitutes; having to do with harlots; lustful; as, meretricious traffic.
Marbling: The art or practice of variegating in color, in imitation of marble.
Malignity: The state or quality of being malignant; disposition to do evil; virulent enmity; malignancy; malice; spite.
Monachism: The system and influences of a monastic life; monasticism.
Maximum: Greatest in quantity or highest in degree attainable or attained; as, a maximum consumption of fuel; maximum pressure; maximum heat.
matchet: a large heavy knife used in Central and South America as a weapon or for cutting vegetation; usually called machete.
Moorstone: A species of English granite, used as a building stone.
macebearer: an official who carries the mace of office before persons in authority.
Mispersuasion: A false persuasion; wrong notion or opinion.
Muscularity: The state or quality of being muscular.
Maggot: The footless larva of any fly. See Larval.
moderating: lessening in intensity or strength.  Opposite of intensifying.
&Verbar;Marsdenia: A genus of plants of the Milkweed family, mostly woody climbers with fragrant flowers, several species of which furnish valuable fiber, and one species (Marsdenia tinctoria) affords indigo.
madonna lily: A lily (Lilium candidum) of the Eastern Mediterranean and Balkans with broad funnel-shaped white flowers.
Mediately: In a mediate manner; by a secondary cause or agent; not directly or primarily; by means; -- opposed to immediately.
Mannered: Having a certain way, esp. a polite way, of carrying and conducting one's self; as, a well-mannered child.
marasca cherry: A Dalmation bitter wild cherry tree (Prunus cerasus marasca) bearing fruit whose juice is made into maraschino liqueur.
Maidenliness: The quality of being maidenly; the behavior that becomes a maid; modesty; gentleness.
minesweeping: the activity of detecting and disposing of marine mines.
Myrtales: A natural order of trees and shrubs including the myrtle family, Myrtaceae; Combretaceae; Elaeagnaceae; Haloragidaceae; Melastomaceae; Lecythidaceae; Lythraceae; Rhizophoraceae; Onagraceae; Lecythidaceae; and Punicaceae.
Milkwort: A genus of plants (Polygala) of many species.  The common European Polygala vulgaris was supposed to have the power of producing a flow of milk in nurses.
Masticatory: A substance to be chewed to increase the saliva.
Metaphoric: Of or pertaining to metaphor; comprising a metaphor; not literal; figurative; tropical; as, a metaphorical expression; a metaphorical sense.
Mixed: Formed by mixing; united; mingled; blended. See Mix, v. t. & i.
menobranch: A large aquatic American salamander of the genus Necturus, having permanent external gills.
&Verbar;Monoxylon: A canoe or boat made from one piece of timber.
Monochlamydeous: Having a single floral envelope, that is, a calyx without a corolla, or, possibly, in rare cases, a corolla without a calyx.
Maypole: A tall pole erected in an open place and wreathed with flowers, about which the rustic May-day sports were had.
Myotome: A muscular segment; one of the zones into which the muscles of the trunk, especially in fishes, are divided; a myocomma.
Microspectroscope: A spectroscope arranged for attachment to a microscope, for observation of the spectrum of light from minute portions of any substance.
massive: Forming, or consisting of, a large mass; compacted; weighty; heavy; massy.
macamba: A tropical American feather palm (Acrocomia aculeata) having a swollen spiny trunk and edible nuts.
Misjudge: To judge erroneously or unjustly; to err in judgment; to misconstrue.
&Verbar;Mitraille: Shot or bits of iron used sometimes in loading cannon.
Macadamize: To cover, as a road, or street, parking lot, playground, or other flat area, with macadam, so as to form a smooth, hard, convex surface.
Megastome: One of a group of univalve shells, having a large aperture or mouth.
Malagasy: A native or natives of Madagascar; also (sing.), the language.
&Verbar;Musci: An order or subclass of cryptogamous plants; the mosses. See Moss, and Cryptogamia.
Moonwort: The herb lunary or honesty. See Honesty.
Monday: The second day of the week; the day following Sunday.
&Verbar;Musca: A genus of dipterous insects, including the common house fly, and numerous allied species.
Mounted: Seated or serving on horseback or similarly; as, mounted police; mounted infantry.
morphemics: The study of the types and functions of morphemes; morphology{4}.
meiotic: Of or pertaining to meiosis; as, meiotic division.
Muzarab: One of a denomination of Christians formerly living under the government of the Moors in Spain, and having a liturgy and ritual of their own.
Mystification: The act of mystifying, or the state of being mystied; also, something designed to, or that does, mystify.
magnetic meridian: An imaginary line passing through both magnetic poles of the earth.
Matriculation: The act or process of matriculating; the state of being matriculated.
Moldy: Overgrown with, or containing, mold; smelling of mold; as, moldy cheese or bread.
&Verbar;Mesopterygium: The middle one of the three principal basal cartilages in the fins of fishes.
Malacology: The science which relates to the structure and habits of mollusks.
&Verbar;Mamzer: A person born of relations between whom marriage was forbidden by the Mosaic law; a bastard.
Multidentate: Having many teeth, or toothlike processes.
mal de mer: Motion sickness experienced while traveling on water; seasickness.
Meddler: One who meddles; one who interferes or busies himself with things in which he has no concern; an officious person; a busybody.
magnetohydrodynamics: The study of the interaction of magnetic fields with electrically conductive fluids, such as a plasma or a molten metal.
Mystacal: Of or pertaining to the upper lip, or mustache.
Mince: A short, precise step; an affected manner.
Merit: To acquire desert; to gain value; to receive benefit; to profit.
Manx cat: A breed of domestic cats having a rudimentary tail, containing only about three vertebrae.  It is believed to have originated on the Isle of Man.
Moonie: A member of the Unification Church, founded by Sun Myun Moon.
magic bullet: A drug or therapy or preventive that cures or prevents a disease, with only minimal side effects; as, there is no magic bullet against cancer.
meretriciousness: an appearance of truth that is false or deceptive; seeming plausibility.
Mimus: The type genus of the family Mimidae, comprising certain of the mockingbirds.
Mousquetaire glove: A woman's glove with a long, loosely fitting wrist.
Miscomprehend: To get a wrong idea of or about; to misunderstand.
Morioplasty: The restoration of lost parts of the body.
Myrosin: An enzyme, resembling diastase, found in mustard seeds.
Magician: One skilled in magic; one who practices the black art; an enchanter; a necromancer; a sorcerer or sorceress; a conjurer.
Mixolydian mode: The seventh ecclesiastical mode, whose scale commences on G.
Melodrama: Formerly, a kind of drama having a musical accompaniment to intensify the effect of certain scenes.  Now, a drama abounding in romantic sentiment and agonizing situations, with a musical accompaniment only in parts which are especially thrilling or pathetic.  In opera, a passage in which the orchestra plays a somewhat descriptive accompaniment, while the actor speaks; as, the melodrama in the gravedigging scene of Beethoven's “Fidelio”.
Magazine: To store in, or as in, a magazine; to store up for use.
Mockado: A stuff made in imitation of velvet; -- probably the same as mock velvet.
mechanization: The act or process of mechanizing.
Machinist: A constructor of machines and engines; one versed in the principles of machines.
Monochromatic: Consisting of one color, or presenting rays of light of one color only.
Meritmonger: One who depends on merit for salvation.
midfield: the middle part of a playing field (as in football or lacrosse); as, he ran the kickoff back to midfield.
&Verbar;Modiolus: The central column in the osseous cochlea of the ear.
Mongoloid: A person affected with Down syndrome; -- not a technical term.
&Verbar;Mel\u00e6na: A discharge from the bowels of black matter, consisting of altered blood.
Menstruous: Having the monthly flow or discharge; menstruating.
Misfeasance: A trespass; a wrong arising from an overt act; the improper doing of an act which a person might lawfully do.
massiness: The state or quality of being massy; ponderousness.
Marauder: A rover in quest of booty or plunder; a plunderer; one who pillages.
misappropriated: taken for one's own use in violation of a trust.
Mortally: In a mortal manner; so as to cause death; as, mortally wounded.
Maleficience: The doing of evil, harm, or mischief.
Molech: The fire god of the Ammonites, to whom human sacrifices were offered; Moloch.
Moebles: Movables; furniture; -- also used in the singular (moeble).
Muskiness: The quality or state of being musky; the scent of musk.
Magnanimously: In a magnanimous manner; with greatness of mind.
Mestizo: The offspring of an Indian or a negro and a European or person of European stock.
macumba: darling; -- an Irish term of address expressing affection.
Mortgage: To grant or convey, as property, for the security of a debt, or other engagement, upon a condition that if the debt or engagement shall be discharged according to the contract, the conveyance shall be void, otherwise to become absolute, subject, however, to the right of redemption.
Marchman: A person living in the marches between England and Scotland or Wales.
Maroc: Of or pertaining to Morocco; as, Maroc mosques cannot be entered by women without a head covering.
male plug: The connecting end of the cord on an electrical device, having two or three pins, that is inserted into a matching socket to make an electrical connection.
Morbid: Not sound and healthful; induced by a diseased or abnormal condition; diseased; sickly; as, a morbid condition; a morbid constitution; a morbid state of the juices of a plant.
Melodiograph: A contrivance for preserving a record of music, by recording the action of the keys of a musical instrument when played upon.
Murmurous: Attended with murmurs; exciting murmurs or complaint; murmuring.
mare nostrum: The term used by the ancient Romans to refer to the Mediterranean Sea.
Mandatary: One to whom a command or charge is given; hence, specifically, a person to whom the pope has, by his prerogative, given a mandate or order for his benefice.
Mohammedan Era: The era in use in Moslem countries. See Mohammedan year, below.
Myxinoidei: A suborder of hagfishes as distinguished from lampreys.
&Verbar;Mitrailleuse: A breech-loading machine gun consisting of a number of barrels fitted together, so arranged that the barrels can be fired simultaneously, or successively, and rapidly.
Mottled: Marked with spots of different colors; variegated; spotted; as, mottled wood.
&Verbar;Monte-jus: An apparatus for raising a liquid by pressure of air or steam in a reservoir containing the liquid.
Meach: To skulk; to cower. See Mich.
Mangifera: genus of tropical trees native to Asia bearing fleshy fruit.
Mandragora: A genus of plants; the mandrake. See Mandrake, 1.
maternity ward: The section of a hospital devoted to assisting women during childbirth and caring for them and their newborn infants until they are released to go home.
Monogyny: Marriage with the one woman only.
Macaronian: Pertaining to, or like, macaroni (originally a dish of mixed food); hence, mixed; confused; jumbled.
Molybdenum: A rare element of the chromium group, occurring in nature in the minerals molybdenite and wulfenite, and when reduced obtained as a hard, silver-white, difficulty fusible metal.  Symbol Mo.  Atomic number 42. Atomic weight 95.94.
Misreport: An erroneous report; a false or incorrect account given.
Machining: Of or pertaining to the machinery of a poem; acting or used as a machine.
Matanza: A place where animals are slaughtered for their hides and tallow.
Masting: The act or process of putting a mast or masts into a vessel; also, the scientific principles which determine the position of masts, and the mechanical methods of placing them.
Manor: The land belonging to a lord or nobleman, or so much land as a lord or great personage kept in his own hands, for the use and subsistence of his family.
Marksman: One skillful to hit a mark with a missile; one who shoots well. especially with a pistol or rifle.
Muffle: Anything with which another thing, as an oar or drum, is muffled; also, a boxing glove; a muff.
Megafarad: One of the larger measures of electrical capacitance, amounting to one million farads; a macrofarad.
Metapeptone: An intermediate product formed in the gastric digestion of albuminous matter.
Missy: An affectionate, or contemptuous, form of miss; a young girl; a miss.
Merlon: One of the solid parts of a battlemented parapet; a battlement. See Illust. of Battlement.
Montem: A custom, formerly practiced by the scholars at Eton school, England, of going every third year, on Whittuesday, to a hillock near the Bath road, and exacting money from all passers-by, to support at the university the senior scholar of the school.
Mon\u0153cism: The state or condition of being monœcious.
Muttony: Like mutton; having a flavor of mutton.
Mulley: Destitute of horns, although belonging to a species of animals most of which have horns; hornless; polled; as, mulley cattle; a mulley (or moolley) cow.
Maleo: A bird of Celebes (megacephalon maleo), allied to the brush turkey. It makes mounds in which to lay its eggs.
Mullet: Small pinchers for curling the hair.
Maladministration: Bad administration; bad management of any business, especially of public affairs.
Mousy: Infested with mice; smelling of mice.
Misacceptation: Wrong acceptation; understanding in a wrong sense.
Marena: A European whitefish of the genus Coregonus.
Maniac: Raving with madness; raging with disordered intellect; affected with mania; mad.
Myrialiter: A metric measure of capacity, containing ten thousand liters.  It is equal to 2641.7 wine gallons.
Monk: A man who retires from the ordinary temporal concerns of the world, and devotes himself to religion; one of a religious community of men inhabiting a monastery, and bound by vows to a life of chastity, obedience, and poverty.
Magisterialness: The quality or state of being magisterial.
Mastotermes: A primitive genus of termites, mostly extinct; sometimes considered the most primitive isopterans.
Mariolatry: The worship of the Virgin Mary.
mapinguari: A supposed human-sized slothlike creature reported sighted by Indians in the Amazon rain forest.
Monthling: That which is a month old, or which lives for a month.
Muzzle: To bring the mouth or muzzle near.
Meth\u00e6moglobin: A stable crystalline compound obtained by the decomposition of hemoglobin.  It is found in old blood stains.
Milkful: Full of milk; abounding with food.
Mensurableness: The quality or state of being mensurable; measurableness.
magnetic flux: A measure of the strength of a magnetic field over a given area.
Medjidie: A silver coin of Turkey formerly rated at twenty, but since 1880 at nineteen, piasters (about 83 cents).
&Verbar;Mesogaster: The fold of peritoneum connecting the stomach with the dorsal wall of the abdominal cavity; the mesogastrium.
Monumental: Of, pertaining to, or suitable for, a monument; as, a monumental inscription.
Monkery: The life of monks; monastic life; monastic usage or customs; -- now usually applied by way of reproach.
management personnel: Personnel having ovrall planning and direction responsibilities.
Melassic: Pertaining to, or designating, an acid obtained from molasses or glucose, and probably identical with saccharic acid (also called D-glucaric acid or tetrahydroxyadipic acid). See Saccharic.
Monophanous: Having one and the same appearance; having a mutual resemblance.
Mistransport: To carry away or mislead wrongfully, as by passion.
Milvine: A bird related to the kite.
Morris-chair: A kind of easy-chair with a back which may be lowered or raised.
Mangonize: To furbish up for sale; to set off to advantage.
Maiden: To act coyly like a maiden; -- with it as an indefinite object.
Miliolitic: Of or pertaining to the genus Miliola; containing miliolites.
Modest: Restraining within due limits of propriety; not forward, bold, boastful, or presumptious; rather retiring than pushing one's self forward; not obstructive; as, a modest youth; a modest man.
Modulator: One who, or that which, modulates.
mantissa: The decimal part of a logarithm, as distinguished from the integral part, or characteristic.
motorization: the act of motorizing (equiping with motors or with motor vehicles).
Mislactation: Defective flow or vitiated condition of the milk.
Macaroon: A small cake, composed chiefly of the white of eggs, almonds or coconut, and sugar.
Milkiness: State or quality of being milky.
Monocotyledonae: A class of plants comprising seed plants that produce an embryo with a single cotyledon and parallel-veined leaves: grasses; lilies; palms; and orchids.  It is divided into four subclasses or superorders: Alismatidae; Arecidae; Commelinidae; and Liliidae.
Meconinic: Pertaining to, or designating, an acid which occurs in opium, and which may be obtained by oxidizing narcotine.
marginality: the property of being marginal or on the fringes.
Monostrophic: Having one strophe only; not varied in measure; written in unvaried measure.
&Verbar;Metanauplius: A larval crustacean in a stage following the nauplius, and having about seven pairs of appendages.
Mongoose: A species of ichneumon (Herpestes griseus), native of India.  Applied also to other allied species, as the African banded mongoose (Crossarchus fasciatus).
Monomachist: One who fights in single combat; a duelist.
Moth-eaten: having holes due to eating by moths or moth larvae; -- of cloth or clothing.
Manful: Showing manliness, or manly spirit; hence, brave, courageous, resolute, noble.
minniebush: A low shrub (Menziesia pilosa) of the eastern U. S. with downy twigs.
Morphotic: Connected with, or becoming an integral part of, a living unit or of the morphological framework; as, morphotic, or tissue, proteids.
Malacosteon: A peculiar disease of the bones, in consequence of which they become softened and capable of being bent without breaking.
Myolin: The essential material of muscle fibers.
Meine: A family, including servants, etc.; household; retinue; train.
Mulierly: In the manner or condition of a mulier; in wedlock; legitimately.
Making-up: The act of bringing spirits to a certain degree of strength, called proof.
Microform: A microscopic form of life; an animal or vegetable organism of microscopic size.
Mossback: A veteran partisan; one who is so conservative in opinion that he may be likened to a stone or old tree covered with moss.
Metallographic: Pertaining to, or by means of, metallography.
Muscicapine: Of or pertaining to the Muscicapidæ, a family of birds that includes the true flycatchers.
mase: To emit coherent microwave radiation, as in a maser{2}.
Moderator: One who, or that which, moderates, restrains, or pacifies.
Misconsequence: A wrong consequence; a false deduction.
mid-eighties: the time of life between 80 and 90.
metastasize: to spread from one part of the body to other parts, and grow there; to spread by metastasis{3}; -- said of cancer cells.
Men-pleaser: One whose motive is to please men or the world, rather than God.
Moth-eat: To eat or prey upon, as a moth eats a garment.
Mesocarp: The middle layer of a pericarp which consists of three distinct or dissimilar layers.
&Verbar;Mus: A genus of small rodents, including the common mouse and rat.
Millenary: The space of a thousand years; a millennium; also, a Millenarian.
mufti: Ordinary civilian dress when worn by persons who serve in a uniformed service, such as the military or police.  It originally was used in reference to British naval or military officers, and originated with the British service in India.
maple-leaf begonia: A tuberous or semi-tuberous South African begonia (Begonia dregei) having shallowly lobed ovate leaves and small white flowers.
mammary gland: The milk-secreting organ of female mammals.
Moltable: Capable of assuming a molten state; meltable; fusible.
Metabolic: Of or pertaining to metamorphosis; pertaining to, or involving, change.
Miscontinuance: Discontinuance; also, continuance by undue process.
Medicommissure: A large transverse commissure in the third ventricle of the brain; the middle or soft commissure.
Modulate: To pass from one key into another.
Middle-earth: The world, considered as lying between heaven and hell.
Monureid: Any one of a series of complex nitrogenous substances regarded as derived from one molecule of urea; as, alloxan is a monureid.
Melospiza: A genus of American song sparrows and swamp sparrows.
mentalism: a doctrine that mind is the only true reality and that objects exist only as aspects of the mind's awareness.
Mediatorship: The office or character of a mediator.
miscegenate: to marry or cohabit with a person of another race.
Monomerous: Composed of solitary parts, as a flower with one sepal, one petal, one stamen, and one pistil.
Mary-bud: The marigold; a blossom of the marigold.
Microtomic: Of or pert. to the microtome or microtomy; cutting thin slices.
&Verbar;Mate: The Paraguay tea, being the dried leaf of the Brazilian holly (Ilex Paraguensis).  The infusion has a pleasant odor, with an agreeable bitter taste, and is much used for tea in South America.
Milleped: A myriapod with many legs, esp. a chilognath, as the galleyworm.
Myrtillocactus: A small genus of arborescent cacti of Mexico and Central America.
Manchester terrier: A breed of short-haired black-and-tan terrier developed in Manchester England.
Medalurgy: The art of making and striking medals and coins.
Maqui: A Chilian shrub (Aristotelia Maqui). Its bark furnishes strings for musical instruments, and a medicinal wine is made from its berries.
Mesosternal: Of or pertaining to the mesosternum.
Mythologic: Of or pertaining to mythology or to myths; as, mythological creatures.
Menstrual: Recurring once a month; monthly; gone through in a month; as, the menstrual revolution of the moon; pertaining to monthly changes; as, the menstrual equation of the sun's place.
maltreat: To treat ill; to abuse; to treat roughly.
mechanism of action: The mechanism{2} by which a pharmacologically active substance produces an effect on a living organism or in a biochemical system; as, the mechanism of action of actinomycin involves its binding to DNA.  The mechanism of action is usually considered to include an identification of the specific molecular targets to which a pharmacologically active substance binds or whose biochemical action it influences; a general recognition of the broad biochemical pathways (such as DNA synthesis, protein synthesis, cholesterol synthesis) which are inhibited or affected by a substance is termed its mode of action.
Mesitylol: A crystalline substance obtained from mesitylene.
Mistle: To fall in very fine drops, as rain; to drizzle.
Moonblink: A temporary blindness, or impairment of sight, said to be caused by sleeping in the moonlight; -- sometimes called nyctalopia.
Magnificence: The act of doing what is magnificent; the state or quality of being magnificent.
Moslings: Thin shreds of leather shaved off in dressing skins.
Magnetize: To communicate magnetic properties to; to make magnetic; as, to magnetize a needle.
Malvaceae: A natural family of herbs and shrubs and some trees, including the mallows, cotton, and okra; the mallow family.
midstream: the middle of a stream; as, don't change horses in midstream.
Manly: In a manly manner; with the courage and fortitude of a manly man; as, to act manly.
Micromillimeter: The millionth part of a meter.
Mustang: The half-wild horse of the plains in Mexico, California, etc.  It is small, hardy, and easily sustained.
Mexicanize: To become like the Mexicans, or their country or government.
Monophyletic: Of or pertaining to a single family or stock, or to development from a single common parent form; -- opposed to polyphyletic; as, monophyletic origin.
Mountaineer: An inhabitant of a mountain; one who lives among mountains.
Melanoscope: An instrument containing a combination of colored glasses such that they transmit only red light, so that objects of other colors, as green leaves, appear black when seen through it.  It is used for viewing colored flames, to detect the presence of potassium, lithium, etc., by the red light which they emit.
Misunderstanding: Mistake of the meaning; error; misconception.
Malediction: A proclaiming of evil against some one; a cursing; imprecation; a curse or execration; -- opposed to benediction.
Mocker: One who, or that which, mocks; a scorner; a scoffer; a derider.
mapping: A function such that for every element of one set there is a unique element of another set.
Mooner: One who abstractedly wanders or gazes about, as if moonstruck.
Malignance: The state or quality of being malignant; extreme malevolence; bitter enmity; malice; disposition toward evil; intense ill will; as, malignancy of heart.
Myelogenic: Derived from, or pertaining to, the bone marrow.
Methodization: The act or process of methodizing, or the state of being methodized.
Mykiss: A salmon (Salmo mykiss, syn. Salmo purpuratus) marked with black spots and a red throat, found in most of the rivers from Alaska to the Colorado River, and in Siberia; -- called also black-spotted trout, cutthroat trout, and redthroat trout.
mailsorter: A machine that sorts mail, according to the address.
Mask shell: Any spiral marine shell of the genus Persona, having a curiously twisted aperture.
Macrocosm: The great world; that part of the universe which is exterior to man; -- contrasted with microcosm, or man. See Microcosm.
Milliamp\u00e8re: The thousandth part of one ampère.
Mattoid: A person of congenitally abnormal mind bordering on insanity or degeneracy.
Modality: The quality or state of being modal.
&Verbar;Mosasauria: An order of large, extinct, marine reptiles, found in the Cretaceous rocks, especially in America.  They were serpentlike in form and in having loosely articulated and dilatable jaws, with large recurved teeth, but they had paddlelike feet. Some of them were over fifty feet long. They are, essentially, fossil sea serpents with paddles. Called also Pythonomarpha, and Mosasauria.
Monodelphic: Of or pertaining to the Monodelphia.
&Verbar;Myxoma: A tumor made up of a gelatinous tissue resembling that found in the umbilical cord.
magnifying glass: A single convex lens which magnifies the apparent dimensions of objects seen through it, and is used to produce an enlarged image.
Mycose: A variety of sugar, isomeric with sucrose and obtained from certain lichens and fungi.  Called also trehalose.
Myophan: A contractile striated layer found in the bodies and stems of certain Infusoria.
Mismate: To mate wrongly or unsuitably; to mismatch; as, to mismate gloves or shoes; a mismated couple.
Morion: A dark variety of smoky quartz.
Miseducate: To educate in a wrong manner.
Myxobacteriaceae: A family of bacteria living mostly in soils and on dung; called also Polyangiaceae.
maintenance staff: Those persons in a business responsible for maintaining the physical plant in good condition.
Mammiferous: Having breasts; of, pertaining to, or derived from, the Mammalia.
monocystic: Of or pertaining to a division (Monocystidea) of the protozoan order  Gregarinida, in which the body consists of one sac.
Monodactylous: Having but one finger or claw.
Mungo: A material of short fiber and inferior quality obtained by deviling woolen rags or the remnants of woolen goods, specif. those of felted, milled, or hard-spun woolen cloth, as distinguished from shoddy, or the deviled product of loose-textured woolen goods or worsted, -- a distinction often disregarded.
main file: A file that is used as the authority in a given job and that is relatively permanent.
Monotriglyph: A kind of intercolumniation in an entablature, in which only one triglyph and two metopes are introduced.
Mystagogue: One who interprets mysteries, especially of a religious kind.
Meditate: To contemplate; to keep the mind fixed upon; to study.
Microvolt: A measure of electro-motive force; the millionth part of one volt.
Manioc: The tropical plants (Manihot utilissima, and Manihot Aipi), from which cassava and tapioca are prepared; also, cassava.
Metroscope: A modification of the stethoscope, for directly auscultating the uterus from the vagina.
Martingale: A strap fastened to a horse's girth, passing between his fore legs, and fastened to the bit, or now more commonly ending in two rings, through which the reins pass.  It is intended to hold down the head of the horse, and prevent him from rearing.
Mesocolon: The fold of peritoneum, or mesentery, attached to the colon.
marsupiate: Related to or resembling the marsupials; furnished with a pouch for the young, as the marsupials, and also some fishes and Crustacea.
metrication: The act or process of converting the standard system of units of a country to those of the metric system; metrification; as, Great Britain has completed its metrification, but the United States still resists complete change.
Metencephalon: The posterior part of the brain, including the medulla; the afterbrain. Sometimes abbreviated to meten.
Mortifying: Tending to mortify; affected by, or having symptoms of, mortification; as, a mortifying wound; mortifying flesh.
Molding: Used in making a mold or moldings; used in shaping anything according to a pattern.
Mechlin: A kind of lace made at, or originating in, Mechlin, in Belgium.
Mur\u00e6noid: Like or pertaining to the genus Muræna, or family Murænidæ.
Mousle: To sport with roughly; to rumple.
Morbidness: The quality or state of being morbid; morbidity.
methanogen: A type of archaebacteria found in anaerobic environments such as animal intestinal tracts or sediments or sewage, and capable of producing methane; a source of natural gas.
Merriness: The quality or state of being merry; merriment; mirth; gayety, with laughter.
madagascar cat: A small lemur having its tail barred with black.
Metamorphism: The state or quality of being metamorphic; the process by which the material of rock masses has been more or less recrystallized by heat, pressure, etc., as in the change of sedimentary limestone to marble.
Mantle: To unfold and spread out the wings, like a mantle; -- said of hawks. Also used figuratively.
Magazinist: One who edits or writes for a magazine.
Muciform: Resembling mucus; having the character or appearance of mucus.
Methal: A white waxy substance, found in small quantities in spermaceti as an ethereal salt of several fatty acids, and regarded as an alcohol of the methane series.
Metamorphist: One who believes that the body of Christ was merged into the Deity when he ascended.
Magnesite: Native magnesium carbonate occurring in white compact or granular masses, and also in rhombohedral crystals.
Marabout: A Mohammedan saint; especially, one who claims to work cures supernaturally.
Mendicant: A beggar; esp., one who makes a business of begging; specifically, a begging friar.
Mainstay: The stay extending from the foot of the foremast to the maintop.
Mydatoxin: A poisonous amido acid, C6H13NO2, separated by Brieger from decaying horseflesh. In physiological action, it is similar to curare.
Mushroom: Of or pertaining to mushrooms; as, mushroom catchup.
M: A quadrat, the face or top of which is a perfect square; also, the size of such a square in any given size of type, used as the unit of measurement for that type: 500 m's of pica would be a piece of matter whose length and breadth in pica m's multiplied together produce that number.
Motherland: The country of one's ancestors; -- same as fatherland.
Mitigatory: Tending to mitigate or alleviate; mitigative.
martagon: A lily (Lilium Martagon) with purplish red flowers, found in Europe and Asia.
Martyniaceae: A natural family in most classifications not considered a separate family but included in the Pedaliaceae.
Moldboard: A curved plate of iron (originally of wood) back of the share of a plow, which turns over the earth in plowing.
Melanosperm: An alga of any kind that produces blackish spores, or seed dust.  The melanosperms include the rockweeds and all kinds of kelp.
midwestern: Of or pertaining to the Midwest  region of the U. S., generally including Ohio; Indiana; Illinois; Iowa; Missouri; Kansas; Nebraska; and sometimes Michigan; Wisconsin; Minnesota; as, a midwestern city; midwestern accent.
&Verbar;Modus vivendi: Mode, or manner, of living; hence, a temporary arrangement of affairs until disputed matters can be settled.
&Verbar;Metanotum: The dorsal portion of the metaphorax of insects.
Merciful: Full of mercy; having or exercising mercy; disposed to pity and spare offenders; unwilling to punish.  Opposite of merciless.
Misdeal: The act of misdealing; a wrong distribution of cards to the players.
Milkman: A man who sells milk or delivers it to customers.
Muslin: A thin cotton, white, dyed, or printed.  The name is also applied to coarser and heavier cotton goods; as, shirting and sheeting muslins.  In sheeting, muslin is not as finely woven as percale.
Menstruant: Subject to monthly flowing or menses.
Microbarograph: An instrument for recording minor fluctuations of atmospheric pressure, as opposed to general barometric surges.
mutualist: One practising or advocating the doctrine of mutualism.
Minnesinger: A love-singer; specifically, one of a class of German poets and musicians who flourished from about the middle of the twelfth to the middle of the fourteenth century.  They were chiefly of noble birth, and made love and beauty the subjects of their verses.
Mucksy: Somewhat mucky; soft, sticky, and dirty; muxy.
Mammilliform: Having the form of a mammilla.
Motor generator: The combination consisting of a generator and a driving motor mechanically connected, usually on a common bedplate and with the two shafts directly coupled or combined into a single shaft.
&Verbar;Mesohippus: An extinct mammal of the Horse family, but not larger than a sheep, and having three toes on each foot.
manger: A trough or open box in which fodder is placed for horses or cattle to eat.
magnetic moment: The torque exerted on a magnet or dipole when it is placed in a magnetic field.
Molecular: Pertaining to, connected with, produced by, or consisting of, molecules; as, molecular forces; molecular groups of atoms, etc.
muted: same as quiet; as, the muted atmosphere of a church.  Opposite of noisy.
Muscarin: A solid crystalline substance, C5H13NO2, found in the toadstool (Agaricus muscarius), and in putrid fish. It is a typical ptomaine, and a violent poison.
monstera: any plant of the genus Monstera; they are often grown as houseplants.
Maniacal: Affected with, or characterized by, madness; maniac.
mailboat: a boat that carries the mail.
Motor car: An automobile, locomobile, or locomotive designed to run and be steered on a street or roadway; esp., an automobile specially designed for passengers and propelled by an internal combustion engine.
major diatonic scale: The natural diatonic scale, which has semitones between the third and fourth, and seventh and eighth notes, and whole tones between the other notes;  the scale of the major mode, of which the third is major; also called major scale.   See Scale, and Diatonic.
Magnanimity: The quality of being magnanimous; greatness of mind; elevation or dignity of soul; that quality or combination of qualities, in character, which enables one to encounter danger and trouble with tranquility and firmness, to disdain injustice, meanness and revenge, and to act and sacrifice for noble objects.
maintenance man: A worker, usually in an enterprise or apartment building, whose job is to repair damaged parts of a building or its fixtures, and sometimes to make improvements or other changes to the building.
magnetic pole: Either of two points where the lines of force of the earth's magnetic field are vertical.
Mesoderm: The layer of the blastoderm, between the ectoderm and endoderm; mesoblast. See Illust. of Blastoderm and Ectoderm.
Maladroit: Of a quality opposed to adroitness; clumsy; awkward; unskillful.
madrilene: a tomato-flavored consomme, often served chilled.
Mis-: A prefix used adjectively and adverbially in the sense of amiss, wrong, ill, wrongly, unsuitably; as, misdeed, mislead, mischief, miscreant.
Murderer: One guilty of murder; a person who, in possession of his reason, unlawfully kills a human being with premeditated malice.
madia oil plant: The Madia sativa, a South American herb with sticky glandular foliage, the source of madia oil.  See Madia.
Mace: A chemical preparation containing tear gas in a solvent, packaged in the form of a spray, and used to temporarily incapacitate people, such as rioters or criminals, by causing intense eye and skin irritation; also called chemical mace.  It is designed to be a non-lethal weapon for defending against violent people.
Mess beef: Barreled salt beef, packed with about 80 pounds chuck and rump, two flanks, and the rest plates.
Micher: One who skulks, or keeps out of sight; hence, a truant; an idler; a thief, etc.
madia oil: The vegetable oil obtained from the Madia sativa.  See Madia and madia oil plant.
Monocotyledonous: Having only one cotyledon, seed lobe, or seminal leaf.
Mollifier: One who, or that which, mollifies.
Multispiral: Having numerous spiral coils round a center or nucleus; -- said of the opercula of certain shells.
Malthus: Thomas Robert Malthus, an English economist who argued that increases in population would outgrow increases in the means of subsistence (1766-1834).
Marked: Designated or distinguished by, or as by, a mark; hence; noticeable; conspicuous; as, a marked card; a marked coin; a marked instance.
Misy: An impure yellow sulphate of iron; yellow copperas or copiapite.
Miscorrect: To fail or err in attempting to correct.
Marker: One who or that which marks.
Miss: The act of missing; failure to hit, reach, find, obtain, etc.
Market: To expose for sale in a market; to traffic in; to sell in a market, and in an extended sense, to sell in any manner; as, most of the farmes have marketed their crops.
Myotomic: Of or pertaining to a myotome or myotomes.
&Verbar;Marai: A sacred inclosure or temple; -- so called by the islanders of the Pacific Ocean.
Melaconite: An earthy black oxide of copper, arising from the decomposition of other ores.
Micrurus: A genus of snakes including certain of the coral snakes, such as the eastern coral snake (Micrurus fulvius).
Mimeograph: A copying device that uses a stencil through which ink is pressed; it was invented by Edison.
Millenarian: One who believes that Christ will personally reign on earth a thousand years; a Chiliast.
Malinger: To act the part of a malingerer; to feign illness or inability.
Metacenter: The point of intersection of a vertical line through the center of gravity of the fluid displaced by a floating body which is tipped through a small angle from its position of equilibrium, and the inclined line which was vertical through the center of gravity of the body when in equilibrium.
Myristone: The ketone of myristic acid, obtained as a white crystalline substance.
Morello: A kind of nearly black cherry with dark red flesh and juice, -- used chiefly for preserving.
marang tree: A Philippine tree (Artocarpus odoratissima) similar to the breadfruit tree bearing edible fruit.  Called also marang.
Mastotermitidae: A natural family comprising primitive termites.
