Metaphysician: One who is versed in metaphysics.
medicaid: A program controlled by the United States government to provide health care for the needy.  It is funded by contributions from the salaries of workers, and is therefore a form of health insurance.
Monothelitic: Of or pertaining to the Monothelites, or their doctrine.
Manna: The food supplied to the Israelites in their journey through the wilderness of Arabia; hence, divinely supplied food.
Monasterial: Of or pertaining to monastery, or to monastic life.
make-believe: A feigning to believe, as in the play of children; a mere pretense; a fiction; an invention.
Macroscopic: Visible to the unassisted eye; -- as opposed to microscopic.
Millinery: The articles made or sold by milliners, as headdresses, hats or bonnets, laces, ribbons, and the like.
Muscle reading: The art of making discriminations between objects of choice, of discovering the whereabouts of hidden objects, etc., by inference from the involuntary movements of one whose hand the reader holds or with whom he is otherwise in muscular contact.
Meg-: Combining forms signifying: (a) Great, extended, powerful; as, megascope, megacosm.
Modicum: A little; a small quantity; a measured supply.
Megaderm: Any one of several species of Old World blood-sucking bats of the genus Megaderma.
Medicinal: Having curative or palliative properties; used for the cure or alleviation of bodily disorders; as, medicinal tinctures, plants, or springs.
Malcolm Little: A militant American black nationalist leader, also called Malcolm X; (1925-1965).
Macrology: Long and tedious talk without much substance; superfluity of words.
Match play: Play in which the score is reckoned by counting the holes won or lost by each side; -- distinguished from medal play.
Marine: A solider serving on shipboard; a sea soldier; one of a body of troops trained to do duty in the navy.
Muddy: To soil with mud; to dirty; to render turbid.
Moon-eye: A eye affected by the moon; also, a disease in the eye of a horse.
mammee apple: A tropical American tree (Mammea americana) having edible fruit (the mammee apple) with a leathery rind.
&Verbar;Majorat: The right of succession to property according to age; -- so termed in some of the countries of continental Europe.
Meatal: Of or pertaining to a meatus; resembling a meatus.
Magnetometric: Pertaining to, or employed in, the measurement of magnetic forces; obtained by means of a magnetometer; as, magnetometric instruments; magnetometric measurements.
Myriologist: One who composes or sings a myriologue.
Millwork: The shafting, gearing, and other driving machinery of mills.
middle-of-the-road: supporting or pursuing a course of action that is neither liberal nor conservative.
&Verbar;Myx\u0153dema: A disease producing a peculiar cretinoid appearance of the face, slow speech, and dullness of intellect, and due to failure of the functions of the thyroid gland.
&Verbar;manul: A wild cat (Felis manul), having long, soft, light-colored fur.  It is found in the mountains of Central Asia, and dwells among rocks.
Methodist: Of or pertaining to the sect of Methodists; as, Methodist hymns; a Methodist elder.
Magnetomotive: Pertaining to, or designating, a force producing magnetic flux, analogous to electromotive force, and equal to the magnetic flux multiplied by the magnetic reluctance.
Marruecos: Morocco, a country in Northwestern Africa.
Methodism: The system of doctrines, polity, and worship, of the sect called Methodists.
Mitella: A genus of low slender herbs of North America and Northeast Asia having flowers with trifid or pinnatifid petals.
Metrology: The science of, or a system of, weights and measures; also, a treatise on the subject.
mustelid: A member of the Mustelidae, fissiped fur-bearing carnivorous mammals.
machine shop: A small business or a room within a business establishment where metal is cut and shaped etc., by machine tools.
Moco: A South American rodent (Cavia rupestris), allied to the Guinea pig, but larger; -- called also rock cavy.
Mostly: For the greatest part; for the most part; chiefly; in the main.
Marcasite: A sulphide of iron resembling pyrite or common iron pyrites in composition, but differing in form; white iron pyrites.
Mesmerization: The act of mesmerizing; the state of being mesmerized.
memorabilia: Things remarkable and worthy of remembrance or record; also, the record of them.
&Verbar;Mya: A genus of bivalve mollusks, including the common long, or soft-shelled, clam.
Myoepithelial: Derived from epithelial cells and destined to become a part of the muscular system; -- applied to structural elements in certain embryonic forms.
Masted: Furnished with a mast or masts; -- chiefly in composition; as, a three-masted schooner.
Modernism: Modern practice; a thing of recent date; esp., a modern usage or mode of expression.
Modernist: One who admires the moderns, or their ways and fashions.
Modificatory: Tending or serving to modify; modifying.
Mullar: A die, cut in intaglio, for stamping an ornament in relief, as upon metal.
Melampyrin: The saccharine substance dulcite; -- so called because found in the leaves of cowwheat (Melampyrum). See Dulcite.
manganese bronze: A brass alloy having from 1 to 4 percent of manganese added to harden it; made by adding manganese to the copper and zinc used in brass.
Macrame lace: A coarse lace made of twine, used especially in decorating furniture.
&Verbar;Maharif: An African antelope (Hippotragus Bakeri). Its face is striped with black and white.
Morsitation: The act of biting or gnawing.
Mesially: In, near, or toward, the mesial plane; mesiad.
&Verbar;Maffia: A secret society which organized in Sicily as a political organization, but is now widespread among Italians, and is used to further or protect private interests, reputedly by illegal methods; called also the Sicilian Mafia.
&Verbar;Mesozoa: A group of very lowly organized, wormlike parasites, including the Dicyemata.  They are found in cephalopods. See Dicyemata.
Mantidae: The natural family conmprising the mantises.  Same as Manteidae.
Megalonychidae: A natural family consisting of the two-toed sloths.
Medi\u00e6valism: The method or spirit of the Middle Ages; devotion to the institutions and practices of the Middle Ages; a survival from the Middle Ages.
&Verbar;Metachrosis: The power of changing color at will by the expansion of special pigment cells, under nerve influence, as seen in many reptiles, fishes, etc.
Maranatha: “Our Lord cometh;” -- an expression used by St. Paul at the conclusion of his first Epistle to the Corinthians (xvi. 22). This word has been used in anathematizing persons for great crimes; as much as to say, “May the Lord come quickly to take vengeance of thy crimes.” See Anathema maranatha, under Anathema.
man and wife: A man and woman who are married to each other; a married couple.
muckrake: To seek for, expose, or charge, especially habitually, corruption, real or alleged, on the part of public men and corporations.
Mischief-maker: One who makes mischief; one who excites or instigates quarrels or enmity.
Manganous: Of, pertaining to, designating, those compounds of manganese in which the element has a lower valence as contrasted with manganic compounds; as, manganous oxide.
M\u00e9ni\u00e8res disease: A disease characterized by deafness and vertigo, resulting in incoordination of movement.  It is supposed to depend upon a morbid condition of the semicircular canals of the internal ear.  Named after Ménière, a French physician.
Mucigenous: Connected with the formation of mucin; resembling mucin.
Moonstruck: Mentally affected or deranged by the supposed influence of the moon; lunatic.
Masty: Full of mast; abounding in acorns, etc.
Magged: Worn; fretted; as, a magged brace.
&Verbar;Monopteron: A circular temple consisting of a roof supported on columns, without a cella.
Maturant: A medicine, or application, which promotes suppuration.
Mudarin: A brown, amorphous, bitter substance having a strong emetic action, extracted from the root of the mudar.
Moonlight: to work at a second job in addition to one's main occupation; -- often done at night.
&Verbar;Myosis: Long-continued contraction of the pupil of the eye.
Modeler: One who models; hence, a worker in plastic art.
Mercurous: Of, pertaining to, or derived from, mercury; containing mercury; -- said of those compounds of mercury in which it is present in its highest proportion.
&Verbar;Megalonyx: An extinct quaternary mammal, of great size, allied to the sloth.
Malignant: A man of extreme enmity or evil intentions.
Mesoc\u0153le: The cavity of the mesencephalon; the iter.
Mercury: To wash with a preparation of mercury.
Mutch: The close linen or muslin cap of an old woman.
Monogynous: Of or pertaining to Monogynia; having only one style or stigma.
Mono-: A prefix signifying one, single, alone; as, monocarp, monopoly; (Chem.) indicating that a compound contains one atom, one radical, or one group of that to the name of which it is united; as, monoxide, monosulphide, monatomic, etc.
main deck: The uppermost sheltered deck that runs the entire length of a large vessel.
Malebranchism: The philosophical system of Malebranche, an eminent French metaphysician.  The fundamental doctrine of his system is that the mind can not have knowledge of anything external to itself except in its relation to God.
mimeograph: to make copies of using a mimeograph; as, She mimeographed the syllabus.
Manometric: Of or pertaining to the manometer; made by the manometer.
&Verbar;mycoderma: One of the forms in which bacteria group themselves; a more or less thick layer of motionless but living bacteria, formed by the bacteria uniting on the surface of the fluid in which they are developed.  This production differs from the zoöglœa stage of bacteria by not having the intermediary mucous substance.
Megascope: A modification of the magic lantern (projector), used esp. for throwing a magnified image of an opaque object on a screen, solar or artificial light being used.
Mali franc: The standard monetary unit in Mali and some other countries.
Malignly: In a malign manner; with malignity.
Monistic: Of, pertaining to, or involving, monism.
modal auxiliary: Any one of the auxiliary verbs of English, such as can, may, will, shall, must, might, could, would, or should, which are used together with the infinitive form of another verb to express distinctions of mood{2}, such as uncertainty, possibility, command, emphasis, and obligation.
Mericarp: One carpel of an umbelliferous fruit. See Cremocarp.
Mineralogically: According to the principles of, or with reference to, mineralogy.
Moderation: The act of moderating, or of imposing due restraint.
Mainpernor: A surety, under the old writ of mainprise, for a prisoner's appearance in court at a day.
Multum: An extract of quassia licorice, fraudulently used by brewers in order to economize malt and hops.
Monstrously: In a monstrous manner; unnaturally; extraordinarily; as, monstrously wicked.
misgiving: Evil premonition; doubt; distrust; a feeling of apprehension; -- used commonly in the plural.
&Verbar;Moderato: With a moderate degree of quickness; moderately.
Majidae: A natural family comprising the spider crabs.
main sequence: That region on a two-dimensional graph of luminosity versus temperature for stars (the Herzsprung-Russel diagram), which runs from high temperature and high luminosity to low temperature and low luminosity, in which most of the stars (plotted as points on the diagram) are found.  A normal star such as the earth's sun will spend most of its time over billions of years within this region of temperature and luminosity, as it progressively converts more of its original hydrogen into heavier elements.  After the hydrogen is consumed, a star may become a red giant or evolve into other types of star not within the main sequence region.
Metacrolein: A polymeric modification of acrolein obtained by heating it with caustic potash.  It is a crystalline substance having an aromatic odor.
Macaca: A genus of macaques including the  rhesus monkey (Macaca mulatta), much used in laboratory biomedical research.  Formerly called Macacus.
Meristem: A tissue of growing cells, or cells capable of further division.
Mulctary: Imposing a pecuniary penalty; consisting of, or paid as, a fine.
Mountain: Of or pertaining to a mountain or mountains; growing or living on a mountain; found on or peculiar to mountains; among mountains; as, a mountain torrent; mountain pines; mountain goats; mountain air; mountain howitzer.
Manacle: To put handcuffs or other fastening upon, for confining the hands; to shackle; to confine; to restrain from the use of the limbs or natural powers.
Moodiness: The quality or state of being moody; specifically, liability to strange or violent moods.
Mouline: The drum upon which the rope is wound in a capstan, crane, or the like.
mailing address: The postal address where a maile can be addressed to a person or organization.
Moistener: One who, or that which, moistens.
Medi\u00e6valist: One who has a taste for, or is versed in, the history of the Middle Ages; one in sympathy with the spirit or forms of the Middle Ages.
main entry word: The form of a word that heads a lexical entry and is alphabetized in a dictionary; also called entry word, headword, and lemma.
morphogenesis: The development of the tissues and organs of an organism; the formation of structural features of an organism.
Methinks: It seems to me; I think. See Me.
Mourn: To grieve for; to lament; to deplore; to bemoan; to bewail.
Merchandise: To make merchandise of; to buy and sell.
Mississippian: A geological period extending from from 310 million to 345 million years ago; it was associated with an increase of land areas, the presence of primitive ammonites, and emergence of winged insects; called also Missippian period and Lower Carboniferous period.
Masoola boat: A kind of boat used on the coast of Madras, India. The planks are sewed together with strands of coir which cross over a wadding of the same material, so that the shock on taking the beach through surf is much reduced.
Merge: To be sunk, swallowed up, or lost.
&Verbar;Masora: A Jewish critical work on the text of the Hebrew Scriptures, composed by several learned rabbis of the school of Tiberias, in the eighth and ninth centuries.
Macassar oil: A kind of oil formerly used in dressing the hair; -- so called because originally obtained from Macassar, a district of the Island of Celebes. Also, an imitation of the same, of perfumed castor oil and olive oil.  Cf. antimacassar.
monocule: A small crustacean with one median eye.
Messianic: Of or relating to the Messiah; as, the Messianic office or character.
Madam: A gentlewoman; -- an appellation or courteous form of address given to a lady, especially an elderly or a married lady; -- much used in the address, at the beginning of a letter, to a woman. The corresponding word in addressing a man is Sir; often abbreviated ma'am when used as a term of address.
Monotonist: One who talks in the same strain or on the same subject until weariness is produced.
Metaphysically: In the manner of metaphysical science, or of a metaphysician.
mass spectrometer: An analytical instrument which determines the mass of molecules of a substance or fragments of its molecules.  It functions by injecting ionized moecules or molecular gragments into a vacuum chamber subjected to a strong magnetic field, in which charged particles move in a curved trajectory.
mannitol: A white crystalline hexose (HO.CH2.(CHOH)4.CH2.OH) of a sweet taste obtained from a so-called manna, the dried sap of the flowering ash (Fraxinus ornus); -- called also mannite, and hydroxy hexane.  Cf. Dulcite.  It is used in pharmacy as excipient and diluent for solids and liquids.  It is also used as a food additive for anti-caking properties, or as a sweetener, and, illegally, to "cut" (dilute) illegal drugs such as cocaine or heroin.
Micro-geology: The part of geology relating to structure and organisms which require to be studied with a microscope.
Multidigitate: Having many fingers, or fingerlike processes.
Mixedly: In a mixed or mingled manner.
Microtomist: One who is skilled in or practices microtomy.
Monitorial: Of or pertaining to a monitor or monitors.
Maam: Madam; my lady; -- a colloquial contraction of madam often used in direct address, and sometimes as an appellation.
Moringic: Designating an organic acid obtained from oil of ben. See Moringa.
Mestling: A kind of brass. See Maslin.
&Verbar;Montgolfier: A balloon which ascends by the buoyancy of air heated by a fire; a fire balloon; -- so called from two brothers, Stephen and Joseph Montgolfier, of France, who first constructed and sent up a fire balloon.
Myopic: Pertaining to, or affected with, or characterized by, myopia; nearsighted.
Myopia: Nearsightedness; shortsightedness; a condition of the eye in which the rays from distant object are brought to a focus before they reach the retina, and hence form an indistinct image; while the rays from very near objects are normally converged so as to produce a distinct image.  It is corrected by the use of a concave lens.
Metonic: Pertaining to, or discovered by, Meton, the Athenian.
male fern: A fern of North America and Europe (Dryopteris filix-mas) whose rhizomes and stalks yield an oleoresin used to expel tapeworms.  It is a member of the woodfern genus.
marginal cost: The increase in total cost of production as a result of producing one more unit of output; since certain ovrhead costs are fixed, the marginal cost is almost aways less than the total per-unit cost of production averaged over all units produced.
Mesaconic: Pertaining to, or designating, one of several isomeric acids obtained from citric acid.
microbial: Of, pertaining to, or caused by, microbes; as, microbial growth; the microbian theory; a microbian disease.
Musculospiral: Of or pertaining to the muscles, and taking a spiral course; -- applied esp. to a large nerve of the arm.
&Verbar;Milliard: A thousand millions; -- usually called billion in the United States.   See Billion.
&Verbar;Media: One of the sonant mutes β, δ, γ (b, d, g), in Greek, or of their equivalents in other languages, so named as intermediate between the tenues, π, τ, κ (p, t, k), and the aspiratæ  (aspirates) φ, θ, χ (ph or f, th, ch). Also called middle mute, or medial, and sometimes soft mute.
Marinate: To salt or pickle, as fish, and then preserve in oil or vinegar; to prepare (food) by the use of marinade.
Microbiology: The branch of biology studying minute organisms, or microbes, such as the bacteria, fungi, viruses, and protozoa.
Moorpan: A clayey layer or pan underlying some moors, etc.
mutt: An dog that is of inferior quality or of mixed breed.
Mouthful: As much as is usually put into the mouth at one time.
Mucronate: Ending abruptly in a sharp point; abruptly tipped with a short and sharp point; as, a mucronate leaf.
Match: To be united in marriage; to mate.
Maternal: Of or pertaining to a mother; becoming to a mother; motherly; as, maternal love; maternal tenderness.
Moble: To wrap the head of in a hood.
magnetic declination: The angle (at a particular location) between magnetic north and true north; called also magnetic variation.
&Verbar;Mesoscutum: The scutum or dorsal plate of the middle thoracic segment of an insect. See Illust. of Butterfly.
&Verbar;Marsipobranchia: A class of Vertebrata, lower than fishes, characterized by their purselike gill cavities, cartilaginous skeletons, absence of limbs, and a suckerlike mouth destitute of jaws.  It includes the lampreys and hagfishes. See Cyclostoma, and Lamprey. Called also Marsipobranchiata, and Marsipobranchii.
&Verbar;Myxa: The distal end of the mandibles of a bird.
manor hall: The large room of a manor or castle.
malpighian layer: The innermost layer of the epidermis.
Misdirect: To give a wrong direction to; as, to misdirect a passenger, or a letter; to misdirect one's energies.
Misplace: To put in a wrong place; to set or place on an improper or unworthy object; as, he misplaced his confidence.
merge: To cause to be swallowed up; to immerse; to sink; to absorb.
Memento: A hint, suggestion, token, or memorial, to awaken memory; that which reminds or recalls to memory; a souvenir.
Mugger: The common crocodile (Crocodilus palustris) of India, the East Indies, etc. It becomes twelve feet or more long.
maidenhair berry: A slow-growing procumbent evergreen shrublet (Gaultheria hispidula) of Northern North America and Japan having white flowers and numerous white fleshy rough-hairy seeds.
midiron: a long iron{5} with a nearly vertical face.
Metasilicic: Designating an acid derived from silicic acid by the removal of water; of or pertaining to such an acid.
Misjoinder: An incorrect union of parties or of causes of action in a procedure, criminal or civil.
Monopyrenous: Having but a single stone or kernel.
Macrodiagonal: The longer of two diagonals, as of a rhombic prism. See Crystallization.
mandrill: A large West African baboon (Papio sphinx syn. Mandrillus sphinx, formerly Cynocephalus mormon syn. Papio mormon).  The adult male has, on the sides of the nose, large, naked, grooved swellings, conspicuously striped with blue and red.  It is an endangered species.
Material: To form from matter; to materialize.
Miscellaneous: Mixed; mingled; consisting of several things; of diverse sorts; promiscuous; heterogeneous; as, a miscellaneous collection.
matric: admission to a group (especially a college or university).
Meteorize: To ascend in vapors; to take the form of a meteor.
Meacock: An uxorious, effeminate, or spiritless man.
Meek: To make meek; to nurture in gentleness and humility.
machismo: A strong, and by some considered exaggerated, sense of manly pride, associated with an attitude that the proper expression of masculinity includes virility, courage, and an entitlement to dominate, especially over women.
motorbus: a road vehicle carrying many passengers; used for public transport; an omnibus.
Mundic: Iron pyrites, or arsenical pyrites; -- so called by the Cornish miners.
Mundil: A turban ornamented with an imitation of gold or silver embroidery.
&Verbar;Mosasaurus: A genus of extinct marine reptiles allied to the lizards, but having the body much elongated, and the limbs in the form of paddles.  The first known species, nearly fifty feet in length, was discovered in Cretaceous beds near Maestricht, in the Netherlands.
Modillion: The enriched block or horizontal bracket generally found under the cornice of the Corinthian and Composite entablature, and sometimes, less ornamented, in the Ionic and other orders; -- so called because of its arrangement at regulated distances.
&Verbar;Marcato: In a marked emphatic manner; -- used adverbially as a direction.
Memnon: A celebrated Egyptian statue near Thebes, said to have the property of emitting a harplike sound at sunrise.
Myriad: Consisting of a very great, but indefinite, number; as, myriad stars.
&Verbar;Myomorpha: An extensive group of rodents which includes the rats, mice, jerboas, and many allied forms.
Mint-master: The master or superintendent of a mint. Also used figuratively.
&Verbar;Monogamia: A Linnæan order of plants, having solitary flowers with united anthers, as in the genus Lobelia.
Masterless: Destitute of a master or owner; ungoverned or ungovernable.
Mammon: Riches; wealth; the god of riches; riches, personified.
Mustelus: A genus of sharks including certain of the smooth dogfishes.
mantled ground squirrel: A common black-striped reddish-brown ground squirrel (Citellus lateralis) of western North America, resembling a large chipmunk.
Meleagrididae: A natural family of fowls including the turkeys and some extinct forms.
majagua: A shrubby tree (Hibiscus tiliaceus) widely distributed along tropical shores, which yields a light tough wood used for canoe outriggers and a fiber used for cordage and caulk; it is often cultivated for ornament.
Myria-: A prefix, esp. in the metric system, indicating ten thousand, ten thousand times; as, myriameter.
Maggotish: Full of whims or fancies; maggoty.
Marconigraph: The apparatus used in Marconi wireless telegraphy.
Megalith: A large stone; especially, a large stone used in constructing ancient monuments.
Matutinal: Of or pertaining to the morning; early.
Metalogical: Beyond the scope or province of logic.
Motivate: To provide with a motive; to move; impel; induce; incite.
Methylated: Impregnated with, or containing, methyl alcohol or wood spirit; as, methylated spirits.
Mantling: The representation of a mantle, or the drapery behind and around a coat of arms: -- called also lambrequin.
mill-girl: a girl who works in a mill.
Meninges: The three membranes that envelop the brain and spinal cord; the pia mater, dura mater, and arachnoid membrane.
major league: The most important league{2} in any sport (especially baseball); contrasted with minor league.  Its teams are more competent, its members are paid more, and its games attract more interest and publicity, than those of a minor league.
Melanuric: Pertaining to, or designating, a complex nitrogenous acid obtained by decomposition of melam, or of urea, as a white crystalline powder; -- called also melanurenic acid.
Mistrust: To regard with jealousy or suspicion; to suspect; to doubt the integrity of; to distrust.
Morne: Of or pertaining to the morn; morning.
Muff: To handle awkwardly; to fumble; to fail to hold, as a ball, in catching it.
Mode: Manner of doing or being; method; form; fashion; custom; way; style; as, the mode of speaking; the mode of dressing.
Metoposcopy: The study of physiognomy; the art of discovering the character of persons by their features, or the lines of the face.
&Verbar;Micraster: A genus of sea urchins, similar to Spatangus, abounding in the chalk formation; -- from the starlike disposal of the ambulacral furrows.
Marchet: In old English and in Scots law, a fine paid to the lord of the soil by a tenant upon the marriage of one the tenant's daughters.
maltase: An enzyme, α-D-glucosidase, which hydrolyzes maltose with production of glucose.
&Verbar;Myopathia: Any affection of the muscles or muscular system.
Multipartite: Divided into many parts; having several parts.
Multiplication: The act or process of multiplying, or of increasing in number; the state of being multiplied; as, the multiplication of the human species by natural generation.
Moorish: Of or pertaining to Morocco or the Moors; in the style of the Moors.
&Verbar;Mesoscapula: A process from the middle of the scapula in some animals; the spine of the scapula.
Mortling: An animal, as a sheep, dead of disease or privation; a morling.
miniaturize: To design or construct on a smaller scale.
Millesimal: Thousandth; consisting of thousandth parts; as, millesimal fractions.
MDMA: Methylenedioxymethamphetamine, a drug designed to have the effects of amphetamines but originally synthesized to avoid the drug laws; it is now a controlled substance.  It is informally called ecstasy.  It is used by some abusively and illegally without a prescription.
Marcian: Under the influence of Mars; courageous; bold.
Modify: To change somewhat the form or qualities of; to change a part of something while leaving most parts unchanged; to alter somewhat; as, to modify a contrivance adapted to some mechanical purpose; to modify the terms of a contract.
Megalomania: A form of mental alienation in which the patient has grandiose delusions.
mamas boy: A boy excessively attached to his mother; a boy lacking the usual masculine interests; also spelled mamma's boy.
Melilotic: Of, pertaining to, or obtained from, sweet clover or melilot; specifically, designating an acid of the aromatic series, obtained from melilot as a white crystalline substance.
&Verbar;Melisma: A piece of melody; a song or tune, -- as opposed to recitative or musical declamation.
MST: Mountain Standard Time, the time of the 105th meridian, used in the mountain states of the U.S.
Miamis: A tribe of Indians that formerly occupied the country between the Wabash and Maumee rivers.
Myrmeleon: The type genus of the Myrmeleontidae, including the antlions.
Misrepresentative: Tending to convey a wrong impression; misrepresenting.
&Verbar;Mittimus: A precept or warrant granted by a justice for committing to prison a party charged with crime; a warrant of commitment to prison.
Mercurialize: To be sprightly, fantastic, or capricious.
&Verbar;Myosotis: A genus of plants. See Mouse-ear.
Monarchist: An advocate of, or believer in, monarchy.
Mineralize: To go on an excursion for observing and collecting minerals; to mineralogize.
Miascite: A granitoid rock containing feldspar, biotite, elæolite, and sodalite.
Marcher: The lord or officer who defended the marches or borders of a territory.
Monarchism: The principles of, or preference for, monarchy.
Mammilloid: Like a mammilla or nipple; mammilliform.
Misinterpret: To interpret erroneously; to understand or to explain in a wrong sense.
Mistide: To happen or come to pass unfortunately; also, to suffer evil fortune.
Metagenesis: The change of form which one animal species undergoes in a series of successively produced individuals, extending from the one developed from the ovum to the final perfected individual.  Hence, metagenesis involves the production of sexual individuals by nonsexual means, either directly or through intervening sexless generations.  Opposed to monogenesis. See Alternate generation, under Generation.
Mannitose: A variety of sugar obtained by the partial oxidation of mannite, and closely resembling levulose.
Musculosity: The quality or state of being musculous; muscularity.
Manicate: Covered with hairs or pubescence so platted together and interwoven as to form a mass easily removed.
Mystic: One given to mysticism; one who holds mystical views, interpretations, etc.; especially, in ecclesiastical history, one who professed mysticism. See Mysticism.
&Verbar;Myriapoda: A class, or subclass, of arthropods, related to the hexapod insects, from which they differ in having the body made up of numerous similar segments, nearly all of which bear true jointed legs.  They have one pair of antennæ, three pairs of mouth organs, and numerous tracheæ, similar to those of true insects.  The larvæ, when first hatched, often have but three pairs of legs. See Centiped, Galleyworm, Milliped.
Mikado: The popular designation of the hereditary sovereign of Japan; the emperor of Japan.
Morainic: Of or pertaining to a moranie.
Monophysite: One of a sect, in the ancient church, who maintained that the human and divine in Jesus Christ constituted but one composite nature. Also used adjectively.
-mancy: A combining form denoting divination; as, aleuromancy, chiromancy, necromancy, etc.
manual alphabet: An alphabet of signs made by movement of the hands, used by the deaf; in it letters are represented by finger positions.  See Dactylology.
Moot-hill: A hill of meeting or council; an elevated place in the open air where public assemblies or courts were held by the Saxons; -- called, in Scotland, mute-hill.
Meadowy: Of or pertaining to meadows; resembling, or consisting of, meadow.
Mockingly: By way of derision; in a contemptuous or mocking manner.
Moderate: To become less violent, severe, rigorous, or intense; as, the wind has moderated.
mess up: To make a mess{5} of; to confuse, disorder, or muddle; to muss; to jumble; to disturb.
Maltin: The fermentative principle of malt; malt diastase; also, a name given to various medicinal preparations made from or containing malt.
mailman: A man who delivers the mail.  A male mail carrier.
Misdeed: An evil deed; a wicked action.
Macerate: To make lean; to cause to waste away.
Maranta: A genus of endogenous plants found in tropical America, and some species also in India.  They have tuberous roots containing a large amount of starch, and from one species (Maranta arundinacea, the American arrowroot or obedience plant) arrowroot (arrowroot starch) is obtained.  Many kinds are cultivated for ornament.
Moutan: The Chinese tree peony (Pæonia Mountan), a shrub with large flowers of various colors.
melamine: A nitrogenous strongly basic chemical substance (C3H6N6), structurally 2,4,6-triamino-1,3,5-triazine, produced from several cyanogen compounds, and obtained as a white crystalline substance; -- formerly supposed to be produced by the decomposition of melam.  Called also cyanuramide.  It is used as one of the starting components (together with formaldehyde) in the preparation of melamine resins, including the commercially marketed Formica (TM).  It is solid at room temperature, and sublimes at temperatures approaching 250° C, decomposing at 345° C.  Density 1.573.
Manila hemp: A fibrous material obtained from the abaca plant (Musa textilis), a plant allied to the banana, growing in the Philippine and other East India islands; -- called also by the native name abaca. From it matting, canvas, ropes, and cables are made.
musclebuilder: someone who does special exercises to develop the musculature; a bodybuilder.
Middlings: A combination of the coarser parts of ground wheat the finest bran, separated from the fine flour and coarse bran in bolting; -- formerly regarded as valuable only for feed; but now, after separation of the bran, used for making the best quality of flour. Middlings contain a large proportion of gluten.
mannequin: a woman who wears clothes to display fashions; a fashion model.
Mistake: An apprehending wrongly; a misconception; a misunderstanding; a fault in opinion or judgment; an unintentional error of conduct.
&Verbar;Moire: Originally, a fine textile fabric made of the hair of an Asiatic goat; afterwards, any textile fabric to which a watered appearance is given in the process of calendering.
morphemic: Of or pertaining to a morpheme.
&Verbar;Moira: The deity who assigns to every man his lot.
Marital: Of or pertaining to a husband; as, marital rights, duties, authority.
Metallist: A worker in metals, or one skilled in metals.
Machiavelism: The supposed principles of Machiavelli, or practice in conformity to them; political artifice, intended to favor arbitrary power.
mockingbird: A long-tailed gray-and-white songbird of North America (Mimus polyglottos), remarkable for its exact imitations of the notes of other birds. Its back is gray; the tail and wings are blackish, with a white patch on each wing; the outer tail feathers are partly white.  Originally its range was confined mostly to the southern states, but by late 19th century it had migrated as far north as New York.  The name is also applied to other members of thee same and related genera, found in Mexico, Central America, and the West Indies, such as the blue mockingbird of Mexico, Melanotis caerulescens.
Marshalsea: The court or seat of a marshal; hence, the prison in Southwark, belonging to the marshal of the king's household.
Musket: The male of the sparrow hawk.
&Verbar;Myalgia: Pain in the muscles; muscular rheumatism or neuralgia.
&Verbar;Medusa: The Gorgon; or one of the Gorgons whose hair was changed into serpents, after which all who looked upon her were turned into stone.
&Verbar;Madreporaria: An extensive division of Anthozoa, including most of the species that produce stony corals. See Illust. of Anthozoa.
Muscardin: The common European dormouse; -- so named from its odor.
monacid: An acid having one replaceable hydrogen atom.
main road: A major road for any form of motor transport.
Muriate: A salt of muriatic hydrochloric acid; a chloride; as, muriate of ammonia.
Midas: A genus of longeared South American monkeys, including numerous species of marmosets. See Marmoset.
Manumit: To release from slavery; to liberate from personal bondage or servitude; to free, as a slave.
&Verbar;Moir\u00e9: Watered; having a watered or clouded appearance; -- as of silk or metals.
Mithraism: The ancient Persian religion which worshiped Mithra; it was popular among Romans during first three centuries a. d.
monetarism: An economic theory holding that the rate of growth of the money supply is the priunciple cause of changes in inflation, economic growth, and unemployment.
Metagastric: Of or pertaining to the two posterior gastric lobes of the carapace of crabs.
monetarist: One who adheres to the theory of monetarism.
Milldam: A dam or mound to obstruct a water course, and raise the water to a height sufficient to turn a mill wheel.
magnetic monopole: a hypothetical subatomic particle having only one type of magnetic charge, the magnetic analogue of an electrically charged particle; it has only one magnetic pole instead of the two observed in all common magnetic object; -- it was still not observed as of 1998.
Mesmerize: To bring into a state of mesmeric sleep; to hypnotize.
&Verbar;Macrura: A subdivision of decapod Crustacea, having the abdomen largely developed. It includes the lobster, prawn, shrimp, and many similar forms.  Cf. Decapoda.
Magh: The eleventh month of the Hindu calendar.
marzipan: A confection made of almonds and sugar mixed into a paste and molded into shapes.  Same as marchpane.
Medicament: Anything used for healing diseases or wounds, especially a medicine; a medication; a healing application.
Motion picture: A series of pictures on a strip of film, taken at regular intervals in rapid succession (now usually 24 frames per second for ordinary work) by a special camera, intended to capture the image of objects in motion.
Mettled: Having mettle; high-spirited; ardent; full of fire.
male chauvinist: A man with a belief in the inferiority of women; one who believes in or practises male chavinism.
Myriare: A measure of surface in the metric system containing ten thousand ares, or one million square meters.  It is equal to about 247.1 acres.
Manograph: An optical device for making an indicator diagram for high-speed engines. It consists of a light-tight box or camera having at one end a small convex mirror which reflects a beam of light on to the ground glass or photographic plate at the other end. The mirror is pivoted so that it can be moved in one direction by a small plunger operated by an elastic metal diaphragm which closes a tube connected with the engine cylinder. It is also moved at right angles to this direction by a reducing motion, called a reproducer, so as to copy accurately on a smaller scale the motion of the engine piston. The resultant of these two movements imparts to the reflected beam of light a motion similar to that of the pencil of the ordinary indicator, and this can be traced on the sheet of ground glass, or photographed.
Mailable: Admissible lawfully into the mail.  Opposed to non-mailable.  Dangerous items such as explosives, weapons, or corrosive chemicals are often classified by the postal authorities as non-mailable.
&Verbar;Macacus: A genus of monkeys, found in Asia and the East Indies, now usually called Macaca.  They have short tails and prominent eyebrows.  See also Macaca.
milkcap: A type of edible mushroom (Lactarius delicioso).
Misname: To call by the wrong name; to give a wrong or inappropriate name to.
Madreporian: Resembling, or pertaining to, the genus Madrepora.
&Verbar;Myxomycetes: A class of peculiar organisms, the slime molds, formerly regarded as animals (Mycetozoa), but now generally thought to be plants and often separated as a distinct phylum (Myxophyta); essentially equivalent to the division Myxomycota.  They are found on damp earth and decaying vegetable matter, and consist of naked masses of protoplasm, often of considerable size, which creep very slowly  over the surface and ingest solid food.
Malva neglecta: The species name of the common mallow, an annual Old World plant with clusters of pink or white flowers; naturalized in U.S..
Molinist: A follower of the opinions of Molina, a Spanish Jesuit (in respect to grace); an opposer of the Jansenists.
Molinism: The doctrines of the Molinists, somewhat resembling the tenets of the Arminians.
Medle: To mix; to mingle; to meddle.
Midgut: The middle part of the alimentary canal from the stomach, or entrance of the bile duct, to, or including, the large intestine.
Muskwood: The wood of a West Indian tree of the Mahogany family (Moschoxylum Swartzii).
Malpighiaceous: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, a natural order of tropical trees and shrubs (Malpighiaceæ), some of them climbing plants, and their stems forming many of the curious lianes of South American forests.
mortarboard: A small square board with a handle beneath, for holding mortar; a hawk; used by masons to hold or carry mortar.
&Verbar;Mesorectum: The fold of peritoneum, or mesentery, attached to the rectum.
Marketable: Fit to be offered for sale in a market; such as may be justly and lawfully sold; as, dacayed provisions are not marketable.
&Verbar;Marrubium: A genus of bitter aromatic plants, sometimes used in medicine; hoarhound.
Mintage: The coin, or other production, made in a mint.
Mustache: That part of the beard which grows on the upper lip; hair left growing above the mouth.
Myrmotherine: Feeding upon ants; -- said of certain birds.
&Verbar;Misurato: Measured; -- a direction to perform a passage in strict or measured time.
mouseketeer: One of a group of children appearing on the television program The Mickey Mouse Club in the 1950's.
major axis: The greater axis of a geometrical figure.
Mole-eyed: Having eyes like those of the mole; having imperfect sight.
Melolonthidae: A natural subfamily of beetles, considered a separate family in some classification systems.
Maidmarian: The lady of the May games; one of the characters in a morris dance; a May queen. Afterward, a grotesque character personated in sports and buffoonery by a man in woman's clothes.
Mandolin: A small and beautifully shaped instrument resembling the lute.
Mellification: The making or production of honey.
Manchet: Fine white bread; a loaf of fine bread.
Morphophyly: The tribal history of forms; that part of phylogeny which treats of the tribal history of forms, in distinction from the tribal history of functions.
Mutuary: One who borrows personal chattels which are to be consumed by him, and which he is to return or repay in kind.
mutagenicity: the degree or measure of the ability to cause mutation{3};  -- said of mutagens.
Metric system: A system of weights and measures originating in France, the use of which is required by law in many countries, and permitted in many others, including the United States; the system is also called by its French name, Le Système International de Unités (abbreviated SI).  The principal unit of length is the meter (see Meter).  From this are formed the are, the liter, the stere, the gram, etc. These units, and others derived from them, are divided decimally, and larger units are formed from multiples by 10, 100, 1,000, and 10,000.  The successive multiplies are designated by the prefixes, deka- (formerly deca-), hecto-, kilo-, and myria- (seldom used); successive parts by deci-, centi-, and milli-.  The prefixes mega- and micro- are used to denote a multiple by one million, and the millionth part, respectively; giga- and nano- denote multiples of one billion (1,000,000,000) and one billionth, respectively.  The prefix for one trillion (1012) is tera, and for one trillionth (10-12) is pico;  for one quintillion (1015) peta, and for (10-15) (one quintillionth) femto;  for (10-18) atto.  See the words formed with these prefixes in the Vocabulary. For metric tables, see p. 1682.
Miskindle: To kindle amiss; to inflame to a bad purpose; to excite wrongly.
Microamp\u00e8re: One of the smaller measures of electrical currents; the millionth part of one ampère.
madagascar plum: A small shrubby tree (Flacourtia indica) of Madagascar cultivated in tropical regions as a hedge plant and for its deep red acid fruits resembling small plums.
Moralize: To make moral reflections; to regard acts and events as involving a moral.
Masoretic: Of or relating to the Masora, or to its authors.
Muharram: the first month of the Islamic calendar.
Monastic: Of or pertaining to monasteries, or to their occupants, rules, etc., as, monastic institutions or rules.
Manducatory: Pertaining to, or employed in, chewing.
Muscadet: A white grape grown esp. in the Loire Valley in France.
Monody: A species of poem of a mournful character, in which a single mourner expresses lamentation; a song for one voice.
Maleic: Pertaining to, or designating, an acid of the ethylene series (maleic acid), metameric with fumaric acid and obtained by heating malic acid.
Mesoxalic: Pertaining to, or designating, an acid, CH2O2(CO2H)2, obtained from amido malonic acid.
Mariner: One whose occupation is to assist in navigating ships; a seaman or sailor.
MEGO: A very dull article, speech, or book, which causes the reader or listener to rapidly lose interest; -- often used of involved discussions of a technical nature, especially in newspapers.
Miniment: A trifle; a trinket; a token.
Mendacious: Given to deception or falsehood; lying; as, a mendacious person.
Menziesia: A genus of deciduous shrubs of North America and eastern Asia.
Multilocular: Having many or several cells or compartments; as, a multilocular shell or capsule.
Madeira vine: A herbaceous climbing vine (Boussingaultia baselloides) very popular in cultivation, having shining entire leaves and racemes of small fragrant white flowers.
manid: Any species of the genus Manis, or family Manidæ.
Moff: A thin silk stuff made in Caucasia.
Military: The whole body of soldiers; soldiery; militia; troops; the army.
macrocyte: An abnormally large red blood cell, associated with pernicious anemia.
Mosey: To go, or move (in a certain manner); -- usually with out, off, along, etc.
Merrymaker: One who makes merriment or indulges in conviviality; a jovial comrade.
Metasternal: Of or pertaining to the metasternum.
Mauling: A severe beating with a stick, cudgel, or the fist.
Mooring: The act of confining a ship to a particular place, by means of anchors or fastenings.
Mischarge: To charge erroneously, as in an account.
Marbleize: To stain or grain in imitation of marble; to cover with a surface resembling marble; as, to marbleize slate, wood, or iron.
Meningitis: Inflammation of the membranes of the brain or spinal cord.
Monadology: The doctrine or theory of monads.
Monasticism: The monastic life, system, or condition.
Mezereon: A small European shrub (Daphne Mezereum), whose acrid bark is used in medicine.
&Verbar;Mabolo: A kind of persimmon tree (Diospyros discolor) from the Philippine Islands, now introduced into the East and West Indies. It bears an edible fruit as large as a quince.
markweed: A climbing plant (Toxicodendron radicans) common in eastern and central U. S. with ternate leaves and greenish flowers followed by white berries.  It yields an irritating oil that causes a rash on contact; commonly called poison ivy.
Mongrelize: To cause to be mongrel; to cross breeds, so as to produce mongrels.
Milady: Lit., my lady; hence (as used on the Continent), an English noblewoman or gentlewoman.
Marchpane: A kind of sweet bread or biscuit; a cake of pounded almonds and sugar.  Called also marzipan.
Muscule: A long movable shed used by besiegers in ancient times in attacking the walls of a fortified town.
Mesial: Middle; median; in, or in the region of, the mesial plane; internal; -- opposed to lateral.
Mesiad: Toward, or on the side toward, the mesial plane; mesially; -- opposed to laterad.
mutagen: A chemical compound or other external influence (such as ionizing radiation) which causes mutations{3}.
Merrily: In a merry manner; with mirth; with gayety and laughter; jovially. See Mirth, and Merry.
Mysticeti: A suborder including baleen whales: right whales; rorquals; blue whales; and humpbacks.
&Verbar;Malacopterygii: An order of fishes in which the fin rays, except the anterior ray of the pectoral and dorsal fins, are closely jointed, and not spiny.  It includes the carp, pike, salmon, shad, etc. Called also Malacopteri.
manifest destiny: A policy of imperialism rationalized as inevitable (as if granted by God).
Manifestness: The quality or state of being manifest; obviousness.
Mauther: A girl; esp., a great, awkward girl; a wench.
Microsthene: One of a group of mammals having a small size as a typical characteristic.  It includes the lower orders, as the Insectivora, Cheiroptera, Rodentia, and Edentata.
Myrmidon: One of a fierce tribe or troop who accompanied Achilles, their king, to the Trojan war.
Mulewort: A fern of the genus Hemionitis.
Methenyl: The hypothetical hydrocarbon radical CH, regarded as an essential residue of certain organic compounds.
macerative: Accompanied by or  characterized by maceration.
Mudwort: A small herbaceous plant growing on muddy shores (Limosella aquatica).
Mouther: One who mouths; an affected speaker.
Musciform: Having the appearance or form of a moss.
mangrove snapper: A fish (Lutjanus griseus) found in shallow waters off the coast of Florida; called also gray snapper.
Minious: Of the color of red or vermilion.
Meracious: Being without mixture or adulteration; hence, strong; racy.
Marinorama: A representation of a sea view.
Martineta: A species of tinamou (Calopezus elegans), having a long slender crest.
Magdaleon: A medicine in the form of a roll, a esp. a roll of plaster.
Marxism: A system of economic and political thought, originated by Karl Marx, and elaborated by others.  It holds that the state has been the a device for suppression of the masses, allowing exploitation by a dominant (capitalistic) class; that historical change occurs through class struggle; and that the capitalist system will inevitably wither away to be superseded by a classless society.
Moliminous: Of great bulk or consequence; very important.
Mulierty: Condition of being a mulier; position of one born in lawful wedlock.
Muriform: Resembling courses of bricks or stones in squareness and regular arrangement; as, a muriform variety of cellular tissue.
Moon-culminating: Culminating, or coming to the meredian, at or about the same time with the moon; -- said of a star or stars, esp. of certain stars selected beforehand, and named in an ephemeris (as the Nautical Almanac), as suitable to be observed in connection with the moon at culmination, for determining terrestrial longitude.
methanol: The simplest alcohol of the paraffin series, CH3.OH; methyl alcohol.  Called also wood alcohol.  It is used as an antifreeze solvent, as a fuel, and as a denaturant for ethyl alcohol.
Marconi: Designating, or pert. to, Marconi's system of wireless telegraphy; as, Marconi aërial, coherer, station, system, etc. [archaic]
Menstruate: To discharge the menses; to have the catamenial flow.
mop-headed: having a bushy top without a leader; -- of trees; as, mop-headed cabbage palms.
meaningful: Having a meaning or purpose; having significance; as, a meaningful explanation; a meaningful discussion; a meaningful pause; to live a meaningful life.  Opposite of meaningless.
Motiveless: Destitute of a motive; not incited by a motive.
Maziness: The state or quality of being mazy.
Masticador: A part of a bridle, the slavering bit.
magnetic north: The direction in which the north-pointing end of a compass needle points; at low latitudes it is close to geographic (true) north, but deviates substantially from true north as one nears the north pole.
Massagist: One who practices massage; a masseur or masseuse.
mayor: The chief magistrate of a city or borough; the chief administrative officer of a municipal corporation.  In some American cities there is a city court of which the major is chief judge.  The post is usually elective, its holder chosen by the electorate of the entire city.
Mainprise: To suffer to go at large, on his finding sureties, or mainpernors, for his appearance at a day; -- said of a prisoner.
mottling: the act of coloring with areas of different shades.
Molecule: One of the very small invisible particles of which all ordinary matter is supposed to consist.
Monetary: Of or pertaining to money, or consisting of money; pecuniary.
Mayaca: A small genus of delicate mossy bog plants having white or violet flowers.
Megasthenic: Having a typically large size; belonging to the megasthenes.
&Verbar;Matelass\u00e9: A quilted ornamented dress fabric of silk or silk and wool.
Mercy: Forbearance to inflict harm under circumstances of provocation, when one has the power to inflict it; compassionate treatment of an offender or adversary; clemency.
Misinform: To give untrue information; (with against) to calumniate.
Mycologic: Of or relating to mycology, or the fungi.
Motion: To direct or invite by a motion, as of the hand or head; as, to motion one to a seat.
&Verbar;Metabola: A comprehensive group of insects, including those that undegro a metamorphosis.
Macaw: Any parrot of the genus Ara, Sittace, or Macrocercus.  About eighteen species are known, all of them found in Central and South America.  They are large and have a very long tail, a strong hooked bill, and a naked space around the eyes.  The voice is harsh, and the colors are brilliant and strongly contrasted; they are among the largest and showiest of parrots.  Different species names have been given to the same macaw, as for example the Hyacinthine macaw, which has been variously classified as Anodorhyncus hyacynthinus, Anodorhyncus maximiliani, and Macrocercus hyacynthinus.
Mandelic: Pertaining to an acid first obtained from benzoic aldehyde (oil of better almonds), as a white crystalline substance; -- called also phenyl glycolic acid.
Minus: Less; requiring to be subtracted; negative; as, a minus quantity.
Millwright: A mechanic whose occupation is to build mills, or to set up their machinery.
Morsel: A little bite or bit of food.
&Verbar;Mooruk: A species of cassowary (Casuarius Bennetti) found in New Britain, and noted for its agility in running and leaping.  It is smaller and has stouter legs than the common cassowary.  Its crest is bilobed; the neck and breast are black; the back, rufous mixed with black; and the naked skin of the neck, blue.
Marque: A license to pass the limits of a jurisdiction, or boundary of a country, for the purpose of making reprisals.
Merosome: One of the serial segments, or metameres, of which the bodies of vertebrate and articulate animals are composed.
Misbehaved: Guilty of ill behavior; illbred; rude.
matrisib: One related on the mother's side.
motorized: same as motored; as, a motorized wheelchair.  Opposite of unmotorized.
Myth: A story of great but unknown age which originally embodied a belief regarding some fact or phenomenon of experience, and in which often the forces of nature and of the soul are personified; an ancient legend of a god, a hero, the origin of a race, etc.; a wonder story of prehistoric origin; a popular fable which is, or has been, received as historical.
Misimprovement: Ill use or employment; use for a bad purpose.
mashed potatoes: Potatoes which have been boiled and mashed to a pulpy consistency, usu. with sparing addition of milk, salt, butter, or other flavoring.  It is a popular accompaniment to a meat course [U.S., 1900's], providing bulk and calories to a meal.
Midship: Of or pertaining to, or being in, the middle of a ship.
Mythology: The science which treats of myths; a treatise on myths.
matchboard: A board that has a groove cut into one edge and a tongue cut into the other so they fit tightly together (as in a floor); see match boarding.
Misbelieve: To believe erroneously, or in a false religion.
Monogamist: One who practices or upholds monogamy.
Meagerness: The state or quality of being meager; leanness; scantiness; barrenness.
Maori: One of the aboriginal inhabitants of New Zealand; also, the original language of New Zealand.
Morphologic: Of, pertaining to, or according to, the principles of morphology.
Mussitation: A speaking in a low tone; mumbling.
&Verbar;morpho: Any one of numerous species of large, handsome, tropical American butterflies, of the genus Morpho. They are noted for the very brilliant metallic luster and bright colors (often blue) of the upper surface of the wings.  The lower surface is usually brown or gray, with eyelike spots.
Massage: To treat by means of massage; to rub or knead; as, to massage a patient with ointment.
Marchantiaceae: A natural family of liverworts with prostrate and usually dichotomously branched thalli.
Metric: Relating to measurement; involving, or proceeding by, measurement.
Mollebart: An agricultural implement used in Flanders, consisting of a kind of large shovel drawn by a horse and guided by a man.
Murexo\u00efn: A complex nitrogenous compound obtained as a scarlet crystalline substance, and regarded as related to murexide.
Mucous: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, mucus; slimy, ropy, or stringy, and lubricous; as, a mucous substance.
Malva: A genus of herbs and subshrubs including the mallows.
myrmecophytic: Of or pertaining to a myrmecophyte.
Metallic: Of or pertaining to a metal; of the nature of metal; resembling metal; as, a metallic appearance; a metallic alloy.
Medina epoch: A subdivision of the Niagara period in the American upper Silurian, characterized by the formations known as the Oneida conglomerate, and the Medina sandstone. See the Chart of Geology.
&Verbar;Morus: A genus of trees, some species of which produce edible fruit; the mulberry. See Mulberry.
&Verbar;Mistigris: A variety of the game of poker in which the joker is used, and called mistigris or mistigri.
Macropinacoid: One of the two planes of an orthorhombic crystal which are parallel to the vertical and longer lateral (macrodiagonal) axes.
&Verbar;Manducus: A grotesque mask, representing a person chewing or grimacing, worn in processions and by comic actors on the stage.
Mephitic: Tending to destroy life; poisonous; noxious; as, mephitic exhalations; mephitic regions.
machine language: a set of instructions{3} in a binary form that can be executed directly by the CPU of a computer without translation by a computer program.
Malleolar: Of or pertaining to the malleolus; in the region of the malleoli of the ankle joint.
Muscling: Exhibition or representation of the muscles.
Morbidity: The quality or state of being morbid.
macrocephaly: THe condition of having an unusually large head; it differs from hydrocephalus because there is no increase intracranial pressure and the overgrowth is symmetrical.
Masonic: Of or pertaining to Freemasons or to their craft or mysteries.
Moderateness: The quality or state of being moderate; temperateness; moderation.
Martinmas: The feast of St. Martin, the eleventh of November; -- often called martlemans.
mierkat: A South African mongooselike viverrine (Suricata suricata) having a lemurlike face and only four toes; called also suricate.
&Verbar;Mochila: A large leather flap which covers the saddletree.
Monophyllous: One-leaved; composed of a single leaf; as, a monophyllous involucre or calyx.
Methide: A binary compound of methyl with some element; as, aluminium methide, Al2(CH3)6.
Marchioness: The wife or the widow of a marquis; a woman who has the rank and dignity of a marquis.
Madonna: My lady; -- a term of address in Italian formerly used as the equivalent of Madame, but for which Signora is now substituted. Sometimes introduced into English.
Mannitan: A white amorphous or crystalline substance obtained by the partial dehydration of mannite.
malady: Any disease of the human body; a distemper, disorder, or indisposition, proceeding from impaired, defective, or morbid organic functions; especially, a lingering or deep-seated disorder.
manned: Having a crew; -- of vehicles; as, a manned earth satellite was considered a necessary research step; to minimize casualties, the military used cruise missiles rather than manned aircraft for the bombardment.  Opposite of unmanned.
Millionairess: A woman who is a millionaire, or the wife of a millionaire.
maniclike: Resembling the mania of manic-depressive illness.
Maara shell: A large, pearly, spiral, marine shell (Turbo margaritaceus), from the Pacific Islands. It is used as an ornament.
magnetic tape: A long thin plastic ribbon coated with iron oxide or other ferromagnetic material, used to record audio or video signals digital data in the form of small magnetized regions on the tape; it is a common digital data storage medium for computer information.
Mercurification: The process or operation of obtaining the mercury, in its fluid form, from mercuric minerals.
Mycteria: A genus of birds including certain of the wood ibises, including the endangered Mycteria americana; it is sometimes assigned to a subfamily Mycteriinae.
magnum: Having a larger charge than usual for a cartridge of the same caliber; -- of cartridges for handgun; as, a .44 magnum cartridge.
Maslach: An excitant containing opium, much used by the Turks.
Meaw: See Mew, to cry as a cat.
Manequin: An artist's model of wood or other material.
Mandarinism: A government by mandarins (senses 1 or 2); character or spirit of the mandarins{2}.
maple family: The natural family of trees Aceraceae, including the maples.
Mileage: An allowance for traveling expenses at a certain rate per mile.
Meak: A hook with a long handle.
Meal: To sprinkle with, or as with, meal.
Mean: That which is mean, or intermediate, between two extremes of place, time, or number; the middle point or place; middle rate or degree; mediocrity; medium; absence of extremes or excess; moderation; measure.
manta ray: An extremely large pelagic tropical ray of the family Mobulidae, that feeds on plankton and small fishes.  It is usually harmless but its size (up to 20 feet across and up to a ton in weight) make it dangerous if harpooned.  Called also manta, sea devil and devilfish.  See also Cephaloptera and Sea devil.
&Verbar;Marseillais: A native or inhabitant of Marseilles.
Mulloid: Like or pertaining to the genus Mullus, which includes the surmullet, or red mullet.
Moate: To void the excrement, as a bird; to mute.
moorfowl: A reddish-brown grouse (Lagopus Scoticus) of upland moors of Great Britain; the European ptarmigan, or red grouse, also called the moorgame.
Monitor: One who admonishes; one who warns of faults, informs of duty, or gives advice and instruction by way of reproof or caution.
Microphyte: A very minute plant, one of certain unicellular algæ, such as the germs of various infectious diseases are believed to be.
Muscadine: A name given to several very different kinds of grapes, but in America used chiefly for the scuppernong, or southern fox grape, which is said to be the parent stock of the Catawba.  See Grapevine.
&Verbar;Monogynia: A Linnæan order of plants, including those which have only one style or stigma.
Metabolian: An insect which undergoes a metamorphosis.
Moselle: A light wine, usually white, produced in the vicinity of the river Moselle.
Masticate: To grind or crush with, or as with, the teeth and prepare for swallowing and digestion; to chew; as, to masticate food.
milometer: a meter that shows mileage traversed.
moonwalk: a kind of dance step in which the dancer seems to be sliding backward on the spot; as, Michael Jackson perfected the moonwalk in the 1980s.
meagerly: same as meager, 2.  Opposite of ample.
Magnality: A great act or event; a great attainment.
Muscoid: A term formerly applied to any mosslike flowerless plant, with a distinct stem, and often with leaves, but without any vascular system.
Menagerie: A place where animals are kept and trained.
Microseismometer: A seismometer for measuring amplitudes or periods, or both, of microseisms.
Memorial Day: A day, originally May 30, appointed for commemorating, by decorating their graves with flowers, by patriotic exercises, etc., the dead soldiers and sailors who served the Civil War (1861-65) in the United States; Also called Decoration Day. It is a legal holiday in most of the States. In the Southern States, the Confederate Memorial Day is: May 30 in Virginia; April 26 in Alabama, Florida, Georgia, and Mississippi; May 10 in North Carolina and South Carolina; the second Friday in May in Tennessee; June 3 in Louisiana.
Monomial: Consisting of but a single term or expression.
Milligram: A measure of weight, in the metric system, being the thousandth part of a gram, equal to the weight of a cubic millimeter of water, or .01543 of a grain avoirdupois.
management consultant: An adviser to business about efficient management practices.
Muscidae: A natural family of two-winged flies esp. the housefly.
Murdress: A battlement in ancient fortifications with interstices for firing through.
magneton: A unit of magnetic moment for a subatomic particle, atom, or molecule.
mirrorlike: capable of reflecting light like a mirror; flat and reflective; as, the mirrorlike surface of the lake.
Munjistin: An orange-red coloring substance resembling alizarin, found in the root of an East Indian species of madder (Rubia munjista).
Minder: One who minds, tends, or watches something, as a child, a machine, or cattle; as, a minder of a loom.
Monogenous: Of or pertaining to monogenesis; as, monogenous, or asexual, reproduction.
Mesocephalic: Of or pertaining to, or in the region of, the middle of the head; as, the mesocephalic flexure.
Mergus: A genus of ducks consisting of mergansers.
Minden: A battle in the Seven Years' War (1759) in which the Anglo-Allied forces under duke Ferdinand of Brunswick defeated the French under Marshal Contades.
Monophysitical: Of or pertaining to Monophysites, or their doctrines.
Mesosperm: A membrane of a seed. See Secundine.
Motherhood: The state of being a mother; the character or office of a mother.
Manslaughter: The slaying of a human being; destruction of men.
Mintman: One skilled in coining, or in coins; a coiner.
Manteidae: A natural family of insects including the mantises.  Also spelled Mantidae.
Multisyllable: A word of many syllables; a polysyllable.
Myxopod: A rhizopod or moneran. Also used adjectively; as, a myxopod state.
magnetosphere: the magnetic field of a planet; the volume around the planet in which charged particles are subject more to the planet's magnetic field than to the solar magnetic field.
Mascled: Composed of, or covered with, lozenge-shaped scales; having lozenge-shaped divisions.
Misbecome: Not to become; to suit ill; not to befit or be adapted to.
Membrane: A thin layer or fold of tissue, usually supported by a fibrous network, serving to cover or line some part or organ, and often secreting or absorbing certain fluids.
Malacoderm: One of a tribe of beetles (Malacodermata), with a soft and flexible body, as the fireflies.
manzanilla: A kind of small roundish olive with a small freestone pit, a fine skin, and a peculiar bitterish flavor. Manzanillas are commonly pitted and stuffed with Spanish pimientos.
moon-splashed: splashed or covered patchily with moonlight; as, the moon-splashed world.
Mediastine: A partition; a septum; specifically, the folds of the pleura (and the space included between them) which divide the thorax into a right and left cavity. The space included between these folds of the pleura, called the mediastinal space, contains the heart and gives passage to the esophagus and great blood vessels.
manila maguey: A hard fiber used in making coarse twine; from Philippine agave plants.
Maioid: Of or pertaining to the genus Maia, or family Maiadeæ.
Mesocuneiform: One of the bones of the tarsus. See 2d Cuneiform.
Meropodite: The fourth joint of a typical appendage of Crustacea.
Manage: To direct affairs; to carry on business or affairs; to administer.
Mastless: Having no mast; as, a mastless vessel.
Musicomania: A kind of monomania in which the passion for music becomes so strong as to derange the intellectual faculties.
Misword: A word wrongly spoken; a cross word.
Malvastrum: A genus of mallows characterized by red and yellow flowers often placed in other genera.
Muciparous: Secreting, or producing, mucus or mucin.
managed economy: A non-market economy in which government intervention is important in allocating goods and resources and determining prices.
Myograph: An instrument for determining and recording the different phases, as the intensity, velocity, etc., of a muscular contraction.
man in the street: An average person; as, the views of the man in the street.
&Verbar;Microlestes: An extinct genus of small Triassic mammals, the oldest yet found in European strata.
marasca: The small bitter fruit of the marasca cherry tree from whose juice maraschino liqueur is made.
Mumbledy peg: A game played with a pocketknife, the object of which is to throw the knife in any of a vairety of ways (such as over the back), or from various positions, and have it stick in the ground or another surface.  Also called mumble-the-peg and mumble peg.
Muggy: Moist; damp; moldy; as, muggy straw.
&Verbar;M\u00e9doc: A class of claret wines, including several varieties, from the district of Médoc in the department of Gironde.
&Verbar;Monotropa: A genus of parasitic or saprophytic plants including the Indian pipe and pine sap. The name alludes to the dropping end of the stem.
Mausoleum: A magnificent tomb, or stately sepulchral monument.
Mink: A carnivorous mammal of the genus Mustela (foremrly Putorius), allied to the weasel.  The European mink is Mustela lutreola.  The common American mink (Mustela vison) varies from yellowish brown to black.  Its fur is highly valued.  Called also minx, nurik, and vison.
mammy: A child's name for mamma, mother.
Mine: Belonging to me; my. Used as a pronominal to me; my. Used as a pronominal adjective in the predicate; as, “Vengeance is mine; I will repay.” Rom. xii. 19. Also, in the old style, used attributively, instead of my, before a noun beginning with a vowel.
&Verbar;Monte: In Spanish America, a wood; forest; timber land; esp., in parts of South America, a comparatively wooden region.
Minx: The mink; -- called also minx otter.
Miny: Abounding with mines; like a mine.
Missish: Like a miss; prim; affected; sentimental.
Mint: A place where money is coined by public authority.
Mammary: Of or pertaining to the mammæ or breasts; as, the mammary arteries and veins.
Memorial: Anything intended to preserve the memory of a person or event; something which serves to keep something else in remembrance; a monument.
minuscular: of or relating to minuscule script, a small cursive script developed from uncial, and used in the 7th to 9th centuries.
Melanin: A black pigment found in the pigment-bearing cells of the skin (particularly in the skin of the negro), in the epithelial cells of the external layer of the retina (then called fuscin), in the outer layer of the choroid, and elsewhere. It is supposed to be derived from the decomposition of hemoglobin.
Monophthongal: Consisting of, or pertaining to, a monophthong.
Masterliness: The quality or state of being masterly; ability to control wisely or skillfully.
Myrrh: A gum resin, usually of a yellowish brown or amber color, of an aromatic odor, and a bitter, slightly pungent taste.  It is valued for its odor and for its medicinal properties.  It exudes from the bark of a shrub of Abyssinia and Arabia, the Commiphora Myrrha (syn. Balsamodendron Myrrha) of the family Burseraceae, or from the Commiphora abyssinica.  The myrrh of the Bible is supposed to have been partly the gum above named, and partly the exudation of species of Cistus, or rockrose.
Matting: A dull, lusterless surface in certain of the arts, as gilding, metal work, glassmaking, etc.
Monest: To warn; to admonish; to advise.
&Verbar;Mesembryanthemum: A genus of herbaceous or suffruticose plants, chiefly natives of South Africa.  The leaves are opposite, thick, and fleshy.  The flowers usually open about midday, whence the name.
Metopic: Of or pertaining to the forehead or frontal bones; frontal; as, the metopic suture.
Morning: Pertaining to the first part or early part of the day; being in the early part of the day; as, morning dew; morning light; morning service.
Marcionite: A follower of Marcion, a Gnostic of the second century, who adopted the Oriental notion of the two conflicting principles, and imagined that between them there existed a third power, neither wholly good nor evil, the Creator of the world and of man, and the God of the Jewish dispensation.
matrass: A round-bottomed glass flask having a long neck; a bolthead.
Maverick brand: A brand originated by a dishonest cattleman, who, without owning any stock, gradually accumulates a herd by finding mavericks.
Musketeer: A soldier armed with a musket.
Mulligrubs: A griping of the intestines; colic.
Muscariform: Having the form of a brush.
Muricoid: Like, or pertaining to, the genus Murex, or family Muricidæ.
Meddlesome: Given to meddling; apt to interpose in the affairs of others; officiously intrusive.
manila bean: A tuberous-rooted twining annual vine (Psophocarpus tetragonolobus) bearing clusters of purplish flowers and pods with four jagged wings; Old World tropics.
Margay: A small American wild cat (Felis wiedi syn. Felis tigrina), ranging from Mexico to Brazil.  It is spotted with black.  Called also long-tailed cat.
Minette: The smallest of regular sizes of portrait photographs.
Mucivore: An insect which feeds on mucus, or the sap of plants, as certain Diptera, of the tribe Mucivora.
Motherliness: The state or quality of being motherly.
Make: Structure, texture, constitution of parts; construction; shape; form.
Manipular: Of or pertaining to the maniple, or company.
Melopiano: A piano having a mechanical attachment which enables the player to prolong the notes at will.
Matcher: One who, or that which, matches; a matching machine. See under 3d Match.
Managerial: Of or pertaining to management or a manager; as, managerial qualities.
Moonshiner: A person engaged in illicit distilling; -- so called because the work is largely done at night.
Measled: Infected or spotted with measles, as pork.
Money-making: Affording profitable returns; lucrative; as, a money-making business.  Opposite of unprofitable.
Morally: In a moral or ethical sense; according to the rules of morality.
Muslinet: A sort of coarse or light cotton cloth.
&Verbar;Monomphalus: A form of double monster, in which two individuals are united by a common umbilicus.
&Verbar;Maharmah: A muslin wrapper for the head and the lower part of the face, worn by Turkish and Armenian women when they go abroad.
Manyplies: The third division, or that between the reticulum, or honeycomb stomach, and the abomasum, or rennet stomach, in the stomach of ruminants; the omasum; the psalterium.  So called from the numerous folds in its mucous membrane. See Illust of Ruminant.
Mistful: Clouded with, or as with, mist.
Misly: Raining in very small drops; drizzling.
Malta: A country on the island of Malta.
manure: Any matter which makes land productive; a fertilizing substance.
Minyan: A quorum, or number necessary, for conducting public worship.
Misle: A fine rain; a thick mist; a mizzle; a drizzle.
mole: A quantity of a substance equal to the molecular weight of a substance expressed in grams; a gram molecule; the basic unit of amount of substance adopted under the System International d'Unites; as, he added two moles of sodium chloride to the medium.
monocarbonic: Containing one carboxyl group; as, acetic acid is a monocarbonic acid.  The more common term is monocarboxylic.  Contrasted with dicarboxylic, tricarboxylic, etc.
Magneto-electric: Pertaining to, or characterized by, electricity by the action of magnets; as, magneto-electric induction.
Multiloquence: Quality of being multiloquent; use of many words; talkativeness.
Merestone: A stone designating a limit or boundary; a landmark.
Monument: Something which stands, or remains, to keep in remembrance what is past; a memorial.
Maladdress: Bad address; an awkward, tactless, or offensive way of accosting one or talking with one.
Materialistic: Of or pertaining to materialism or materialists; of the nature of materialism.
magnetic bottle: Any configuration of magnetic fields used to contain a plasma during controlled thermonuclear reactions.
Makebate: One who excites contentions and quarrels.
Mulatto: The offspring of a negress by a white man, or of a white woman by a negro, -- usually of a brownish yellow complexion.
malignant anemia: A chronic progressive anemia of older adults, thought to result from a lack of intrinsic factor (a substance secreted by the stomach that is responsible for the absorption of vitamin B-12); also called pernicious anemia.
Mockingstock: A butt of sport; an object of derision.
mandil: A loose outer garment worn the 16th and 17th centuries.
Macron: A short, straight, horizontal mark [-], placed over vowels to denote that they are to be pronounced with a long sound; as, ā, in dāme; ē, in sēam, etc.
manila bay: The name of a naval battle in the Spanish-American War (1898), in which the American fleet under Admiral Dewey defeated the Spanish fleet off the shore of Manila in the Phillipines.
Moxa: A soft woolly mass prepared from the young leaves of Artemisia Chinensis, and used as a cautery by burning it on the skin; hence, any substance used in a like manner, as cotton impregnated with niter, amadou.
&Verbar;Mesopodiale: One of the bones of either the carpus or tarsus.
&Verbar;Marmoratum opus: A kind of hard finish for plasterwork, made of plaster of Paris and marble dust, and capable of taking a high polish.
Mettlesome: Full of spirit; possessing constitutional ardor; fiery; as, a mettlesome horse.
manicurist: A person who makes a business of taking care of people's hands, especially their fingernails; -- formerly called a manicure.
mallee: A dwarf Australian eucalypt with a number of thin stems springing from a thickened stock.  The most common species are Eucalyptus dumosa and Eucalyptus Gracilis.
Madrier: A thick plank, used for several mechanical purposes
Mynchery: A nunnery; -- a term still applied to the ruins of certain nunneries in England.
muttonfish: A fish (Lutjanus analis) similar to and often marketed as “red snapper”.
Macro-: A combining form signifying long, large, great; as macrodiagonal, macrospore, macromolecule, macrocosm.
Menispermaceous: Pertaining to a natural order (Menispermaceæ) of climbing plants of which moonseed (Menispermum) is the type.
Mordacity: The quality of being mordacious; biting severity, or sarcastic quality.
manginess: The condition or quality of being mangy.
&Verbar;Moquette: A kind of carpet having a short velvety pile.
Monothalmic: Formed from one pistil; -- said of fruits.
menthol: A white, crystalline, aromatic substance (C10H20O) resembling camphor, extracted from oil of peppermint (Mentha); -- called also mint camphor or peppermint camphor.  It has the peculiar effect on skin and membranes of making them feel cool, and is used in liqueurs, confections, cigarettes, cough drops and perfumes, among other things.
Moravian: One of a religious sect called the United Brethren (an offshoot of the Hussites in Bohemia), which formed a separate church of Moravia, a northern district of Austria, about the middle of the 15th century.  After being nearly extirpated by persecution, the society, under the name of The Renewed Church of the United Brethren, was reëstablished in 1722-35 on the estates of Count Zinzendorf in Saxony.  Called also Herrnhuter.
Miserly: Like a miser; very covetous; avaricious; stingy; sordid; niggardly.
Mortpay: Dead pay; the crime of taking pay for the service of dead soldiers, or for services not actually rendered by soldiers.
marchand de vin: A sauce consisting of brown sauce with mushrooms and red wine or madeira.
Mineral: Of or pertaining to minerals; consisting of a mineral or of minerals; as, a mineral substance.
Marchantia: The type genus of Marchantiaceae; liverworts that reproduce asexually by gemmae and have stalked antheridiophores.
Mishnic: Of or pertaining to the Mishna.
