muesli: A mixture of untoasted dry cereals, nuts, and fruits, eaten mostly as a breakfast cereal; -- of Swiss origin.
Magneto-electricity: Electricity evolved by the action of magnets.
&Verbar;Morphosis: The order or mode of development of an organ or part.
Maigre: Belonging to a fast day or fast; as, a maigre day.
Mycologist: One who is versed in, or who studies, mycology.
Mannish: Resembling a human being in form or nature; human.
mellowed: having a mild and pleasing flavor through proper aging.
mud-dauber: A wasp of the family Sphegidae (Sphecidae) which builds a nest of mud and stores insects and spiders in it; a digger-wasp.
Mayan arch: A form of corbel arch employing regular small corbels.
Minglement: The act of mingling, or the state of being mixed.
Malaya: Formerly, an Asian country on Borneo and the Malay Peninsula, now part of Malaysia.
Muckworm: A larva or grub that lives in muck or manure; -- applied to the larvæ of the tumbledung and allied beetles.
Maskery: The dress or disguise of a masker; masquerade.
madagascar periwinkle: A commonly cultivated Old World woody herb (Vinca rosea) having large pinkish to red flowers.
Misconception: Erroneous conception; false opinion; wrong understanding.
Merman: The male corresponding to mermaid; a sea man, or man fish.
Muniment: The act of supporting or defending.
Mount: That upon which a person or thing is mounted
Mistrustful: Having or causing mistrust, suspicions, or forebodings.
Magnoliaceae: A natural family of plants, a subclass of the Magnoliidae; it includes the genera Liriodendron; Magnolia; Manglietia; and Michelia.
Mound: To fortify or inclose with a mound.
Matajuelo: A large squirrel fish (Holocentrus ascensionis) of Florida and the West Indies.
Meroblastic: Consisting only in part of germinal matter; characterized by partial segmentation only; as, meroblastic ova, in which a portion of the yolk only undergoes fission; meroblastic segmentation; -- opposed to holoblastic.
Misstep: To take a wrong step; to go astray.
metaphosphoric: Pertaining to, or designating, a monobasic acid, HPO3, analogous to nitric acid, and, by heating phosphoric acid, obtained as a crystalline substance, commonly called glacial phosphoric acid.  Compare the tribasic orthophosphoric acid.
Metapectin: A substance obtained from, and resembling, pectin, and occurring in overripe fruits.
Metapectic: Pertaining to, or designating, a supposed acid obtained from pectin.
Martin: One of several species of swallows, usually having the tail less deeply forked than the tail of the common swallows.
Model: To make a copy or a pattern; to design or imitate forms; as, to model in wax.
Metropolitan: The superior or presiding bishop of a country or province.
Mosaically: In the manner of a mosaic.
Malayan tapir: A large inoffensive chiefly nocturnal ungulate (Tapirus indicus) of tropical America and Southeast Asia having a heavy body and fleshy snout.
Marrowfat: A rich but late variety of pea.
&Verbar;Myzostomata: An order of curious parasitic worms found on crinoids. The body is short and disklike, with four pairs of suckers and five pairs of hook-bearing parapodia on the under side.
&Verbar;Mentha: A widely distributed genus of fragrant herbs, including the peppermint, spearmint, etc. The plants have small flowers, usually arranged in dense axillary clusters.
&Verbar;Myroxylon: A genus of leguminous trees of tropical America, the different species of which yield balsamic products, among which are balsam of Peru, and balsam of Tolu.  The species were formerly referred to Myrospermum.
Motorbike: a light two-wheeled vehicle containing a motor for propulsion.  It is lighter in construction and has a lower speed than a motorcycle.
Microfilm: to photograph and produce images of on microfilm.
Muscatel: A common name for several varieties of rich sweet wine, made in Italy, Spain, and France.
Midbrain: The middle segment of the brain; the mesencephalon. See Brain.
Malosma: A genus having only one species; often included in the genus Rhus.
Martyrologic: Pertaining to martyrology or martyrs; registering, or registered in, a catalogue of martyrs.
Malarial: Of or pertaining, to or infected by, malaria.
Milt: To impregnate (the roe of a fish) with milt.
Micrometry: The art of measuring with a micrometer.
Mild: Gentle; pleasant; kind; soft; bland; clement; hence, moderate in degree or quality; -- the opposite of harsh, severe, irritating, violent, disagreeable, etc.; -- applied to persons and things; as, a mild disposition; a mild eye; a mild air; a mild medicine; a mild insanity.
Mile: A certain measure of distance, being equivalent in England and the United States to 320 poles or rods, or 5,280 feet.
Madecassee: Of or pertaining to Madagascar or its inhabitants.
Mill: To fill (a winze or interior incline) with broken ore, to be drawn out at the bottom.
Milk: To draw or to yield milk.
magnetic mine: A marine mine that is detonated by a mechanism that detects the nearness of magnetic material (as the steel hull of a ship).  A magnetic counter mine may allow the passagw of several ships before detonating.
Meteyard: A yard, staff, or rod, used as a measure.
magnetic head: An electromagnet (as on a tape recorder) that converts electrical variations into magnetic variations that can be stored on a magnetizable surface and later retrieved.
Museum: A repository or a collection of natural, scientific, or literary curiosities, or of works of art.
Monton: A heap of ore; a mass undergoing the process of amalgamation.
Mangonel: A military engine formerly used for throwing stones and javelins.
&Verbar;Monsieur: The common title of civility in France in speaking to, or of, a man; Mr. or Sir.
Mundane: Of or pertaining to the world; worldly, as contrasted with heavenly; earthly; terrestrial; as, the mundane sphere; mundane concerns.
Marceline: A thin silk fabric used for linings, etc., in ladies' dresses.
Mucker: To scrape together, as money, by mean labor or shifts.
manganic acid: A dibasic acid H2MnO4, formed from manganese, analogous to sulphuric acid; it is found only in solution and in manganate salts.
Mackinaw: A short, heavy, double-breasted plaid coat, the design of which is large and striking.
Mauritius: A country on the island of Mauritius.
Macropod: Any one of a group of maioid crabs remarkable for the length of their legs; -- called also spider crab.
Manifestly: In a manifest manner; obviously; evidently; clearly.
Manse: A dwelling house, generally with land attached.
Musaceous: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, plants of the genus Musa.
Medicine: To give medicine to; to affect as a medicine does; to remedy; to cure.
Marcescent: Withering without falling off; fading; decaying.
Manuducent: One who leads by the hand; a manuductor.
Mucific: Inducing or stimulating the secretion of mucus; blennogenous.
Marionette: A puppet moved by strings, as in a puppet show.
Madid: Wet; moist; as, a madid eye.
morpheme: The smallest unit of meaning of a language, which cannot be divided into smaller parts carrying meaning; it is usually smaller than a single wordform, such as the -ed morpheme of verbs in the past tense or the -s morpheme of nouns in the plural form.
Magnitude: Extent of dimensions; size; -- applied to things that have length, breadth, and thickness.
Madecass: A native or inhabitant of Madagascar, or Madecassee. See Malagasy
Marinism: A bombastic literary style marked by the use of metaphors and antitheses characteristic of the Italian poet Giambattista Marini (1569-1625).
Micrograph: An instrument for executing minute writing or engraving.
mass-produce: To produce on a large scale.
mulligan: A stew made typically of meat, vegetables, and any conveniently available ingredients; also, an Irish version of burgoo.
martel: To make a blow with, or as with, a hammer.
Mentomeckelian: Of or pertaining to the chin and lower jaw.
Maid: An unmarried woman; usually, a young unmarried woman; esp., a girl; a virgin; a maiden.
Maim: The privation of the use of a limb or member of the body, by which one is rendered less able to defend himself or to annoy his adversary.
Mail: To deliver into the custody of the postoffice officials, or place in a government letter box, for transmission by mail; to post; as, to mail a letter.
maccaroni wheat: A type of wheat (Triticum durum) with hard dark-colored kernels high in gluten and used for bread and pasta; grown especially in South Russia, North Africa, and North central North America.
Myronic: Pertaining to, or obtained from, mustard; -- used specifically to designate a glucoside called myronic acid, found in mustard seed.
Manageable: Such as can be managed or used; suffering control; governable; tractable; subservient; as, a manageable horse.
Mammonite: One devoted to the acquisition of wealth or the service of Mammon.
&Verbar;Metrorrhagia: Profuse bleeding from the womb, esp. such as does not occur at the menstrual period.
Moon-eyed: Having eyes affected by the moon; moonblind; dim-eyed; purblind.
Mytiloid: Like, or pertaining to, the genus Mytilus, or family Mytilidæ.
manna grass: Any of several tall slender grasses of the genus Glyceria.  They have long loose panicles, have a sweet flavor or odor, and grow in moist places.  Nerved manna grass is Glyceria nervata, and Floating manna grass is Glyceria fluitans.
Menthyl: A compound radical forming the base of menthol.
Muskrat: A North American aquatic fur-bearing rodent (Ondatra zibethica formerly Fiber zibethicus).  It resembles a rat in color and having a long scaly tail, but the tail is compressed, the hind feet are webbed, and the ears are concealed in the fur.  It has scent glands which secrete a substance having a strong odor of musk.  Called also musquash, musk beaver, ondatra, and sometimes water rat.
major form class: Any of the parts of speech of traditional grammar.
Murza: One of the hereditary nobility among the Tatars, esp. one of the second class.
Misinformer: One who gives untrue or incorrect information.
mains: The source of electrical power in a building; the wiring system of a building.
Musrole: The nose band of a horse's bridle.
Misology: Hatred of argument or discussion; hatred of enlightenment.
musclebuilding: exercise that builds muscles through tension; bodybuilding.
&Verbar;Mycetozoa: The Myxomycetes; -- so called by those who regard them as a class of animals.
Marantaceae: A natural family of tropical perennial herbs with usually starchy rhizomes, including the arrowroot; the arrowroot family.
Madrepore: Any coral of the genus Madrepora, a group of corals having calcareous skeletons aggregations of which form reefs and islands; formerly, often applied to any stony coral.
Myelonal: Of or pertaining to the myelon; as, the myelonal, or spinal, nerves.
malcontent: discontented; uneasy; dissatisfied; especially, dissatisfied with the government.
Miquelet: An irregular or partisan soldier; a bandit.
Mho: A unit of conductivity, being the reciprocal of the ohm.
Maquis: A guerrilla fighter in the French underground in World War II.
Miscue: A false stroke with a billiard cue, the cue slipping from the ball struck without impelling it as desired.
Mussite: A variety of pyroxene, from the Mussa Alp in Piedmont; diopside.
Melioration: The act or operation of meliorating, or the state of being meliorated; improvement.
Metropolitanate: The see of a metropolitan bishop.
mucosa: The mucus-secreting membrane lining all body cavities or passages that communicate with the exterior; called also mucous membrane.
Menial: A domestic servant or retainer, esp. one of humble rank; one employed in low or servile offices.
&Verbar;marsupium: The pouch, formed by a fold of the skin of the abdomen, in which marsupials carry their young; also, a pouch for similar use in other animals, as certain Crustacea.
Marquisate: The seigniory, dignity, or lordship of a marquis; the territory governed by a marquis.
Methionic: Of, pertaining to, or designating, a sulphonic (thionic) acid derivative of methane, obtained as a stable white crystalline substance, CH2.(SO3H)2, which forms well defined salts.
Micromyx: A genus of Old World harvest mice.
Main-hamper: A hamper to be carried in the hand; a hand basket used in carrying grapes to the press.
Musty: Having the rank, pungent, offensive odor and taste which substances of organic origin acquire during warm, moist weather; foul or sour and fetid; moldy; as, musty corn; musty books.
Mongols: One of the great races of man, including the greater part of the inhabitants of China, Japan, and the interior of Asia, with branches in Northern Europe and other parts of the world.  By some American Indians are considered a branch of the Mongols.  In a more restricted sense, the inhabitants of Mongolia and adjacent countries, including the Burats and the Kalmuks.
Malvales: A natural order of plants including the families Malvaceae, Bombacaceae, Elaeocarpaceae, Sterculiaceae, and Tiliaceae.
Multinuclear: Containing many nuclei; as, multinuclear cells.
Mellifluous: Flowing as with honey; smooth; flowing sweetly or smoothly; as, a mellifluous voice.
Maritime provinces: The Canadian provinces of New Brunswick and Nova Scotia and Prince Edward Island.
Myeloid: Resembling marrow in appearance or consistency; as, a myeloid tumor.
Menticirrhus: A genus of kingfishes, including the whiting.
Mendicancy: The condition of being mendicant; beggary; begging.
Malaysia: A country in Southeast Asia including the former nation of Malaya on the Malay Peninsula, and part of Borneo; sometimes still referred to as Malaya.
Minionette: A size of type between nonpareil and minion; -- used in ornamental borders, etc.
Moraine: An accumulation of earth and stones carried forward and deposited by a glacier.
Mesquite: Aany of several small spiny trees or shrubs of the southwestern part of North America belonging to the genus Prosopis having small flowers in axillary cylindrical spikes followed by large sugar-rich pods, especially the honey mesquite, and screw-pod mesquite.
Maldon: A battle in which the Danes defeated the East Saxons in 991; it is celebrated in an old English poem.
mummify: To turn into a mummy-like corpse; to dry up with unusually little decomposition; -- said of dead animals; as, A mummified body was found in the attic.
morphogenetic: Of or pertaining to morphogenesis; concerned with the process of development of the normal features of an organism.
Midwest: The north central region of the U. S.
&Verbar;Meandrina: A genus of corals with meandering grooves and ridges, including the brain corals.
&Verbar;mentum: The front median plate of the labium in insects. See Labium.
micrometeoritic: of or relating to a micrometeorite.
Mesothorium: a radioactive isotope of radium (radium-228) with a half-life of 5.8 years.  Also called mesothorium-1 or mesothorium I to distinguish it from a subsequent decay product, mesothorium II (actinium-228).  It was discovered in 1907 by Otto Hahn as a decay product of thorium (produced by decay of thorium-232).  Mesothorium-1 (radium-228) in turn produces actinium-228 (mesothorium-2) as the first product of its radioactive decay, and the actinium-228 in turn decays quickly (half-life of 6 hours) to thorium-228 (which is also called radiothorium; the thorium-228 has a half-life of 1.91 years, shorter than that of the radium-228).  It was discovered and named before full recognition of the nature of isotopes of the elements, and was distinguished from other variants of radium by its half-life and mode of production and decay.  It was also cheaper to prepare than other short-lived radium isotopes, and was thus sold commercially, for use, e.g. in making watch dials readable in the dark by painting the hands and hour marks with a self-luminous paint containing the radioactive substance; it is therefore often referred to (e.g. in regulatory legislation) as though distinct from radium.  It was one of the isotopes believed responsible for radiation-induced diseases observed in industrial workers who painted radium on watch dials in the late 1950's and early 1960's.  The primary isotope of radium (radium-226) has a half-life of 1620 years, and these isotopes with shorter half-lives proved difficult to isolate and study for the purpose of finding the cause of such diseases.
Milepost: A post, or one of a series of posts, set up to indicate spaces of a mile each or the distance in miles from a given place.
Multiplier: One who, or that which, multiplies or increases number.
Man-of-war: A government vessel employed for the purposes of war, esp. one of large size; a ship of war.
muttonhead: A stupid or foolish person; a dolt; a numbskull; a blockhead; -- disparaging and offensive.  These words are used to express a low opinion of someone's intelligence.
Morality: The relation of conformity or nonconformity to the moral standard or rule; quality of an intention, a character, an action, a principle, or a sentiment, when tried by the standard of right.
Manannan: The Irish god of the sea; son of Ler.
Massy: Compacted into, or consisting of, a mass; having bulk and weight or substance; ponderous; bulky and heavy; weighty; heavy; as, a massy shield; a massy rock.
Meteorology: The science which treats of the atmosphere and its phenomena, particularly of its variations of heat and moisture, of its winds, storms, etc.
Metaplast: A word having more than one form of the root.
Metaplasm: A change in the letters or syllables of a word.
Miscall: To call by a wrong name; to name improperly.
Medrick: A species of gull or tern.
Mercer: Originally, a dealer in any kind of goods or wares; now restricted to a dealer in textile fabrics, as silks or woolens.
misanthrope: A hater of mankind; a misanthropist.
mediocre: Of a middle quality; of but a moderate or low degree of excellence; indifferent; ordinary.
Moule: To contract mold; to grow moldy; to mold.
Magneto-: A prefix meaning pertaining to, produced by, or in some way connected with, magnetism.
media: The latinic plural form of medium, sometimes used as a singular noun with the same meaning as medium; as, (Computers) place your installation media into the device which will read it; (Microbiology) the tuberculosis bacterium will only grow in a special media.
Mellifluence: A flow of sweetness, or a sweet, smooth flow.
Mediant: The third above the keynote; -- so called because it divides the interval between the tonic and dominant into two thirds.
man-of-the-earth: A long-rooted morning glory (Ipomoea leptophylla) of Western U. S.
Myrrhic: Of, pertaining to, or obtained from, myrrh.
Mounty: The rise of a hawk after prey.
Mammoth: Resembling the mammoth in size; very large; gigantic; as, a mammoth ox.
mantichora: A mythical monster having the head of man (with horns) and the body of a lion and the tail of a scorpion.
Militate: To make war; to fight; to contend; -- usually followed by against and with.
Maya: the Indian people occupying the area of Veracruz, Chiapas, Tabasco, Campeche, and Yucatan, together with a part of Guatemala and a part of Salvador.  The Maya peoples are dark, short, and brachycephalic, and at the time of the discovery had attained a higher grade of culture than any other American people.  They cultivated a variety of crops, were expert in the manufacture and dyeing of cotton fabrics, used cacao as a medium of exchange, and were workers of gold, silver, and copper.  Their architecture comprised elaborately carved temples and palaces, and they possessed a superior calendar, and a developed system of hieroglyphic writing, with records said to go back to about 700 a. d.
Microcyte: One of the elementary granules found in blood.  They are much smaller than an ordinary corpuscle, and are particularly noticeable in disease, as in anæmia.
Mucedin: A yellowish white, amorphous, nitrogenous substance found in wheat, rye, etc., and resembling gluten; -- formerly called also mucin.
Morintannic: Pertaining to, or designating, a variety of tannic acid extracted from fustic (Chlorophora tinctoria,  formerly Maclura tinctoria and Morus tinctoria) as a yellow crystalline substance; -- called also maclurin.
muck: To excavate and remove muck{5}.  Often used with out, as, to muck out a round.
maternity: Of or pertaining to childbirth or the period during which a woman is pregnant; as, maternity care; a maternity hospital.
&Verbar;Macrosporangium: A sporangium or conceptacle containing only large spores; -- opposed to microsporangium.  Both are found in the genera Selaginella, Isoctes, and Marsilia, plants remotely allied to ferns.
Might: Force or power of any kind, whether of body or mind; energy or intensity of purpose, feeling, or action; means or resources to effect an object; strength; force; power; ability; capacity.
Mancipate: To enslave; to bind; to restrict.
mirrored: Reflected in or as if in a mirror.
Mellowness: Quality or state of being mellow.
Margosa: A large tree of the genus Melia (Melia Azadirachta) found in India.  Its bark is bitter, and used as a tonic.  A valuable oil is expressed from its seeds, and a tenacious gum exudes from its trunk.  The Melia Azedarach is a much more showy tree, and is cultivated in the Southern United States, where it is known as Pride of India, Pride of China, or bead tree.  Various parts of the tree are considered anthelmintic.
Mesotrochal: Having the middle of the body surrounded by bands of cilia; -- said of the larvæ of certain marine annelids.
Mohammedan year: The year used by Mohammedans, consisting of twelve lunar months without intercalation, so that they retrograde through all the seasons in about 321/2 years.  The Mohammedan era begins with the year 622 a. d., the first day of the Mohammedan year 1332 being Nov. 30, 1913, acording to the Gregorian calendar.
Moabite: One of the posterity of Moab, the son of Lot. (Gen. xix. 37.)  Also used adjectively.
Monochronic: Existing at the same time; contemporaneous.
Metapode: The posterior division of the foot in the Gastropoda and Pteropoda.
Melic: Of or pertaining to song; lyric; tuneful.
Machinator: One who machinates, or forms a scheme with evil designs; a plotter or artful schemer.
Mystagogic: Of or pertaining to interpretation of mysteries or to mystagogue; of the nature of mystagogy.
Magnetograph: An automatic instrument for registering, by photography or otherwise, the states and variations of any of the terrestrial magnetic elements.
Message stick: A stick, carved with lines and dots, used, esp. by Australian aborigines, to convey information.
Mare: Sighing, suffocative panting, intercepted utterance, with a sense of pressure across the chest, occurring during sleep; the incubus; -- obsolete, except in the compound nightmare.
Marc: A weight of various commodities, esp. of gold and silver, used in different European countries. In France and Holland it was equal to eight ounces.
Marl: To overspread or manure with marl; as, to marl a field.
Mark: To take particular notice; to observe critically; to note; to remark.
Mechanurgy: That branch of science which treats of moving machines.
Mars: The god of war and husbandry.
Minimal: Of, pertaining to, or having a character of, a minim or minimum; least; smallest; as, a minimal amount or value.
Martyrly: In the manner of a martyr.
Marattiales: An order of lower ferns coextensive with the family Marattiaceae.
Musculature: The muscular system of an animal, or of any of its parts; musculation.
mango tree: An East Indian tree of the genus Mangifera (Mangifera Indica), related to the cashew and the sumac.  It grows to a large size, and produces a large oval smooth-skinned fruit which is the mango of commerce.  It is now cultivated in tropical America.
Milesian: A native or inhabitant of Miletus.
Microspore: One of the exceedingly minute spores found in certain flowerless plants, as Selaginella and Isoetes, which bear two kinds of spores, one very much smaller than the other.  Cf. Macrospore.
Mahwa tree: An East Indian sapotaceous tree (Bassia latifolia, and also Bassia butyracea), whose timber is used for wagon wheels, and the flowers for food and in preparing an intoxicating drink. It is one of the butter trees. The oil, known as mahwa and yallah, is obtained from the kernels of the fruit.
mandrake: A low plant (Mandragora officinarum) of the Nightshade family, having a fleshy root, often forked, and supposed to resemble a man.  It was therefore supposed to have animal life, and to cry out when pulled up.  All parts of the plant are strongly narcotic.  It is found in the Mediterranean region.
Modifier: One who, or that which, modifies.
Mathematical: Of or pertaining to mathematics; according to mathematics; hence, theoretically precise; accurate; as, mathematical geography; mathematical instruments; mathematical exactness.
muck pile: The broken material at the face of a tunnel being bored, after being crushed by blasting.
Monobasic: Capable of being neutralized by a univalent base or basic radical; having but one acid hydrogen atom to be replaced; -- said of acids; as, acetic, nitric, and hydrochloric acids are monobasic.
mallee hen: The adult female of the mallee fowl (Leipoa ocellata).  See Leipoa.
&Verbar;Modus operandi: manner of operating. Often abbreviated to MO
Mesopodial: Of or pertaining to the mesopodialia or to the parts of the limbs to which they belong.
Meeting: A coming together; an assembling; as, the meeting of Congress.
Majorana: A small genus of herbs usually included in the genus Origanum.
Moroxylic: Of, pertaining to, or derived from, the mulberry; moric.
Masher: One who, or that which, mashes; also (Brewing), a machine for making mash.
Miscreance: The quality of being miscreant; adherence to a false religion; false faith.
manipulative: Any object given to children to encourage them to learn by manipulating physical objects; applied especially to solid objects of varying geometrical shape that can be fit together to form larger aggregates.
Malting: The process of making, or of becoming malt.
machinelike: behaving in an unthinking manner, like the functioning of a machine; as, machine-like fools.
Mansionry: The state of dwelling or residing; occupancy as a dwelling place.
Misplacement: The act of misplacing, or the state of being misplaced.
Momos: The god of blame and mockery; Momus.
Mutic: Without a point or pointed process; blunt.
Mal-: A prefix in composition denoting ill, or evil, F. male, adv., fr. malus, bad, ill.  In some words it has the form male-, as in malediction, malevolent. See Malice.
Mover: A person or thing that moves, stirs, or changes place.
moneyman: a person skilled in large scale financial transactions.
machine gunner: A soldier who operates a machine gun.
maned sheep: A type of wild sheep (Ammotragus lervia) of northern Africa; called also Barbary sheep and aoudad.
Monkeys puzzle: A lofty coniferous Chilian tree (Araucaria araucana, formerly Araucaria imbricata), the branches of which are so crowded and intertwisted “as to puzzle a monkey to climb.”  It is also called monkey puzzle and monkey puzzle tree.  The edible nuts are over an inch long, and are called piñon by the Chilians.
Mangabey: Any one of several African monkeys of the genus Cercocebus, as the sooty mangabey (Cercocebus fuliginosus), which is sooty black.
Malcolmia: A genus of plants usually found in coastal habitats; native from the Mediterranean to Afghanistan.
Metempsychose: To translate or transfer, as the soul, from one body to another.
Midass ear: A pulmonate mollusk (Auricula aurismidæ or Ellobium aurismidæ); -- so called from resemblance to a human ear.
Milanese: Of or pertaining to Milan in Italy, or to its inhabitants.
Malleability: The quality or state of being malleable; -- opposed to friability and brittleness.
mealybug: Any of several homopteran scale insects (as, Coccus adonidum, and related species of the families Pseudococcidae and Eriococcidae), that cover themselves with a white powderlike or cottony wax secretion.  They are common plant-eating pests in hothouses and are also destructive of fruit trees.
Molestation: The act of molesting, or the state of being molested; disturbance; annoyance.
Murine: One of a tribe of rodents, of which the mouse is the type.
Manway: A small passageway, as in a mine, that a man may pass through.
Murder: To kill with premediated malice; to kill (a human being) willfully, deliberately, and unlawfully. See Murder, n.
Mexican: Of or pertaining to Mexico or its people.
Modern: A person of modern times; -- opposed to ancient.
Matweed: A name of several maritime grasses, as the sea sand-reed (Ammophila arundinacea) which is used in Holland to bind the sand of the seacoast dikes (see Beach grass, under Beach); also, the Lygeum Spartum, a Mediterranean grass of similar habit.
&Verbar;Mach\u00e6rodus: A genus of extinct mammals allied to the cats, and having in the upper jaw canine teeth of remarkable size and strength; -- hence called saber-toothed tigers.
&Verbar;Mollities: Unnatural softness of any organ or part.
Medusoid: Like a medusa; having the fundamental structure of a medusa, but without a locomotive disk; -- said of the sessile gonophores of hydroids.
Metalammonium: A hypothetical radical derived from ammonium by the substitution of metallic atoms in place of hydrogen.
Monstrance: A transparent pyx, in which the consecrated host is exposed to view.
Moses: A large flatboat, used in the West Indies for taking freight from shore to ship.
Maneuver: To change the positions of, as of troops of ships.
Metamerism: The symmetry of a metameric structure; serial symmetry; the state of being made up of metameres.
Masterwort: A tall and coarse European umbelliferous plant (Peucedanum Ostruthium, formerly Imperatoria).
Molasses: The thick, brown or dark colored, viscid, uncrystallizable sirup which drains from sugar, in the process of manufacture; any thick, viscid, sweet sirup made from vegetable juice or sap, as of the sorghum or maple. See Treacle.
mid-nineties: the time of life between 90 and 100.
Meaking: The process of picking out the oakum from the seams of a vessel which is to be recalked.
mail car: A  railway car of special design used for the transportation and sorting of mail en route to its destination, and having employees of the post office inside to perform those functions.
Maxillo-mandibular: Pertaining to the maxilla and mandible; as, the maxillo-mandibular nerve.
Mindful: Bearing in mind; regardful; attentive; heedful; observant.
Midnight: Being in, or characteristic of, the middle of the night; as, midnight studies; midnight gloom.
Martes: The genus of mammals including the martens.
Meniscal: Pertaining to, or having the form of, a meniscus.
Martialize: To render warlike; as, to martialize a people.
Magnetizer: One who, or that which, imparts magnetism.
Magnetizee: A person subjected to the influence of animal magnetism.
Myriorama: A picture made up of several smaller pictures, drawn upon separate pieces in such a manner as to admit of combination in many different ways, thus producing a great variety of scenes or landscapes.
&Verbar;Maltha: A variety of bitumen, viscid and tenacious, like pitch, unctuous to the touch, and exhaling a bituminous odor.
Mastership: The state or office of a master.
March-mad: Extremely rash; foolhardy. See under March, the month.
Manicure: To care for (the hands and nails); to care for the hands and nails of; to do manicure work.
Musang: A small animal of Java (Paradoxirus fasciatus), allied to the civets. It swallows, but does not digest, large quantities of ripe coffee berries, thus serving to disseminate the coffee plant; hence it is called also coffee rat.
Maltese dog: A breed of toy dog having a long straight silky white coat; also called a Maltese.
Membranology: The science which treats of membranes.
Mangle: To smooth with a mangle, as damp linen or cloth.
Melaphyre: Any one of several dark-colored augitic, eruptive rocks allied to basalt.
Meconin: A substance regarded as an anhydride of meconinic acid, existing in opium and extracted as a white crystalline substance.  Also erroneously called meconina, meconia, etc., as though it were an alkaloid.
Medico-legal: Of or pertaining to law as affected by medical facts.
Meconic: Pertaining to, or obtained from, the poppy or opium; specif. (Chem.), designating an acid related to aconitic acid, found in opium and extracted as a white crystalline substance.
&Verbar;Moineau: A small flat bastion, raised in the middle of an overlong curtain.
Malthusianism: The system of Malthusian doctrines relating to population.  See Malthusian.
Misrepute: To have in wrong estimation; to repute or estimate erroneously.
Memorability: The quality or state of being memorable.
midsummer-men: A Eurasian mountain plant (Sedum rosea) with fleshy pink-tipped leaves and a cluster of yellow flowers.
Multipotent: Having manifold power, or power to do many things.
Mythic: Of or relating to myths; described in a myth; of the nature of a myth; fabulous; imaginary; fanciful; mythological.
Manchu: Of or pertaining to Manchuria or its inhabitants.
Multisiliquous: Having many pods or seed vessels.
Melinae: A subdivision of mammals not used in some classifications; it includes the badgers.
Manganite: One of the oxides of manganese; -- called also gray manganese ore.  It occurs in brilliant steel-gray or iron-black crystals, also massive.
Modocs: A tribe of warlike Indians formerly inhabiting Northern California. They are nearly extinct.
Monocular: Having only one eye; with one eye only; as, monocular vision.
Matie: A fat herring with undeveloped roe.
Martian: An inhabitant of the planet Mars; -- fictional or hypothetical.
Myxomycota: The slime molds; organisms having a noncellular and multinucleate creeping vegetative phase and a propagative spore-producing stage: comprises Myxomycetes and Acrasiomycetes and Plasmodiophoromycetes; in some classifications placed in the kingdom Protoctista.
&Verbar;Micella: A theoretical aggregation of molecules constituting a structural particle of protoplasm, capable of increase or diminution without change in chemical nature.
Meditation: The act of meditating; close or continued thought; the turning or revolving of a subject in the mind; serious contemplation; reflection; musing.
macadamia nut: The hard-shelled nut of the Macadamia ternifolia, or the delicious edible nut without its shell; large quantities are produced in Hawaii and sold commercially.
Magnetotherapy: The treatment of disease by the application of magnets to the surface of the body.
Mechitarist: One of a religious congregation of the Roman Catholic Church devoted to the improvement of Armenians.
Monoxylous: Made of one piece of wood.
magenta: An aniline dye obtained as an amorphous substance having a green bronze surface color, which dissolves to a shade of red; also, the color; -- so called from Magenta, in Italy, in allusion to the battle fought there about the time the dye was discovered. Called also fuchsin, fuchsine, roseïne, etc.
Merismatic: Dividing into cells or segments; characterized by separation into two or more parts or sections by the formation of internal partitions; as, merismatic growth, where one cell divides into many.
Medal play: Play in which the score is reckoned by counting the number of strokes.
Multiplicity: The quality of being multiple, manifold, or various; a state of being many; a multitude; as, a multiplicity of thoughts or objects.
malnourished: Not getting adequate food; suffering from malnutrition; underfed.
morphing: The smooth transformation of one shape or image into another, displayed on the computer screen as a series of images that appear to be continuous, as if in a movie.
Mistook: imp. & obs. p. p. of Mistake.
Micronesian: Of or pertaining to Micronesia, a collective designation of the islands in the western part of the Pacific Ocean, embracing the Marshall and Gilbert groups, the Ladrones, the Carolines, etc.
Muriatic: Of, pertaining to, or obtained from, sea salt, or from chlorine, one of the constituents of sea salt; hydrochloric.
Maleficent: Doing evil to others; harmful; mischievous.
Myrtle: A species of the genus Myrtus, especially Myrtus communis. The common myrtle has a shrubby, upright stem, eight or ten feet high. Its branches form a close, full head, thickly covered with ovate or lanceolate evergreen leaves.  It has solitary axillary white or rosy flowers, followed by black several-seeded berries.  The ancients considered it sacred to Venus.  The flowers, leaves, and berries are used variously in perfumery and as a condiment, and the beautifully mottled wood is used in turning.
&Verbar;Maasha: An East Indian coin, of about one tenth of the weight of a rupee.
mainland China: The People's Republic of China, also called Communist China, in distinction from Nationalist China, the government located on the island of Taiwan.  Both governments claim to represent the entire people of China, but the People's republic is recognized as China by the United Nationss and most of its member states.
Mull: To heat, sweeten, and enrich with spices; as, to mull wine.
Mule: A hybrid animal; specifically, one generated between an ass and a mare.  Sometimes the term is applied to the offspring of a horse and a she-ass, but that hybrid is more properly termed a hinny.  See Hinny.
mix up: To confuse the identities of (two or more objects); to mistake (one object for another); as, at the family gathering he mixed up his two nieces, to their great amusement.
Mishmash: A hodgepodge or hotchpotch; a confused jumble.
Moody: Subject to varying moods, especially to states of mind which are unamiable or depressed.
misalignment: The act of aligning improperly or state of being improperly aligned.
&Verbar;Mahoohoo: The African white two-horned rhinoceros (Atelodus simus).
motivated: Having a strong motive; -- of people.  Opposite of unmotivated.
Meccawee: Of or pertaining to Mecca, in Arabia.
magnetic field: The space around a magnet through which it exerts magnetic force; a field of force surrounding a permanent magnet, electrical current, or a moving charged particle; called also magnetic flux and field of magnetic force.
Masthouse: A building in which vessels' masts are shaped, fitted, etc.
Mares-tail: A long streaky cloud, spreading out like a horse's tail, and believed to indicate rain; a cirrus cloud. See Cloud.
Myropolist: One who sells unguents or perfumery.
Mutessarifat: In Turkey, a sanjak whose head is a mutessarif.
&Verbar;Morula: The sphere or globular mass of cells (blastomeres), formed by the clevage of the ovum or egg in the first stages of its development; -- called also mulberry mass, segmentation sphere, and blastosphere. See Segmentation.
Meatoscope: A speculum for examining a natural passage, as the urethra.
Manipulate: To use the hands in dexterous operations; to do hand work;
Manipulator: One who manipulates, sometimes in an underhanded or fraudulent manner; as, a stock market manipulator.
Middle-age: Of or pertaining to the Middle Ages; mediæval.
&Verbar;Musquaw: The American black bear. See Bear.
Mendels law: A principle governing the inheritance of many characters in animals and plants, discovered by Gregor J. Mendel (Austrian Augustinian abbot, 1822-84) in breeding experiments with peas.  He showed that the height, color, and other characters depend on the presence of determinating factors behaving as units.  In any given germ cell each of these is either present or absent.
Markov process: a random process in which the probabilities of states in a series depend only on the properties of the immediately preceding state or the next preceeding state, independent of the path by which the preceding state was reached.  It is distinguished from a Markov chain in that the states of a Markov process may be continuous as well as discrete.
Misween: To ween amiss; to misjudge; to distrust; to be mistaken.
Masticin: A white, amorphous, tenacious substance resembling caoutchouc, and obtained as an insoluble residue of mastic.
Misconstruable: Such as can be misconstrued, as language or conduct.
&Verbar;Meatus: A natural passage or canal; as, the external auditory meatus. See Illust. of Ear.
Matrimony: The union of man and woman as husband and wife; the nuptial state; marriage; wedlock.
Majolica: A kind of pottery, with opaque glazing and showy decoration, which reached its greatest perfection in Italy in the 16th century.
Makeweight: That which is thrown into a scale to make weight; something of little account added to supply a deficiency or fill a gap.
Macrozo\u00f6spore: A large motile spore having four vibratile cilia; -- found in certain green algæ.
Malacostomous: Having soft jaws without teeth, as certain fishes.
maiden over: An over in which no runs are scored.
Muddily: In a muddy manner; turbidly; without mixture; cloudily; obscurely; confusedly.
&Verbar;Monadelphia: A Linnæan class of plants having the stamens united into a tube, or ring, by the filaments, as in the Mallow family.
Methylene: A divalent hydrocarbon radical, -CH2-, not known in the free state, but regarded as an essential residue and component of certain derivatives of methane; as, methylene bromide, CH2Br2; -- formerly called also methene.
major term: That term of a syllogism which forms the predicate of the conclusion.
&Verbar;Meum: Lit., mine; that which is mine; -- used in the phrase meum et tuum, or meum and tuum; as, to confound meum and tuum, to fail to distinguish one's own property from that of others; to be dishonest.
&Verbar;Morn\u00e9: Without teeth, tongue, or claws; -- said of a lion represented heraldically.
maniglion: Either one of two handles on the back of a piece of ordnance.
Monticle: A little mount; a hillock; a small elevation or prominence.
&Verbar;Muschelkalk: A kind of shell limestone, whose strata form the middle one of the three divisions of the Triassic formation in Germany. See Chart, under Geology.
Margaric: Pertaining to, or resembling, pearl; pearly.
Marquee: A large field tent; esp., one adapted to the use of an officer of high rank.
Molotov: a city in the European part of Soviet Russia.
Margarin: A fatty substance, extracted from animal fats and certain vegetable oils, formerly supposed to be a definite compound of glycerin and margaric acid, but now known to be simply a mixture or combination of tristearin and tripalmitin.
marasmus: A wasting of flesh without fever or apparent disease; a kind of consumption; atrophy; phthisis.
Mutchkin: A liquid measure equal to four gills, or an imperial pint.
Mesencephalic: Of or pertaining to the mesencephalon or midbrain.
Marconism: The theory or practice of Marconi's wireless telegraph system.
Manifesto: A public declaration, usually of a prince, sovereign, or other person claiming large powers, showing his intentions, or proclaiming his opinions and motives in reference to some act done or contemplated by him; as, a manifesto declaring the purpose of a prince to begin war, and explaining his motives.
Malaria parasite: Any of several minute protozoans of the genus Plasmodium (syn. Hæmatozoön) which in their adult condition live in the tissues of mosquitoes of the genus Anopheles (which see) and when transferred to the blood of man, by the bite of the mosquito, produce malaria.
Mung: Green gram, a kind of legume (pulse) (Vigna radiata syn. Phaseolus aureus, syn. Phaseolus Mungo), grown for food in British India; called also gram, mung bean, Chinese mung bean, and green-seeded mung bean.  It is an erect, bushy annual producing edible green or yellow seeds, and edible pods and young sprouts.
&Verbar;Morne: A ring fitted upon the head of a lance to prevent wounding an adversary in tilting.
&Verbar;Mezza voce: With a medium fullness of sound.
&Verbar;Mollusca: One of the grand divisions of the animal kingdom, a phylum including the classes Cephalopoda, Gastropoda, Pteropoda, Scaphopoda, and Pelecyopoda (syn. Bivalvia, formerly called Lamellibranchiata, or Conchifera).  These animals have an unsegmented bilateral body, with most of the organs and parts paired, but not repeated longitudinally.  Most of them develop a mantle, which incloses either a branchial or a pulmonary cavity.  They are generally more or less covered and protected by a calcareous shell, which may be univalve, bivalve, or multivalve.
Meatotome: An instrument for cutting into the urethra so as to enlarge its orifice.
Multitude: A great number of persons collected together; a numerous collection of persons; a crowd; an assembly.
mellowing: The act or process of acquiring desirable qualities by being left undisturbed for some time.
Metaleptic: Of or pertaining to a metalepsis.
Malamide: The acid amide derived from malic acid, as a white crystalline substance metameric with asparagine.
made-to-order: made specially for a specific purpose; -- of articles of manufacture.  Contrasted with mass-produced, standard.
Myself: I or me in person; -- used for emphasis, my own self or person; as I myself will do it; I have done it myself; -- used also instead of me, as the object of the first person of a reflexive verb, without emphasis; as, I will defend myself.
Marmatite: A ferruginous variety of shalerite or zinc blende, nearly black in color.
Magnet: The loadstone; a species of iron ore (the ferrosoferric or magnetic ore, Fe3O4) which has the property of attracting iron and some of its ores, and, when freely suspended, of pointing to the poles; -- called also natural magnet.
maiden aunt: Literally, an aunt who has never been married.  Figuratively, it is a term used as the prototype of a person who is broadly naive and not wise in worldly ways; as, he knows as much about programming as my maiden aunt.
Mugginess: The condition or quality of being muggy.
male body: The body of an adult human male; -- a term used especially in art; as, Da Vinci was unexcelled in painting the male body.
mockernut: A smooth-barked North American hickory (Carya tomentosa) with 7 to 9 leaflets bearing a hard-shelled edible nut, which is far inferior to the true shagbark hickory nut.
Monosaccharide: A simple sugar; any of a number of sugars (including the trioses, tetroses, pentoses, hexoses, etc.), not decomposable into simpler sugars by hydrolysis. Specif., as used by some, a hexose.  The monosaccharides are all open-chain compounds containing hydroxyl groups and either an aldehyde group or a ketone group.
Megadyne: One of the larger measures of force, amounting to one million dynes.
Marvelously: In a marvelous manner; wonderfully; strangely.
Macrospore: One of the specially large spores of certain flowerless plants, as Selaginella, etc.
Machinate: To contrive, as a plot; to plot; as, to machinate evil.
maiden pink: A low-growing loosely mat-forming Eurasian pink (Dianthus deltoides) with single crimson-eyed pale pink flowers.
Moorball: A fresh-water alga (Cladophora Ægagropila) which forms a globular mass.
mainsheet: One of the ropes by which the mainsail is hauled aft and trimmed.
Malacostracology: That branch of zoölogical science which relates to the crustaceans; -- called also carcinology.
Mimotannic: Pertaining to, or designating, a variety of tannin or tannic acid found in Acacia, Mimosa, etc.
Mention: To make mention of; to speak briefly of; to name.
Malleate: To hammer; to beat into a plate or leaf.
Mandate: An official or authoritative command, order, or authorization from a superior official to a subordinate; an order or injunction; a commission; a judicial precept.
&Verbar;Morro: A round hill or point of land; hence, Morro castle, a castle on a hill.
Monetize: To convert into money; to adopt as current money; as, to monetize silver.
Muskogees: A powerful tribe of North American Indians that formerly occupied the region of Georgia, Florida, and Alabama.  They constituted a large part of the Creek confederacy.
monogram: To inscribe or ornament with a monogram.
Mottoed: Bearing or having a motto; as, a mottoed coat or device.
Maybird: The whimbrel; -- called also May fowl, May curlew, and May whaap.
Monazite: A mineral occurring usually in small isolated crystals, -- a phosphate of the cerium metals.
Microcephalic: Having a small head; having the cranial cavity small; -- opposed to megacephalic.
Monopathy: Suffering or sensibility in a single organ or function.
Marlitic: Partaking of the qualites of marlite.
Mantelletta: A silk or woolen vestment without sleeves worn by cardinals, bishops, abbots, and the prelates of the Roman court. It has a low collar, is fastened in front, and reaches almost to the knees.
Malvaviscus: A small genus of shrubs of Central and South America: wax mallows.
Mon\u0153cious: Having the sexes united in one individual, as when male and female flowers grow upon the same individual plant; hermaphrodite; -- opposed to diœcious.
&Verbar;Melluco: A climbing plant (Ullucus officinalis) of the Andes, having tuberous roots which are used as a substitute for potatoes.
main course: The principal part of a meal.
memorizer: A person who learns by rote.
Metathoracic: Of or pertaining to the metathorax.
macrencephaly: The condition of having an abnormally large braincase.
Mosaism: Attachment to the system or doctrines of Moses; that which is peculiar to the Mosaic system or doctrines.
Melancholy: Depressed in spirits; dejected; gloomy dismal.
Minutary: Pertaining to, or consisting of, minutes.
Most: In the greatest or highest degree.
mentation: the process of thinking (especially thinking carefully); mental activity.
Moss: To cover or overgrow with moss.
modal logic: A system of logic which studies how to combine propositions which include the concepts of necessity, possibility, and obligation.
Marsileaceae: A natural family of clover ferns.
Metronome: An instrument consisting of a short pendulum with a sliding weight.  It is set in motion by clockwork, and serves to measure time in music.
Methodistic: Of or pertaining to methodists, or to the Methodists.
Metronomy: Measurement of time by an instrument.
Micrology: That part of science which treats of microscopic objects, or depends on microscopic observation.
Metely: According to measure or proportion; proportionable; proportionate.
Manliness: The quality or state of being manly.
&Verbar;Monocondyla: A group of vertebrates, including the birds and reptiles, or those that have only one occipital condyle; the Sauropsida.
mainframe: A large digital computer serving 100-400 users and occupying a special air-conditioned room.  At any given point in development of computer technology, the mainframe will be faster, have large main memeory, and be more capable than a minicomputer, which will in turn be faster and more capable than a personal computer.  The typical personal computer in 1999 is faster than a mainframe was in 1970.
Mongolian: Of or pertaining to Mongolia or the Mongols.
Mytacism: Too frequent use of the letter m, or of the sound represented by it.
Mannitic: Of, pertaining to, resembling, or derived from, mannitol.
Moile: A kind of high shoe anciently worn.
Macrame: the art of tying knots in patterns.
meadowlark: Any species of Sturnella, a genus of North American songbirds allied to the starlings.  The common species (Sturnella magna) has a yellow breast with a black crescent.
monomeric: Not linked to other molecules of the same kind; having the property of a monomer.  Opposed to polymeric.
makeshift: That with which one makes shift; a temporary expedient, with implication of inferiority to the more usual object or means.
Malamic: Of or designating an acid intermediate between malic acid and malamide, and known only by its salts.
Mantelet: A short cloak formerly worn by knights.
Mezuza: A piece of parchment bearing the Decalogue and attached to the doorpost; -- in use among orthodox Hebrews.  The term is also used to refer to the small case containing this scroll, together with the biblical inscription inside.  The text is usually taken from Deuteronomy 6:4-9 and 11:13-21.
Melezitose: A variety of sugar, isomeric with sucrose, extracted from the manna of the larch (Larix).
Mnemonic: Assisting in memory; helping to remember; as, a mnemonic device.
Morsing horn: A horn or flask for holding powder, as for priming.
Marmoration: A covering or incrusting with marble; a casing of marble; a variegating so as to resemble marble.
&Verbar;Mezza majolica: Italian pottery of the epoch and general character of majolica, but less brilliantly decorated, esp. such pottery without tin enamel, but painted and glazed.
Millefiore glass: Slender rods or tubes of colored glass fused together and embedded in clear glass; -- used for paperweights and other small articles.
marsh marigold: A perennial plant of the genus Caltha (Caltha palustris), growing in wet places and bearing bright yellow flowers.  In the United States it is used as a pot herb under the name of cowslip. See Cowslip.
Mutage: A process for checking the fermentation of the must of grapes.
&Verbar;Mesomycetes: One of the three classes into which the fungi are divided in Brefeld's classification.
&Verbar;Menses: The catamenial or menstrual discharge, a periodic flow of blood or bloody fluid from the uterus or female generative organs.
Mataco: The three-banded armadillo (Tolypeutis tricinctus). See Illust. under Loricata.
Misbegot: Unlawfully or irregularly begotten; of bad or disreputable origin; pernicious.
meritocracy: A form of social system in which power goes to those with superior intellects.
Meritot: A play of children, in swinging on ropes, or the like, till they are dizzy.
motivating: causing motion or impelling to action; providing a motive{2}; as, motivating arguments.
Mooter: A disputer of a mooted case.
male chauvinism: Disparaging, patronizing, discriminatory or abusive speech or behavior by males toward females stemming from a belief that males are superior to females and females therefore worthy of less respect and inferior treatment.  A form of sexism.
Melilot: Any species of Melilotus, a genus of leguminous herbs having a vanillalike odor; sweet clover; hart's clover. The blue melilot (Melilotus cærulea) is used in Switzerland to give color and flavor to sapsago cheese.
Magnoliopsida: A class of seed plants that produce an embryo with two cotyledons and net-veined leaves; divided into six (not always well distinguished) subclasses (or superorders): Magnoliidae and Hamamelidae (considered primitive); Caryophyllidae (an early and distinctive offshoot); and three more or less advanced groups: Dilleniidae; Rosidae; Asteridae.
Momier: A name given in contempt to strict Calvinists in Switzerland, France, and some parts of Germany, in the early part of the 19th century.
maltreatment: Cruel or inhumane treatment; ill usage; abuse.
Melodramatist: One who acts in, or writes, melodramas.
Miliary: One of the small tubercles of Echini.
Momentum: The quantity of motion in a moving body, being always proportioned to the quantity of matter multiplied by the velocity; impetus.
Melter: One who, or that which, melts.
Multicentral: Having many, or several, centers; as, a multicentral cell.
manna lichen: Any of several Old World semicrustaceous or shrubby lecanoras that roll up and are blown about over African and Arabian deserts and used as food by people and animals; same as manna{2}.
Mutuation: The act of borrowing or exchanging.
Matelote: A stew, commonly of fish, flavored with wine, and served with a wine sauce containing onions, mushrooms, etc.
&Verbar;Mescal: A distilled liquor prepared in Mexico from a species of agave. See Agave.
Monogenism: The theory or doctrine that the human races have a common origin, or constitute a single species.
Maypop: The edible fruit of a passion flower, especially that of the North American Passiflora incarnata, an oval yellowish berry as large as a small apple.
moleskin: Any fabric having a thick soft shag, like the fur of a mole; esp., a kind of strong twilled fustian.
Macrodactyl: One of a group of wading birds (Macrodactyli) having very long toes.
Monomania: Derangement of the mind in regard of a single subject only; also, such a concentration of interest upon one particular subject or train of ideas to show mental derangement.
Monogenist: One who maintains that the human races are all of one species; -- opposed to polygenist.
Megrim: The British smooth sole, or scaldfish (Psetta arnoglossa).
mad-dog skullcap: An American mint (Scutellaria lateriflora) that yields a resinous exudate used esp. formerly as an antispasmodic.
Microseme: Having the orbital index relatively small; having the orbits broad transversely; -- opposed to megaseme.
Microzo\u00f6spore: A small motile spore furnished with two vibratile cilia, found in certain green algæ.
mallee bird: The leipoa, or Australian moundbird; it incubates eggs naturally in sandy mounds.  See Leipoa.
Meckelian: Pertaining to, or discovered by, J. F. Meckel, a German anatomist.
Mislight: To deceive or lead astray with a false light.
Mobcap: A plain cap or headdress for women or girls; especially, one tying under the chin by a very broad band, generally of the same material as the cap itself.
Materialist: One who denies the existence of spiritual substances or agents, and maintains that spiritual phenomena, so called, are the result of some peculiar organization of matter.  A believer in philosophical materialism.
Monotessaron: A single narrative framed from the statements of the four evangelists; a gospel harmony.
Melolonthidian: A beetle of the genus Melolontha, and allied genera.  See May beetle, under May.
Moplah: One of a class of Mohammedans in Malabar.
Materialism: The doctrine of materialists; materialistic views and tenets; called also philosophical materialism.
Mannheim gold: A kind of brass made in imitation of gold.  It contains eighty per cent of copper and twenty of zinc.
&Verbar;Mesa: A high tableland; a plateau on a hill.
&Verbar;Monomya: An order of lamellibranchs having but one muscle for closing the shell, as the oyster.
maraud: To rove in quest of plunder; to make an excursion for booty; to plunder.
Mesothorax: The middle segment of the thorax in insects. See Illust. of Coleoptera.
malodorous: Offensive to the sense of smell; ill-smelling.
maffick: to celebrate publicly with boisterous rejoicing and hilarious and extravagant behavior.
Marmoreal: Pertaining to, or resembling, marble; made of marble.
&Verbar;Menaion: A work of twelve volumes, each containing the offices in the Greek Church for a month; also, each volume of the same.
&Verbar;Mesovarium: The fold of peritoneum connecting the ovary with the wall of the abdominal cavity.
Microbicide: Any agent detrimental to, or destructive of, the life of microbes or bacterial organisms.
Magnifiable: Such as can be magnified, or extolled.
Metalloid: Having the appearance of a metal.
Madrilenian: Of or pertaining to Madrid in Spain, or to its inhabitants.
Mahatma: One of a class of sages, or “adepts,” reputed to have knowledge and powers of a higher order than those of ordinary men.
manic disorder: An affective disorder in which the victim tends to respond excessively and sometimes violently.
Malaga: A city and a province of Spain, on the Mediterranean.   Hence, Malaga grapes, Malaga raisins, Malaga wines.
mallowwort: Any plant of the order Malvaceæ.
Meridian: Being at, or pertaining to, midday; belonging to, or passing through, the highest point attained by the sun in his diurnal course.
Myricyl: A hypothetical radical regarded as the essential residue of myricin; -- called also melissyl.
Mesne: Middle; intervening; as, a mesne lord, that is, a lord who holds land of a superior, but grants a part of it to another person, in which case he is a tenant to the superior, but lord or superior to the second grantee, and hence is called the mesne lord.
Ministrant: Performing service as a minister; attendant on service; acting under command; subordinate.
mallee fowl: Same as mallee bird (Leipoa ocellata).  See also Leipoa.
&Verbar;Musa: A genus of perennial, herbaceous, endogenous plants of great size, including the banana (Musa sapientum), the plantain (Musa paradisiaca of Linnæus, but probably not a distinct species), the Abyssinian (Musa Ensete), the Philippine Island (Musa textilis, which yields Manila hemp), and about eighteen other species. See Illust. of Banana and Plantain.
Monodrama: A drama acted, or intended to be acted, by a single person.
malthusian theory: Malthus' theory that population increase would outpace increases in the means of subsistence; Malthusianism.  See Malthusian.
Miocene: Of or pertaining to the middle division of the Tertiary.
Mismanage: To manage ill or improperly; as, to mismanage public affairs.
Mitis casting: A process, invented by P. Ostberg, for producing malleable iron castings by melting wrought iron, to which from 0.05 to 0.1 per cent of aluminum is added to lower the melting point, usually in a petroleum furnace, keeping the molten metal at the bubbling point until it becomes quiet, and then pouring the molten metal into a mold lined with a special mixture consisting essentially of molasses and ground burnt fire clay; also, a casting made by this process; -- called also wrought-iron casting.
marbleizing: A texture like that of marble.
morel: Nightshade; -- so called from its blackish purple berries.
Mixtilineal: Containing, or consisting of, lines of different kinds, as straight, curved, and the like; as, a mixtilinear angle, that is, an angle contained by a straight line and a curve.
Mortality: The condition or quality of being mortal; subjection to death or to the necessity of dying.
mimer: A person who performs in a mime.
&Verbar;Molluscoidea: A division of Invertebrata which includes the classes Brachiopoda and Bryozoa; -- called also Anthoid Mollusca.
&Verbar;Macauco: Any one of several species of small lemurs, as Lemur murinus, which resembles a rat in size.
Mashie: A golf club like the iron, but with a shorter head, slightly more lofted, used chiefly for short approaches.
Mesothoracic: Of or pertaining to the mesothorax.
Maxilliped: One of the mouth appendages of Crustacea, situated next behind the maxillæ.  Crabs have three pairs, but many of the lower Crustacea have but one pair of them.  Called also jawfoot, and foot jaw.
Mother-in-law: The mother of one's husband or wife.
The customary abbreviation of Mistress or Missess when used as a title of courtesy, in writing and printing; as, Mrs. Clinton is commonly called by her full name, Hillary Rodham Clinton.
mind-bending: intensely affecting the mind, especially in producing hallucinations; -- usually of chemical substances.
&Verbar;Mistura: A mingled compound in which different ingredients are contained in a liquid state; a mixture. See Mixture, n., 4.
Martyrdom: The condition of a martyr; the death of a martyr; the suffering of death on account of adherence to the Christian faith, or to any cause.
Mogul: A person of the Mongolian race.
Morphology: That branch of biology which deals with the structure of animals and plants, treating of the forms of organs and describing their varieties, homologies, and metamorphoses. See Tectology, and Promorphology.
Manbote: A sum paid to a lord as a pecuniary compensation for killing his man (that is, his vassal, servant, or tenant).
&Verbar;Metalepsis: The continuation of a trope in one word through a succession of significations, or the union of two or more tropes of a different kind in one word.
Moorland: Land consisting of a moor or moors.
Musky: Having an odor of musk, or somewhat the like.
minelayer: a ship equipped for laying underwater mines.
Mazedness: The condition of being mazed; confusion; astonishment.
Metempirics: The concepts and relations which are conceived as beyond, and yet as related to, the knowledge gained by experience.
Mandarining: The process of giving an orange color to goods formed of animal tissue, as silk or wool, not by coloring matter, but by producing a certain change in the fiber by the action of dilute nitric acid.
Monogrammic: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, a monogram.
Microcosm: A little world; a miniature universe.  Hence (so called by Paracelsus), a man, as a supposed epitome of the exterior universe or great world.  Opposed to macrocosm.
-ment: A suffix denoting that which does a thing; an act or process; the result of an act or process; state or condition; as, aliment, that which nourishes, ornament, increment; fragment, piece broken, segment; abridgment, act of abridging, imprisonment, movement, adjournment; amazement, state of being amazed, astonishment.
major suit: A suit of playing cards which has higher scoring value; specifically, either spades or hearts.  Contrasted with a minor suit, being either diamonds or clubs.
Misentry: An erroneous entry or charge, as of an account.
Mesam\u0153boid: One of a class of independent, isolated cells found in the mesoderm, while the germ layers are undergoing differentiation.
Mawkishness: The quality or state of being mawkish.
Marsala: A kind of wine exported from Marsala in Sicily.
&Verbar;Meminna: A small deerlet, or chevrotain, of India.
Megaphone: A device to magnify sound, or direct it in a given direction in a greater volume, as a very large funnel used as an ear trumpet or as a speaking trumpet.
Methysticin: A white, silky, crystalline substance extracted from the thick rootstock of a species of pepper (Piper methysticum) of the South Sea Islands; -- called also kanakin.
Microanalysis: Analysis of the structure of materials from careful observation of photomicrographs.
Membership: The state of being a member.
Methylic: Pertaining to, derived from, or containing, methyl; specifically, designating methyl alcohol. See under Methyl.
magnetron: a diode vacuum tube in which the flow of electrons from a central cathode to a cylindrical anode is controlled by crossed magnetic and electric fields; used mainly in microwave oscillators.
Manh\u00e8s process: A process by which copper matte is treated by passing through it a blast of air, to oxidize and remove sulphur. It is analogous in apparatus to the Bessemer process for decarbonizing cast iron. So called from Pierre Manhès, a French metallurgist, who invented it.
Manrope: One of the side ropes to the gangway of a ship.
matzo: A cake of unleavened bread eaten by the Jews at the feast of the Passover.
Militiaman: One who belongs to the militia.
The customary abbreviation of Mister in writing and printing. See Master, 4.
&Verbar;Mesonotum: The dorsal portion of the mesothorax of insects.
Mill-sixpence: A milled sixpence; -- the sixpence being one of the first English coins milled (1561).
Muliebrity: The state of being a woman or of possessing full womanly powers; womanhood; -- correlate of virility.
Mittlers green: A pigment of a green color, the chief constituent of which is oxide of chromium.
man of action: A person who prefers to act rather than contemplate and gets things accomplished quickly an efficiently.
Mediastinal: Of or pertaining to a mediastinum.
Mechoacan: A species of jalap, of very feeble properties, said to be obtained from the root of a species of Convolvulus (Convolvulus Mechoacan); -- so called from Michoacan, in Mexico, whence it is obtained.
Mitis metal: The malleable iron produced by mitis casting; -- called also simply mitis.
McCarthyism: Unscrupulously accusing people of disloyalty (as by saying they were Communists).
&Verbar;Myxophyta: A phylum of the vegetable kingdom consisting of the class Myxomycetes.  By some botanists it is not separated from the Thallophyta.
Messieurs: Sirs; gentlemen; -- abbreviated to Messrs., which is used as the plural of Mr.
Misbehavior: Improper, rude, or uncivil behavior; ill conduct.
Middle: The point or part equally distant from the extremities or exterior limits, as of a line, a surface, or a solid; an intervening point or part in space, time, or order of series; the midst; central portion
Metallotherapy: Treatment of disease by applying metallic plates to the surface of the body.
Margarine: A processed food product used as an inexpensive substitute for butter, made primarily from refined vegetable oils, sometimes including animal fats, and churned with skim milk to form a semisolid emulsion; also called oleomargarine; artificial butter.
Mastigophora: A phylum of protozoans the kingdom Protista, consisting mainly of free-living flagellated unicellular organisms, lacking photosynthetic capability.  Some members are pathogenic in man.
&Verbar;Minutia: A minute particular; a small or minor detail; -- used chiefly in the plural.
Macro-chemistry: The science which treats of the chemical properties, actions or relations of substances in quantity; -- distinguished from micro-chemistry.
Mezzo-soprano: Having a medium compass between the soprano and contralto; -- said of the voice of a female singer.
Mobocratic: Of, or relating to, a mobocracy.
Melanterite: A hydrous sulphate of iron of a green color and vitreous luster; iron vitriol.
Meteorite: A mass of stone or iron which has fallen to the earth from space; an aërolite.
Mesonephric: Of or pertaining to the mesonephros; as, the mesonephric, or Wolffian, duct.
Muscivora-forficata: A gray flycatcher of Southwestern U. S. and Mexico and Central America having a long forked tail and white breast and salmon and scarlet markings; the scissortailed flycatcher.
Monopolize: To acquire a monopoly of; to have or get the exclusive privilege or means of dealing in, or the exclusive possession of; to engross the whole of; as, to monopolize the coffee trade; to monopolize land.
Meuse: A European river, flowing into the North Sea.
Mews: An alley where there are stables; a narrow passage; a confined place.
Macrocheira: A genus of giant crabs of Japan.
&Verbar;Moir\u00e9 m\u00e9tallique: A crystalline or frosted appearance produced by some acids on tin plate; also, the tin plate thus treated.
moneybag: a drawstring bag for holding money.
Multiply: To become greater in number; to become numerous.
Mewl: To cry, as a young child; to squall.
Minstrel: In the Middle Ages, one of an order of men who subsisted by the arts of poetry and music, and sang verses to the accompaniment of a harp or other instrument; in modern times, a poet; a bard; a singer and harper; a musician.
Mesmeree: A person subjected to mesmeric influence; one who is mesmerized.
Meliaceous: Pertaining to a natural order (Meliacæ) of plants of which the genus Melia is the type. It includes the mahogany and the Spanish cedar.
modernistic: Conspicuously (sometimes outrageously) modern in style or appearance; as, shiny tables in modernistic design.
Monkly: Like, or suitable to, a monk.
Monosyllabism: The state of consisting of monosyllables, or having a monosyllabic form; frequent occurrence of monosyllables.
madake: large bamboo having thick-walled culms; native of China and perhaps Japan; widely brown elsewhere.
Misdo: To do wrong; to commit a fault.
Marginal: Of or pertaining to a margin.
Miargyrite: A mineral of an iron-black color, and very sectile, consisting principally of sulphur, antimony, and silver.
managing editor: The editor in charge of all editorial activities of a newspaper or magazine.
Monadiform: Having the form of a monad; resembling a monad in having one or more filaments of vibratile protoplasm; as, monadiform young.
Midships: The timbers at the broadest part of the vessel.
Mandibuliform: Having the form of a mandible; -- said especially of the maxillæ of an insect when hard and adapted for biting.
Malicious: Indulging or exercising malice; harboring ill will or enmity.
Madden: To become mad; to act as if mad.
Madder: A plant of the genus Rubia (Rubia tinctorum).  The root is much used in dyeing red, and formerly was used in medicine.  It is cultivated in France and Holland.  See Rubiaceous.
measure: A standard of dimension; a fixed unit of quantity or extent; an extent or quantity in the fractions or multiples of which anything is estimated and stated; hence, a rule by which anything is adjusted or judged.
Macowanites americanus: A small fungus with a fragile cap that cracks to expose the white context and a white stalk that is practically enclosed by the cap.
maravilla: A wildflower (Mirabilis multiflora) having vibrant deep pink tubular evening-blooming flowers; found in sandy and desert areas from Southern California to Southern Colorado and into Mexico.
&Verbar;Myelencephalon: The brain and spinal cord; the cerebro-spinal axis.  Sometimes abbreviated to myelencephal.
Mabby: A spirituous liquor or drink distilled from potatoes; -- used in the Barbadoes.
Messiad: A German epic poem on the Messiah, by Klopstock.
Monomaniac: Affected with monomania, or partial derangement of intellect; caused by, or resulting from, monomania; as, a monomaniacal delusion.
Messiah: The expected king and deliverer of the Hebrews; the Savior; Christ.
mankind: The human race; man, taken collectively.
maddened: filled with or indicating extreme anger.
Maize: A large species of American grass of the genus Zea (Zea Mays), widely cultivated as a forage and food plant; Indian corn, commonly called corn.  Also, its seed, growing on cobs, and used as food for men and animals.
Merry-go-round: Any revolving contrivance for affording amusement; esp., a group of seats in the shape of hobbyhorses or other fanciful animals, arranged in a circle on a platform that is rotated by a mechanical drive, often to the accompaniment of music; the seats often move up and down in synchrony with the rotation; -- called also carousel.  It is employed primarily for the amusement of children, and is typically found at an amusement park.
Matchable: Capable of being matched; comparable on equal conditions; adapted to being joined together; correspondent.
Monstrousness: The state or quality of being monstrous, unusual, extraordinary.
malignant melanoma: Any of several malignant neoplasms (usually of the skin) consisting of melanocytes; called also melanoma.  It is classed as a type of skin cancer.
Meliphagan: Any bird of the genus Meliphaga and allied genera; a honey eater; -- called also meliphagidan.
&Verbar;Mac\u00e9doine: A kind of mixed dish, as of cooked vegetables with white sauce, sweet jelly with whole fruit, mixed diced fruits or vegetables etc.; served hot or cold;
Menstruation: The discharge of the menses; also, the state or the period of menstruating.
meloid: A beetle belongoing to the family Meloidae.
Madcap: A person of wild behavior; an excitable, rash, violent person.
masjid: A Muslim place of worship; a mosque.
Misunderstand: To misconceive; to mistake; to miscomprehend; to take in a wrong sense.
Magnesian: Pertaining to, characterized by, or containing, magnesia or magnesium.
Milliliter: A measure of capacity in the metric system, containing the thousandth part of a liter.  It is a cubic centimeter, and is equal to .061 of an English cubic inch, or to .0338 of an American fluid ounce.
Mangonism: The art of mangonizing, or setting off to advantage.
Molt: The act or process of changing the feathers, hair, skin, etc.; molting.
Mysterize: To make mysterious; to make a mystery of.
mycobacteria: A group of rod-shaped bacteria, some saprophytic or causing diseases.
Mandibular: Of or pertaining to a mandible; like a mandible.
microphone: An instrument for converting sounds into electrical signals, for the purpose of recording or amplifying the sounds.  It produces its effects in various ways, as for example by the changes of intensity in an electric current, occasioned by the variations in the contact resistance of conducting bodies, especially of imperfect conductors, under the action of acoustic vibrations.  Other forms of microphone may use changes in capacitance or other phenomena to transduce the sounds into electrical signals.
Mulch: To cover or dress with mulch.
Misgovern: To govern badly; as, to misgovern a country.
&Verbar;Maclurea: A genus of spiral gastropod shells, often of large size, characteristic of the lower Silurian rocks.
Merry: A kind of wild red cherry.
&Verbar;Mydriasis: A long-continued or excessive dilatation of the pupil of the eye.
Miterwort: Any plant of the genus Mitella, -- slender, perennial herbs with a pod slightly resembling a bishop's miter; bishop's cap.
make known: To reveal; to disclose; as, the congressman made known his interest in the company only after he voted on the bill.
Monochromy: The art of painting or drawing in monochrome.
Multiserial: Arranged in many rows, or series, as the scales of a pine cone, or the leaves of the houseleek.
Monochrome: A painting or drawing in a single color; a picture made with a single color.
Metadiscoidal: Discoidal by derivation; -- applied especially to the placenta of man and apes, because it is supposed to have been derived from a diffused placenta.
Membraniform: Having the form of a membrane or of parchment.
Maty: A native house servant in India.
Mate: To be or become a mate or mates, especially in sexual companionship; as, some birds mate for life; this bird will not mate with that one.
&Verbar;Mohurrum: The first month of the Mohammedan year.
Math: A mowing, or that which is gathered by mowing; -- chiefly used in composition; as, an aftermath.
manzanita: A name given to several species of Arctostaphylos, but mostly to Arctostaphylos glauca and Arctostaphylos pungens, shrubs of California, Oregon, etc., with reddish smooth bark, ovate or oval coriaceous evergreen leaves, and bearing clusters of red berries, which are said to be a favorite food of the grizzly bear.
Monkeytail: A short, round iron bar or lever used in naval gunnery.
Millennial: Of or pertaining to the millennium, or to a thousand years; as, a millennial period; millennial happiness.
Marquis: A nobleman in England, France, and Germany, of a rank next below that of duke.  Originally, the marquis was an officer whose duty was to guard the marches or frontiers of the kingdom.  The office has ceased, and the name is now a mere title conferred by patent.
Mida: The larva of the bean fly.
Merganser: Any bird of the genus Mergus (Merganser), and allied genera of the subfamily Merginae.  They are allied to the ducks, but have a sharply serrated bill, eat fish, and dive for food.  Also called fish duck.
motorboat: a boat propelled by an internal-combustion engine driving propellers immersed in the water.
Mercuric: Of, pertaining to, or derived from, mercury; containing mercury; -- said of those compounds of mercury into which this element enters in its lowest proportion.
Mahrati: The language of the Mahrattas; the language spoken in the Deccan and Concan.
Manlike: Like man, or like a man, in form or nature; having the qualities of a man, esp. the nobler qualities; manly.
Misrule: The act, or the result, of misruling.
&Verbar;Marmorosis: The metamorphism of limestone, that is, its conversion into marble.
Malleable: Capable of being extended or shaped by beating with a hammer, or by the pressure of rollers; -- applied to metals.
Mysterious: Of or pertaining to mystery; containing a mystery; difficult or impossible to understand; inexplicable; obscure; not revealed or explained; enigmatical; incomprehensible.
Masterful: Inclined to play the master; domineering; imperious; arbitrary.
Magnetism: The property, quality, or state, of being magnetic; the manifestation of the force in nature which is seen in a magnet.  At one time it was believed to be separate from the electrical force, but it is now known to be intimately associated with electricity, as part of the phenomenon of electromagnetism.
Momentous: Of moment or consequence; very important; weighty; as, a momentous decision; momentous affairs.
Monogram: A character or cipher composed of two or more letters interwoven or combined so as to represent a name, or a part of it (usually the initials).  Monograms are often used on seals, ornamental pins, rings, buttons, and by painters, engravers, etc., to distinguish their works.
monovular: derived from a single egg or ovum; -- of twins; as, identical twins are monovular.  Contrasted with fraternal.
