Monarchian: One of a sect in the early Christian church which rejected the doctrine of the Trinity; -- called also patripassian.
Motoring: Pertaining to motor cars or automobiles, or to the technology of such; addicted to riding in or driving automobiles; as, motoring parlance; my motoring friend.
middle-level: intermediate in rank or position; as, middle-level management.
Mountain specter: An optical phenomenon sometimes seen on the summit of mountains (as on the Brocken) when the observer is between the sun and a mass of cloud.  The figures of the observer and surrounding objects are seen projected on the cloud, greatly enlarged and often encircled by rainbow colors.
Muscovite: A native or inhabitant of Muscovy or ancient Russia; hence, a Russian.
&Verbar;Millepora: A genus of Hydrocorallia, which includes the millipores.
macro lens: a camera lens designed to focus at short distances so as to achieve photographic magnifications of objects larger than with standard lenses.
Malayalam: The name given to one the cultivated Dravidian languages, closely related to the Tamil.
Macrography: Examination or study with the naked eye, as distinguished from micrography.
Malachite: Native hydrous carbonate of copper, usually occurring in green mammillary masses with concentric fibrous structure.
Music: The science and the art of tones, or musical sounds, i. e., sounds of higher or lower pitch, begotten of uniform and synchronous vibrations, as of a string at various degrees of tension; the science of harmonical tones which treats of the principles of harmony, or the properties, dependences, and relations of tones to each other; the art of combining tones in a manner to please the ear.
Metabasis: A transition from one subject to another.
Misinterpretation: The act of interpreting erroneously; a mistaken interpretation.
Misgive: To give out doubt and apprehension; to be fearful or irresolute.
mackerel scad: A small silvery fish (Decapterus macarellus) found from Nova Scotia to Brazil.
Metrometer: An instrument for measuring the size of the womb.
Mirage: An optical effect, sometimes seen on the ocean, but more frequently in deserts, due to total reflection of light at the surface common to two strata of air differently heated.  The reflected image is seen, commonly in an inverted position, while the real object may or may not be in sight.  When the surface is horizontal, and below the eye, the appearance is that of a sheet of water in which the object is seen reflected; when the reflecting surface is above the eye, the image is seen projected against the sky.  The fata Morgana and looming are species of mirage.
Mump: To utter imperfectly, brokenly, or feebly.
Micrometric: Belonging to micrometry; made by the micrometer.
&Verbar;Meros: The proximal segment of the hind limb; the thigh.
Moonglade: The bright reflection of the moon's light on an expanse of water.
Meliority: The state or quality of being better; melioration.
Monodynamism: The theory that the various forms of activity in nature are manifestations of the same force.
Maxilloturbinal: Pertaining to the maxillary and turbinal regions of the skull.
Mariposa lily: One of a genus (Calochortus) of tuliplike bulbous herbs with large, and often gaycolored, blossoms.  Called also butterfly lily.  Most of them are natives of California.
Malingerer: In the army, a soldier who feigns himself sick, or who induces or protracts an illness, in order to avoid doing his duty; hence, in general, one who shirks his duty by pretending illness or inability.
Mannerism: Adherence to a peculiar style or manner; a characteristic mode of action, bearing, behavior, or treatment of others.
&Verbar;Messidor: The tenth month of the French republican calendar dating from September 22, 1792.  It began June 19, and ended July 18.  See VendÉmiaire.
Mumm: To sport or make diversion in a mask or disguise; to mask.
Mannerist: One addicted to mannerism; a person who, in action, bearing, or treatment, carries characteristic peculiarities to excess. See citation under Mannerism.
Membered: Having limbs; -- chiefly used in composition.
metatherian: Any of a group of primitive pouched mammals found mainly in Australia and the Americas.
&Verbar;Marquise: The wife of a marquis; a marchioness.
motorcycling: The process of riding a motocycle.
Motto: A sentence, phrase, or word, forming part of an heraldic achievment.
Mistletoe: A parasitic evergreen plant of Europe (Viscum album), bearing a glutinous fruit.  When found upon the oak, where it is rare, it was an object of superstitious regard among the Druids.  A bird lime is prepared from its fruit.
Murre: Any one of several species of sea birds of the genus Uria, or Catarractes; a guillemot.
Monosyllabic: Being a monosyllable, or composed of monosyllables; as, a monosyllabic word; a monosyllabic language.
Mixture: The act of mixing, or the state of being mixed; as, made by a mixture of ingredients.
Mown: Cut down by mowing, as grass; deprived of grass by mowing; as, a mown field.
Mignonette: A plant (Reseda odorata) having greenish flowers with orange-colored stamens, and exhaling a delicious fragrance.  In Africa it is a low shrub, but further north it is usually an annual herb.
&Verbar;Mycelium: The white threads or filamentous growth from which a mushroom or fungus is developed; the so-called mushroom spawn.
Matchmaking: Busy in making or contriving marriages; as, a matchmaking woman.
Macaca mulatta: The rhesus monkey of South Asia; used in medical research.
Multiform: Having many forms, shapes, or appearances.
Mulberry-faced: Having a face of a mulberry color, or blotched as if with mulberry stains.
Murmuring: Uttering murmurs; making low sounds; complaining.
Manuscript: An original literary or musical composition written by the author, formerly with the hand, now usually by typewriter or word processor.  It is contrasted with a printed copy.
&Verbar;Mater: See Alma mater, Dura mater, and Pia mater.
Marasmius: A genus of chiefly small white-spored mushrooms, including the Marasmius oreades, the mushroon that grow in a fairy ring.
&Verbar;Maha: A kind of baboon; the wanderoo.
Malformation: Ill formation; irregular or anomalous formation; abnormal or wrong conformation or structure; -- often used of body parts such as limbs which do not develop properly during fetal maturation.
Modish: According to the mode, or customary manner; conformed to the fashion; fashionable; hence, conventional; as, a modish dress; a modish feast.
maleberry: A deciduous much-branched shrub (Lyonia ligustrina) with dense downy panicles of small bell-shaped white flowers; also called swamp andromeda.
Mercurism: A communication of news; an announcement.
Mayan: Designating, or pertaining to, an American Indian linguistic stock occupying the Mexican States of Veracruz, Chiapas, Tabasco, Campeche, and Yucatan, together with a part of Guatemala and a part of El Salvador. See 2nd Maya.
Mason: To build stonework or brickwork about, under, in, over, etc.; to construct by masons; -- with a prepositional suffix; as, to mason up a well or terrace; to mason in a kettle or boiler.
Malaxis-unifolia: A North American orchid having a solitary leaf and flowers with threadlike petals.
Macowanites: A stout-stemmed genus of fungi belonging to the family Secotiaceae having fruiting bodies that never expand completely.
Moghul empire: The empire created in India by invading Mongolians (Tatars), established under Baber, who conquered Hindustan in 1526.  The establsihed religion of the empire was Mohammedanism.  After the death of the Great Mogul Aurung-Zeb in 1707, power passed to the Mahrattas and the British.  The empire existed only nominally in the early 1800's, and was finally abolished in 1857 by the deposing of the last emperor.
Monoousian: Having but one and the same nature or essence.
Mercurialist: One under the influence of Mercury; one resembling Mercury in character.
Manesheet: A covering placed over the upper part of a horse's head.
mutation: Change; alteration, either in form or qualities.
Mobocracy: A condition in which the lower classes of a nation control public affairs without respect to law, precedents, or vested rights.
Myriacanthous: Having numerous spines, as certain fishes.
magnetic needle: A slender magnet suspended in a magnetic compass on a low-friction mounting; used to indicate the direction of the earth's magnetic pole.
Miasmatic: Containing, or relating to, miasma; caused by miasma; as, miasmatic diseases.
Mantuamaker: One who makes dresses, cloaks, etc., for women; a dressmaker.
Marinade: A brine or pickle containing wine or vinegar, with opil, herbs, and spices, for enriching the flavor of meat and fish, which are steeped in it prior to cooking.
Medicean: Of or relating to the Medici, a noted Italian family; as, the Medicean Venus.
Merchandisable: Such as can be used or transferred as merchandise.
make believe: To pretend; -- often used with that, but often having the that omitted; as, he made believe he didn't hear her; or he made believe that he didn't hear her.
&Verbar;Metapophysis: A tubercle projecting from the anterior articular processes of some vertebræ; a mammillary process.
Munificent: Very liberal in giving or bestowing; lavish; as, a munificent benefactor.
&Verbar;Maucaco: A lemur; -- applied to several species, as the White-fronted, the ruffed, and the ring-tailed lemurs.
methadon: a narcotic drug similar to morphine but less habit-forming; used in treating heroin addiction.
Multipolar: Having many poles; in Anat., designating specif. a nerve cell which has several dendrites.
mucker: An excavating machine designed to remove particulate material from within a confined area, as in a tunnel or mine.
Mephistophelean: Pertaining to, or resembling, the devil Mephistopheles, “a crafty, scoffing, relentless fiend;” devilish in character or aspect; crafty; showing cunning or ingenuity or wickedness; as, a mephistophelean glint in his eye.
Meteorograph: An instrument which registers meteorologic phases or conditions.
Mucilaginous: Partaking of the nature of, or resembling, mucilage; moist, soft, and viscid; slimy; ropy; as, a mucilaginous liquid.
Magnetician: One versed in the science of magnetism; a magnetist.
marketplace: an area in a town where a public market is set up; a market place; a market{2}.
Maturation: The process of bringing, or of coming, to maturity; hence, specifically, the process of suppurating perfectly; the formation of pus or matter.
Micturition: The act of voiding urine; urination; also, a morbidly frequent passing of the urine, in consequence of disease.
March-ward: A warden of the marches; a marcher.
Measuring: Used in, or adapted for, ascertaining measurements, or dividing by measure.
Mining: Of or pertaining to mines; as, mining engineer; mining machinery; a mining region.
Million: The number of ten hundred thousand, or a thousand thousand, -- written 1,000,000. See the Note under Hundred.
Mouth: To speak with a full, round, or loud, affected voice; to vociferate; to rant.
Malonyl: A divalent diacyl radical, CH2.(CO)2, from malonic acid.
Memorable: Worthy to be remembered; very important or remarkable.
Myodynamics: The department of physiology which deals with the principles of muscular contraction; the exercise of muscular force or contraction.
Motivity: The power of moving or producing motion.
Morgay: The European small-spotted dogfish, or houndfish. See the Note under Houndfish.
Martinetism: The principles or practices of a martinet; rigid adherence to discipline, etc.
Meteorometer: An apparatus which transmits automatically to a central station atmospheric conditions as marked by the anemometer, barometer, thermometer, etc.
Morgan: John Pierpont Morgan, a noted American financier and philanthropist; 1837-1913.
&Verbar;Monozoa: A division of Radiolaria; -- called also Monocyttaria.
Melville: Herman Melville, American novelist, author of Moby Dick; b. 1819, d. 1891.
Megathere: An extinct gigantic quaternary mammal, allied to the ant-eaters and sloths. Its remains are found in South America.
Mullion: To furnish with mullions; to divide by mullions.
Metalline: A substance of variable composition, but resembling a soft, dark-colored metal, used in the bearings of machines for obviating friction, and as a substitute for lubricants.
Miserableness: The state or quality of being miserable.
Maudlin: An aromatic composite herb, the costmary; also, the South European Achillea Ageratum, a kind of yarrow.
Misremember: To mistake in remembering; not to remember correctly.
Micrologic: Of or pertaining to micrology; very minute; as, micrologic examination.
Mortuary: Of or pertaining to the dead; as, mortuary monuments.
Monaxial: Having only one axis; developing along a single line or plane; as, monaxial development.
Mammillary: Of or pertaining to the mammilla, or nipple, or to the breast; resembling a mammilla; mammilloid.
minuscule: Of or relating to a minuscule{2} or of a script written in minuscules{2}; of the size and style of minuscules{2}; written in minuscules{2}; minuscular.
Macrouridae: A natural family of fish including the grenadiers.
Marattiaceae: The natural family of ferns coextensive with the order Marattiales, consisting of chiefly tropical eusporantiate ferns with gigantic fronds.
Mythop\u0153ic: Making or producing myths; giving rise to mythical narratives.
Megalosaur: A gigantic carnivorous dinosaur, whose fossil remains have been found in England and elsewhere.
Medallic: Of or pertaining to a medal, or to medals.
Mettle: Substance or quality of temperament; spirit, esp. as regards honor, courage, fortitude, ardor, etc.; disposition; -- usually in a good sense; as, to test a person's mettle.
Manoscopy: The science of the determination of the density of vapors and gases.
malma: A spotted trout (Salvelinus malma), inhabiting Northern America, west of the Rocky Mountains; -- called also Dolly Varden trout, bull trout, red-spotted trout, and golet.
Manstealing: The act or business of stealing or kidnaping human beings, especially with a view to e&unr_;slave them.
Metazoic: Of or pertaining to the Metazoa.
Margrave: Originally, a lord or keeper of the borders or marches in Germany.
&Verbar;Mademoiselle: A French title of courtesy given to a girl or an unmarried lady, equivalent to the English Miss.
Mazy: Perplexed with turns and windings; winding; intricate; confusing; perplexing; embarrassing; as, mazy error.
&Verbar;Macula: A spot, as on the skin, or on the surface of the sun or of some other luminous orb; called also macule.
managing director: A person who manages a busness though not the owner or chief executive.
Mayduke: A large dark-red cherry of excellent quality.
&Verbar;Melastoma: A genus of evergreen tropical shrubs; -- so called from the black berries of some species, which stain the mouth.
malacca cane: A walking cane made from the stem of a species of palm of the genus Calamus (Calamus Scipionum), and of a brown color, often mottled. The plant is a native of Cochin China, Sumatra, and Malays.
Manege: The art of horsemanship, or of training horses.
Minuteman: A militiaman who was to be ready to march at a moment's notice; -- a term used in the American Revolution.
mem: the 13th letter of the Hebrew alphabet.
Mesoplast: The nucleus of a cell; mesoblast.
&Verbar;Malbrouck: A West African arboreal monkey (Cercopithecus cynosurus).
Mixer: One who, or that which, mixes.
&Verbar;Mesohepar: A fold of the peritoneum connecting the liver with the dorsal wall of the abdominal cavity.
Moonless: Being without a moon or moonlight.
Malacanthidae: A natural family of short-headed marine fishes which are often brightly colored.
Mineralogical: Of or pertaining to mineralogy; as, a mineralogical table.
Manhood: The state of being man as a human being, or man as distinguished from a child or a woman.
Manumission: The act of manumitting, or of liberating a slave from bondage.
Mitu: A South American curassow of the genus Mitua.
mugful: the quantity that can be held in a mug.
mooch: to ask for and get free; to borrow without intending to repay; to sponge; -- usually with objects of small value; as, he mooched a few cigarettes from me.
merchant marine: The ships owned by nationals of a particular country that are engaged in civilian commerce; also, the personnel operating those vessels.  Distinguished from the navy, which contains the vessels of war.
Microbic: Of or pertaining to a microbe.
&Verbar;Melancholia: A kind of mental unsoundness characterized by extreme depression of spirits, ill-grounded fears, delusions, and brooding over one particular subject or train of ideas.
made-up: formed or conceived by the imagination; not true; as, a made-up story.
Mugilidae: A natural family of fish including the gray mullets.
Magazine rack: A rack or stand for displaying magazines{4}.
&Verbar;Magma: Any crude mixture of mineral or organic matters in the state of a thin paste.
Merozoite: A form of spore, usually elongate or falciform, and somewhat amoeboid, produced by segmentation of the schizonts of certain Sporozoa, as the malaria parasite.
Megaseme: Having the orbital index relatively large; having the orbits narrow transversely; -- opposed to microseme.
&Verbar;Madoqua: A small Abyssinian antelope (Neotragus Saltiana), about the size of a hare.
Mousse: A frozen dessert of a frothy texture, made of sweetened and flavored whipped cream, sometimes with the addition of egg yolks and gelatin.  Mousse differs from ice cream in being beaten before -- not during -- the freezing process.
Multicostate: Having numerous ribs, or costæ, as the leaf of a plant, or as certain shells and corals.
Mezzotinto: To engrave in mezzotint; to represent by mezzotint.
Matriarchate: The office or jurisdiction of a matriarch; a matriarchal form of government.
Miscarriageable: Capable of miscarrying; liable to fail.
Myrmeleontidae: A natural family of the order Neuroptera, including the antlions.
Myriagram: A metric weight, consisting of ten thousand grams or ten kilograms.  It is equal to 22.046 lbs. avoirdupois.
Morinda: A genus of rubiaceous trees and shrubs, mostly East Indian, many species of which yield valuable red and yellow dyes. The wood is hard and beautiful, and used for gunstocks.
Mutinous: Disposed to mutiny; in a state of mutiny; characterized by mutiny; seditious; insubordinate.
Mahometanize: To convert to the religion of Mohammed; to Mohammedanize.
Metamere: One of successive or homodynamous parts in animals and plants; one of a series of similar parts that follow one another in a vertebrate or articulate animal, as in an earthworm; a segment; a somite. See Illust. of Loeven's larva.
Massacre: To kill in considerable numbers where much resistance can not be made; to kill with indiscriminate violence, without necessity, and contrary to the usages of nations; to butcher; to slaughter; -- limited to the killing of human beings.
Microseism: A feeble earth tremor not directly perceptible, but detected only by means of specially constructed apparatus.
mahonia: The Oregon grape, a species of barberry (Berberis Aquifolium), often cultivated for its hollylike foliage.
Meloplasty: The process of restoring a cheek which has been destroyed wholly or in part.
Methodize: To reduce to method; to dispose in due order; to arrange in a convenient manner; as, to methodize one's work or thoughts.
Magnoliophyta: A class of flowering plants that produce seeds enclosed in an ovary; in some systems considered a class (Angiospermae) and in others a division (Magnoliophyta or Anthophyta).
Meropidan: One of a family of birds (Meropidæ), including the bee-eaters.
mutagenesis: the causing of a mutation or the occurrence of a mutation{3}.
&Verbar;Mammalia: The highest class of Vertebrata.  The young are nourished for a time by milk, or an analogous fluid, secreted by the mammary glands of the mother.
Matte: A partly reduced copper sulphide, obtained by alternately roasting and melting copper ore in separating the metal from associated iron ores, and called coarse metal, fine metal, etc., according to the grade of fineness.  On the exterior it is dark brown or black, but on a fresh surface is yellow or bronzy in color.
Maldive Islands: A group of about 2000 islands in the Indian ocean; also known as the Maldives.
Mordantly: In the manner of a mordant.
&Verbar;metate: A flat or somewhat hollowed stone upon which grain or other food is ground, by means of a smaller stone or pestle.
Motioner: One who makes a motion; a mover.
marvel of Peru: A common garden plant (Mirabilis jalapa or Mirabilis uniflora) of North America having fragrant red or purple or yellow or white flowers that open in late afternoon; called also four-o'clock.  See four-o'clock.
macrocytosis: An abnormal physiological condition characterized by the presence of macrocytes in the blood.
Misrepeat: To repeat wrongly; to give a wrong version of.
Molybdous: Of, pertaining to, or containing, molybdenum; specif., designating those compounds in which molybdenum has a lower valence as contrasted with molybdic compounds.
Midmain: The middle part of the main or sea.
Marmorate: Variegated like marble; covered or overlaid with marble.
Mechanography: The art of mechanically multiplying copies of a writing, or any work of art.
Molossine: A bat of the genus Molossus, as the monk bat.
Marble-edged: Having the edge veined or spotted with different colors like marble, as a book.
Maghet: A name for daisies and camomiles of several kinds.
Merino: A breed of sheep originally from Spain, noted for the fineness of its wool.
Mush: To travel on foot, esp. across the snow with dogs.
Muse: Contemplation which abstracts the mind from passing scenes; absorbing thought; hence, absence of mind; a brown study.
Must: To make musty; to become musty.
&Verbar;M\u00e9nage: A collection of animals; a menagerie.
Misbede: To wrong; to do injury to.
&Verbar;Manu: One of a series of progenitors of human beings, and authors of human wisdom.
&Verbar;Mano: The muller, or crushing and grinding stone, used in grinding corn on a metate.
Mirror: To reflect, as in a mirror.
Mammiform: Having the form of a mamma (breast) or mammæ.
Monteith: A kind of cotton handkerchief having a uniform colored ground with a regular pattern of white spots produced by discharging the color; -- so called from the Glasgow manufactures.
massif: A block of the earth's crust bounded by faults and shifted to form peaks of a mountain range.
Magnetometer: An instrument for measuring the intensity of magnetic forces; also, less frequently, an instrument for determining any of the terrestrial magnetic elements, as the dip and declination.
Maculate: Marked with spots or maculæ; blotched; hence, defiled; impure; as, most maculate thoughts.
Meritorious: Possessing merit; deserving of reward or honor; worthy of recompense; valuable.
Malefic: Doing mischief; causing harm or evil; nefarious; hurtful.
Mesh: To engage with each other, as the teeth of wheels.
Multitudinous: Consisting of a multitude; manifold in number or condition; as, multitudinous waves.
&Verbar;Macrochires: A division of birds including the swifts and humming birds. So called from the length of the distal part of the wing.
monicker: The name of a person, especially an alias or a nickname.
Mantel: The finish around a fireplace, covering the chimney-breast in front and sometimes on both sides; especially, a shelf above the fireplace, and its supports.  The shelf is called also a mantelpiece or mantlepiece.
Mercenariness: The quality or state of being mercenary; venality.
Mesmeric: Of, pertaining to, or induced by, mesmerism; as, mesmeric sleep.
macroglia: Tissue consisting of large stellate neuroglial cells.
mid-thirties: the time of life between 30 and 40.
Moonsail: A sail sometimes carried in light winds, above a skysail.
Murexide: A crystalline nitrogenous substance (C8H8N6O6, 5-5'-nitrilodibarbituric acid monoammonium salt) having a splendid dichroism, being green by reflected light and garnet-red by transmitted light.  It was formerly used in dyeing calico, and was obtained in a large quantities from guano.  It is now synthesized from alloxan.  Formerly called also ammonium purpurate.
Mastoid: Resembling the nipple or the breast; -- applied specifically to a process of the temporal bone behind the ear.
&Verbar;Metasternum: The most posterior element of the sternum; the ensiform process; xiphisternum.
mitigating: serving to reduce blame; -- of situations; as, mitigating factors; mitigating circumstances.  Opposite of aggravating.
Mule killer: Any of several arthropods erroneously supposed to kill live stock, in the southern United States, by stinging or by being swallowed;
Modernize: To render modern; to adapt to modern person or things; to cause to conform to recent or present usage or taste.
Mascagnin: Native sulphate of ammonia, found in volcanic districts; -- so named from Mascagni, who discovered it.
Menyanthes: The type genus of the Menyanthaceae, having only one species: the bogbeans.
Mediterranean fruit fly: A small two-winged fly (Ceratitis capitata), a native of the Mediterranean countries but now widely distributed in warm regions, which can cause great damage to citrus and other succulent fruit crops when present in large numbers.  It is black and white and irregularly banded. It lays eggs in ripening oranges, peaches, and other fruits; when the eggs hatch into larvae (maggots) inside the fruit, they cause the fruit to decay and fall, and make the fruit unsaleable.  It is also popularly called the medfly.
mint: Like new; in brand-new condition; unworn, as a coin recently made at a mint{1}; as, he had a '53 Cadillac in mint condition.
Motty: Full of, or consisting of, motes.
Mangel-wurzel: A kind of large field beet (Beta macrorhiza), used as food for cattle, -- by some considered a mere variety of the ordinary beet. See Beet.
Motte: A clump of trees in a prairie.
Mahdi: Among Mohammedans, the last imam or leader of the faithful.  The Sunni, the largest sect of the Mohammedans, believe that he is yet to appear.
&Verbar;Melasma: A dark discoloration of the skin, usually local; as, Addison's melasma, or Addison's disease.
minium: A heavy, brilliant red pigment, consisting of an oxide of lead, Pb3O4, obtained by exposing lead or massicot to a gentle and continued heat in the air.  It is used as a cement, as a paint, and in the manufacture of flint glass.  Called also red lead, lead tetroxide, lead orthoplumbate, mineral orange, mineral red, Paris red, Saturn red, and less definitively, lead oxide.
An abbreviation for minute, a unit of time equal to 60 seconds or 1/60th of an hour.
Multicipital: Having many heads or many stems from one crown or root.
Megohm: One of the larger measures of electrical resistance, amounting to one million ohms.
malted milk: A milkshake made with malt powder; also called simply a malted.
Multiflue: Having many flues; as, a multiflue boiler. See Boiler.
Microhm: The millionth part of an ohm.
maria: Plural form of mare, a dark region of considerable extent on the surface of the moon.
Mocha: A seaport town of Yemen, on the Red Sea, also spelled Mukha.
mailing: The act or process of sending materials through the mail.
mineralized: containing or impregnated with minerals; as, mineralized water; red stains that signify mineralized land.
Masseteric: Of or pertaining to the masseter.
Mollify: To soften; to make tender; to reduce the hardness, harshness, or asperity of; to qualify; as, to mollify the ground.
Macho: The striped mullet of California (Mugil cephalus, syn. Mugil Mexicanus).
Mitriform: Having the form of a miter, or a peaked cap; as, a mitriform calyptra.
Makalu: A mountain in Nepal and Tibet, 27,824 feet high.
microchemistry: The application of chemical tests to minute objects or portions of matter, usually assisted by sensitive instruments; -- distinguished from macro-chemistry.
&Verbar;Malapterurus: A genus of African siluroid fishes, including the electric catfishes. See Electric cat, under Electric.
Miasma: Infectious particles or germs floating in the air; air made noxious by the presence of such particles or germs; noxious effluvia; malaria.
Mainland: The continent; the principal land; -- opposed to island, or peninsula.
&Verbar;Milvus: A genus of raptorial birds, including the European kite.
&Verbar;Mare clausum: Lit., closed sea; hence, a body of water within the separate jurisdiction of the nation; -- opposed to open sea (mare liberum), the water open to all nations and over which no single nation has special control.
Mangler: One who smooths with a mangle.
morphinism: A morbid condition produced by the excessive or prolonged use of morphine.
Mudsill: The lowest sill of a structure, usually embedded in the soil; the lowest timber of a house; also, that sill or timber of a bridge which is laid at the bottom of the water. See Sill.
Melam: A white or buff-colored granular powder, C6H9N11, obtained by heating ammonium sulphocyanate.
Masseter: The large muscle which raises the under jaw, and assists in mastication.
Myelencephalic: Of or pertaining to the myelencephalon; cerebro-spinal.
Mountainous: Full of, or containing, mountains; as, the mountainous country of the Swiss.
Mordacious: Biting; given to biting; hence, figuratively, sarcastic; severe; scathing.
&Verbar;Mesopodium: The middle portion of the foot in the Gastropoda and Pteropoda.
marco polo sheep: An Asiatic wild sheep (Ovis poli) with exceptionally large horns; sometimes considered a variety of the argali: Ovis ammon poli.
Manikin: A little man; a dwarf; a pygmy; a manakin.
&Verbar;Mat\u00e9riel: That in a complex system which constitutes the materials, or instruments employed, in distinction from the personnel, or men; as, the baggage, munitions, provisions, etc., of an army; or the buildings, libraries, and apparatus of a college, in distinction from its officers.
Mittened: Covered with a mitten or mittens.
magnetic compass: An device using a magnet (such as a magnetic needle) to indicate the direction of magnetic north.
Muscardine: A disease which is very destructive to silkworms, and which sometimes extends to other insects.  It is attended by the development of a fungus (provisionally called Botrytis bassiana).  Also, the fungus itself.
Magically: In a magical manner; by magic, or as if by magic.
Metallography: The science or art of metals and metal working; also, a treatise on metals.
&Verbar;Mesothelium: Epithelial mesoderm; a layer of cuboidal epithelium cells, formed from a portion of the mesoderm during the differetiation of the germ layers. It constitutes the boundary of the cœlum.
Muscat: A name given to several varieties of Old World grapes, differing in color, size, etc., but all having a somewhat musky flavor. The muscat of Alexandria is a large oval grape of a pale amber color.
Mohawk: One of a tribe of Indians who formed part of the Five Nations.  They formerly inhabited the valley of the Mohawk River.
Mercable: Capable of being bought or sold.
Marined: Having the lower part of the body like a fish.
Metabranchial: Of or pertaining to the lobe of the carapace of crabs covering the posterior branchiæ.
&Verbar;Morendo: Dying; a gradual decrescendo at the end of a strain or cadence.
&Verbar;Manus: The distal segment of the fore limb, including the carpus and fore foot or hand.
&Verbar;M\u00e9tayer: One who cultivates land for a share (usually one half) of its yield, receiving stock, tools, and seed from the landlord.
Misobserver: One who misobserves; one who fails to observe properly.
Monometallic: Consisting of one metal; of or pertaining to monometallism.
mangle: A machine for smoothing linen or cotton cloth, as sheets, tablecloths, napkins, and clothing, by roller pressure, often with heated rollers.
Malva sylvestris: The species name of the tall mallow, an erect or decumbent Old World perennial with axillary clusters of rosy-purple flowers; introduced into the U. S.
Mosaic: Of or pertaining to Moses, the leader of the Israelites, or established through his agency; as, the Mosaic law, rites, or institutions.
Mohur: A British Indian gold coin, of the value of fifteen silver rupees, or $7.21 (in 1913).
Mulberry: The berry or fruit of any tree of the genus Morus; also, the tree itself. See Morus.
Misthink: To have erroneous thoughts or judgment of; to think ill of.
make: To cause to exist; to bring into being; to form; to produce; to frame; to fashion; to create.
Muddle: A state of being turbid or confused; hence, intellectual cloudiness or dullness.
Misdirection: The act of directing wrongly, or the state of being so directed.
mid-twenties: the time of life between 20 and 30.
Murnival: In the game of gleek, four cards of the same value, as four aces or four kings; hence, four of anything.
militaristic: imbued with militarism, in senses 3 or 4.
Mandibulohyoid: Pertaining both to the mandibular and the hyoid arch, or situated between them.
Mythologizer: One who, or that which, mythologizes.
Morris: A marine fish having a very slender, flat, transparent body.  It is now generally believed to be the young of the conger eel or some allied fish.
Mango: The fruit of the mango tree. It is rather larger than an apple, and of an ovoid shape. Some varieties are fleshy and luscious, and others tough and tasting of turpentine. The green fruit is pickled for market.
&Verbar;Mactra: Any marine bivalve shell of the genus Mactra, and allied genera. Many species are known. Some of them are used as food, as Mactra stultorum, of Europe. See Surf clam, under Surf.
Mange: The scab or itch in cattle, dogs, and other beasts.
Methanometer: An instrument, resembling a eudiometer, to detect the presence and amount of methane, as in coal mines.
Mallard: A drake; the male of Anas boschas.
merchantry: The body of merchants taken collectively; as, the merchantry of a country.
Muset: A small hole or gap through which a wild animal passes; a muse.
Matador: The killer; the man appointed to kill the bull in bullfights; a bullfighter; a toreador.
Masquerader: One who masquerades; a person wearing a mask; one disguised.
Mysticete: Any right whale, or whalebone whale. See Cetacea.
Monologist: One who soliloquizes; esp., one who monopolizes conversation in company.
man of affairs: A person engaged in commercial or industrial business (especially an owner or executive).
Mawworm: Any intestinal worm found in the stomach, esp. the common round worm (Ascaris lumbricoides), and allied species.
Monotomous: Having a distinct cleavage in a single direction only.
Mnium: A genus of mosses similar to those of genus Bryum but larger.
Martite: Iron sesquioxide in isometric form, probably a pseudomorph after magnetite.
Misbehave: To behave ill; to conduct one's self improperly; -- often used with a reciprocal pronoun.
Menace: To act in threatening manner; to wear a threatening aspect.
Macrurous: Of or pertaining to the Macrura; having a long tail.
Misadventure: Mischance; misfortune; ill luck; unlucky accident; ill adventure.
Memorist: One who, or that which, causes to be remembered.
modulated: Having either amplitude, intensity, frequency, or phase altered at intervals to represent information to be transmitted; -- of the carrier wave of a radio signal transmitted from one device to another for the purpose of conveying information.  Opposite of unmodulated.
Moschine: Of or pertaining to Moschus, a genus including the musk deer.
&Verbar;Maraschino: A liqueur distilled from fermented cherry juice, and flavored with the pit of a variety of cherry which grows in Dalmatia.
&Verbar;Mirabilis: A genus of plants. See Four-o'clock.
Margarate: A compound of the so-called margaric acid with a base.
Menhir: A large stone set upright in olden times as a memorial or monument.  Many, of unknown date, are found in Brittany and throughout Northern Europe.
Manumotor: A small wheel carriage, so constructed that a person sitting in it may move it.
&Verbar;Medicornu: The middle or inferior horn of each lateral ventricle of the brain.
Marly: Consisting or partaking of marl; resembling marl; abounding with marl.
Millrind: A figure supposed to represent the iron which holds a millstone by being set into its center.
Merils: A boy's play, called also fivepenny morris. See Morris.
Maguey: Any of several species of Agave,  such as the century plant (Agave Americana), a plant requiring many years to come to maturity and blossoming only once before dying; and the Agave atrovirens, a Mexican plant used especially for making pulque, the source of the colorless Mexican liquor mescal; and the cantala (Agave cantala), a Philippine plant yielding a hard fibre used in making coarse twine.  See Agave.
Memorialist: One who writes or signs a memorial.
Mosasaur: One of an extinct order of reptiles, including Mosasaurus and allied genera. See Mosasauria.
M\u00e6gbote: Compensation for the injury done by slaying a kinsman.
myna: Any one of numerous species of Asiatic starlings of the genera Acridotheres, Sturnopastor, Sturnia, Gracula, and allied genera.  In habits they resemble the European starlings, and like them are often caged and taught to talk.  See Hill myna, under Hill, and Mino bird.
Maidenhood: The state of being a maid or a virgin; virginity.
Mocking: Imitating, esp. in derision, or so as to cause derision; mimicking; derisive.
Moke: A mesh of a net, or of anything resembling a net.
manner name: A word that denotes a manner of doing something; a troponym; as, "march" is a manner name for "walk".
marten: Any one of several fur-bearing carnivores of the genus Martes (formerly Mustela), closely allied to the sable.  Among the more important species are the European beech marten or stone marten (Martes foina); the pine marten (Martes martes); and the American marten, or sable (Martes Americana), which some zoölogists consider only a variety of the Russian sable.
Mountebankery: The practices of a mountebank; quackery; boastful and vain pretenses.
myrmecophilous: Associated with, or benefitted by ants through sharing their nest.
marinara: Served in marinara sauce; -- used postpositionally, as veal marinara.
mandrake root: The root of the mandrake plant; used medicinally or as a narcotic; as a substance it is also called mandrake.
Mutuality: The quality of correlation; reciprocation; interchange; interaction; interdependence.
&Verbar;Mala: Evils; wrongs; offenses against right and law.
Manhandle: To move, or manage, by human force without mechanical aid; as, to manhandle a cannon.
manic-depressive psychosis: A mental disorder characterized by alternating episodes of mania and depression.
Myoh\u00e6matin: A red-colored respiratory pigment found associated with hemoglobin in the muscle tissue of a large number of animals, both vertebrate and invertebrate.
Moiety: One of two equal parts; a half; as, a moiety of an estate, of goods, or of profits; the moiety of a jury, or of a nation.
&Verbar;Monothalama: A division of Foraminifera including those that have only one chamber.
microphonous: Serving to augment the intensity of weak sounds; microcoustic.
Madman: A man who is mad; lunatic; a crazy person.
Monogenetic: One in genesis; resulting from one process of formation; -- used of a mountain range.
Micronometer: An instrument for noting minute portions of time.
Mockery: The act of mocking, deriding, and exposing to contempt, by mimicry, by insincere imitation, or by a false show of earnestness; a counterfeit appearance.
Magazining: The act of editing, or writing for, a magazine.
Misgoverned: Ill governed, as a people; ill directed.
matriarchal: Of or pertaining to a matriarch; governed by a matriarch or matriarchs; as, a matriarchal society.
Modifiability: Capability of being modified; state or quality of being modifiable.
Misrepresentation: Untrue representation; false or incorrect statement or account; -- usually unfavorable to the thing represented; as, a misrepresentation of a person's motives.
malicious mischief: Malicious and willful destructionof or injury to the property of others; -- it is an offense at common law.
Myotic: Producing myosis, or contraction of the pupil of the eye, as opium, calabar bean, etc.
Mesodermal: Pertaining to, or derived from, the mesoderm; as, mesodermal tissues.
Moonrise: The rising of the moon above the horizon; also, the time of its rising.
maldanian: Any species of marine annelids of the genus Maldane, or family Maldanidæ.  They have a slender, round body, and make tubes in the sand or mud.
Mother-of-thyme: An aromatic plant (Thymus Serphyllum); -- called also wild thyme.
Mortifier: One who, or that which, mortifies.
mid-forties: the time of life between 40 and 50.
monkeypod: large ornamental tropical American tree (Albizia saman) with bipinnate leaves and globose clusters of flowers with crimson stamens and sweet-pulp seed pods eaten by cattle.
Meionite: A member of the scapolite group, occuring in glassy crystals on Monte Somma, near Naples.
Myosin: A protein present in muscle, serving as the principle contractile protein in muscle contraction.
&Verbar;Macaque: Any one of several species of short-tailed monkeys of the genus Macaca (formerly Macacus), found in rocky regions of Asia and Africa; as, Macaca maurus, the moor macaque of the East Indies.
Molecast: A little elevation of earth made by a mole; a molehill.
Mealiness: The quality or state of being mealy.
must: Being in a condition of dangerous frenzy, usually connected with sexual excitement; -- said of adult male elephants which become so at irregular intervals, typicaly due to increased testosterone levels.
Molybdenite: A mineral occurring in soft, lead-gray, foliated masses or scales, resembling graphite; sulphide of molybdenum.
Meibomian: Of, pertaining to, or discovered by, Meibomius.
Melanistic: Affected with melanism; of the nature of melanism.
Melodize: To make melody; to compose melodies; to harmonize.
&Verbar;Mycetes: A genus of South American monkeys, including the howlers. See Howler, 2, and Illust.
Matagasse: A shrike or butcher bird; -- called also mattages.
Mobocrat: One who favors a form of government in which the unintelligent populace rules without restraint.
manufacturing business: A business engaged in manufacturing some product.
Metempsychosis: The passage of the soul, as an immortal essence, at the death of the animal body it had inhabited, into another living body, whether of a brute or a human being; transmigration of souls.
Monocotyledon: A plant with only one cotyledon, or seed lobe; a member of the Monocotyledonae.
Merger: One who, or that which, merges.
Manswear: To swear falsely. Same as Mainswear.
Moony: A follower of the Rev. Sun Myun Moon; a member of the Unification Church; -- often considered disparaging.
majors: The teams in the major leagues.
mu: The 12th letter of the Greek alphabet (μ, Μ).
Monogamy: Single marriage; marriage with but one person, husband or wife, at the same time; -- opposed to polygamy. Also, one marriage only during life; -- opposed to deuterogamy.
menhaden: An American marine fish (Brevoortia tyrannus) of the Herring family (Clupeidae), chiefly valuable for its oil and as a component of fertilizers; -- called also mossbunker, bony fish, chebog, pogy, hardhead, whitefish, etc.
Masquerade: To conceal with masks; to disguise.
Masterpiece: Anything done or made with extraordinary skill; a capital performance; a chef-d'œuvre; a supreme achievement.
Minaceous: Of the color of minium or red lead; miniate.
makeup: The way in which the parts of anything are put together.
Mirthful: Full of mirth or merriment; merry; as, mirthful children.
Mothering: A rural custom in England, of visiting one's parents on Midlent Sunday, -- supposed to have been originally visiting the mother church to make offerings at the high altar.
magnum opus: A great work of art or literature.
Moonstone: A nearly pellucid variety of feldspar, showing pearly or opaline reflections from within.  It is used as a gem.  The best specimens come from Ceylon.
&Verbar;Myaria: A division of bivalve mollusks of which the common clam (Mya) is the type.
&Verbar;Monerula: A germ in that stage of development in which its form is simply that of a non-nucleated mass of protoplasm.  It precedes the one-celled germ.  So called from its likeness to a moner.
Milksop: A piece of bread sopped in milk; figuratively, an effeminate or weak-minded person.
Marxist: Of or pertaining to Marx or Marxism.
Margaritaceous: Pertaining to, or resembling, pearl; pearly.
Mutability: The quality of being mutable, or subject to change or alteration, either in form, state, or essential character; susceptibility of change; changeableness; inconstancy; variation.
Mad-apple: The eggplant bush (Solanum melongena).  See Eggplant.
Madnep: The masterwort (Peucedanum Ostruthium), a tall and coarse European umbelliferous plant.
Martyrology: A history or account of martyrs; a register of martyrs.
Melting: Causing to melt; becoming melted; -- used literally or figuratively; as, a melting heat; a melting appeal; a melting mood.
Misregulate: To regulate wrongly or imperfectly; to fail to regulate.
malar: The cheek bone, which forms a part of the lower edge of the orbit; that arch of bone beneath the eye that forms the prominence of the cheek; also called the malar bone.
Mellone: A yellow powder, C6H3N9, obtained from certain sulphocyanates.  It has acid properties and forms compounds called mellonides.
Musette: A small bagpipe formerly in use, having a soft and sweet tone.
Miserably: In a miserable; unhappily; calamitously; wretchedly; meanly.
moccasin: A shoe made of deerskin, or other soft leather, the sole and upper part being one piece.  It is the customary shoe worn by the American Indians.
Meditatist: One who is given to meditation.
Metatungstic: Of, pertaining to, or designating, an acid known only in its salts (the metatungstates) and properly called polytungstic, or pyrotungstic, acid.
Mayoralty: The office, or the term of office, of a mayor.
Miscolor: To give a wrong color to.
&Verbar;Mesogl\u0153a: A thin gelatinous tissue separating the ectoderm and endoderm in certain cœlenterates.
Mutable: Capable of alteration; subject to change; changeable in form, qualities, or nature.
mach number: The ratio of the speed of a moving body to the speed of sound.
&Verbar;Mesometrium: The fold of the peritoneum supporting the oviduct.
Misform: To make in an ill form.
malta fever: An infectious disease contracted from meat or milk products from infected domestic animals; called also brucellosis and undulant fever.
mac: Shortened form of mackintosh, a waterproof raincoat made of rubberized fabric.
Mosquito: Any one of various species of gnats of the genus Culex and allied genera.  The females have a proboscis containing, within the sheathlike labium, six fine, sharp, needlelike organs with which they puncture the skin of man and animals to suck the blood.  These bites, when numerous, cause, in many persons, considerable irritation and swelling, with some pain.  The larvæ and pupæ, called wigglers, are aquatic.
mag: Shortened form of magazine, the periodic paperback publication.
malaxator: One who, or that which, malaxates; esp., a machine for grinding, kneading, or stirring into a pasty or doughy mass.
&Verbar;Monde: The world; a globe as an ensign of royalty.
Misfall: To befall, as ill luck; to happen to unluckily.
Martyrologist: A writer of martyrology; an historian of martyrs.
Mutual: Reciprocally acting or related; reciprocally receiving and giving; reciprocally given and received; reciprocal; interchanged; as, a mutual love, advantage, assistance, aversion, etc.
Masked: Wearing a mask or masks; characterized by masks; concealed; hidden.
Metallicly: In a metallic manner; by metallic means.
Muscle: An organ which, by its contraction, produces motion.
Mollemoke: Any one of several species of large pelagic petrels and fulmars, as Fulmarus glacialis, of the North Atlantic, and several species of Æstrelata, of the Southern Ocean. See Fulmar.
Mugiloidea: A suborder of fishes distinguished by abdominal pelvic fins, including the families Mugilidae; Atherinidae; and Sphyraenidae.
Memorialize: To address or petition by a memorial; to present a memorial to; as, to memorialize the legislature.
Masonry: The art or occupation of a mason.
main: A hand or match at dice.
mismatched: Matched unsuitably; grouped into pairs or sets with incompatible characteristics.
Meekness: The quality or state of being meek.
Multiplicator: The number by which another number is multiplied; a multiplier.
Minimum: The least quantity assignable, admissible, or possible, in a given case; hence, a thing of small consequence; -- opposed to maximum.
Measurement: The act or result of measuring; mensuration; as, measurement is required.
Marcosian: One of a Gnostic sect of the second century, so called from Marcus, an Egyptian, who was reputed to be a margician.
Mixtly: With mixture; in a mixed manner; mixedly.
Marlaceous: Resembling marl; partaking of the qualities of marl.
Merovingian: Of or pertaining to the first Frankish dynasty in Gaul or France.
Maksutov telescope: A type of reflecting telescope in which the aberration of the concave mirror is reduced by a meniscus lens.
microchemical: Of or pertaining to microchemistry; as, a micro-chemical test.
machilid: A wingless insect living in dark moist places, as under tree trunks; they make erratic leaps when disturbed; called also jumping bristletail.
maned wolf: A reddish-gray wolf (Canis rufus or Canis niger) of Southwestern North America.
Mooress: A female Moor; a Moorish woman.
man-made fiber: A fiber created from natural materials or by chemical processes.
Metachronism: An error committed in chronology by placing an event after its real time.
macon: A fine Burgundy wine usually white and dry, produced in the area around Macon, a city in France.
Monembryony: The condition of an ovule having but a single embryo.
Methylal: A light, volatile liquid, H2C(OCH3)2, regarded as a complex ether, and having a pleasant ethereal odor. It is obtained by the partial oxidation of methyl alcohol.  Called also formal.
Minerva: The goddess of wisdom, of war, of the arts and sciences, of poetry, and of spinning and weaving; -- identified with the Grecian Pallas Athene.
mendelevium: an unstable radioactive element discovered in 1955 and produced artificially only in very small quantities; symbol Md (also Mv).  It is a transuranic element with atomic number 101.  Isotopes 255, 256, 257, and 258 have been prepared.  Md258, the longest-lived, has a half-life of two months.
Meander: To wind or turn in a course or passage; to be intricate.
&Verbar;Mucro: A minute abrupt point, as of a leaf; any small, sharp point or process, terminating a larger part or organ.
Mozetta: A cape, with a small hood; -- worn by the pope and other dignitaries of the Roman Catholic Church.
Mishna: A collection or digest of Jewish traditions and explanations of Scripture, forming the text of the Talmud.
Masterhood: The state of being a master; hence, disposition to command or hector.
Malversation: Evil conduct; fraudulent practices; misbehavior, corruption, or extortion in office.
marble cake: A made of light and dark batter very lightly blended, so as to produce a variegated appearance resembling that of marble.
Mistime: To time wrongly; not to adapt to the time.
Maturative: A remedy promoting maturation; a maturant.
modulator-demodulator: An electronic device that converts electronic signals into sound waves, and sound waves into electronic signals, used to transmit information between computers by the use of ordinary telephone lines; usually called a modem.
Marginicidal: Dehiscent by the separation of united carpels; -- said of fruits.
marijuana: A strong-smelling Asian plant (Cannabis sativa), also called hemp, from which a number of euphorogenic and halucinogenic drugs are prepared.  The euphoric effect is predominently due to tetrahydrocannabinol (THC).
&Verbar;Malambo: A yellowish aromatic bark, used in medicine and perfumery, said to be from the South American shrub Croton Malambo.
&Verbar;Myocardium: The main substance of the muscular wall of the heart inclosed between the epicardium and endocardium.
Macrencephalic: Of or pertaining to macrencephaly; having a large brain.
&Verbar;Maestoso: Majestic or majestically; -- a direction to perform a passage or piece of music in a dignified manner.
Mercaptide: A compound of mercaptan formed by replacing its sulphur hydrogen by a metal; as, potassium mercaptide, C2H5SK.
Mome: A dull, silent person; a blockhead.
Mattowacca: An American clupeoid fish (Clupea mediocris), similar to the shad in habits and appearance, but smaller and less esteemed for food; -- called also hickory shad, tailor shad, fall herring, and shad herring.
Mimir: A giant who guarded the well of wisdom.
Mesquite bean: The pod or seed of the mesquite.
Mimic: One who imitates or mimics, especially one who does so for sport; a copyist; a buffoon.
Moniliform: Joined or constricted, at regular intervals, so as to resemble a string of beads; as, a moniliform root; a moniliform antenna.  See Illust. of Antenna.
marconi rig: A rig of triangular sails for a yacht.
Multilobar: Consisting of, or having, many lobes.
Meridionally: In the direction of the meridian.
Midrib: A continuation of the petiole, extending from the base to the apex of the lamina of a leaf.
Magnetomotor: A voltaic series of two or more large plates, producing a great quantity of electricity of low tension, and hence adapted to the exhibition of electro-magnetic phenomena.
Mustela: The type genus of the family Mustelidae: minks and weasels.
MACHO: A form of dark matter in distant outer space unobservable except by its gravitational effect, and believed to be at least part of the “missing matter” which is unobservable as ordinary stars, but helps keep galaxies from flying apart; MACHOS are massive but compact objects such as neutron stars or brown dwarfs, which can be detected (with difficulty) by their effect in bending light from distant light sources, such as other galaxies.  This can occur if by rare chance a MACHO passes in front of a more distant visible object, and the light from that object becomes temporarily amplified by the MACHO acting as a gravitational lens.  Some MACHOs have been discovered in the halo of dark matter that surrounds our milky way.  It is, however, questionable whether the amount of such matter is sufficient to explain the ability of galaxies to stay together in spite of rotation rates that would cause them to fly apart if the only matter present was that observable as visible stars.
Minaret: A slender, lofty tower attached to a mosque and surrounded by one or more projecting balconies, from which the summon to prayer is cried by the muezzin.
Mufti: An official expounder of Mohammedan law.
mud-crab: A crab of the genus Panopœus (also written Panopeus).
&Verbar;Molossus: A foot of three long syllables.
Metantimonic: Pertaining to, or designating, an acid (formerly called antimonic acid) analogous to metaphosphoric acid, and obtained as a white amorphous insoluble substance, (HSbO3).
Marattia: The type genus of the Marattiaceae, consisting of ferns having the sporangia fused together in two rows.
munj: A tough Asiatic grass (Saccharum bengalense syn. Saccharum munja) whose culms are used for ropes and baskets.
Making-iron: A tool somewhat like a chisel with a groove in it, used by calkers of ships to finish the seams after the oakum has been driven in.
Myrtaceous: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, a large and important natural family of trees and shrubs (Myrtaceæ of the order Myrtales), of which the myrtle (Myrtus) is the type.  It includes the genera Eucalyptus, Pimenta, Lechythis, and about seventy more.
Manduca: A genus of moths whose larvae are hornworms.
Mammalian: Of or pertaining to the Mammalia or mammals.
Mentor: A wise and faithful counselor or monitor.
Maltose: A crystalline disaccharide (C12H22O11) formed from starch by the action of diastase of malt, and the amylolytic ferment of saliva and pancreatic juice; called also maltobiose and malt sugar.  Chemically it is 4-O-α-D-glucopyranosyl-D-glucose.  It rotates the plane of polarized light further to the right than does dextrose and possesses a lower cupric oxide reducing power.
Midway: In the middle of the way or distance; half way.
Mantic: Of or pertaining to divination, or to the condition of one inspired, or supposed to be inspired, by a deity; prophetic.
&Verbar;Modus: The arrangement of, or mode of expressing, the terms of a contract or conveyance.
Metheglin: A fermented beverage made of honey and water; mead.
major power: A nation powerful enough to influence events throughout the world.
&Verbar;Microsporangium: A sporangium or conceptacle containing only very minute spores.  Cf. Macrosporangium.
milline: an advertising measure; one agate line appearing in one million copies of a publication.
Mouthpiece: The part of a musical or other instrument to which the mouth is applied in using it; as, the mouthpiece of a bugle, or of a tobacco pipe.
Mousehole: A hole made by a mouse, for passage or abode, as in a wall; hence, a very small hole like that gnawed by a mouse.
Mastodontic: Pertaining to, or resembling, a mastodon; as, mastodontic dimensions.
Miraculize: To cause to seem to be a miracle.
Metabolism: The act or process, by which living tissues or cells take up and convert into their own proper substance the nutritive material brought to them by the blood, or by which they transform their cell protoplasm into simpler substances, which are fitted either for excretion or for some special purpose, as in the manufacture of the digestive enzymes.  Hence, metabolism may be either constructive (anabolism), or destructive (catabolism).
Monastery: A house of religious retirement, or of secusion from ordinary temporal concerns, especially for monks; -- more rarely applied to such a house for females.
Moneyage: A tax paid to the first two Norman kings of England to prevent them from debashing the coin.
Monition: Instruction or advice given by way of caution; an admonition; a warning; a caution.
Marlstone: A sandy calcareous straum, containing, or impregnated with, iron, and lying between the upper and lower Lias of England.
Magna Mater: A great nature goddess of ancient Phrygia in Asia Minor; the counterpart of the Greek Rhea and the Roman Ops.
Manucode: Any bird of the genus Manucodia, of Australia and New Guinea.  They are related to the bird of paradise.
millpond: a pond formed by damming a stream to provide a head of water to turn a mill wheel.
&Verbar;Mucor: A genus of minute fungi.  The plants consist of slender threads with terminal globular sporangia; mold.
Meedful: Worthy of meed, reward, or recompense; meritorious.
Macle: Chiastolite; -- so called from the tessellated appearance of a cross section. See Chiastolite.
Milliweber: The thousandth part of one weber.
Millennianism: Belief in, or expectation of, the millennium{2}; millenarianism.
Murrhine: Made of the stone or material called by the Romans murrha; -- applied to certain costly vases of great beauty and delicacy used by the luxurious in Rome as wine cups; as, murrhine vases, cups, vessels.
Modeling: The act or art of making a model from which a work of art is to be executed; the formation of a work of art from some plastic material. Also, in painting, drawing, etc., the expression or indication of solid form.
Mustaiba: A close-grained, heavy wood of a brownish color, brought from Brazil, and used in turning, for making the handles of tools, and the like.
Misspend: To spend amiss or for wrong purposes; to squander; to waste; as, to misspend time or money.
-meister: A suffix denoting master or professional practitioner, as in spinmeister or hypemeister.
Melodious: Containing, or producing, melody; musical; agreeable to the ear by a sweet succession of sounds; as, a melodious voice.
Mesonasal: Of or pertaining to the middle portion of the nasal region.
malposed tooth: A tooth that has grown in a faulty position.
Midweek: The middle of the week. Also used adjectively.
Myomancy: Divination by the movements of mice.
M\u00f6bius strip: A mathematical object, or a physical representation of it, which is a two-dimensional sheet with only one surface.  It is constructed or visualized as a rectangle, one end of which is held fixed while the opposite end is twisted through a 180 degree angle and joined to the fixed end.  It is a two-dimensional object that can only exist in a three-dimensional space.
Moresque: Of or pertaining to, or in the manner or style of, the Moors; Moorish.
&Verbar;Melissa: A genus of labiate herbs, including the balm, or bee balm (Melissa officinalis).
Monoclinous: Hermaphrodite, or having both stamens and pistils in every flower.
macadamia: any tree of the genus Macadamia, especially Macadamia ternifolia.
Monovalent: Having a valence of one; univalent. See Univalent.
Microcoustic: An instrument for making faint sounds audible, as to a partially deaf person.
Mondays Child: A child who is fair of face; -- a reference to a nineteenth century poem.  See below.
Mercators chart: See under Chart, and see Mercator's projection, under Projection.
Manich\u00e6an: Of or pertaining to the Manichæans.
&Verbar;Mesenteron: All that part of the alimentary canal which is developed from the primitive enteron and is lined with hypoblast. It is distinguished from the stomodæum, a part at the anterior end of the canal, including the cavity of the mouth, and the proctodæum, a part at the posterior end, which are formed by invagination and are lined with epiblast.
myo-: A combining form of Gr. &unr_;, &unr_;, a muscle; as, myograph, myochrome.
motorcade: a procession of people traveling in motor cars.
&Verbar;Mastodonsaurus: A large extinct genus of labyrinthodonts, found in the European Triassic rocks.
mortgaged: burdened with legal or financial obligations; as, His house was mortgaged to the hilt.
macro: very large in scale or scope or capability; as, macroeconomics.
markup: The amount added to the cost to determine the asking price.
Micrometer: An instrument, used with a telescope or microscope, for measuring minute distances, or the apparent diameters of objects which subtend minute angles.  The measurement given directly is that of the image of the object formed at the focus of the object glass.
malope: A Western Mediterranean annual (Malope trifida) having deep purple-red flowers subtended by three large cordate bracts.
Matterless: Not being, or having, matter; as, matterless spirits.
Molybdic: Of, pertaining to, or containing, molybdenum; specif., designating those compounds in which the element has a higher valence, as contrasted with molybdous compounds; as, molybdic oxide.
Misinterpretable: Capable of being misinterpreted; liable to be misunderstood.
&Verbar;Moto: Movement; manner of movement; particularly, movement with increased rapidity; -- used especially in the phrase con moto, directing to a somewhat quicker movement; as, andante con moto, a little more rapidly than andante, etc.
Merciless: Destitute of mercy; cruel; unsparing; -- said of animate beings, and also, figuratively, of things; as, a merciless tyrant; merciless waves.
memsahib: Lady; mistress; -- used by Hindustani-speaking natives in India in addressing European women.
Microzyme: A microörganism which is supposed to act like a ferment in causing or propagating certain infectious or contagious diseases; a pathogenic bacterial organism.
Merce: To subject to fine or amercement; to mulct; to amerce.
Metergram: A measure of energy or work done; the power exerted in raising one gram through the distance of one meter against gravitation; 100 gram-centimeters.
mol: A quantity of a substance equal to the molecular weight of a substance expressed in grams; a gram molecule; the basic unit of amount of substance adopted under the System International d'Unites; as, he added two mols of dextrose to the medium.
Mangosteen: A tree of the East Indies of the genus Garcinia (Garcinia Mangostana) with thick leathery leaves.  The tree grows to the height of eighteen feet, and bears fruit also called mangosteen, of the size of a small apple, the pulp of which is very delicious food.
Microphthalmia: An unnatural smallness of the eyes, occurring as the result of disease or of imperfect development.
militarize: to lend a military character to (a country), as by building up a military force.
Monocracy: Government by a single person; undivided rule.
macrobiotic diet: A diet consisting chiefly of beans and whole grains.
Moreover: Beyond what has been said; further; besides; in addition; furthermore; also; likewise.
Meteorous: Of the nature or appearance of a meteor.
Monosulphide: A sulphide containing one atom of sulphur, and analogous to a monoxide; -- contrasted with a polysulphide; as, galena is a monosulphide.
matching: having identical or closely similar appearance or properties; as, a pair of matching candlesticks.
Misogynous: Hating women; having deep-seated distrust of women; -- used of men.
Men: A man; one; -- used with a verb in the singular, and corresponding to the present indefinite one or they.
mousetrap: Any device that catches, and usually kills, mice.  They are of various designs, the most common being a stiff loop of wire mounted on a small wooden platform base and attached to a strong spring, which holds the loop firmly against the base.  To activate the trap, the loop is pulled through a 180° arc against the tension of the spring and held against the base by a delicate metal catch, which can keep the loop from moving, though in a state of high tension.  The metal catch is moved when a mouse tries to take a piece of bait attached to it, releasing the loop which forcefully moves though an arc, usually killing the mouse.  A larger version of the same device is used as a rat trap.
Met: p. p. of Mete, to dream.
Mew: The common cry of a cat.
mitrewort: Any of various rhizomatous perennial herbs of the genus Mitella having a capsule resembling a bishop's miter.
&Verbar;Meson: The mesial plane dividing the body of an animal into similar right and left halves. The line in which it meets the dorsal surface has been called the dorsimeson, and the corresponding ventral edge the ventrimeson.
Melic grass: A genus of grasses (Melica) of little agricultural importance.
manufactured: Produced in a large-scale industrial operation.  Contrasted with hand-made.
&Verbar;Merostomata: A class of Arthropoda, allied to the Crustacea.  It includes the trilobites, Eurypteroidea, and Limuloidea.  All are extinct except the horseshoe crabs (Limulus) of the last group. See Limulus.
monogamousness: The state of being monogamous; having one wife at a time.
M-Naught: To increase the power of (a single-cylinder beam engine) by adding a small high-pressure cylinder with a piston acting on the beam between the center and the flywheel end, using high-pressure steam and working as a compound engine, -- a plan introduced by M'Naught, a Scottish engineer, in 1845.
Mortmain: Possession of lands or tenements in, or conveyance to, dead hands, or hands that cannot alienate.
Maximization: The act or process of increasing to the highest degree.
Moline: The crossed iron that supports the upper millstone by resting on the spindle; a millrind.
Medi\u00e6vally: In the manner of the Middle Ages; in accordance with mediævalism.
Mestee: The offspring of a white person and a quadroon; -- so called in the West Indies.
Maintenance: The act of maintaining; sustenance; support; defense; vindication.
main office: The office that serves as the administrative center of an enterprise,
Modalist: One who regards Father, Son, and Spirit as modes of being, and not as persons, thus denying personal distinction in the Trinity.
matin\u00e9e: A reception, or a musical or dramatic entertainment, held in the daytime. See SoirÉe.
Misincline: To cause to have a wrong inclination or tendency; to affect wrongly.
Mordant: To subject to the action of, or imbue with, a mordant; as, to mordant goods for dyeing.
Macedonian: One of a certain religious sect, followers of Macedonius, Bishop of Constantinople, in the fourth century, who held that the Holy Ghost was a creature, like the angels, and a servant of the Father and the Son.
money-spinner: a project that generates a continuous flow of money.
melatonin: A hormone secreted by the pineal gland.  Chemically it is N-acety-5-methoxytryptamine.  Research has indicated that there are daily rhythms in secretion of melatonin, in particular due to the depressing effect on melatonin production by light received by the retina.  Conversely it appears that melatonin may influence the circadian rhythms of animals.  There is some experimental evidence that administration of melatonin may increase the amount of sleep in people with sleep disorders.  However, the evidence is not convincing and the effect is not profound.  Nevertheless, the deregulation of melatonin and its availability over-the-counter has led to many people taking melatonin to help sleep, without consulting a physician.
Migrant: A migratory bird, person, or other animal.
Metaldehyde: A white crystalline substance isomeric with, and obtained from, acetic aldehyde by polymerization, and reconvertible into the same.
Mucoid: One of a class of mucinlike substances yielding on decomposition a reducing carbohydrate together with some form of proteinaceous matter.
Mannerliness: The quality or state of being mannerly; civility; complaisance.
Multivocal: Signifying many different things; of manifold meaning; equivocal.
Masorite: One of the writers of the Masora.
Music drama: An opera in which the text and action are not interrupted by set arias, duets, etc., the music being determined throughout by dramatic appropriateness; musical drama of this character, in general.  It involves the use of a kind of melodious declamation, the development of leitmotif, great orchestral elaboration, and a fusion of poetry, music, action, and scene into an organic whole.  The term is applied esp. to the later works of Wagner: “Tristan und Isolde,” “Die Meistersinger,” “Rheingold,” “Walküre,” “Siegfried,” “Götterdämmerung,” and “Parsifal.”
Microcrystalline: Crystalline on a fine, or microscopic, scale; consisting of fine crystals; as, the ground mass of certain porphyrics is microcrystalline.
Marxism-Leninism: Marxism, as interpreted by V. I. Lenin.
Mythologize: To relate, classify, and explain, or attempt to explain, myths; to write upon myths.
&Verbar;Metastoma: A median elevation behind the mouth in the arthropods.
Meteorolite: A meteoric stone; an aërolite; a meteorite.
Major: An officer next in rank above a captain and next below a lieutenant colonel; the lowest field officer.
&Verbar;Medius: The third or middle finger; the third digit, or that which corresponds to it.
mammothrept: A child brought up by its grandmother; a spoiled child.
Metasome: One of the component segments of the body of an animal.
Myristic: Pertaining to, or derived from, the nutmeg (Myristica).  Specifically, designating an acid (C14H28O2) found in nutmeg oil and otoba fat, and extracted as a white crystalline waxy substance.
Madwort: A genus of cruciferous plants (Alyssum) with white or yellow flowers and rounded pods. Alyssum maritimum is the commonly cultivated sweet alyssum, a fragrant white-flowered annual.
Myristin: The myristate of glycerin, -- found as a vegetable fat in nutmeg butter, etc.
Mandarinate: The collective body of officials or persons of rank in China.
molecular formula: An expression representing the composition of elements in a chemical substance, commonly consisting of a series of letters and numbers comprising the atomic symbols of each element present in a compound followed by the number of atoms of that element present in one molecule of the substance.  Thus the molecular formula for common alcohol (ethyl alcohol) is C2H6O, meaning that each molecule contains two carbon atoms, six hydrogen atoms, and one oxygen atom.  The molecular formula may be written to provide some indication of the actual structure of the molecule, in which case structural units may be written separately.  Thus, ethyl alcohol can also be written as CH3.CH2.OH or CH3-CH2-OH, in which the period or dash between functional groups indicates a single bond between the principle atoms of each group.  This formula shows that in ethyl alcohol, the carbon of a methyl group (CH3-) is attached to the carbon of a methylene group (-CH2-), which is attached to the oxygen of a hydroxyl group (-OH).  A structural formula is a graphical depiction of the relative positions of atoms in a molecule, and may be very complicated.
Microseismograph: A microseismometer; specif., a microseismometer producing a graphic record.
Mood: Temper of mind; temporary state of the mind in regard to passion or feeling; humor; as, a melancholy mood; a suppliant mood.
Moon: To act if moonstruck; to wander or gaze about in an abstracted manner.
Misprofess: To make a false profession of.
Moor: To cast anchor; to become fast.
Moot: Subject, or open, to argument or discussion; undecided; debatable; mooted.
Mishandle: To handle ill or wrongly; to maltreat.
M-1: A semiautomatic rifle which was standard issue to infantrymen in the United States Army in the mid-20th century.
Monks seam: An extra middle seam made at the junction of two breadths of canvas, ordinarily joined by only two rows of stitches.
Montre: A stop, usually the open diapason, having its pipes “shown” as part of the organ case, or otherwise specially mounted.
Marechal Niel: A kind of large yellow rose.
Multifariously: With great multiplicity and diversity; with variety of modes and relations.
Maravedi: A small copper coin of Spain, equal to three mils American money, less than a farthing sterling.  Also, an ancient Spanish gold coin.
Meroblast: An ovum, as that of a mammal, only partially composed of germinal matter, that is, consisting of both a germinal portion and an albuminous or nutritive one; -- opposed to holoblast.
monestrous: Having only one estrus period per breeding cycle or per year; -- of certain mammals.
map maker: A person who makes maps; a cartographer.
Melene: An unsaturated hydrocarbon, C30H60, of the ethylene series, obtained from beeswax as a white, scaly, crystalline wax; -- called also melissene, and melissylene.
Mossy: Overgrown with moss; abounding with or edged with moss; as, mossy trees; mossy streams.
Millstone: One of two circular stones used for grinding grain or other substance in a mill{1}.
Magnifico: A grandee or nobleman of Venice; -- so called in courtesy.
moneylender: someone who lends money at excessive rates of interest.
Mucopurulent: Having the character or appearance of both mucus and pus.
Mitotic: Of or pertaining to mitosis; karyokinetic; as, mitotic cell division; -- opposed to amitotic.
main-topmast: the mast next above the mainmast.
Memorial rose: A Japanese evergreen rose (Rosa wichuraiana) with creeping branches, shining leaves, and single white flowers. It is often planted in cemeteries.
Manichord: The clavichord or clarichord; -- called also dumb spinet.
Muffler: Anything used in muffling; esp., a scarf for protecting the head and neck in cold weather; a tippet.
Minute-jack: A figure which strikes the hour on the bell of some fanciful clocks; -- called also jack of the clock house.
Multifid: Having many segments; cleft into several parts by linear sinuses; as, a multifid leaf or corolla.
malaria: Air infected with some noxious substance capable of engendering disease; esp., an unhealthy exhalation from certain soils, as marshy or wet lands, producing fevers; miasma.
Metal: To cover with metal; as, to metal a ship's bottom; to metal a road.
&Verbar;Myopsis: The appearance of muscæ volitantes. See Muscæ volitantes, under Musca.
medick: Any of several Old World herbs of the genus Medicago having small flowers and trifoliate compound leaves.
maraschino cherry: A cherry which is colored a deep red and sweetened by cooking in colored syrup, and flavored with maraschino.  It is used as a garnish in deserts and cocktails.
Mummichog: Any one of several species of small American cyprinodont fishes of the genus Fundulus, and of allied genera; the killifishes; -- called also minnow.
midweekly: occurring during the middle of the week; as, a midweekly prayer meeting.
Mastful: Abounding in mast; producing mast in abundance; as, the mastful forest; a mastful chestnut.
Mucocele: An enlargement or protrusion of the mucous membrane of the lachrymal passages, or dropsy of the lachrymal sac, dependent upon catarrhal inflammation of the latter.
Macaroni: Long slender tubes made of a paste chiefly of a wheat flour such as semolina, and used as an article of food; a form of Italian pasta.
Mimicry: The act or practice of one who mimics; ludicrous imitation for sport or ridicule.
Magnolia State: The state of Mississippi; -- a nickname.
Melissic: Pertaining to, or derived from, beeswax; specif., denoting an acid obtained by oxidation of myricin.
Mechanograph: One of a number of copies of anything multiplied mechanically.
Mitigable: Admitting of mitigation; that may be mitigated.
Morass: A tract of soft, wet ground; a marsh; a fen.
Monogenesis: Oneness of origin; esp. (Biol.), development of all beings in the universe from a single cell; -- opposed to polygenesis. Called also monism.
Muffin: A light, spongy, cylindrical cake, used for breakfast and tea.
Minotaur: A fabled monster, half man and half bull, confined in the labyrinth constructed by Dædalus in Crete.
Metrotome: An instrument for cutting or scarifying the uterus or the neck of the uterus.
milliammeter: a sensitive ammeter for detecting small currents, graduated in milliamperes.
Marrowish: Of the nature of, or like, marrow.
Metrotomy: The operation of cutting into the uterus; hysterotomy; the Cæsarean section.
Muzziness: The state or quality of being muzzy.
Magnase black: A black pigment which dries rapidly when mixed with oil, and is of intense body.
Matthiola: A genus of Old World plants grown as ornamentals.
Meaning: That which is meant or intended; intent; purpose; aim; object; as, a mischievous meaning was apparent.
Muddler: One who, or that which, muddles.
Misconstrue: To construe wrongly; to interpret erroneously.
Mavis: The European throstle or song thrush (Turdus musicus).
Marplot: One who, by his officious interference, mars or frustrates a design or plot.
Medley: Mixed; of mixed material or color.
Megavolt: One of the larger measures of electro-motive force, amounting to one million volts.
Muricate: Formed with sharp points; full of sharp points or of pickles; covered, or roughened, as a surface, with sharp points or excrescences.
maltese cat: A short-haired bluish-gray breed of the domestic cat.
Muscular: Of or pertaining to a muscle, or to a system of muscles; consisting of, or constituting, a muscle or muscles; as, muscular fiber.
&Verbar;Mollah: One of the higher order of Turkish; also, a Turkish title of respect for a religious and learned man.
Marriageability: The quality or state of being marriageable.
myrmecophile: An organism such as an insect that habitually shares the nest of a species of ant.
mainstreamed: Placed in regular school classes; -- of the handicapped.
Melain: The dark coloring matter of the liquid of the cuttlefish.
maternalistic: showing maternal instincts; behaving as a mother should; motherly.
&Verbar;Metanephros: The most posterior of the three pairs of embryonic renal organs developed in many vertebrates.
Micronesians: A dark race inhabiting the Micronesian Islands. They are supposed to be a mixed race, derived from Polynesians and Papuans.
