Minie ball: A conical rifle bullet, with a cavity in its base plugged with a piece of iron, which, by the explosion of the charge, is driven farther in, expanding the sides to fit closely the grooves of the barrel.
&Verbar;Mytilus: A genus of marine bivalve shells, including the common mussel. See Illust. under Byssus.
Microcosmography: Description of man as a microcosm.
Margarous: Margaric; -- formerly designating a supposed acid.
&Verbar;Mantra: A prayer; an invocation; a religious formula; a charm.
Monarchizer: One who monarchizes; also, a monarchist.
magnetic equator: An imaginary line paralleling the equator where a magnetic needle has no dip, the dipping needle being horizontal; called also aclinic line.
Medium: Having a middle position or degree; mean; intermediate; medial; as, a horse of medium size; a decoction of medium strength.
Miry: Abounding with deep mud; full of mire; muddy; as, a miry road.
Macroprism: A prism of an orthorhombic crystal between the macropinacoid and the unit prism; the corresponding pyramids are called macropyramids.
Malvaceous: Pertaining to, or resembling, a natural family of plants (Malvaceæ), of which the mallow is the type.  The cotton plant, hollyhock, and abutilon are of this family.  It was formerly classified as an order, and included the baobab and the silk-cotton trees.  The baobab and silk-cotton trees are now placed in the family Bombacaceae, which is included with the Malvaceae in the order Malvales.
Muster: To be gathered together for parade, inspection, exercise, or the like; to come together as parts of a force or body; as, his supporters mustered in force.
Man-eater: One who, or that which, has an appetite for human flesh; specifically, one of certain large sharks (esp. Carcharodon carcharias syn. Carcharodon Rondeleti); also, a lion or a tiger which has acquired the habit of feeding upon human flesh.
Moon shot: The action or event of sending a spacecraft to the moon; -- used of manned or unmanned missions.
Myxine: A genus of marsipobranchs, including the hagfish. See Hag, 4.
Monographic: Of or pertaining to a monograph, or to a monography; as, a monographic writing; a monographic picture.
Misdate: To put a false or erroneous date on (a document).
Manner: Mode of action; way of performing or effecting anything; method; style; form; fashion.
McKinley: Mount McKinley, the highest peak in North America; 20,300 feet high; also called by the native name Denali.
Milk vetch: A leguminous herb (Astragalus glycyphyllos) of Europe and Asia, supposed to increase the secretion of milk in goats.
Molotov cocktail: A home-made incendiary device consisting of a bottle filled with gasoline, and a cloth wick.  The wick is lighted, and the bottle thrown at a target, such as a vehicle, where it may shatter and spread intense flames over the vehicle, destroying or damaging it.
make-belief: A feigning to believe; make believe.
Mangcorn: A mixture of wheat and rye, or other species of grain.
Maturely: In a mature manner; with ripeness; completely.
&Verbar;Madia: A genus of composite plants, of which one species (Madia sativa) is cultivated for the oil yielded from its seeds by pressure.  This oil is sometimes used instead of olive oil for the table.
Mediostapedial: Pertaining to that part of the columella of the ear which, in some animals, connects the stapes with the other parts of the columella.
Mercurammonium: A radical regarded as derived from ammonium by the substitution of mercury for a portion of the hydrogen.
Misconstruct: To construct wrongly; to construe or interpret erroneously.
Misalliance: A marriage with a person of inferior rank or social station; an improper alliance; a mesalliance.
Medullary: Pertaining to, consisting of, or resembling, marrow or medulla.
Monostichous: Arranged in a single row on one side of an axis, as the flowers in grasses of the tribe Chloridæ.
Mitten: A covering for the hand, worn to defend it from cold or injury.  It differs from a glove in not having a separate sheath for each finger.
Maculose: Of or pertaining to spots upon a surface; spotted; maculate.
Magdala: Designating an orange-red dyestuff obtained from naphthylamine, and called magdala red, naphthalene red, etc.
Manito: A name given by tribes of American Indians to a great spirit, whether good or evil, or to any object of worship.
Moderately: In a moderate manner or degree; to a moderate extent.
Misapply: To apply wrongly; to use for a wrong purpose; as, to misapply a name or title; to misapply public money.
Monish: To admonish; to warn. See Admonish.
Mercurify: To obtain mercury from, as mercuric minerals, which may be done by any application of intense heat that expels the mercury in fumes, which are afterward condensed.
Melastomaceous: Belonging to the order of which Melastoma is the type.
Monism: That doctrine which refers all phenomena to a single ultimate constituent or agent; -- the opposite of dualism.
Madefaction: The act of madefying, or making wet; the state of that which is made wet.
Misconfident: Having a mistaken confidence; wrongly trusting.
Metagraphy: The art or act of rendering the letters of the alphabet of one language into the possible equivalents of another; transliteration.
Multigranulate: Having, or consisting of, many grains.
Municipally: In a municipal relation or condition.
&Verbar;Malleolus: A projection at the distal end of each bone of the leg at the ankle joint. The malleolus of the tibia is the internal projection, that of the fibula the external.
Magian: One of the Magi, or priests of the Zoroastrian religion in Persia; an adherent of the Zoroastrian religion.
Marikina: A small marmoset (Midas rosalia); the silky tamarin.
motherlike: suggestive of or acting like a mother; motherly; maternal.
Microscopal: Pertaining to microscopy, or to the use of the microscope.
Melursus: A genus of mammals including the sloth bears; in some classifications not a separate genus from Ursus.
Monopsychism: The doctrine that there is but one immortal soul or intellect with which all men are endowed.
&Verbar;Missa: The service or sacrifice of the Mass.
Mammuthus primigenius: The species name for the woolly mammoth, a very hairy mammoth common in colder portions of the Northern hemisphere.
Midgard: The middle space or region between heaven and hell, the abode of human beings; the earth.
Mellifluent: Flowing as with honey; smooth; mellifluous.
Multisect: Divided into many similar segments; -- said of an insect or myriapod.
malignant: Disposed to do harm, inflict suffering, or cause distress; actuated by extreme malevolence or enmity; virulently inimical; bent on evil; malicious.
Maltonic: Of, pertaining to, or derived from, maltose; specif., designating an acid called also gluconic or dextronic acid. See Gluconic.
Mortifiedness: The state of being mortified; humiliation; subjection of the passions.
merged: formed or united into a whole; -- of formerly separate objects, groups, etc.
manna ash: A South Mediterranean ash (Fraxinus ornus) having fragrant white flowers in dense panicles and yielding manna.
Magic: Pertaining to the hidden wisdom supposed to be possessed by the Magi; relating to the occult powers of nature, and the producing of effects by their agency.
Melodics: The branch of musical science which treats of the pitch of tones, and of the laws of melody.
Monothelite: One of an ancient sect who held that Christ had but one will as he had but one nature.  Cf. Monophysite.
Manifold: To take copies of by the process of manifold writing; as, to manifold a letter.
Mariput: A species of civet; the zoril.
Melchite: One of a sect, chiefly in Syria and Egypt, which acknowledges the authority of the pope, but adheres to the liturgy and ceremonies of the Eastern Church.
Misimprove: To use for a bad purpose; to abuse; to misuse; as, to misimprove time, talents, advantages, etc.
&Verbar;Micrococcus: A genus of Spherobacteria, in the form of very small globular or oval cells, forming, by transverse division, filaments, or chains of cells, or in some cases single organisms shaped like dumb-bells (Diplococcus), all without the power of motion. See Illust. of Ascoccus.
mouthwash: a medicated solution used for gargling and rinsing the mouth.
Moan: A low prolonged sound, articulate or not, indicative of pain or of grief; a low groan.
Morse: A clasp for fastening garments in front.
Metallurgy: The art of working metals, comprehending the whole process of separating them from other matters in the ore, smelting, refining, and parting them; sometimes, in a narrower sense, only the process of extracting metals from their ores.
&Verbar;Marcor: A wasting away of flesh; decay.
Mysidacea: An order of crustaceans including the opossum shrimp.
Mouse-ear: The forget-me-not (Myosotis palustris) and other species of the same genus.
Manganic: Of, pertaining to resembling, or containing, manganese; specif., designating compounds in which manganese has a higher valence as contrasted with manganous compounds.  Cf. Manganous.
Matico: A Peruvian plant (Piperelongatum or Artanthe elongatum), allied to the pepper, the leaves of which are used as a styptic and astringent.
Monopoly: The exclusive power, or privilege of selling a commodity; the exclusive power, right, or privilege of dealing in some article, or of trading in some market; sole command of the traffic in anything, however obtained; as, the proprietor of a patented article is given a monopoly of its sale for a limited time; chartered trading companies have sometimes had a monopoly of trade with remote regions; a combination of traders may get a monopoly of a particular product.
mailbox: A public box for deposit of mail, where it is later picked up by the postal authority for delivery.
Maker: One who makes, forms, or molds; a manufacturer; specifically, the Creator.
Mentzelia: A genus of bristly herbs or subshrubs of Western America lacking stinging hairs.
Megalobatrachus: A genus of giant salamanders; in some classifications included in the genus Cryptobranchus.
minus: A factor counted as a disadvantage; a loss or potential loss in a situation or plan; as, he added up all the pluses and minuses and decided not to do it; as, the lack of money is a big minus in an election campaign.
Moonseed: A climbing plant of the genus Menispermum; -- so called from the crescentlike form of the seeds.
meadowgrass: Any of various grasses that thrive in the presence of abundant moisture, especially those of the genus Poa, common in meadows, and of great value for hay and for pasture. See Grass.
Metempiricism: The science that is concerned with metempirics.
Margent: To enter or note down upon the margin of a page; to margin.
Mountainousness: The state or quality of being mountainous.
Motorman: A man who controls a motor.
man Friday: A person who contributes to the fulfillment of a need or furtherance of an effort or purpose; a devoted assistant.
Monothalaman: A foraminifer having but one chamber.
minesweeper: A boat designed for the purpose of detecting and disposing of marine mines.
Mephitinae: A subfamily of mammals including the skunks; it is a subdivision not used in some classifications.
Monopetalous: Having only one petal, or the corolla in one piece, or composed of petals cohering so as to form a tube or bowl; gamopetalous.
Malcolm stock: Any of various ornamental flowering plants of the genus Malcolmia.
Moot-hall: A hall for public meetings; a hall of judgment.
monosodium glutamate: The monosodium salt of the natural amino acid L-glutamine (C5H8NNaO4), used as a food additive to enhance flavor; abbreviated MSG.  It is usually marketed as the monhydrate (C5H8NNaO4.H2O). It is commmonly used in Chinese-American restaurants, and has been identified as a main cause of Chinese restaurant syndrome.
Mechanicalness: The state or quality of being mechanical.
Mithra: The sun god of the ancient Persians; the god of light and truth.
Marconigram: same as radiogram; a wireless message.
moreen: A thick woolen fabric, watered or with embossed figures; -- used in upholstery, for curtains, etc.
Myope: A person having myopia; a myops.
Mucousness: The quality or state of being mucous; sliminess.
magnus hitch: A rolling hitch similar to a clove hitch.
mahimahi: either of two large slender food and game fish (Coryphaena equisetis or Coryphaena hippurus) of warm waters.  They are highly esteemed as food fish, especially in Hawaii.  See also dolphin{2}.
&Verbar;Mantis: Any one of numerous species of voracious orthopterous insects of the genus Mantis, and allied genera. They are  predacious long-bodied large-eyed insects of warm regions, are remarkable for their slender grotesque forms, and for holding their stout anterior legs in a manner suggesting hands folded in prayer. The common American species is Mantis Carolina.
moralistic: narrowly and conventionally moral; -- of people.
Monkhood: The character or condition of a monk.
Misalter: To alter wrongly; esp., to alter for the worse.
Ministerialist: A supporter of the ministers, or the party in power.
migraine: A kind of intense sick or nervous headache, usually periodical and confined to one side of the head; called also migraine headache.  Same as megrim.
Mythopoetic: Making or producing myths or mythical tales.
Minutely: At intervals of a minute; very often and regularly.
Multiplicate: Consisting of many, or of more than one; multiple; multifold.
Monograph: A written account or description of a single thing, or class of things; a special treatise on a particular subject of limited range.
Many-sided: Having many sides; -- said of figures. Hence, presenting many questions or subjects for consideration; as, a many-sided topic.
&Verbar;Melanosis: The morbid deposition of black matter, often of a malignant character, causing pigmented tumors.
Merrymake: To make merry; to be jolly; to feast.
M\u00fcllerian: Of, pertaining to, or discovered by, Johannes Müller.
Metric ton: A weight of 1,000 kilograms, or 2,204.6 pounds avoirdupois.
Melaniline: A complex nitrogenous hydrocarbon obtained artificially (as by the action of cyanogen chloride on aniline) as a white, crystalline substance; -- called also diphenyl guanidin.
Myrmecophaga: The type genus of the Myrmecophagidae; the South American ant bear.
&Verbar;Mouillation: The act of uttering the sound of a mouillé letter.
Murenger: One who had charge of the wall of a town, or its repairs.
Momotus: The type genus of the Momotidae.
major leaguer: A member of a major-league baseball team.
Married: Being in the state of matrimony; having a spouse; wedded; as, a married man or woman; -- of one person.
Melanism: The character of having a high degree of pigmentation, as shown in dark skin, eyes, and hair.
Magnesium: A light silver-white metallic element of atomic number 12, malleable and ductile, quite permanent in dry air but tarnishing in moist air. It burns, forming (the oxide) magnesia, with the production of a blinding light (the so-called magnesium light) which is used in signaling, in pyrotechny, or in photography where a strong actinic illuminant is required. Its compounds occur abundantly, as in dolomite, talc, meerschaum, etc.  Symbol Mg.  Atomic weight, 24.305.  Specific gravity, 1.75.
Melanconiales: The smallest of the three orders of Fungi Imperfecti, including those with no asci nor pycnidia, but as a rule having the spores in cavities without special walls.  They cause many of the plant diseases known as anthracnose.
Mosstrooper: One of a class of marauders or bandits that formerly infested the border country between England and Scotland; -- so called in allusion to the mossy or boggy character of much of the border country.
&Verbar;Madame: My lady; -- a French title formerly given to ladies of quality; now, in France, given to all married women.
Mesoseme: Having a medium orbital index; having orbits neither broad nor narrow; between megaseme and microseme.
Mudhole: A hole, or hollow place, containing mud, as in a road.
Milkmaid: A woman who milks cows or is employed in the dairy.
Management: The act or art of managing; the manner of treating, directing, carrying on, or using, for a purpose; conduct; administration; guidance; control; as, the management of a family or of a farm; the management of a business enterprise; the management of state affairs.
Mallet: A small maul with a short handle, -- used esp. for driving a tool, as a chisel or the like; also, a light beetle with a long handle, -- used in playing croquet.
Messenger: One who bears a message; the bearer of a verbal or written communication, notice, or invitation, from one person to another, or to a public body; specifically, an office servant who bears messages.
minefield: a region in which explosive mines{4} have been placed, especially a region on land.
Mechanographist: An artist who, by mechanical means, multiplies copies of works of art.
Monotheist: One who believes that there is but one God.
Monotonic: Of, pertaining to, or uttered in, a monotone; monotonous.
Modular: Of or pertaining to mode, modulation, module, or modius; as, modular arrangement; modular accent; modular measure.
Master vibrator: In an internal-combustion engine with two or more cylinders, an induction coil and vibrator placed in the circuit between the battery or magneto and the coils for the different cylinders, which are used without vibrators of their own.
metaphor: The transference of the relation between one set of objects to another set for the purpose of brief explanation; a compressed simile; e. g., the ship plows the sea.
Myography: The description of muscles, including the study of muscular contraction by the aid of registering apparatus, as by some form of myograph; myology.
Manure: To cultivate by manual labor; to till; hence, to develop by culture.
Moonlighter: One who follows an occupation or pastime by moonlight;
Mountebankism: The practices of a mountebank; mountebankery.
&Verbar;Matachin: An old dance with swords and bucklers; a sword dance.
Mountebankish: Like a mountebank or his quackery.
Megalesian: Pertaining to, or in honor of, Cybele; as, the Megalesian games at Rome.
Moonflower: The oxeye daisy; -- called also moon daisy.
Millennium: A period of one thousand years.
&Verbar;Ma: But; -- used in cautionary phrases; as, “Vivace, ma non troppo presto” (i. e., lively, but not too quick).
Moidore: A gold coin of Portugal, valued at about 27s. sterling.
&Verbar;Megalocephalia: The condition of having an abnormally large head; called also megacephaly.
Millepore: Any coral of the genus Millepora, having the surface nearly smooth, and perforated with very minute unequal pores, or cells. The animals are hydroids, not Anthozoa. See Hydrocorallia.
Mutilate: To cut off or remove a limb or essential part of; to maim; to cripple; to disfigure; to hack; as, to mutilate the body, a statue, etc.
Main-gauche: The dagger held in the left hand, while the rapier is held in the right; -- used to parry thrusts of the adversary's rapier.
Molar: Any one of the teeth back of the incisors and canines.  The molars which replace the deciduous or milk teeth are designated as premolars, and those which are not preceded by deciduous teeth are sometimes called true molars. See Tooth.
Myotomy: The dissection, or that part of anatomy which treats of the dissection, of muscles.
malonylurea: A white crystalline acid derived from pyrimidine; it is used in preparing barbiturate drugs.
Mangrove: The name of one or two trees of the genus Rhizophora (Rhizophora Mangle, and Rhizophora mucronata, the last doubtfully distinct) inhabiting muddy shores of tropical regions, where they spread by emitting aërial roots, which fasten in the saline mire and eventually become new stems. The seeds also send down a strong root while yet attached to the parent plant.
Muck rake: A rake for scraping up muck or dung. See Muckrake, v. i., below.
Medi\u00e6vals: The people who lived in the Middle Ages.
malvasia: A sweet grape used to make malmsey wine.
Matron: A wife or a widow, especially, one who has borne children; a woman of staid or motherly manners.
Monomorphic: Having but a single form; retaining the same form throughout the various stages of development; of the same or of an essentially similar type of structure; -- opposed to dimorphic, trimorphic, and polymorphic.
miniaturization: The act or process of making on a greatly reduced scale.
Minatorially: In a minatory manner; with threats.
Machaeranthera: A genus of wildflowers of Western North America.
maltese cross: A Eurasian garden perennial (Lychins chalcedonica) having scarlet flowers in dense terminal heads.
Masculinity: The state or quality of being masculine; masculineness.
Myeloidin: A substance, present in the protoplasm of the retinal epithelium cells, and resembling, if not identical with, the substance (myelin) forming the medullary sheaths of nerve fibers.
Mistic: A kind of small sailing vessel used in the Mediterranean.  It is rigged partly like a xebec, and partly like a felucca.
Map: To represent by a map; -- often with out; as, to survey and map, or map out, a county. Hence, figuratively: To represent or indicate systematically and clearly; to sketch; to plan; as, to map, or map out, a journey; to map out business.
Mar: A mark or blemish made by bruising, scratching, or the like; a disfigurement.
Mat: To grow thick together; to become interwoven or felted together like a mat, as hair when wetted with a sticky substance; as, a long-haired cat whose fur is matted.
May: The fifth month of the year, containing thirty-one days.
Mormon: Of or pertaining to the Mormons; as, the Mormon religion; Mormon practices.
Maccabean: Of or pertaining to Judas Maccabeus or to the Maccabees; as, the Maccabean princes; Maccabean times.
Maa: The common European gull (Larus canus); -- called also mar. See New, a gull.
Mac: A prefix, in names of Scotch origin, signifying son.
Mischaracterize: To characterize falsely or erroneously; to give a wrong character to.
Misdistinguish: To make wrong distinctions in or concerning.
mayonnaise: A thick white sauce compounded of raw yolks of eggs beaten up with olive oil to the consistency near to that of a gel, and seasoned with vinegar, pepper, salt, etc.; -- used in dressing salads, fish, etc.  Also, a dish dressed with this sauce.
Medal: To honor or reward with a medal.
Man: To supply with men; to furnish with a sufficient force or complement of men, as for management, service, defense, or the like; to guard; as, to man a ship, boat, or fort.
Mormondom: The country inhabited by the Mormons; the Mormon people.
Miniature: To represent or depict in a small compass, or on a small scale.
Mouser: A cat that catches mice; as, a good mouser is better than a dozen mousetraps.
Muscid: Any fly of the genus Musca, or family Muscidæ.
Midheaven: The midst or middle of heaven or the sky.
majority rule: The rule or doctrine that the numerical majority{2} of an organized group can make decisions binding on the whole group; as, our club makes decisions by majority rule..  Contrasted with unanimous consent, or decision by a decree of a single person or small committee forming part of an organization.
&Verbar;Maya: The name (in Vedantic philosphy) for the doctrine of the unreality of matter, called, in English, idealism; hence, nothingness; vanity; illusion.
Mitome: The denser part of the protoplasm of a cell.
mix-up: a mistake that results from taking one thing to be another.
Macer: A mace bearer; an officer of a court.
Metalbumin: A form of albumin found in ascitic and certain serous fluids.  It is sometimes regarded as a mixture of albumin and mucin.
minors: The minor leagues, those leagues of professional sports teams less proficient than the majors, or major leagues.
Misapprehension: A mistaking or mistake; wrong apprehension of one's meaning of a fact; misconception; misunderstanding.
Monosyllabled: Formed into, or consisting of, monosyllables.
Megachile: A leaf-cutting bee of the genus Megachilus. See Leaf cutter, under Leaf.
&Verbar;Modiste: One, esp. a woman, who makes, or deals in, articles of fashion, esp. of the fashionable dress of ladies; a dress-maker or milliner.
magnetic resonance: A phenomenon resulting from quantization in the magnetic field of electrons or atoms or molecules or nuclei exposed to an external magnetic field, by which a narrow frequency band of radio waves may be absorbed and re-emitted by the object.
Matteuccia: A small genus sometimes included in genus Onoclea; in some classifications both genera are placed in Polypodiaceae.
masculine: Of the male sex; not female.
Mantology: The act or art of divination.
Minibus: A kind of light passenger vehicle, carrying four persons.
&Verbar;Metosteon: The postero-lateral ossification in the sternum of birds; also, the part resulting from such ossification.
&Verbar;Mousseline de soie: A soft thin silk fabric with a weave like that of muslin.
Mushroom-headed: Having a cylindrical body with a convex head of larger diameter; having a head like that of a mushroom.
Mawmet: A puppet; a doll; originally, an idol, because in the Middle Ages it was generally believed that the Mohammedans worshiped images representing Mohammed.
Methane: A light, colorless, gaseous, inflammable hydrocarbon, CH4; marsh gas.  It is the simplest of the aliphatic hydrocarbons.  See Marsh gas, under Gas.
molar: Being at a concentration having the designated number of moles (of solute) per liter of solvent; as, an 0.2 molar solution of sodium chloride in water is close to isotonic.
&Verbar;Microlepidoptera: A tribe of Lepidoptera, including a vast number of minute species, as the plume moth, clothes moth, etc.
Mural: Of or pertaining to a wall; being on, or in, a wall; growing on, or against, a wall; as, a mural quadrant.
Manducate: To masticate; to chew; to eat.
molal: Being at a concentration with the designated number of moles (of solute) per 1000 grams of solvent; as, an 0.5 molal solution of glycerol in water.  Compare molar.
Manageability: The state or quality of being manageable; manageableness.
mayhaw: The hawthorn tree (Crataegus aestivalis) of the Southern U. S. bearing a juicy acid scarlet fruit often used in jellies or preserves.
Male-spirited: Having the spirit of a male; vigorous; courageous.
Monorganic: Belonging to, or affecting, a single organ, or set of organs.
Misstate: To state wrongly; as, to misstate a question in debate.
Matter-of-fact: Adhering to facts; not turning aside from absolute realities; not fanciful or imaginative; commonplace; dry.
Meteoric: Of or pertaining to a meteor, or to meteors; atmospheric, as, meteoric phenomena; meteoric stones.
Meride: A permanent colony of cells or plastids which may remain isolated, like Rotifer, or may multiply by gemmation to form higher aggregates, termed zoides.
Marriage: The act of marrying, or the state of being married; legal union of a man and a woman for life, as husband and wife; wedlock; matrimony.
Misadjust: To adjust wrongly of unsuitably; to throw out of adjustment.
Mesityl: A hypothetical radical formerly supposed to exist in mesityl oxide.
Matterhorn: A mountain in Italy and Switzerland, 14,690 feet high.
Morulation: The process of cleavage, or segmentation, of the ovum, by which a morula is formed.
Megapode: Any one of several species of large-footed, gallinaceous birds of the genera Megapodius and Leipoa, inhabiting Australia and other Pacific islands.  Called also mound builder, scrub fowl, moundbird, and brush turkey.  See Jungle fowl (b) under Jungle, and Leipoa.
&Verbar;Microbacteria: In the classification of Cohn, one of the four tribes of Bacteria.
Magyar: Of or pertaining to the Magyars or their language; Hungarian.
Micaceous: Pertaining to, or containing, mica; splitting into laminæ or leaves like mica.
mahjong: A Chinese game played by 4 people with 144 tiles.
Manila: Of or pertaining to Manila or Manilla, the capital of the Philippine Islands; made in, or exported from, that city.
Mordication: The act of biting or corroding; corrosion.
Mock: Imitating reality, but not real; false; counterfeit; assumed; sham.
matchbush: any of several plants of the genus Gutierrezia having tiny matchlike flowerheads.
Melitose: A variety of sugar isomeric with sucrose, extracted from cotton seeds and from the so-called Australian manna (a secretion of certain species of Eucalyptus).
Mistress: To wait upon a mistress; to be courting.
&Verbar;Maikel: A South American carnivore of the genus Conepatus, allied to the skunk, but larger, and having a longer snout. The tail is not bushy.
Metavanadic: Of, pertaining to, or designating, a vanadic acid analogous to metaphosphoric acid.
machine-oriented language: A programming language designed for use on a specific class of computers.
Managery: Management; manner of using; conduct; direction.
&Verbar;Marginella: A genus of small, polished, marine univalve shells, native of all warm seas.
&Verbar;Maidan: In various  parts of Asia, an open space, as for military exercises, or for a market place; an open grassy tract; an esplanade.
Modenese: Of or pertaining to Modena or its inhabitants.
Musteline: Like or pertaining to the family Mustelidæ, or the weasels and martens.
Monandric: Of or pertaining to monandry; practicing monandry as a system of marriage.
&Verbar;Malpighia: A genus of tropical American shrubs with opposite leaves and small white or reddish flowers. The drupes of Malpighia glabra (formerly Malpighia urens) are eaten under the name of Barbadoes cherries.
&Verbar;Mesencephalon: The middle segment of the brain; the midbrain.  Sometimes abbreviated to mesen. See Brain.
Metemptosis: The suppression of a day in the calendar to prevent the date of the new moon being set a day too late, or the suppression of the bissextile day once in 134 years.  The opposite to this is the proemptosis, or the addition of a day every 330 years, and another every 2,400 years.
Mugget: The small entrails of a calf or a hog.
Monodynamic: Possessing but one capacity or power.
Merchant: To be a merchant; to trade.
Middler: One of a middle or intermediate class in some schools and seminaries.
Mimetite: A mineral occurring in pale yellow or brownish hexagonal crystals. It is an arseniate of lead.
&Verbar;Mesenchyma: The part of the mesoblast which gives rise to the connective tissues and blood.
Meter: Rhythmical arrangement of syllables or words into verses, stanzas, strophes, etc.; poetical measure, depending on number, quantity, and accent of syllables; rhythm; measure; verse; also, any specific rhythmical arrangements; as, the Horatian meters; a dactylic meter.
madder family: A widely distributed natural family of mostly tropical trees and shrubs and herbs including coffee; chinchona; gardenia; madder; bedstraws; nd partridgeberry.
Monosepalous: Having only one sepal, or the calyx in one piece or composed of the sepals united into one piece; gamosepalous.
Malapterurus electricus: The species name of the electric catfish, a freshwater catfish of the Nile and tropical central Africa having an electric organ.
Multiparous: Producing many, or more than one, at a birth.
Maturing: Approaching maturity; as, maturing fruits; maturing notes of hand.
Molly: A pet or colloquial name for Mary.
Manufacture: To be employed in manufacturing something.
Metatarsus: That part of the skeleton of the hind or lower limb between the tarsus and phalanges; metatarse. It consists, in the human foot, of five bones. See Illustration in Appendix.
Merulidan: A bird of the Thrush family.
mail train: A railroad train that carries mail.
Musar: An itinerant player on the musette, an instrument formerly common in Europe.
Melanotype: A positive picture produced with sensitized collodion on a smooth surface of black varnish, coating a thin plate of iron; also, the process of making such a picture.
methylenedioxymethamphetamine: a drug designed to have the effects of amphetamines but to avoid the drug laws, but now a controlled substance.  Called also MDMA.
Microbe: A microscopic organism; a microorganism; -- particularly applied to bacteria and especially to pathogenic forms; as, the microbe of fowl cholera.
Ministerially: In a ministerial manner; in the character or capacity of a minister.
Milli-: A prefix denoting a thousandth part of; as, millimeter, milligram, milliampère.
Mother: To become like, or full of, mother, or thick matter, as vinegar.
Marguerite: The daisy (Bellis perennis). The name is often applied also to the ox-eye daisy and to the China aster.
-metry: A suffix denoting the art, process, or science, of measuring; as, acidimetry, bathymetry, chlorometry, chronometry.
Moroccan: Of or pertaining to Morocco, or its inhabitants.
Montero: An ancient kind of cap worn by horsemen or huntsmen.
Malay Archipelago: A group of islands in the Indian and Pacific Oceans between Asia and Australia.
Motorize: To substitute motor-driven vehicles, or automobiles, for the horses and horse-drawn vehicles of (a fire department, city, etc.).
main line: Ahe principal route of a transportation system, such as a railroad or bus line.
Mantologist: One who is skilled in mantology; a diviner.
mail clerk: A clerk in a post office.
Mercery: The trade of mercers; the goods in which a mercer deals.
&Verbar;Monoceros: A one-horned creature; a unicorn; a sea monster with one horn.
mako shark: A powerful and fierce mackerel shark of the Atlantic and Pacific, of the family Lamidae.
&Verbar;Mecate: A rope of hair or of maguey fiber, for tying horses, etc.
Minivet: A singing bird of India of the family Campephagidæ.
Miniver: A fur esteemed in the Middle Ages as a part of costume.  It is uncertain whether it was the fur of one animal only or of different animals.
Medlar: A tree of the genus Mespilus (Mespilus Germanica); also, the fruit of the tree.  The fruit is something like a small apple, but has a bony endocarp.  When first gathered the flesh is hard and austere, and it is not eaten until it has begun to decay.
Manifolded: Having many folds, layers, or plates; as, a manifolded shield.
magic trick: An feat of illusion performed by an illusionist, which appears magical to naive observers.
Maclura: A genus of plants including the yellowwood trees and shrubs.
Mellite: A mineral of a honey color, found in brown coal, and partly the result of vegetable decomposition; honeystone.  It is a mellitate of alumina.
Medication: The act or process of medicating.
&Verbar;Mastax: The pharynx of a rotifer. It usually contains four horny pieces. The two central ones form the incus, against which the mallei, or lateral ones, work so as to crush the food.
Mayfish: A common American minnow (Fundulus majalis). See Minnow.
Mniaceae: A natural family of erect mosses with club-shaped paraphyses andgonal cells of the upper leaf surface; sometimes treated as a subfamily of Bryaceae.
Mainor: A thing stolen found on the person of the thief.
Monoptote: A noun having only one case.
magnetic force: The force caused by a magnetic field, a force which affects objects having a magnetic field and objects in which a magnetic field can be induced, such as ferromagnetic substances; a magnetic force manifests itself as an attraction for iron. It is associated with electric currents and moving charged paticles as well as permanent magnets.
Mirliton: A kind of musical toy into which one sings, hums, or speaks, producing a coarse, reedy sound.  It is also called a kazoo.
Misenter: To enter or insert wrongly, as a charge in an account.
Malaxation: The act of softening by mixing with a thinner substance; the formation of ingredients into a mass for pills or plasters.
Montrue: That on which anything is mounted; a setting; hence, a saddle horse.
&Verbar;Mousquetaire: A musketeer, esp. one of the French royal musketeers of the 17th and 18th centuries, conspicuous both for their daring and their fine dress.
morph: To transform smoothly in imperceptible steps from one image to another, on a computer screen.
Misstayed: Having missed stays; -- said of a ship.
Margarodite: A hidrous potash mica related to muscovite.
Mydaleine: A toxic alkaloid (ptomaine) obtained from putrid flesh and from herring brines.  As a poison it is said to execute profuse diarrhoea, vomiting, and intestinal inflammation.
&Verbar;Monotremata: A subclass of Mammalia, having a cloaca in which the ducts of the urinary, genital, and alimentary systems terminate, as in birds.  The female lays eggs like a bird. See Duck mole, under Duck, and Echidna.
Malaxis: A large genus of largely terrestrial orchids with one or a few plicate leaves and slender spikes or tiny mostly green flowers; it is cosmopolitan.
Mealy-mouthed: Using soft words; not straightforward; plausible; affectedly or timidly delicate of speech; speaking deviously; unwilling to tell the truth in plain language.  Opposite of frank or blunt.
maharani: A great rani; a princess in India or the wife of a maharaja.
Machine: To subject to the action of machinery; to make, cut, shape, or modify with a machine; to effect by aid of machinery; to print with a printing machine.
mil: One million dollars; as, his new house cost over a mil.
Mouflon: A wild sheep (Ovis musimon), inhabiting the mountains of Sardinia, Corsica, etc.  Its horns are very large, with a triangular base and rounded angles.  It is supposed by some to be the original of the domestic sheep.  Called also musimon or musmon.
&Verbar;Malaise: An indefinite feeling of uneasiness, or of being sick or ill at ease.
Millionaire: One whose wealth is counted by millions of francs, dollars, or pounds; a very rich person; a person worth a million or more.
Muscled: Furnished with muscles; having muscles; as, things well muscled.
Martialism: The quality of being warlike; exercises suitable for war.
Metaphrase: A verbal translation; a version or translation from one language into another, word for word; a literal translation; -- opposed to paraphrase.
Multicellular: Consisting of, or having, many cells or more than one cell.
Misrepresent: To make an incorrect or untrue representation.
Matronize: To make a matron of; to make matronlike.
Mormal: A bad sore; a gangrene; a cancer.
marqueterie: Inlaid work; work inlaid with pieces of wood, shells, ivory, veneer, and the like, of several colors, fitted together to form a design or picture that is then used to ornament furniture.
Mop: To rub or wipe with a mop, or as with a mop; as, to mop a floor; to mop one's face with a handkerchief.
Mow: To lay, as hay or sheaves of grain, in a heap or mass in a barn; to pile and stow away.
Mot: A word; hence, a motto; a device.
Manic: Of or pert. to, or characterized by, mania, or excitement; frenzied; as, with manic energy.
Mania: Violent derangement of mind; madness; insanity.  Cf. Delirium.
Mon: The badge of a family, esp. of a family of the ancient feudal nobility.  The most frequent form of the mon is circular, and it commonly consists of conventionalized forms from nature, flowers, birds, insects, the lightnings, the waves of the sea, or of geometrical symbolic figures; color is only a secondary character.  It appears on lacquer and pottery, and embroidered on, or woven in, fabrics.  The imperial chrysanthemum, the mon of the reigning family, is used as a national emblem.  Formerly the mon of the shoguns of the Tokugawa family was so used.
Mob: To crowd about, as a mob, and attack or annoy; as, to mob a house or a person.
Moa: Any one of several very large extinct species of wingless birds belonging to Dinornis, and other related genera, of the suborder Dinornithes, found in New Zealand.  They are allied to the apteryx and the ostrich.  They were probably exterminated by the natives before New Zealand was discovered by Europeans.  Some species were much larger than the ostrich.
Mog: To move away; to go off.
Malevolent: Wishing evil; disposed to injure others; rejoicing in another's misfortune.
Mimosoideae: An alternative name used in some classification systems for the family Mimosaceae.
Myricin: A silky, crystalline, waxy substance, forming the less soluble part of beeswax, and regarded as a palmitate of a higher alcohol of the paraffin series; -- called also myricyl alcohol.
Myriophyllous: Having an indefinitely great or countless number of leaves.
Meloidae: A natural family of insects comprising the blister beetles.
mascara: A cosmetic used to darken and thicken the eye lashes, usually applied with a small brush.
Mafa: A Chadic language spoken south of Lake Chad; called also Matakam.
Mediatize: To cause to act through an agent or to hold a subordinate position; to annex; -- specifically applied to the annexation during the former German empire of a smaller German state to a larger, while allowing it a nominal sovereignty, and its prince his rank.
metalanguage: Any language that can be used to describe another language or system of symbols.
Metameric: Having the same molecular formula, but possessing a different bonding structure and different properties; as, methyl ether and ethyl alcohol are metameric compounds.  See Isomeric.
Monitorship: The post or office of a monitor.
Methyl: A univalent hydrocarbon radical, CH3-, not existing alone but regarded as an essential residue of methane, and appearing as a component part of many derivatives; as, methyl alcohol, methyl ether, methyl amine, etc.
madras: A large silk-and-cotton kerchief, usually of bright colors, such as those often used by negroes for turbans.
Monochord: An instrument for experimenting upon the mathematical relations of musical sounds. It consists of a single string stretched between two bridges, one or both of which are movable, and which stand upon a graduated rule for the purpose of readily changing and measuring the length of the part of the string between them.
Monocrotic: Of, pertaining to, or showing, monocrotism; as, a monocrotic pulse; a pulse of the monocrotic type.
mailing list: A list of names and addresses to which advertising, solicitations of money, or other materials material sent in large quantities is mailed; -- it is usually used by comercial or charitable organizations.  Mailing lists are often sold by organizations to other organizations, and are frequently used for targeted mailing, i. e., mailing to groups of people who are more likely htan the general population to respond as desired to the message in the mail.
Moccasined: Covered with, or wearing, a moccasin or moccasins.
Mellow: To become mellow; as, ripe fruit soon mellows.
Memorializer: One who petitions by a memorial.
&Verbar;Mahaled: A cherry tree (Prunus Mahaleb) of Southern Europe.  The wood is prized by cabinetmakers, the twigs are used for pipe stems, the flowers and leaves yield a perfume, and from the fruit a violet dye and a fermented liquor (like kirschwasser) are prepared.
Multiple: A quantity containing another quantity an integral number of times without a remainder.
&Verbar;Moonshee: A Mohammedan professor or teacher of language.
Mesaticephalic: Having the ratio of the length to the breadth of the cranium a medium one; neither brachycephalic nor dolichocephalic.
Maxillo-palatine: Pertaining to the maxillary and palatine regions of the skull; as, the maxillo-palatine process of the maxilla. Also used as n.
Magpie: Any one of numerous species of the genus Pica and related genera, allied to the jays, but having a long graduated tail.
Mismake: To make or form amiss; to spoil in making.
Meuse-Argonne: an American operation in World War I (1918); American troops under Pershing drove back the German armies which were saved only by the Armistice on November 11.
mallow family: The natural family Malvaceae, a dilleniid dicot family consisting of herbs and shrubs and some trees, and including the mallows, cotton, and okra.
mauve\u00efne: An artificial organic base, obtained by oxidizing a mixture of aniline and toluidine, and valuable for the dyestuffs it forms.
mugwump: A bolter from the Republican party in the national election of 1884; an Independent.
Muskmelon: The fruit of a cucurbitaceous plant (Cucumis Melo) of the gourd family, having a peculiar aromatic flavor, and cultivated in many varieties, the principal sorts being the cantaloupe, of oval form and yellowish flesh, and the smaller nutmeg melon with greenish flesh.  See Illust. of Melon.
Matureness: The state or quality of being mature; maturity.
Melton: A kind of stout woolen cloth with unfinished face and without raised nap. A commoner variety has a cotton warp.
Moros: The Mohammedan tribes of the southern Philippine Islands, said to have formerly migrated from Borneo.  Some of them are warlike and addicted to piracy.
manually: By hand.  In some contexts, contrasted with automatically.
Monostrophe: A metrical composition consisting of a single strophe.
Mechanism: The arrangement or relation of the parts of a machine; the parts of a machine, taken collectively; the arrangement or relation of the parts of anything as adapted to produce an effect; as, the mechanism of a watch; the mechanism of a sewing machine; the mechanism of a seed pod.
Mechanist: A maker of machines; one skilled in mechanics.
Moron: An inferior olive size having a woody pulp and a large clingstone pit, growing in the mountainous and high-valley districts around the city of Moron, in Spain.
matchbook: A small folder of paper safety matches.
mull over: To think about; to consider; to ruminate about; as, mull it over and decide in the morning.
mercury fulminate: The mercury salt of fulminic acid (Hg(CNO)2), called also fulminate of mercury.  It is an explosive compound prepared as gray crystals, and is used primarily in detonators for detonating high explosives, such as dynamite or TNT.  It is sensitive to shock and may be detonated by a blow.
&Verbar;Mesotheca: The middle layer of the gonophore in the Hydrozoa.
Melancholic: One affected with a gloomy state of mind.
Mesoblastic: Relating to the mesoblast; as, the mesoblastic layer.
moniliasis: An infectious disease caused by fungi of the genera Monilia or Candida especially Candida albicans.
Micmacs: A tribe of Indians inhabiting Nova Scotia and New Brunswick.
menstruating: discharging menstrual fluid; -- of women during their menstrual period.
&Verbar;martel de fer: A weapon resembling a hammer, often having one side of the head pointed; -- used by horsemen in the Middle Ages to break armor.
Magnifier: One who, or that which, magnifies.
medfly: Same as Mediterranean fruit fly; -- a shortened form.
Medullated: Furnished with a medulla or marrow, or with a medullary sheath; as, a medullated nerve fiber.
&Verbar;Monopodium: A single and continuous vegetable axis; -- opposed to sympodium.
Monatomic: Consisting of, or containing, one atom; as, the molecule of mercury is monatomic.
Melancholian: A person affected with melancholy; a melancholic.
muscle: To compel by threat of force; as, they muscled the shopkeeper into paying protection money.
Monotype: The only representative of its group, as a single species constituting a genus.
Mass\u00e9 shot: A stroke made with the cue held vertically.
Moderatism: Moderation in doctrines or opinion, especially in politics or religion.
&Verbar;Midrash: A talmudic exposition of the Hebrew law, or of some part of it.
Macleaya: A genus of East Asian perennial herbs including the plume poppy.
Mistitle: To call by a wrong title.
Mavournin: My darling; -- an Irish term of endearment for a girl or woman.
Middling: Of middle rank, state, size, or quality; about equally distant from the extremes; medium; moderate; mediocre; ordinary.
Macroclemys: A genus of alligator snapping turtles.
Misty: Accompanied with mist; characterized by the presence of mist; obscured by, or overspread with, mist; as, a misty morning; misty weather; misty mountains; a misty atmosphere.
Madrigal: A little amorous poem, sometimes called a pastoral poem, containing some tender and delicate, though simple, thought.
Mistaught: Wrongly taught; as, a mistaught youth.
Medullin: A variety of lignin or cellulose found in the medulla, or pith, of certain plants.  Cf. Lignin, and Cellulose.
&Verbar;Madjoun: An intoxicating confection from the hemp plant; -- used by the Turks and Hindus.
massicot: Lead monoxide (also called Lead protoxide), PbO, obtained as a yellow amorphous powder, the fused and crystalline form of which is called litharge; lead ocher. It is used as a pigment.  It is also called lead oxide yellow, as opposed to red lead, which is lead tetroxide Pb3O4.
minicomputer: a mid-sized digital computer; at any given point in the development of computer technology, a minicomputer will be faster and have greater capacity than a microcomputer, but will be slower and have less capacity than a mainframe computer.
Mistaken: Being in error; judging wrongly; having a wrong opinion or a misconception; as, a mistaken man; he is mistaken.
Maximize: To increase to the highest degree.
micromercurialism: A form of mercury poisoning resulting from long term exposure to low doses of mercury.  The syndrome of micromercurialism involves complex symptoms of stress, fatigue, memory loss, fine tremors, muscular and reflex insufficiency and low blood pressure, caused by accumulation of mercury in the system.  A condition of hyperthermia is accompanied by a series of functional changes under the effects of mercury.  The combined simultaneous effect of toxic action, temperature and galvanic response infers a cycle of disintegration and change.
Malacologist: One versed in the science of malacology.
madrona: A small evergreen tree or shrub (Arbutus Menziesii), of Pacific North America, having a smooth bark, thick glossy leathery leaves, and edible orange-red berries, which are often called madroña apples; the wood is used for furniture and the bark for tanning.
Mensuration: The act, process, or art, of measuring.
Mao Tsetung: The leader of the Chinese communist party and later of teh People's Repbulic of China; b. 1893, d. 1976.  Also referred to a simply Mao.
Mundification: The act or operation of cleansing.
mesonic: Of or pertaining to a meson.
mandarin orange: A shrub or small tree (Citrus reticulata) having flattened globose fruit with very sweet aromatic pulp and thin yellow-orange to flame-orange rind that is loose and easily removed; native to Southeast Asia.
Manganese steel: Cast steel containing a considerable percentage (10-14) of manganese, which makes it very hard and tough and highly resistant to wear. See Alloy steel, above.
Maxim gun: A kind of machine gun; -- named after its inventor, Hiram S. Maxim.
Maronite: One of a body of nominal Christians, who speak the Arabic language, and reside on Mount Lebanon and in different parts of Syria.  They take their name from one Maron of the 6th century.
Mixogamous: Pairing with several males; -- said of certain fishes of which several males accompany each female during spawning.
Margate fish: A sparoid fish (Diabasis aurolineatus) of the Gulf of Mexico, esteemed as a food fish; -- called also red-mouth grunt.
Matchlock: An old form of gunlock containing a match for firing the priming; hence, a musket fired by means of a match.
Multipresent: Being, or having the power to be, present in two or more places at once.
militarization: act of assembling and putting into readiness the military forces for war or other emergency.
Microsthenic: Having a typically small size; of or pertaining to the microsthenes.
Mainsail: The principal sail in a ship or other vessel.
Muffetee: A small muff worn over the wrist.
Magazine camera: A camera in which a number of plates can be exposed without reloading.
Misapprehend: To take in a wrong sense; to misunderstand.
Maldivian: A native or inhabitant of Maldives.
motor-driven: Driven or actuated by a motor, esp. by an individual electric motor. An electric motor forms an integral part of many machine tools in numerous modern machine shops.
moo-cow: a cow{1}; -- a child's word.  See 1st cow{1}, n.
&Verbar;Maikong: A South American wild dog (Canis cancrivorus); the crab-eating dog.
Musal: Of or pertaining to the Muses, or to Poetry.
&Verbar;Mont de pi\u00e9t\u00e9: One of certain public pawnbroking establishments which originated in Italy in the 15th century, the object of which was to lend money at a low rate of interest to poor people in need; -- called also mount of piety. The institution has been adopted in other countries, as in Spain and France. See Lombard-house.
Millinet: A stiff cotton fabric used by milliners for lining bonnets.
Methoxyl: A hypothetical radical, CH3O, analogous to hydroxyl.
Match game: A game arranged as a test of superiority; also, one of a series of such games.
mare liberum: A navigable body of water to which all nations have equal access; the opposite of mare clausum.
myxosporidian: An organism of the order Myxosporidia, mostly parasitic in fishes and including various serious pathogens.
Microtasimeter: A tasimeter, especially when arranged for measuring very small extensions. See Tasimeter.
Mother-of-pearl: The hard, iridescent, pearly internal layer of several kinds of shells, esp. of pearl oysters, river mussels, and the abalone shells; nacre. See Pearl.
Mystify: To involve in mystery; to make obscure or difficult to understand; as, to mystify a passage of Scripture.
marmot: Any rodent of the genus Marmota (formerly Arctomys) of the subfamily Sciurinae.  The common European marmot (Marmota marmotta) is about the size of a rabbit, and inhabits the higher regions of the Alps and Pyrenees. The bobac is another European species.  The common American species (Marmota monax) is the woodchuck (also called groundhog), but the name marmot is usually used only for the western variety.
Meantime: In the intervening time; during the interval.
Molder: To turn to dust; to cause to crumble; to cause to waste away.
Mulse: Wine boiled and mingled with honey.
Millennialist: One who believes that Christ will reign personally on earth a thousand years; a Chiliast; also, a believer in the universal prevalence of Christianity for a long period.
Meetinghouse: A house used as a place of worship; a church; -- in England, applied only to a house so used by Dissenters.
Mayflower: In England, the hawthorn; in New England, the trailing arbutus (see Arbutus); also, the blossom of these plants.
Missioner: A missionary; an envoy; one who conducts a mission. See Mission, n., 6.
Movable: An article of wares or goods; a commodity; a piece of property not fixed, or not a part of real estate; generally, in the plural, goods; wares; furniture.
Mackinaw blanket: A thick blanket formerly in common use in the western part of the United States.
Movably: In a movable manner or condition.
motored: equipped with a motor or motors; motorized.  Opposite of unmotorized.
Myadestes: A genus of birds including  the solitaires, thrushes noted for their beautiful songs.
Most-favored-nation clause: A clause, often inserted in treaties, by which each of the contracting nations binds itself to grant to the other in certain stipulated matters the same terms as are then, or may be thereafter, granted to the nation which receives from it the most favorable terms in respect of those matters.  It is used most frequently in treaties regarding the terms of trade between countries, as regarding tariffs and non-tariff barriers to trade.
Marmoset: Any one of numerous species of small South American monkeys of the genera Hapale and Midas, family Hapalidæ.  They have long soft fur, and a hairy, nonprehensile tail.  They are often kept as pets.  Called also squirrel monkey.
Motograph: A device utilized in the making of a loud-speaking telephone, depending on the fact that the friction between a metallic point and a moving cylinder of moistened chalk, or a moving slip of paper, on which it rests is diminished by the passage of a current between the point and the moving surface.
Misemploy: To employ amiss; as, to misemploy time, advantages, talents, etc.
Metallophone: An instrument like a pianoforte, but having metal bars instead of strings.
&Verbar;Modulus: A quantity or coefficient, or constant, which expresses the measure of some specified force, property, or quality, as of elasticity, strength, efficiency, etc.; a parameter.
Matronal: Of or pertaining to a matron; suitable to an elderly lady or to a married woman; grave; motherly.
millrace: a channel from a millpond to a millwheel, to provide the water current that turns the millwheel.
malpighian body: The capsule that contains a glomerulus at the expanded end of a nephron; also called malpighian corpuscle and Malpighian capsule.
Mistemper: To temper ill; to disorder; as, to mistemper one's head.
Magistracy: The office or dignity of a magistrate.
Monopodial: Having a monopodium or a single and continuous axis, as a birchen twig or a cornstalk.
&Verbar;Meconidium: A kind of gonophore produced by hydroids of the genus Gonothyræa.  It has tentacles, and otherwise resembles a free medusa, but remains attached by a pedicel.
Mitt: A mitten; also, a covering for the wrist and hand and not for the fingers, usually worn by women.
machmeter: an instrument for measuring the speed of an aircraft relative to the speed of sound.
Moralization: The act of moralizing; moral reflections or discourse.
Mnemosyne: The goddess of memory and the mother of the Muses.
Metastatic: Of, pertaining to, or caused by, metastasis; as, a metastatic abscess; the metastatic processes of growth; a metastatic tumor.
Manifestation: The act of manifesting or disclosing, or the state of being manifested; discovery to the eye or to the understanding.
Mite: A minute arachnid, of the order Acarina, of which there are many species; as, the dust mite, cheese mite, sugar mite, harvest mite, three-toed spider mite, etc. See Acarina.
Messuage: A dwelling house, with the adjacent buildings and curtilage, and the adjoining lands appropriated to the use of the household.
mainspring: The principal or most important spring in a piece of mechanism, especially the moving spring of a watch or clock or the spring in a gunlock which impels the hammer.
Multiseptate: Divided into many chambers by partitions, as the pith of the pokeweed.
&Verbar;Malacozoa: An extensive group of Invertebrata, including the Mollusca, Brachiopoda, and Bryozoa. Called also Malacozoaria.
Malian: A native or inhabitant of Mali.
motorcyclist: A person who rides a motorcycle.
Murexan: A complex nitrogenous substance obtained from murexide, alloxantin, and other ureids, as a white, or yellowish, crystalline which turns red on exposure to the air; -- called also uramil, dialuramide, and formerly purpuric acid.
make-work: Active work of litle value, such as assignments given by teachers to students to keep them busy while the teacher performs other tasks, or chores performed to while away time; also called busywork.
mass-produced: Produced in large quantity, often by automated or assembly-line techniques.
Mesolite: A zeolitic mineral, grayish white or yellowish, occuring in delicate groups of crystals, also fibrous massive. It is a hydrous silicate of alumina, lime, and soda.
Montessori Method: A system of training and instruction, primarily for use with normal children aged from three to six years, devised by Dr. Maria Montessori while teaching in the “Houses of Childhood” (schools in the poorest tenement districts of Rome, Italy), and first fully described by her in 1909.  The fundamental aim is to create self-motivation for education, and the leading features are freedom for physical activity (no stationary desks and chairs), informal and individual instruction, the very early development of reading and writing skills, and an extended sensory and motor training (with special emphasis on vision, touch, perception of movement, and their interconnections), mediated by a patented, standardized system of “didactic apparatus,” which is declared to be “auto-regulative.”  Most of the chief features of the method are borrowed from current methods used in many institutions for training feeble-minded children, and dating back especially to the work of the French-American physician Edouard O. Seguin (1812-80).
Malevolence: The quality or state of being malevolent; evil disposition toward another; inclination to injure others; ill will. See Synonym of Malice.
major-league club: A sports team that plays in a major league.
Misderive: To turn or divert improperly; to misdirect.
mares-nest: A supposed discovery which turns out to be a hoax; something grossly absurd.
Malefaction: A crime; an offense; an evil deed.
Manks: Of or pertaining to the language or people of the Isle of Man.
Maccabees: The name given in later times to the Asmonæans, a family of Jewish patriots, who headed a religious revolt in the reign of Antiochus IV., 168-161 b. c., which led to a period of freedom for Israel.
&Verbar;Mesophyllum: The parenchyma of a leaf between the skin of the two surfaces.
Millimicron: The thousandth part of a micron or the millionth part of a millimeter; -- a unit of length used in measuring light waves, etc.
Mantispidae: The natural family comprising the mantispids.
Made: Artificially produced; pieced together; formed by filling in; as, made ground; a made mast, in distinction from one consisting of a single spar.
motley collection: A collection of objects of various kinds; a hodgepodge; a medley; a confused mixture; an omnium gatherum.
Messiahship: The state or office of the Messiah.
Misdemean: To behave ill; -- with a reflexive pronoun; as, to misdemean one's self.
&Verbar;Moll: Minor; in the minor mode; as, A moll, that is, A minor.
Metallization: The act or process of metallizing.
Mince-meat: Minced meat; meat chopped very fine; a mixture of boiled meat, suet, apples, etc., chopped very fine, to which spices and raisins are added; -- used in making mince pie.
Micropegmatite: A rock showing under the microscope the structure of a graphic granite (pegmatite).
Macrograph: A picture of an object as seen by the naked eye (that is, unmagnified); as, a macrograph of a metallic fracture.
Macule: To blur; especially (Print.), to blur or double an impression from type. See Mackle.
Murage: A tax or toll paid for building or repairing the walls of a fortified town.
maidenhair spleenwort: A small rock-inhabiting fern (Asplenium trichomanes) of the North temperate zone and Hawaii, having pinnate fronds.
myxomatosis: a viral disease (usually fatal) of rabbits.
Macruroid: Like or pertaining to the Macrura.
micturate: to pass urine through the ureter; to urinate.
Municipality: A municipal district; a borough, city, or incorporated town or village.
Martello tower: A building of masonry, generally circular, usually erected on the seacoast, with a gun on the summit mounted on a traversing platform, so as to be fired in any direction.
&Verbar;Mesophl\u0153um: The middle bark of a tree; the green layer of bark, usually soon covered by the outer or corky layer, and obliterated.
maulstick: A stick used by painters as a rest for the hand while working.
Mutteringly: With a low voice and indistinct articulation; in a muttering manner.
Mister: To be needful or of use.
&Verbar;Myoma: A tumor consisting of muscular tissue.
mnemonic: Something used to assist the memory, as an easily remembered acronym or verse.
misdating: The assignment of a date to something at a time when it could not have existed or occurred.
Moted: Filled with motes, or fine floating dust; as, the air.
Monometer: A rhythmic series, consisting of a single meter.
Malpighia glabra: THe species name of the acerola, also called barbados cherry, a tropical American shrub bearing edible cherrylike acid red fruit.
Matross: Formerly, in the British service, a gunner or a gunner's mate; one of the soldiers in a train of artillery, who assisted the gunners in loading, firing, and sponging the guns.
mayhem: The maiming of a person by depriving him of the use of any of his members which are necessary for defense or protection. See Maim.
Motet: A composition adapted to sacred words in the elaborate polyphonic church style; an anthem.
Macrometer: An instrument for determining the size or distance of inaccessible objects by means of two reflectors on a common sextant.
Morbific: Causing disease; generating a sickly state; as, a morbific matter.
&Verbar;Melanorrh\u0153a: An East Indian genus of large trees. Melanorrhœa usitatissima is the lignum-vitæ of Pegu (in Burma), and yields a valuable black varnish.
&Verbar;Metapterygium: The posterior of the three principal basal cartilages in the fins of fishes.
Moniment: Something to preserve memory; a reminder; a monument; hence, a mark; an image; a superscription; a record.
maieutic method: A method of teaching by question and answer; it was used by Socrates to elicit truths from his students; -- called also the Socratic method
Marian: Pertaining to the Virgin Mary, or sometimes to Mary, Queen of England, daughter of Henry VIII.
Moonset: The descent of the moon below the horizon; also, the time when the moon sets.
&Verbar;Mandamus: A writ issued by a superior court and directed to some inferior tribunal, or to some corporation or person exercising authority, commanding the performance of some specified duty.
Marlin: The American great marbled godwit (Limosa fedoa). Applied also to the red-breasted godwit (Limosa hæmatica).
Mamma: A glandular organ for secreting milk, characteristic of all mammals, but usually rudimentary in the male; a mammary gland; a breast; udder; bag.
Mawmetry: The religion of Mohammed; also, idolatry. See Mawmet.
Microcrith: The weight of the half hydrogen molecule, or of the hydrogen atom, at one time taken as the standard in comparing the atomic weights of the elements; thus, an atom of oxygen weighs sixteen microcriths.  This unit is no longer used, and has been replaced by the Dalton, which is of approximately the same value.  See molecular weight and Crith.
Mucorales: An order of mostly saprophytic fungi.
Marvelousness: The quality or state of being marvelous; wonderfulness; strangeness.
&Verbar;Melanochroi: A group of the human race, including the dark whites.
Monoxide: An oxide containing one atom of oxygen in each molecule; as, barium monoxide.
Marysole: A large British fluke, or flounder (Rhombus megastoma); -- called also carter, and whiff.
Mariolater: One who worships the Virgin Mary.
Messinese: Of or pertaining to Messina, or its inhabitans.
Meloplastic: Of or pertaining to meloplasty, or the artificial formation of a new cheek.
Modification: The act of modifying, or the state of being modified; a change; as, the modification of an opinion, or of a machine.
&Verbar;Minorat: A custom or right, analogous to borough-English in England, formerly existing in various parts of Europe, and surviving in parts of Germany and Austria, by which certain entailed estates, as a homestead and adjacent land, descend to the youngest male heir.
Myology: That part of anatomy which treats of muscles.
Magistratic: Of, pertaining to, or proceeding from, a magistrate; having the authority of a magistrate.
Muntin: Same as Mullion; -- especially used in joiner's work.
Mobile: a form of sculpture having several sheets or rods of a stiff material attached to each other by thin wire or twine in a balanced and artfully arranged tree configuration, with the topmost member suspended in air from a support so that the parts may move independently when set in motion by a current of air.
Monachal: Of or pertaining to monks or a monastic life; monastic.
&Verbar;Mygale: A genus of very large hairy spiders of the family Ctenizidae, having four lungs and only four spinnerets.  They do not spin webs, but usually construct tubes in the earth, which are often furnished with a trapdoor.  The South American bird spider (Mygale avicularia), and the crab spider, or matoutou (Mygale cancerides) are among the largest species.  They are also called trapdoor spiders.  Some of the species are erroneously called tarantulas, as the Texas tarantula (Mygale Hentzii).
Maintain: To hold or keep in any particular state or condition; to support; to sustain; to uphold; to keep up; not to suffer to fail or decline; as, to maintain a certain degree of heat in a furnace; to maintain a fence or a railroad; to maintain the digestive process or powers of the stomach; to maintain the fertility of soil; to maintain present reputation.
manicure: A person who makes a business of taking care of people's hands, especially their nails; -- an older term for a manicurist.
&Verbar;Mesonephros: The middle one of the three pairs of embryonic renal organs developed in most vertebrates; the Wolffian body.
Manitrunk: The anterior segment of the thorax in insects. See Insect.
Mobility: The quality or state of being mobile; as, the mobility of a liquid, of an army, of the populace, of features, of a muscle.
&Verbar;Madrague: A large fish pound used for the capture of the tunny in the Mediterranean; also applied to the seines used for the same purpose.
Mediate: To effect by mediation or interposition; to bring about as a mediator, instrument, or means; as, to mediate a peace.
&Verbar;Miliaria: A fever accompanied by an eruption of small, isolated, red pimples, resembling a millet seed in form or size; miliary fever.
Monopolylogue: An exhibition in which an actor sustains many characters.
magneto: A small electric generator with an armature rotating in a magnetic field, having a secondary winding that generates a high voltage, such as one used to generate a voltage sufficient to cause a spark to jump between the poles of a spark plug in an internal-combustion engine.
mapmaking: the making of maps and charts; cartography.
Meta-: A prefix meaning between, with, after, behind, over, about, reversely; as, metachronism, the error of placing after the correct time; metaphor, lit., a carrying over; metathesis, a placing reversely.
Mischievous: Causing mischief; harmful; hurtful; -- now often applied where the evil is done carelessly or in sport; as, a mischievous child.
Madreporiform: Resembling a madreporian coral in form or structure.
militarized: Equipped with eapons; armed; -- used of persons, regions, or the military.  Contrasted to unarmed and demilitarized.
Mincing: That minces; characterized by primness or affected nicety.
Marigenous: Produced in or by the sea.
Megameter: In the metric system, one million meters, or one thousand kilometers.
merchandising: The activities associated with selling products, such as identification of the market{7}, advertising at the right time in the right media{7}, and creating attractive packaging and displays; also, the study of the best methods to accomplish such goals.
Myxophyceae: A former term for the natural family Cyanophyceae.
Mismeter: To give the wrong meter to, as to a line of verse.
megakaryocyte: A large bone marrow cell not usually found in the circulating blood; it is regarded as the precursors of blood platelets; it is up to 100 μm in diameter, with a polyploid nucleus.  Also referred to as megacaryocyte, megalokaryocyte, and thromboblast.
malanders: A scurfy eruption in the bend of the knee of the fore leg of a horse. See Sallenders.
&Verbar;Miliola: A genus of Foraminifera, having a porcelanous shell with several longitudinal chambers.
&Verbar;Monera: The lowest division of rhizopods, including those which resemble the amœbas, but are destitute of a nucleus.
mail fraud: The use of the mails to defraud someone.
Menuridae: A natural family of birds including the lyrebirds.
Mesorhine: Having the nose of medium width; between leptorhine and platyrhine.
Mendelian character: A character which obeys Mendel's law in regard to its hereditary transmission.
&Verbar;Monseigneur: My lord; -- a title in France of a person of high birth or rank; as, Monseigneur the Prince, or Monseigneur the Archibishop.  It was given, specifically, to the dauphin, before the Revolution of 1789. (Abbrev. Mgr.)
Monotony: A frequent recurrence of the same tone or sound, producing a dull uniformity; absence of variety, as in speaking or singing.
&Verbar;Mesoc\u00e6cum: The fold of peritoneum attached to the cæcum.
Militiate: To carry on, or prepare for, war.
Magnoliaceous: Pertaining to a natural order (Magnoliaceæ) of trees of which the magnolia, the tulip tree, and the star anise are examples.
mercurialism: The syndrome produced by poisoning due to exposure to mercury, it fumes, or its compounds; mercury poisoning.  Such exposure may occur in mining or smelting, or in using mercurial compounds.
Mandingos: An extensive and powerful tribe of West African negroes.
Mazer: A large drinking bowl; -- originally made of maple.
Menispermine: An alkaloid distinct from picrotoxin and obtained from the cocculus indicus (the fruit of Anamirta Cocculus, formerly Menispermum Cocculus) as a white, crystalline, tasteless powder; -- called also menispermina.
microphonic: Of or pertaining to a microphone; serving to intensify weak sounds.
Meteoromancy: A species of divination by atmospheric phenomena, chiefly by thunder and lightning, which was held in high estimation by the Romans.
Mummify: To embalm and dry as a mummy; to make into, or like, a mummy.
Mithridate: An antidote against poison, or a composition in form of an electuary, supposed to serve either as a remedy or a preservative against poison; an alexipharmic; -- so called from King Mithridates, its reputed inventor.
Mormonism: The doctrine, system, and practices of the Mormons.
&Verbar;Melop\u0153ia: The art of forming melody; melody; -- now often used for a melodic passage, rather than a complete melody.
&Verbar;Monodelphia: The group that includes all ordinary or placental mammals; the Placentalia. See Mammalia.
Muntjac: Any one of several species of small Asiatic deer of the genus Cervulus, esp. Cervulus muntjac, which occurs both in India and on the East Indian Islands.
Markov chain: A random process (Markov process) in which the probabilities of discrete states in a series depend only on the properties of the immediately preceding state or the next preceeding state, independent of the path by which the preceding state was reached.  It differs from the more general Markov process in that the states of a Markov chain are discrete rather than continuous. Certain physical processes, such as diffusion of a molecule in a fluid, are modelled as a Markov chain.  See also random walk.
marteline: A small hammer used by marble workers and sculptors.
Mercantile: Of or pertaining to merchants, or the business of merchants; having to do with trade, or the buying and selling of commodities; commercial.
Maxilliform: Having the form, or structure, of a maxilla.
Margaryize: To impregnate (wood) with a preservative solution of copper sulphate (often called Mar"ga*ry's flu"id (-r&ibreve_;z)).
Maxillar: Pertaining to either the upper or the lower jaw, but now usually applied to the upper jaw only.
mepacrine: Quinacrine, a drug once used to treat malaria; Atabrine is a trademark.
Marcidity: The state or quality of being withered or lean.
Malonic: Pertaining to, or designating, a dicarboxylic acid produced artifically as a white crystalline substance, CH2.(CO2H)2, and so called because obtained by the oxidation of malic acid.
Menstruum: Any substance which dissolves a solid body; a solvent.
magnetic dip: The angle that a magnetic needle makes with the plane of the horizon.
Moory: A kind of blue cloth made in India.
Mensal: Occurring once in a month; monthly.
Marking: The act of one who, or that which, marks; the mark or marks made; arrangement or disposition of marks or coloring; as, the marking of a bird's plumage.
motherboard: The board containing the main circuits of an electronic device, especially computers.  The term is used primarily in microcomputer literature, where it designates the board containing the main expansion bus, and usually also the cpu.   On motherboards designed with an expansion bus, often all of the circuits not contained on an expansion card are on the motherboard.
motorless: having no motor.  Opposite of motorized.
maharaja: A sovereign prince in India; a Hindu prince or king in India ranking above a raja; -- a title given also to other persons of high rank.
Microscopist: One skilled in, or given to, microscopy.
Megarian: Belonging, or pertaining, to Megara, a city of ancient Greece.
Macedon: the ancient kingdom of Phillip II and Alexander the Great in the Southeastern Balkans that is now part of Greece, Bulgaria and the former Yugoslavia.
margin call: A demand by a broker that a customer deposit enough to bring his margin up to the minimum requirement; -- caused by the decline in market prices of  a security or commodity purchased on margin{5}.
man-at-arms: A heavily armed and sometimes mounted soldier in medieval times.
mug: To take property from (a person) in a public place by threatening or committing violence on the person who is robbed; to rob, especially to rob by use of a weapon such as a knife or gun.
Methylate: To impregnate or mix with methyl or methyl alcohol.
Morphogeny: History of the evolution of forms; that part of ontogeny that deals with the germ history of forms; -- distinguished from physiogeny.
mu-meson: an elementary particle with a negative charge and a half-life of 2 microseconds; the muon.  It is a lepton, not a true meson, and decays to an electron and neutrino and antineutrino.
malabar kino: The reddish or black juice or resin from certain trees of the genus Pterocarpus, used in medicine and tanning etc.
Main yard: The yard on which the mainsail is extended, supported by the mainmast.
Mycoprotein: The protoplasmic matter of which bacteria are composed.
Malice: To regard with extreme ill will.
Miltwaste: A small European fern (Asplenium Ceterach) formerly used in medicine.
merging: The act or process of joining together into one entity.
Mallow: A genus of plants (Malva) having mucilaginous qualities. See Malvaceous.
&Verbar;Molluscum: A cutaneous disease characterized by numerous tumors, of various forms, filled with a thick matter; -- so called from the resemblance of the tumors to some molluscous animals.
Myriologue: An extemporaneous funeral song, composed and sung by a woman on the death of a friend.
&Verbar;Moratorium: A period during which an obligor has a legal right to delay meeting an obligation, esp. such a period granted, as to a bank, by a moratory law.
&Verbar;Meloe: A genus of beetles without wings, but having short oval elytra; the oil beetles.  These beetles are sometimes used instead of cantharides for raising blisters. See Oil beetle, under Oil.
Monography: Representation by lines without color; an outline drawing.
misaffection: An evil or wrong affection; the state of being ill affected.
machine pistol: A fully automatic pistol; a small submachine gun.
Moneran: Of or pertaining to the Monera.
Moneral: Of or pertaining to the Monera.
Metacism: A defect in pronouncing the letter m, or a too frequent use of it.
Misproportion: To give wrong or unesthetic proportions to; to join without due proportion; as, the legs were misrpoportioned to the body.
Manuring: The act of process of applying manure; also, the manure applied.
&Verbar;Mona: A small, handsome, long-tailed West American monkey (Cercopithecus mona). The body is dark olive, with a spot of white on the haunches.
&Verbar;Megaphyton: An extinct genus of tree ferns with large, two-ranked leaves, or fronds.
&Verbar;Mono: The black howler (Mycetes villosus), a monkey of Central America.
Millennist: One who believes in the millennium{2}.
Malingery: The spirit or practices of a malingerer; malingering.
Mojarra: Any of certain basslike marine fishes (mostly of tropical seas, and having a deep, compressed body, protracile mouth, and large silvery scales) constituting the family Gerridæ, as Gerres plumieri, found from Florida to Brazil and used as food.  Also, any of numerous other fishes of similar appearance but belonging to other families.
machine bolt: A threaded hexagonal or square-headed bolt with a nut; it is tightened with a wrench and used to connect metal parts.
