Manx shearwater: A small black-and-white oceanic bird (Puffinus puffinus, or Puffinus anglorum), common in the Eastern North Atlantic.  Called also Manx petrel, Manx puffin.  It is avariety of shearwater.  It was formerly abundant in the Isle of Man.
Metachloral: A white, amorphous, insoluble substance regarded as a polymeric variety of chloral.
Mnemonician: One who instructs in the art of improving or using the memory.
Mend: To grow better; to advance to a better state; to become improved; to recover; to heal.
Madagascan: a native or inhabitant of Madagascar.
Microcosmic: Of or pertaining to the microcosm.
Mustelidae: A natural family of fissiped fur-bearing carnivorous mammals including the weasels; polecats; ferrets; minks; fishers; otters; badgers; skunks; wolverines; and martens.
Motherly: In a manner of a mother.
Mutely: Without uttering words or sounds; in a mute manner; silently.
moose: A large cervine mammal (Alces alces syn. Alces machlis, syn Alces Americanus), native of the Northern United States and Canada. The adult male is about as large as a horse, and has very large, palmate antlers. It closely resembles the European elk, and by many zoölogists is considered the same species. See Elk.
Monoclinic: Having one oblique intersection; -- said of that system of crystallization in which the vertical axis is inclined to one, but at right angles to the other, lateral axis. See Crystallization.
Moisten: To make damp; to wet in a small degree.
M\u00e9linite: A high explosive similar to lyddite, consisting principally of picric acid, used in the French military service.
molting: The act or process by which an animal molts; especially, the periodic shedding of the cuticle in arthropods or the outer skin in reptiles, or feathers in birds.
Mowing: The act of one who, or the operation of that which, mows.
Major general: An officer of the army holding a rank next above that of brigadier general and next below that of lieutenant general, and who usually commands a division or a corps.
Misgrowth: Bad growth; an unnatural or abnormal growth.
Mirounga: A genus comprising the elephant seals.
Manager: One who manages; a conductor or director; as, the manager of a theater.
Mesognathous: Having the jaws slightly projecting; between prognathous and orthognathous. See Gnathic index, under Gnathic.
Manciple: A steward; a purveyor, particularly of a college or Inn of Court.
&Verbar;Muscales: An old name for mosses in the widest sense, including the true mosses and also hepaticæ and sphagna.
Mercaptan: Any one of series of compounds having an -SH radical attached to a carbon atom, also considered as hydrosulphides of alcohol radicals, in composition resembling the alcohols, but containing sulphur in place of oxygen, and hence called also the sulphur alcohols.  In general, they are colorless liquids having a strong, repulsive, garlic odor.  The name is specifically applied to ethyl mercaptan, C2H5SH.  So called from its avidity for mercury, and other metals.
Mercaptal: Any one of a series of compounds of mercaptans with aldehydes.
Misteach: To teach wrongly; to instruct erroneously.
Misconceive: To conceive wrongly; to interpret incorrectly; to receive a false notion of; to misunderstand; to misjudge; to misapprehend.
misprint: A mistake in printing; a deviation from the copy; as, a book full of misprints.  Misprints are sometimes noted and corrected in a list of corrigenda distributed with a book.
Myrmicine: Of or pertaining to Myrmica, a genus of ants including the small house ant (Myrmica molesta), and many others.
Mulct: To punish for an offense or misdemeanor by imposing a fine or forfeiture, esp. a pecuniary fine; to fine.
Metrical: Of or pertaining to the meter; arranged in meter; consisting of verses; as, metrical compositions.
Mastaba: In Mohammedan countries, a fixed seat, common in dwellings and in public places.
Melanure: A small fish of the Mediterranean; a gilthead. See Gilthead (a).
&Verbar;Mycothrix: The chain of micrococci formed by the division of the micrococci in multiplication.
&Verbar;Monopneumona: A suborder of Dipnoi, including the Ceratodus.
Magnification: The act of magnifying; enlargement; exaggeration.
Mealies: Maize or Indian corn; -- the common name in South Africa.
Madderwort: A name proposed for any plant of the same natural order (Rubiaceæ) as the madder.
Morse code: a telegraphic code, in which dots, dashes, and spaces represent letters, numbers, and other elements of text.  The original code was invented by Samuel B. Morse. The code now mostly used is the International Morse code, also referred to simply as the Morse code.
major premise: That premise of a syllogism that contains the major term (which is the predicate of the conclusion).  Contrasted to minor premise.
Mosque: A Mohammedan church or place of religious worship.
Manuductor: A conductor; an officer in the ancient church who gave the signal for the choir to sing, and who beat time with the hand, and regulated the music.
&Verbar;Macaco: Any one of several species of lemurs, as the ruffed lemur (Lemur macaco), and the ring-tailed lemur (Lemur catta).
Much: To a great degree or extent; greatly; abundantly; far; nearly.
Monopode: One of a fabulous tribe or race of Ethiopians having but one leg and foot.
Misnurture: To nurture or train wrongly; as, to misnurture children.
Mankind: Manlike; not womanly; masculine; bold; cruel.
Monopody: A measure of but a single foot.
Megatheroid: One of a family of extinct edentates found in America. The family includes the megatherium, the megalonyx, etc.
Maximilian: A gold coin of Bavaria, of the value of about 13s. 6d. sterling, or about three dollars and a quarter.
Mind: To give attention or heed; to obey; as, the dog minds well.
Mitral: Pertaining to a miter; resembling a miter; as, the mitral valve between the left auricle and left ventricle of the heart.
margin account: An account with a securities brokerage in which the broker extends credit.
Macaca sylvana: The Barbary ape, a tailless macaque of rocky cliffs and forests of Northwest Africa and Gibralter.
Machiner: One who or operates a machine; a machinist{2}.
Mylohyoid: Pertaining to, or in the region of, the lower jaw and the hyoid apparatus; as, the mylohyoid nerve.
Mae West: An inflatable life jacket, originally used as a personal flotation device by aviators downed at sea.
Mercerize: To treat (cotton fiber or fabrics) with a solution of caustic alkali.  Such treatment causes the fiber to shrink in length and become stronger and more receptive of dyes. If the yarn or cloth is kept under tension during the process, it assumes a silky luster.
merkin: Originally, a wig; afterwards, a mop for cleaning cannon.
Motherwort: A labiate herb (Leonurus Cardiaca), of a bitter taste, used popularly in medicine; lion's tail.
Mantua: A superior kind of rich silk formerly exported from Mantua in Italy.
&Verbar;Mezzo-rilievo: A middle degree of relief in figures, between high and low relief.
Metol: A whitish soluble powder used as a developer in photography.  Chemically, it is the sulphate of methyl-p-amino-m-cresol.
Melanochroic: Having a dark complexion; of or pertaining to the Melanochroi.
Murrayin: A glucoside found in the flowers of a plant (Murraya exotica) of South Asia, and extracted as a white amorphous slightly bitter substance.
Muck: Dung in a moist state; manure.
&Verbar;Meiosis: Diminution; a species of hyperbole, representing a thing as being less than it really is; understatement; see also litotes.
M\u0153sogothic: The language of the Mœsogoths; -- also called Gothic.
Mediacy: The state or quality of being mediate.
Merchantable: Fit for market; such as is usually sold in market, or such as will bring the ordinary price; as, merchantable wheat; sometimes, a technical designation for a particular kind or class.
Mesobranchial: Of or pertaining to a region of the carapace of a crab covering the middle branchial region.
Mummiform: Having some resemblance to a mummy; -- in zoölogy, said of the pupæ of certain insects.
Mailclad: Protected by a coat of mail; clad in armor.
Myrmecophyte: A plant that affords shelter and food to certain species of ants which live in symbiotic relations with it. Special adaptations for this purpose exist; thus, Acacia spadicigera has large hollows thorns, and species of Cecropia have stem cavities.
Manna croup: The portions of hard wheat kernels not ground into flour by the millstones: a kind of semolina prepared in Russia and used for puddings, soups, etc. -- called also manna groats.
mandibular joint: The joint between the head of the lower jawbone and the temporal bone.
Mahonia: A genus of evergreen shrubs and small trees of North and Central America and Asia.
Minie rifle: A rifle adapted to minie balls.
&Verbar;Metacromion: A process projecting backward and downward from the acromion of the scapula of some mammals.
Motmot: Any one of several species of long-tailed, passerine birds of the genus Momotus, having a strong serrated beak.  In most of the species the two long middle tail feathers are racket-shaped at the tip, when mature.  The bird itself is said by some writers to trim them into this shape.  They feed on insects, reptiles, and fruit, and are found from Mexico to Brazil.  The name is derived from its note.
Mothers Day: A day appointed for the honor and uplift of motherhood by the loving remembrance of each person of his mother through the performance of some act of kindness, visit, tribute, or letter. The founder of the day is Anna Jarvis, of Philadelphia, who designated the second Sunday in May, or for schools the second Friday, as the time, and a white carnation as the badge.
Mortise: To cut or make a mortise in.
Morning-glory: A climbing plant (Ipomœa purpurea) having handsome, funnel-shaped flowers, usually red, pink, purple, white, or variegated, sometimes pale blue. See Dextrorsal.
&Verbar;Millier: A weight of the metric system, being one million grams; a metric ton.
Maltman: A man whose occupation is to make malt.
megalithic: Of or pertaining to megaliths or the period during which they were erected; as, megalithic monuments like Stonehenge.
Mytilotoxine: A poisonous base (leucomaine) found in the common mussel.  It either causes paralysis of the muscles, or gives rise to convulsions, including death by an accumulation of carbonic acid in the blood.
Marigold: A name for several plants with golden yellow blossoms, especially the Calendula officinalis (see Calendula), and the cultivated species of Tagetes.
Music hall: A place for public musical entertainments; specif. (Eng.), esp. a public hall for vaudeville performances, in which smoking and drinking are usually allowed in the auditorium.
Melotype: A picture produced by a process in which development after exposure may be deferred indefinitely, so as to permit transportation of exposed plates; also, the process itself.
matchbox: a box for holding matches.  See first match, n.
Milestone: A stone serving the same purpose as a milepost.
masturbate: To achieve sexual gratification by stimulating one's own sexual organs, without the aid of a partner; -- typically to the point of orgasm.
&Verbar;Mahabarata: A celebrated sacred epic poem of the Hindus, written in Sanskrit.  It is of great length, and is chiefly devoted to a history, in many episodes, of a civil war between two dynasties of ancient India.
Mattages: A shrike or butcher bird; -- written also matagasse.
Mactation: The act of killing a victim for sacrifice.
Moonfish: An American marine fish (Vomer setipennis); -- called also bluntnosed shiner, horsefish, and sunfish.
Melungeon: One of a mixed white and Indian people living in parts of Tennessee and the Carolinas.  They are descendants of early intermixtures of white settlers with natives.  In North Carolina the Croatan Indians, regarded as descended from Raleigh's lost colony of Croatan, formerly classed with negroes, are now legally recognized as distinct.
marine mine: A military explosive device designed to be placed on or under the surface of a body of water, and to explode when ships pass nearby or come in contact with it.  Its function is to destroy enemy ships or deny hostile naval forces access to certain areas of the sea, usually near the shoreline.  Also called underwater mine and floating mine, and previously referred to as a torpedo (See torpedo{2} (a)).
Myrtiform: Resembling myrtle or myrtle berries; having the form of a myrtle leaf.
Metacarpus: That part of the skeleton of the hand or forefoot between the carpus and phalanges. In man it consists of five bones. See Illust. of Artiodactyla.
Mindless: Not indued with mind or intellectual powers; stupid; unthinking.
Mellitic: Containing saccharine matter; marked by saccharine secretions; as, mellitic diabetes.
Methodios: The art and principles of method.
Mease: Five hundred; as, a mease of herrings.
Mastigure: Any one of several large spiny-tailed lizards of the genus Uromastix.  They inhabit Southern Asia and North Africa.
Myall wood: A durable, fragrant, and dark-colored Australian wood, used by the natives for spears. It is obtained from the small tree Acacia homolophylla.
Mandragorite: One who habitually intoxicates himself with a narcotic obtained from mandrake.
Mucronulate: Having, or tipped with, a small point or points.
&Verbar;Moodir: The governor of a province in Egypt, etc.
Multifarious: Having multiplicity; having great diversity or variety; of various kinds; diversified; made up of many differing parts; manifold.
Mohammedan calendar: A lunar calendar reckoning from the year of the hegira (hejira), 622 a. d. Thirty of its years constitute a cycle, of which the 2d, 5th, 7th, 10th, 13th, 16th, 18th, 21st, 24th, 26th, and 29th are leap years, having 355 days; the others are common, having 354 days.
Mincingly: In a mincing manner; not fully; with affected nicety.
Matrimonial: Of or pertaining to marriage; derived from marriage; connubial; nuptial; hymeneal; as, matrimonial rights or duties.
Monolith: A single stone, especially one of large size, shaped into a pillar, statue, or monument.
muscleman: a bully employed by a gangster.
Maine: One of the New England States.
machine tool: A power-driven machine for cutting or shaping or finishing metals or other materials.
Mugwumpery: The acts and views of the mugwumps.
morals: motivation based on ideas of right and wrong.
Mammonish: Actuated or prompted by a devotion to money getting or the service of Mammon.
Mammonism: Devotion to the pursuit of wealth; worldliness.
Member: To remember; to cause to remember; to mention.
mail call: A call of the names of those persons receiving mail for the purpose of transmitting mail to them; -- a technique used in the military services to deliver mail to enlisted personnel.
Murrelet: One of several species of sea birds of the genera Synthliboramphus and Brachyramphus, inhabiting the North Pacific.  They are closely related to the murres.
&Verbar;Manes: The benevolent spirits of the dead, especially of dead ancestors, regarded as family deities and protectors.
Medium-sized: Having a medium size; as, a medium-sized man.
Meanly: In a mean manner; unworthily; basely; poorly; ungenerously.
Monandry: The possession by a woman of only one husband at the same time; -- contrasted with polyandry.
&Verbar;Maneh: A Hebrew weight for gold or silver, being one hundred shekels of gold and sixty shekels of silver.
machine screw: A type of screw used either with a nut or with a tapped hole; it has a slotted head which can be driven by a screwdriver.
Mesotype: An old term covering natrolite or soda mesolite, scolecite or lime mesotype, and mesolite or lime-soda mesotype.
mainline: to inject (illegal drugs) into the vein; as, he preferred to mainline heroin rather than sniff coke.
malt whiskey: A whiskey distilled in Scotland (esp. whiskey made from malted barley in a pot still); Scotch whisky.
Motile: A person whose prevailing mental imagery takes the form of inner feelings of action, such as incipient pronunciation of words, muscular innervations, etc.
Melanocomous: Having very dark or black hair; black-haired.
Mino bird: An Asiatic bird (Gracula musica), allied to the starlings.  It is black, with a white spot on the wings, and a pair of flat yellow wattles on the head.  It is often tamed and taught to pronounce words.  It is one of the birds called mynah bird.
Monamine: A basic compound containing one amido group; a monoamine; as, methyl amine is a monamine.
Mix: To become united into a compound; to be blended promiscuously together.
Miscognize: To fail to apprehend; to misunderstand.
&Verbar;Matamata: The bearded tortoise (Chelys fimbriata) of South American rivers.
man jack: A single individual person; as, every man jack of them.
Missing: Absent from the place where it was expected to be found; lost; lacking; wanting; not present when called or looked for.
Marketing: The act of selling or of purchasing in, or as in, a market.
Menthene: A colorless liquid hydrocarbon resembling oil of turpentine, obtained by dehydrating menthol. It has an agreeable odor and a cooling taste.
merbromine: A mercurial compound applied topically as an antiseptic; Mercurochrome is the trademark.
Misarrange: To place in a wrong order, or improper manner.
Mopstick: The long handle of a mop.
micrometeorite: A meteorite so small that it drifts down to Earth without becoming intensely heated in the earth's atmosphere.
Malpais: The rough surface of a congealed lava stream.
Maha: A member of the Siouan people formerly living in the Missouri river valley in Northeastern Nebraska; called also Omaha.
&Verbar;Madrepora: A genus of reef corals abundant in tropical seas. It includes than one hundred and fifty species, most of which are elegantly branched.
&Verbar;Mastigopoda: Formerly considered identical to the Infusoria, now distinguished from that group, which has been reordered.  See Mastigophora.
Mustard: The name of several cruciferous plants of the genus Brassica (formerly Sinapis), as white mustard (Brassica alba), black mustard (Brassica Nigra), wild mustard or charlock (Brassica Sinapistrum).
&Verbar;Marimonda: A spider monkey (Ateles belzebuth) of Central and South America.
Mesomyodian: A bird having a mesomyodous larynx.
Merry-andrew: One whose business is to make sport for others; a buffoon; a zany; especially, one who attends a mountebank or quack doctor.
Milfoil: A common composite herb (Achillea Millefolium) with white flowers and finely dissected leaves; yarrow.
&Verbar;Moho: A gallinule (Notornis Mantelli) formerly inhabiting New Zealand, but now supposed to be extinct.  It was incapable of flight. See Notornis.
Melt: To be changed from a solid to a liquid state under the influence of heat; as, butter and wax melt at moderate temperatures.
macrotus: A large-eared grayish bat (Macrotus californicus) of southern California and northwestern Mexico.
mutative: Of or pertaining to or marked by genetic mutation{3}.
&Verbar;Molto: Much; very; as, molto adagio, very slow.
mantlepiece: A shelf that projects from the wall above a fireplace; a mantel; as, in England they call a mantelpiece a chimneypiece.
Meld: In the game of pinochle, to declare or announce for a score; as, to meld a sequence.
microcomputer: A small computer based on a microprocessor; in practise, at any given time in the technology of computer development, a microcomputer will be one that is less powerful than a minicomputer.
Millimeter: A lineal measure in the metric system, containing the thousandth part of a meter; equal to .03937 of an inch. See 3d Meter.
Monarchic: Of or pertaining to a monarch, or to monarchy.
Moving: The act of changing place or posture; esp., the act of changing one's dwelling place or place of business.
Menurae: A suborder of birds including lyrebirds and scrubbirds.
magnetic field strength: The amount of magnetic flux in a unit area perpendicular to the direction of magnetic flow.
&Verbar;M\u00e9tayage: A system of farming on halves.
Mutoscope: A simple form of moving-picture machine in which the series of views, exhibiting the successive phases of a scene, are printed on paper and mounted around the periphery of a wheel.  The rotation of the wheel brings them rapidly into sight, one after another, and the blended effect gives a semblance of motion.
&Verbar;Mastodynia: Pain occuring in the mamma or female breast, -- a form of neuralgia.
maidenhair: Any of various small to large terrestrial ferns of the genus Adiantum having very slender graceful stalks and delicate palmately branched fronds, especially  (Adiantum pedatum).  It is common in the United States, and is sometimes used in medicine.  The name is also applied to other species of the same genus, as to the Venus-hair.
Mucus: A viscid fluid secreted by mucous membranes, which it serves to moisten and protect. It covers the lining membranes of all the cavities which open externally, such as those of the mouth, nose, lungs, intestinal canal, urinary passages, etc.
Meteoroid: A small body moving through space, or revolving about the sun, which on entering the earth's atmosphere would be deflagrated and appear as a meteor.
monarch butterfly: A very large red and black butterfly (Danais Plexippus) having striking orange-brown wings with black veins in a reticulated pattern; -- called also milkweed butterfly and monarch.  Its larvae feed on the leaves of the milkweed.
Midwife: To perform the office of midwife.
&Verbar;Mallotus: A genus of small Arctic fishes. One American species, the capelin (Mallotus villosus), is extensively used as bait for cod.
Monology: The habit of soliloquizing, or of monopolizing conversation.
magnetic line of force: A line of force in a magnetic field.
Mucamide: The acid amide of mucic acid, obtained as a white crystalline substance.
Madhouse: An house or institution where insane persons are confined; an insane asylum; a bedlam; -- usually used in a deprecatory sense.
Marconis law: The law that the maximum good signaling distance varies directly as the square of the height of the transmitting antenna.
Mariet: A kind of bellflower, Companula Trachelium, once called Viola Mariana; but it is not a violet.
Meteorism: Flatulent distention of the abdomen; tympanites.
Morphon: A morphological individual, characterized by definiteness of form, in distinction from bion, a physiological individual. See Tectology.
Mendacity: The quality or state of being mendacious; a habit of lying.
Mealtime: The usual time of eating a meal.
mass-spectrometric: of or pertaining to mass spectrometry; determined by mass spectrometry.
Manqueller: A killer of men; a manslayer.
Majuscule: A capital letter; especially, one used in ancient manuscripts. See Majusculæ.
mind-altering: producing mood changes or distorted perception; -- used mostly of psychoactive substances; as, hallucinogenic drugs are mind-altering substances.
Mazologist: One versed in mazology or mastology.
mint state: A numerical grade indicating the degree of perfection of the condition of a coin which is classified as uncirculated, ranging from 70 for a coin in perfect condition to 60 for a coin which is uncirculated but may have a weak strike, or numerous small scratches from being handled in mint bags; usually used as the abbreviation MS; as, an MS-67 Morgan Dollar.
mid-fifties: the time of life between 50 and 60.
Misthrive: To thrive poorly; to be not thrifty or prosperous.
Maundy Thursday: The Thursday in Passion week, or next before Good Friday.
&Verbar;M\u00e4nnerchor: A German men's chorus or singing club.
&Verbar;Marbrinus: A cloth woven so as to imitate the appearance of marble; -- much used in the 15th and 16th centuries.
Mowburn: To heat and ferment in the mow, as hay when housed too green.
Maidenhead: The state of being a maiden; maidenhood; virginity.
Mesolabe: An instrument of the ancients for finding two mean proportionals between two given lines, required in solving the problem of the duplication of the cube.
mated: Brought together for sexual activity; bred; -- of animals.
matey: having the relationship of friends or pals.
Moggan: A closely fitting knit sleeve; also, a legging of knitted material.
millwheel: a waterwheel that is used to drive machinery in a mill.
Menticultural: Of or pertaining to mental culture; serving to improve or strengthen the mind.
Maltese: Of or pertaining to Malta or to its inhabitants.
Mitigator: One who, or that which, mitigates.
Multi-: A prefix signifying much or many; several; more than one; as, multiaxial, multocular.
Mnemonics: The art of memory; a method for improving the memory; a system of precepts and rules intended to assist the memory; artificial memory.
Malagasy Republic: Former name of the Republic of Madagascar, a nation in Africa occupying the island of Madagascar in the Indian Ocean east of Mozambique.
Mucilage: A gummy or gelatinous substance produced in certain plants by the action of water on the cell wall, as in the seeds of quinces, of flax, etc.
Megalocyte: A large, flattened red blood cell corpuscle having no nucleus, twice the diameter of the ordinary red corpuscle, found in considerable numbers in the blood in profound anæmia.
Moric: Pertaining to, or derived from, fustic (see Morin); as, moric acid.
Monotonous: Uttered in one unvarying tone; continued with dull uniformity; characterized by monotony; without change or variety; wearisome.
Moril: An edible fungus. Same as 1st Morel.
Maroon: A brownish or dull red of any description, esp. of a scarlet cast rather than approaching crimson or purple.
Miniate: Of or pertaining to the color of red lead or vermilion; painted with vermilion.
-morphous: A combining form denoting form, shape; as, isomorphous.
Macco: A gambling game in vogue in the eighteenth century.
&Verbar;Malacobdella: A genus of nemertean worms, parasitic in the gill cavity of clams and other bivalves. They have a large posterior sucker, like that of a leech. See Illust. of Bdellomorpha.
man hour: The quantity of work which one person can perform in one hour; -- often an estimate made for the purpose of deciding whether to undertake a project, and sometimes used in accounting; as, it will take a hundred man-hours to write the program.
masturbation: The act of masturbating; sexual self-gratification; onanism.
microsome: a tiny granule in the cytoplasm of a cell; it consists of ribosomes bound to fragments of the endoplasmic reticulum and mitochondria.
Mazourka: A Polish dance, or the music which accompanies it, usually in 3-4 or 3-8 measure, with a strong accent on the second beat.
microphonics: The science which treats of the means of increasing the intensity of low or weak sounds, or of the microphone.
Marbler: One who works upon marble or other stone.
Multiplicand: The number which is to be multiplied by another number called the multiplier. See Note under Multiplication.
Monteth: A vessel in which glasses are washed; -- so called from the name of the inventor.
Missit: To sit badly or imperfectly upon; to misbecome.
Marbled: Made of, or faced with, marble.
Missis: A mistress; a wife; -- so used by the illiterate.
Metallochrome: A coloring produced by the deposition of some metallic compound; specifically, the prismatic tints produced by depositing a film of peroxide of lead on polished steel by electricity.
meals on wheels: A program that delivers hot meals to persons, such as the elderly or disabled, who are confined to their homes and unable to cook for themselves; also, the meals thus delivered.  Such programs are usually conducted by governmental or charitable organizations.
Metrograph: An instrument attached to a locomotive for recording its speed and the number and duration of its stops.
Metallochromy: The art or process of coloring metals.
Merestead: The land within the boundaries of a farm; a farmstead or farm.
Megilp: A gelatinous compound of linseed oil and mastic varnish, used by artists as a vehicle for colors.
Magen David: A hexagram{1a}, when used as the symbol of Judaism; called also Mogen David and Star of David.  It is included on the flag of Israel
maturement: The process of maturing; coming to full development; becoming mature; maturation.
&Verbar;Malleus: The outermost of the three small auditory bones, ossicles; the hammer. It is attached to the tympanic membrane by a long process, the handle or manubrium. See Illust. of Far.
majority leader: The leader of the majority party in a legislature.  Compare minority leader.
mappery: The making, or study, of maps.
Mackintosh: A waterproof outer garment; -- so called from the name of the inventor.
Mutiny: To rise against, or refuse to obey, lawful authority in military or naval service; to excite, or to be guilty of, mutiny or mutinous conduct; to revolt against one's superior officer, or any rightful authority.
Microsorium: A genus of tropical usually epiphytic ferns, found from Africa to Asia, and from Polynesia to Australia.
Morgue: A place where the bodies of dead persons are kept, until they are identified, or claimed by their friends; a deadhouse.
&Verbar;Mesoarium: The fold of peritoneum which suspends the ovary from the dorsal wall of the body cavity; the mesovarium.
Misrender: To render wrongly; to translate or recite wrongly.
Medinilla: A genus of tropical Old World ornamental evergreen shrubs having fleshy leaves and large panicles of white pink flowers.
Metallize: To impart metallic properties to; to impregnate with a metal.
Misfeign: To feign with an evil design.
Middlemost: Being in the middle, or nearest the middle; midmost.
Monte-acid: An acid elevator, as a tube through which acid is forced to some height in a sulphuric acid manufactory.
Manganese: An element obtained by reduction of its oxide, as a hard, grayish white metal, fusible with difficulty (melting point 1244° C), but easily oxidized.  Its ores occur abundantly in nature as the minerals pyrolusite, manganite, etc.  Symbol Mn.  Atomic number 25; Atomic weight 54.938 [C=12.011].
Mammonization: The process of making mammonish; the state of being under the influence of mammonism.
Month: One of the twelve portions into which the year is divided; the twelfth part of a year, corresponding nearly to the length of a synodic revolution of the moon, -- whence the name.  In popular use, a period of four weeks is often called a month.
Mopboard: A narrow board nailed against the wall of a room next to the floor; skirting board; baseboard. See Baseboard.
monarda: Any of various aromatic herbs of the genus Monarda.
Mortification: The act of mortifying, or the condition of being mortified
Meanness: The condition, or quality, of being mean; want of excellence; poorness; lowness; baseness; sordidness; stinginess.
Mechanician: One skilled in the theory or construction of machines; a machinist.
Metallifacture: The production and working or manufacture of metals.
man-of-war bird: The frigate bird, a long-billed warm-water seabird with wide wingspan and forked tail; also applied to the skua gulls, and to the wandering albatross.
mistiming: The act or process of assigning something to a time when it could not have existed or occurred.
maleic acid: An unsaturated dicarboxylic acid (HO.CO.CH=CH.CO.OH) of cis conformation, having various uses in the manufacture of artificial resins, the dyeing and finishing of wool, silk, and cotton, and also combined with certain drugs to make salts more soluble than the basic forms.  The corresponding isomer having trans conformation, is identical in chemical formula, is called fumaric acid.
Mennonist: One of a small denomination of Christians, so called from Menno Simons of Friesland, their founder.  They believe that the New Testament is the only rule of faith, that there is no original sin, that infants should not be baptized, and that Christians ought not to take oath, hold office, or render military service.
&Verbar;Mallophaga: An extensive group of insects which are parasitic on birds and mammals, and feed on the feathers and hair; -- called also bird lice. See Bird louse, under Bird.
Myeloc\u0153le: The central canal of the spinal cord.
Money-maker: One who coins or prints money; also, a counterfeiter of money.
Morganatic: Pertaining to, in the manner of, or designating, a kind of marriage, called also left-handed marriage, between a man of superior rank and a woman of inferior, in which it is stipulated that neither the latter nor her children shall enjoy the rank or inherit the possessions of her husband.
Myrobalan: A dried astringent fruit much resembling a prune.  It contains tannin, and was formerly used in medicine, but is now chiefly used in tanning and dyeing.  Myrobolans are produced by various species of Terminalia of the East Indies, and of Spondias of South America.
&Verbar;Myelon: The spinal cord. (Sometimes abbrev. to myel.)
Marathi: A Sanskritic language of western India, prob. descended from the Maharastri Prakrit, spoken by the Marathas and neighboring peoples.  It has an abundant literature dating from the 13th century.  It has a book alphabet nearly the same as Devanagari and a cursive script translation between the Devanagari and the Gujarati.
Mumble: To utter with a low, inarticulate voice.
meperidine: A synthetic narcotic drug used as a sedative; Demerol is the trademark of a brand of meperidine.
Moldery: Covered or filled with mold; consisting of, or resembling, mold.
Mortiferous: Bringing or producing death; deadly; destructive; as, a mortiferous herb.
mother-of-thousands: An East Asiatic saxifrage (Saxifraga stolonifera) with racemes of small red-and-white flowers; spreads by numerous creeping stolons; called also strawberry geranium and strawberry saxifrage.
Mendication: The act or practice of begging; beggary; mendicancy.
Mousetail: A genus of ranunculaceous plants (Myosurus), in which the prolonged receptacle is covered with imbricating achenes, and so resembles the tail of a mouse.
moronic: having a mental age of between eight and twelve years; also used as a derogatory term.
Medi\u00e6val: Of or relating to the Middle Ages; as, mediæval architecture.
Mete: Measure; limit; boundary; -- used chiefly in the plural, and in the phrase metes and bounds.
muffled: same as muted; as, muffled drums; the muffled noises of the street.
&Verbar;Momus: The god of mockery and censure.
minimize: To reduce to the smallest part or proportion possible; to reduce to a minimum.
&Verbar;Machete: A large heavy knife resembling a broadsword, often two or three feet in length, -- used by the inhabitants of Spanish America as a hatchet to cut their way through thickets, and for various other purposes.
modem: An electronic device that converts electronic signals into sound waves, and sound waves into electronic signals, used to transmit information between computers by the use of ordinary telephone lines; also called modulator-demodulator; as, the latest modems can transmit data at 56,000 baud over a clear telephone line.  The speed of transmission of information by a modem is usually measured in units of baud, equivalent to bits per second.
Miter: To meet and match together, as two pieces of molding, on a line bisecting the angle of junction.
Modificative: That which modifies or qualifies, as a word or clause.
Marchantiales: An oder of liverworts with gametophyte differentiated internally.
Municipal: Of or pertaining to a city or a corporation having the right of administering local government; as, municipal rights; municipal officers.
monolingual: Using or knowing only one language; as, monolingual speakers; a monolingual dictionary.  Opposite of multilingual.
Monolithic: Of or pertaining to a monolith; consisting of a single stone.
Missile: A weapon thrown or projected or intended to be projected, as a lance, an arrow, or a bullet.
Muggletonian: One of an extinct sect, named after Ludovic Muggleton, an English journeyman tailor, who (about 1657) claimed to be inspired.
Microfarad: The millionth part of a farad.
Maudle: To throw onto confusion or disorder; to render maudlin.
Manualist: One who works with the hands; an artificer.
Marmottes oil: A fine oil obtained from the kernel of Prunus brigantiaca. It is used instead of olive or almond oil.
Manx: The language of the inhabitants of the Isle of Man, a dialect of the Celtic.
Many: The populace; the common people; the majority of people, or of a community.
&Verbar;Meerkat: A South African carnivore (Suricata suricata, formerly Cynictis penicillata), allied to the ichneumons, having a lemurlike face and only four toes; called also yellow mongoose and suricate.
Mutism: The condition, state, or habit of being mute, or without speech.
Meadowsweet: The name of several plants of the genus Spiræa, especially the white- or pink-flowered Spiræa salicifolia, a low European and American shrub, and the herbaceous Spiræa Ulmaria, which has fragrant white flowers in compound cymes.
Mane: The long and heavy hair growing on the upper side of, or about, the neck of some quadrupedal animals, as the horse, the lion, etc. See Illust. of Horse.
&Verbar;Magi: A caste of priests, philosophers, and magicians, among the ancient Persians; hence, any holy men or sages of the East.
mugger: A thief who takes property by threatening (or performing) violence on the person who is robbed; a person who commits a mugging; one who mugs.  See mug, v. t.
Majestic: Possessing or exhibiting majesty; of august dignity, stateliness, or imposing grandeur; lofty; noble; grand.
Mawkish: Apt to cause satiety or loathing; nauseous; slightly nauseating; disgusting.
Mahori: One of the dark race inhabiting principally the islands of Eastern Polynesia. Also used adjectively.
&Verbar;M\u00eal\u00e9e: A fight in which the combatants are mingled in one confused mass; a hand to hand conflict; an affray.
Metatitanic: Of, pertaining to, or designating, an acid of titanium analogous to metasilicic acid.
Moonbeam: A ray of light from the moon.
-mo: A suffix added to the names of certain numerals or to the numerals themselves, to indicate the number of leaves made by folding a sheet of paper; as, sixteenmo or 16mo; eighteenmo or 18mo.  It is taken from the Latin forms similarly used; as, duodecimo, sextodecimo, etc.  A small circle, placed after the number and near its top, is often used for -mo; as, 16°, 18°, etc.
mass spectrometry: A method for identifying chemical composition of substances by use of a mass spectrometer.
Mustiness: The quality or state of being musty.
Minargent: An alloy consisting of copper, nickel, tungsten, and aluminium; -- used by jewelers.
Mounting: The act of one that mounts.
Mildness: The quality or state of being mild; as, mildness of temper; the mildness of the winter.
maple-leaved bayur: An Indian tree (Pterospermum acerifolium) having fragrant nocturnal white flowers and yielding a reddish wood used for planking; often grown as an ornamental or shade tree.  Called also mayeng.
moot: A ring for gauging wooden pins.
Mucigen: A substance which is formed in mucous epithelial cells, and gives rise to mucin.
Malamethane: A white crystalline substance forming the ethyl salt of malamic acid.
Macropodal: Having long or large feet, or a long stem.
Moppet: A rag baby; a puppet made of cloth; hence, also, in fondness, a little girl, or a woman.
Metropolitical: Of or pertaining to a metropolis; being a metropolis; metropolitan; as, the metropolitical chair.
Mystagogy: The doctrines, principles, or practice of a mystagogue; interpretation of mysteries.
matrilineal: tracing descent through the female line.
magnetic dipole moment: A physical quantity associated with the magnetic field of a dundamental particle; as, An orbiting electron in an atom will have a magnetic dipole moment.
Massiveness: The state or quality of being massive; massiness.
Mon\u0153cian: Of or pertaining to the Monœcia; monœcious.
&Verbar;Macavahu: A small Brazilian monkey (Callithrix torquatus), -- called also collared teetee.
Milk sickness: A peculiar malignant disease, occurring in parts of the western United States, and affecting certain kinds of farm stock (esp. cows), and persons using the meat or dairy products of infected cattle. Its chief symptoms in man are uncontrollable vomiting, obstinate constipation, pain, and muscular tremors. Its origin in cattle has been variously ascribed to the presence of certain plants in their food, and to polluted water.
Malefactor: An evil doer; one who commits a crime; one subject to public prosecution and punishment; a criminal.
Micaceo-calcareous: Partaking of the nature of, or consisting of, mica and lime; -- applied to a mica schist containing carbonate of lime.
Megascopic: Of or pertaining to the megascope or the projection upon a screen of images of opaque objects.
Minstrelsy: The arts and occupation of minstrels; the singing and playing of a minstrel.
Marver: A stone, or cast-iron plate, or former, on which hot glass is rolled to give it shape.
Meroistic: Applied to the ovaries of insects when they secrete vitelligenous cells, as well as ova.
Mimosaceae: A natural family of spiny woody plants (usually shrubs or small trees) whose leaves mimic animals in sensitivity to touch; commonly included in the family Leguminosae.
Mendel: Gregor Johann Mendel, founder of the science of genetics (1822-1884); Gregor Mendel.
Monsoon: A wind blowing part of the year from one direction, alternating with a wind from the opposite direction; -- a term applied particularly to periodical winds of the Indian Ocean, which blow from the southwest from the latter part of May to the middle of September, and from the northeast from about the middle of October to the middle of December.
Mandible: The bone, or principal bone, of the lower jaw; the inferior maxilla; -- also applied to either the upper or the lower jaw in the beak of birds.
-meter: A suffix denoting that by which anything is measured; as, barometer, chronometer, dynamometer.
mycobacterium: Any of various rod-shaped bacteria, some saprophytic or causing diseases.
&Verbar;Meleagris: A genus of American gallinaceous birds, including the common turkey and the wild turkeys.
mahlstick: A long stick that a painter uses to support the hand holding the brush while painting.  Same as Maul-stick.
Mathematics: That science, or class of sciences, which treats of the exact relations existing between quantities or magnitudes, and of the methods by which, in accordance with these relations, quantities sought are deducible from other quantities known or supposed; the science of spatial and quantitative relations.
mercury bichloride: the compound (HgCl2) consisting of two atoms of chlorine united with one atom of mercury.   Also called bichloride of mercury, mercuric chloride, corrosive sublimate, and mercury perchloride.  It is used as “a topical antiseptic and disinfectant for inanimate objects”.
Muller: A stone or thick lump of glass, or kind of pestle, flat at the bottom, used for grinding pigments or drugs, etc., upon a slab of similar material.
Micropantograph: A kind of pantograph which produces copies microscopically minute.
malconformation: Imperfect, disproportionate, or abnormal formation; ill form; disproportion of parts.
Miscarriage: Unfortunate event or issue of an undertaking; failure to attain a proper or desired result or reach a destination; as, a serious miscarriage of justice.
Maternity: The state of being a mother; motherhood.
Mysteriousness: The state or quality of being mysterious.
midair: some point in the air; above ground level; as, the planes collided in midair; also used attributively; as, a midair collision.
Marconi system: A system or wireless telegraphy developed by G. Marconi, an Italian physicist, in which Hertzian waves are used in transmission and a coherer is used as the receiving instrument.
Mahoe: A name given to several malvaceous trees (species of Hibiscus, Ochroma, etc.), and to their strong fibrous inner bark, which is used for strings and cordage.
Majesty: The dignity and authority of sovereign power; quality or state which inspires awe or reverence; grandeur; exalted dignity, whether proceeding from rank, character, or bearing; imposing loftiness; stateliness; -- usually applied to the rank and dignity of sovereigns.
Medically: In a medical manner; with reference to healing, or to the principles of the healing art.
Magaziner: One who edits or writes for a magazine.
Melicerous: Consisting of or containing matter like honey; -- said of certain encysted tumors.
Maple: A tree of the genus Acer, including about fifty species. Acer saccharinum is the rock maple, or sugar maple, from the sap of which sugar is made, in the United States, in great quantities, by evaporation; the red maple or swamp maple is Acer rubrum; the silver maple, Acer dasycarpum, having fruit wooly when young; the striped maple, Acer Pennsylvanium, called also moosewood.  The common maple of Europe is Acer campestre, the sycamore maple is Acer Pseudo-platanus, and the Norway maple is Acer platanoides.
Megerg: One of the larger measures of work, amounting to one million ergs; -- called also megalerg.
Miryachit: A nervous disease in which the patient involuntarily imitates the words or action of another.
Minor: A person of either sex who has not attained the age at which full civil rights are accorded; an infant; in England and the United States, one under twenty-one years of age.
Minos: A king and lawgiver of Crete, fabled to be the son of Jupiter and Europa.  After death he was made a judge in the Lower Regions.
matrilineage: The line of descent traced through the maternal side of the family; the mother's line of descent.
Melancholiness: The state or quality of being melancholy.
Muskellunge: A large American pike (Esox masquinongy formerly Esox nobilior) found in the Great Lakes, and other Northern lakes, and in the St. Lawrence River. It is valued as a food fish.
Multisonous: Having many sounds, or sounding much.
Monocephalous: Having a solitary head; -- said of unbranched composite plants.
Monocardian: Having a single heart, as fishes and amphibians.
Morepork: The Australian crested goatsucker (Ægotheles Novæ-Hollandiæ).  Also applied to other allied birds, as Podargus Cuveiri.
Malfeasance: The doing of an act which a person ought not to do; evil conduct; an illegal deed.
Multigraph: A combined rotary type-setting and printing machine for office use.  The type is transferred semi-automatically by means of keys from a type-supply drum to a printing drum.  The printing may be done by means of an inked ribbon to print “typewritten” letters, or directly from inked type or a stereotype plate, as in a printing press.
Momentarily: Every moment; from moment to moment.
Mollification: The act of mollifying, or the state of being mollified; a softening.
Macao: A territory in South China, on the Zhu Jiang river on the South China sea, formerly a territory of Portugal.  Also, the capital city of this territory.
&Verbar;Myelitis: Inflammation of the spinal marrow or its membranes.
Monocarpic: Bearing fruit but once, and dying after fructification, as beans, maize, mustard, etc.
Magniloquence: The quality of being magniloquent; pompous discourse; grandiloquence.
Meleagrine: Of or pertaining to the genus Meleagris.
Memoir: A memorial account; a history composed from personal experience and memory; an account of transactions or events (usually written in familiar style) as they are remembered by the writer. See History, 2.
Mico: A small South American monkey (Mico melanurus), allied to the marmoset. The name was originally applied to an albino variety.
Myogalid: One of the Myogalodæ, a family of Insectivora, including the desman, and allied species.
Maculation: The act of spotting; a spot; a blemish; a macula.
Mick: a person of Irish descent; -- an ethnic slur, offensive and disparaging.
Mich: To lie hid; to skulk; to act, or carry one's self, sneakingly.
Mica: The name of a group of minerals characterized by highly perfect cleavage, so that they readily separate into very thin leaves, more or less elastic.  They differ widely in composition, and vary in color from pale brown or yellow to green or black.  The transparent forms are used in lanterns, the doors of stoves, etc., being popularly called isinglass.  Formerly called also cat-silver, and glimmer.
Magisterial: Of or pertaining to a master or magistrate, or one in authority; having the manner of a magister; official; commanding; authoritative. Hence: Overbearing; dictatorial; dogmatic.
Morphologist: One who is versed in the science of morphology.
&Verbar;M\u00e9tis: The offspring of a white person and an American Indian.
motherfucker: A person who is deemed to be worthless or despicable; -- obscene and highly offensive.
mayoral: Of or pertaining to a mayor; as, the mayoral limousine.
&Verbar;Morbidezza: Delicacy or softness in the representation of flesh.
Membranous: Pertaining to, consisting of, or resembling, membrane; as, a membranous covering or lining.
Myrtaceae: A natural family of trees and shrubs yielding fragrant oils, including the myrtles, eucalyptus, clove, allspice, and guava; the myrtle family.
Mammillate: Having small nipples, or small protuberances like nipples or mammæ.
milkshake: A frothy drink of milk and flavoring and sometimes fruit or ice cream, shaken together or blended in  a blender.
main-topsail: a topsail set on the mainmast.
Monitory: Admonition; warning; especially, a monition proceeding from an ecclesiastical court, but not addressed to any one person.
Mutule: A projecting block worked under the corona of the Doric corice, in the same situation as the modillion of the Corinthian and Composite orders. See Illust. of Gutta.
main memory: The memory in a computer that holds programs and data for rapid access during execution of a program; it usually hold the largest quantity of rapid-access storage in a computer; -- also called RAM (random access memory.  It is contrasted to ROM, disk data storage, cache, registers and other forms of data storage.
Mistral: A violent and cold northwest wind experienced in the Mediterranean provinces of France, etc.
Muffineer: A dish for keeping muffins hot.
Macaranga gum: A gum of a crimson color, obtained from a tree (Macaranga Indica) that grows in the East Indies.  It is used in taking impressions of coins, medallions, etc., and sometimes as a medicine.
Minoress: See Franciscan Nuns, under Franciscan, a.
Microcoulomb: A measure of electrical quantity; the millionth part of one coulomb.
Mask: To take part as a masker in a masquerade.
Mash: To convert into a mash; to reduce to a soft pulpy state by beating or pressure; to bruise; to crush; as, to mash apples in a mill, or potatoes with a pestle.
Morocco: A fine kind of leather, prepared commonly from goatskin (though an inferior kind is made of sheepskin), and tanned with sumac and dyed of various colors; -- said to have been first made by the Moors.
Mast: To furnish with a mast or masts; to put the masts of in position; as, to mast a ship.
Mass: To form or collect into a mass; to form into a collective body; to bring together into masses; to assemble.
Misbeliever: One who believes wrongly; one who holds a false religion.
mid-off: the fielding position in cricket closest to the bowler on the off side.
&Verbar;Maxilla: The bone of either the upper or the under jaw.
Manilkara: A genus of large evergreen trees with milky latex; pantropical.
Madly: In a mad manner; without reason or understanding; wildly.
Minable: Such as can be mined; as, minable earth.
&Verbar;M\u00e9salliance: A marriage with a person of inferior social position; a misalliance.
Matted: Covered with a mat or mats; as, a matted floor.
manila tamarind: A common thorny tropical American tree (Pithecellobium dulce) having terminal racemes of yellow flowers followed by sickle-shaped or circinate edible pods and yielding good timber and a yellow dye and mucilaginous gum.
Matter: To regard as important; to take account of; to care for.
Monochromic: Made, or done, with a single color; as, a monochromic picture.  Called also, monochromatic and monochrome.
manual laborer: A person who works with the hands, rather than with the mind.
mahon stock: An annual cruciferous plant with reddish purple or white flowers (Malcolmia maritima).  It is called in England Virginia stock, but the plant comes from the Mediterranean.
Marvelous: Exciting wonder or surprise; astonishing; wonderful.
Metallurgist: One who works in metals, or prepares them for use; one who is skilled in metallurgy.
madagascar pepper: A climber (Piper nigrum) having dark red berries (peppercorns) when fully ripe; found in South India and Sri Lanka; naturalized in North Burma and Assam.
maine lobster: Any of several cold-water lobsters with large tender claws, caught from Maine to the Carolinas.
Mullein: Any plant of the genus Verbascum.  They are tall herbs having coarse leaves, and large flowers in dense spikes.  The common species, with densely woolly leaves, is Verbascum Thapsus.
manilla: See manila, manila hemp, manila paper.
&Verbar;Morale: The moral condition, or the condition in other respects, so far as it is affected by, or dependent upon, moral considerations, such as zeal, spirit, hope, and confidence; mental state, as of a body of men, an army, and the like.
Mandarin: A Chinese public officer or nobleman; a civil or military official in China and Annam.
March: The act of marching; a movement of soldiers from one stopping place to another; military progress; advance of troops.
Mackle: To blur, or be blurred, in printing, as if there were a double impression.
Monostich: A composition consisting of one verse only.
&Verbar;Magnificat: The song of the Virgin Mary, Luke i. 46; -- so called because it commences with this word in the Vulgate.
Macaronic: A heap of things confusedly mixed together; a jumble.
Mephistopheles: A familiar spirit mentioned in the old legend of Sir John Faustus, and a principal agent in Marlowe's play Dr. Faustus and in Goethe's Faust.  In medieval demonology, he was one of the seven chief devils.
Malacozoic: Of or pertaining to the Malacozoa.
Multifoil: Having more than five divisions or foils.
Mux: To mix in an untidy and offensive way; to make a mess of.
Mort: A variety of dummy whist for three players; also, the exposed or dummy hand in this game.
Militant: Engaged in warfare; fighting; combating; serving as a soldier.
Mug: A kind of ceramic or metal drinking cup, with a handle, -- usually cylindrical and without a lip.
Morn: The first part of the day; the morning; -- used chiefly in poetry.
Moro: A member of any of the Moros, a group one of various tribes of the southern Phillippine Islands, mostly Malays adhering to Mohammedanism.
militate against: To argue against; to cast doubt on; -- used in reference to facts which tend to disprove a hypothesis; as, the absence of a correlation of budget deficits with inflation militates against any causal relation between the two.  Opposite of support.
Mum: A sort of strong beer, originally made in Brunswick, Germany.
Mora: A leguminous tree of Guiana and Trinidad (Dimorphandra excelsa); also, its timber, used in shipbuilding and making furniture.
Maundy: The sacrament of the Lord's Supper.
mythologization: The construction of a myth; the restatement of a message as a myth.
Manorial: Of or pertaining to a manor.
Metaxylene: That variety of xylene, or dimethyl benzene, in which the two methyl groups occupy the meta position with reference to each other. It is a colorless inflammable liquid.
Mylodontidae: A natural family of extinct South American edentates.
Mesmerism: An earlier name for hypnosis or hypnotism, the art of inducing an extraordinary or abnormal state of the nervous system, in which the actor claims to control the actions, and communicate directly with the mind, of the recipient.  It is believed to be a state between sleep and wakefulness, in which a person is more susceptible to suggestion than when awake.  See Animal magnetism, under Magnetism.
Malt: To become malt; also, to make grain into malt.
Moir\u00e9: To give a watered or clouded appearance to (a surface).
Mall: A public access area containing a promenade for pedestrians; as, to gather near the Washington monument on the mall in Washington.
Malm: A kind of brick of a light brown or yellowish color, made of sand, clay, and chalk.
Male: An animal of the male sex.
Mesmerist: One who practices, or believes in, mesmerism.
Meridionality: The state of being in the meridian.
Murderous: Of or pertaining to murder; characterized by, or causing, murder or bloodshed; having the purpose or quality of murder; bloody; sanguinary; as, the murderous king; murderous rapine; murderous intent; a murderous assault.
Melting pot: A vessel in which anything is melted; a crucible.
Metapodial: Of or pertaining to the metapodialia, or to the parts of the limbs to which they belong.
Methodic: Arranged with regard to method; disposed in a suitable manner, or in a manner to illustrate a subject, or to facilitate practical observation; well-ordered; as, the methodical arrangement of arguments; a methodical treatise.
Merocele: Hernia in the thigh; femoral hernia .
malapropos: Unseasonable or unseasonably; unsuitable or unsuitably.
Metasomatism: An alteration in a mineral or rock mass when involving a chemical change of the substance, as of chrysolite to serpentine; -- opposed to ordinary metamorphism, as implying simply a recrystallization.
Mayweed: A composite plant (Anthemis Cotula), having a strong odor; dog's fennel.  It is a native of Europe, now common by the roadsides in the United States.
Misknow: To have a mistaken notion of or about.
main rotor: The assembly of large rotating airfoils (blades) on a helicopter that produce the lift to support the helicopter in the air.
melamine resin: A thermosetting plastic formed by the reaction of melamine and formaldehyde.  It is used for molding and for preparing laminated sheets used to surface counter tops, walls, and furniture.  The commercially marketed Formica (TM) is one type of melamine resin.
Multiversant: Turning into many shapes; assuming many forms; protean.
Melodramatic: Of or pertaining to melodrama; like or suitable to a melodrama; unnatural in situation or action.
Malic: Pertaining to, or obtained from, apples; as, malic acid.
Mauve: A color of a delicate purple, violet, or lilac.
mamoncillo: A tropical American tree (Melicocca bijuga, or Melicocca bijugatus) bearing a small edible fruit with green leathery skin and sweet juicy translucent pulp.
motivation: The act or process of motivating.
Miasmatist: One who has made a special study of miasma.
Midwifery: The art or practice of assisting women in childbirth; obstetrics.
Mournful: Full of sorrow; expressing, or intended to express, sorrow; mourning; grieving; sad; also, causing sorrow; saddening; grievous; as, a mournful person; mournful looks, tones, loss.
Mohammedanize: To make conformable to the principles, or customs and rites, of Mohammedanism.
Moratory: Of or pertaining to delay; esp., designating a law passed, as in a time of financial panic, to postpone or delay for a period the time at which notes, bills of exchange, and other obligations, shall mature or become due.
Maurist: A member of the Congregation of Saint Maur, an offshoot of the Benedictines, originating in France in the early part of the seventeenth century.  The Maurists have been distinguished for their interest in literature.
manic-depressive: A person suffering from manic-depressive psychosis.
magnetic induction: The process that makes a substance magnetic (temporarily or permanently).
Mesethmoid: Of or pertaining to the middle of the ethmoid region or ethmoid bone.
Miscegenation: A mixing of races; amalgamation, as by intermarriage of black and white.
Meagre: A large European sciænoid fish (Sciæna umbra or Sciæna aquila), having white bloodless flesh.  It is valued as a food fish.
&Verbar;Miohippus: An extinct Miocene mammal of the Horse family, closely related to the genus Anhithecrium, and having three usable hoofs on each foot.
Muscoidea: A superfamily of two-winged flies esp. the families: Muscidae; Gasterophilidae; Calliphoridae; and Tachinidae.
Myxocephalus: A genus of fish including the grubb (Myxocephalus aenaeus), a type of sculpin.
Manred: Homage or service rendered to a superior, as to a lord; vassalage.
Majority: The quality or condition of being major or greater; superiority.
Modernization: The act of rendering modern in style; the act or process of causing to conform to modern of thinking or acting.
&Verbar;Mimosa: A genus of leguminous plants, containing many species, and including the sensitive plants (Mimosa sensitiva, and Mimosa pudica).
mimeo: to make copies of using a mimeograph.
&Verbar;Mesobronchium: The main bronchus of each lung.
Munerary: Having the nature of a gift.
Marmolite: A thin, laminated variety of serpentine, usually of a pale green color.
mailbag: A bag in which mailed matter is conveyed or shipped under public authority.
Monkshood: A plant of the genus Aconitum; aconite. See Aconite.
Mediatorial: Of or pertaining to a mediator, or to mediation; mediatory; as, a mediatorial office.
marocain: A dress crepe; similar to Canton crepe.
Monotrematous: Of or pertaining to the Monotremata.
Metanephritic: Of or pertaining to the metanephros.
Moralist: One who moralizes; one who teaches or animadverts upon the duties of life; a writer of essays intended to correct vice and inculcate moral duties.
Moralism: A maxim or saying embodying a moral truth.
Mitigation: The act of mitigating, or the state of being mitigated; abatement or diminution of anything painful, harsh, severe, afflictive, or calamitous; as, the mitigation of pain, grief, rigor, severity, punishment, or penalty.
Multiplane: An aëroplane with three or more superposed main planes.
matin: Of or pertaining to the morning, or to matins; used in the morning; matutinal.
Mogen David: A hexagram{1a}, when used as the symbol of Judaism; called also Magen David and Star of David.  It is included on the flag of the state of Israel
Mainmast: The principal mast in a ship or other vessel.
madeira winter cherry: A small South American shrub (Solanum pseudocapsicum) cultivated as a houseplant for its abundant ornamental but poisonous red or yellow cherrylike fruit.
Midnight sun: The sun shining at midnight in the arctic or antarctic summer.
Myacidae: A natural family of soft-shell clams.
Metecorn: A quantity of corn formerly given by the lord to his customary tenants, as an encouragement to, or reward for, labor and faithful service.
Metalliform: Having the form or structure of a metal.
Multiferous: Bearing or producing much or many.
Mascot: A person who is supposed to bring good luck to the household to which he or she belongs.
Mahayana: a major school of Buddhism teaching social concern and universal salvation, found in China; Japan; Tibet; Nepal; Korea; and Mongolia.
Manual: A small book, such as may be carried in the hand, or conveniently handled; a handbook; specifically, the service book of the Roman Catholic Church.
Myelencephalous: Of or pertaining to the Myelencephala.
Mazama: A goatlike antelope (Haplocerus montanus) which inhabits the Rocky Mountains, frequenting the highest parts; -- called also mountain goat.
Metic: A sojourner; an immigrant; an alien resident in a Grecian city, but not a citizen.
Marmose: A species of small opossum (Didelphys murina) ranging from Mexico to Brazil.
Meadow: Of or pertaining to a meadow; of the nature of a meadow; produced, growing, or living in, a meadow.
marshiness: The state or condition of being marshy.
Majesticness: The quality or state of being majestic.
Manovery: A contrivance or maneuvering to catch game illegally.
man-eating shark: A term applied to sharks that attack humans, especially the great white shark (Carcharodon carcharias), a large aggressive shark widespread in warm seas.
Moloch: The fire god of the Ammonites in Canaan, to whom human sacrifices were offered; Molech.  Also applied figuratively.
Miting: A little one; -- used as a term of endearment.
Musculocutaneous: Pertaining both to muscles and skin; as, the musculocutaneous nerve.
myrmecophagous: feeding on ants but usually not living with them.
&Verbar;Metapodiale: One of the bones of either the metacarpus or metatarsus.
manhunt: An organized search (by police) for a person (charged with a crime).
Malpighian: Of, pertaining to, or discovered by, Marcello Malpighi, an Italian anatomist of the 17th century.
&Verbar;Murex: A genus of marine gastropods, having rough, and frequently spinose, shells, which are often highly colored inside; the rock shells.  They abound in tropical seas.
&Verbar;Myrcia: A large genus of tropical American trees and shrubs, nearly related to the true myrtles (Myrtus), from which they differ in having very few seeds in each berry.
Machiavelian: One who adopts the principles of Machiavelli; a cunning and unprincipled politician.
Melanochroite: A mineral of a red, or brownish or yellowish red color.  It is a chromate of lead; -- called also phœnicocroite.
Mameluke: One of a body of mounted soldiers recruited from slaves converted to Mohammedanism, who, during several centuries, had more or less control of the government of Egypt, until exterminated or dispersed by Mehemet Ali in 1811.
matchwood: wood in small pieces or splinters; as, the vessel was beaten to matchwood on the rocks.
Munify: To prepare for defense; to fortify.
manila paper: A durable brown or buff paper or thin cardboard with a smooth light brown finish, made of Manila hemp, and used as a wrapping paper, or as a cheap printing and writing paper. The name is also given to inferior papers, made of other fiber.
Mudder: a racehorse that exhibits a better than usual performance when the racetrack is wet or muddy.
Misshape: To shape ill; to give an ill or unnatural from to; to deform.
Mootman: One who argued moot cases in the inns of court.
Melanian: One of a family of fresh-water pectinibranchiate mollusks, having a turret-shaped shell.
Meso-: A combining form denoting in the middle, intermediate.
&Verbar;Mesymnicum: A repetition at the end of a stanza.
Matronlike: Like a matron; sedate; grave; matronly.
Miller: One who keeps or attends a flour mill or gristmill.
Mineralizer: An element which is combined with a metal, thus forming an ore.  Thus, in galena, or lead ore, sulphur is a mineralizer; in hematite, oxygen is a mineralizer.
Milled: Having been subjected to some process of milling.
Molluscoid: Resembling the true mollusks; belonging to the Molluscoidea.
Multivious: Having many ways or roads; by many ways.
Mynheer: The Dutch equivalent of Mr. or Sir; hence, a Dutchman.
machine translation: The translation of human language from one language to another by a computer; -- a branch of artificial intelligence.
Microtomy: The art of using the microtome; investigation carried on with the microtome.
marsupite: A fossil crinoid of the genus Marsupites, resembling a purse in form.
Mightily: In a mighty manner; with might; with great earnestness; vigorously; powerfully.
Magellanic cloud: Either of two conspicuous celestial nebulæ near the south celestial pole, resembling thin white clouds, each of which is a galaxy{2} smaller than but separate from the Milky Way galaxy, and together they are the galactic formations nearest to our galaxy.  They are not visible from the northern hemisphere, and are named after Ferdinand Magellan, who saw them in his expedition, which passed through the Strait of Magellan in South America, and one ship of which completed the first circumnavigation of the globe.
Microtome: An instrument for making very thin sections for microscopical examination.
Mealy: Having the qualities of meal; resembling meal; soft, dry, and friable; easily reduced to a condition resembling meal; as, a mealy potato.
manatee: Any species of Trichechus, a genus of sirenians; -- called also sea cow.
Mantilla: A lady's light cloak of cape of silk, velvet, lace, or the like.
macromolecular: Of, pertaining to, or consisting of macromolecules.
mandarin duck: A showy crested Asiatic duck (Aix galericulata, formerly Dendronessa galericulata), often domesticated, and regarded by the Chinese as an emblem of conjugal affection.
Metaphysics: The science of real as distinguished from phenomenal being; ontology; also, the science of being, with reference to its abstract and universal conditions, as distinguished from the science of determined or concrete being; the science of the conceptions and relations which are necessarily implied as true of every kind of being; philosophy in general; first principles, or the science of first principles.
Misterm: To call by a wrong name; to miscall.
&Verbar;Myeloplax: One of the huge multinucleated cells found in the marrow of bone and occasionally in other parts; a giant cell. See Osteoclast.
Mumbo Jumbo: Among the Mandingos of the western Sudan, a bugbear by means of which the women are terrified and disciplined by societies of the men, one of whom assumes a masquerade for the purpose; hence, loosely, any Negro idol, fetish, or bugaboo.
Macadamization: The process or act of macadamizing.
Mohair: The long silky hair or wool of the Angora goat of Asia Minor; also, a fabric made from this material, or an imitation of such fabric.
Malcontent: One who discontented; especially, a discontented subject of a government; one who expresses his discontent by words or overt acts.
Manchineel: A euphorbiaceous tree (Hippomane Mancinella) of tropical America, having a poisonous and blistering milky juice, and poisonous acrid fruit somewhat resembling an apple.
&Verbar;Marsupialia: A subclass of Mammalia, including nearly all the mammals of Australia and the adjacent islands, together with the opossums of America.  They differ from ordinary mammals in having the corpus callosum very small, in being implacental, and in having their young born while very immature.  The female generally carries the young for some time after birth in an external pouch, or marsupium.  Called also Marsupiata.
Microscopy: The use of the microscope; investigation with the microscope.
male orgasm: An orgasm in a male animal accompanied by the ejaculation of semen.
Microscope: An optical instrument, consisting of a lens, or combination of lenses, for making an enlarged image of an object which is too minute to be viewed by the naked eye.
Misdoing: A wrong done; a fault or crime; an offense; as, it was my misdoing.
msasa: Amall shrubby African tree (Brachystegia speciformis) having compound leaves and racemes of small fragrant green flowers.
Muscicapidae: A natural family of Old World (true) flycatchers.
Motive: To prompt or incite by a motive or motives; to move.
Monstrosity: The state of being monstrous, or out of the common order of nature; that which is monstrous; a monster.
&Verbar;Maggiore: Greater, in respect to scales, intervals, etc., when used in opposition to minor; major.
Midland: The interior or central region of a country; -- usually in the plural.
Minster: A church of a monastery.  The name is often retained and applied to the church after the monastery has ceased to exist (as Beverly Minster, Southwell Minster, etc.), and is also improperly used for any large church.
&Verbar;Metrosideros: A myrtaceous genus of trees or shrubs, found in Australia and the South Sea Islands, and having very hard wood.  Metrosideros vera is the true ironwood.
Monkey-bread: The fruit of the Adansonia digitata; also, the tree. See Adansonia.
mantled: Covered with or as if with clothes or a wrap or cloak.
Mandarinic: Appropriate or peculiar to a mandarin.
mangrove family: A natural family (Rhizophoraceae) of trees and shrubs that usually form dense jungles along tropical seacoasts.  It includes the mangrove Rhizophora Mangle.
Monkflower: A name of certain curious orchids which bear three kinds of flowers formerly referred to three genera, but now ascertained to be sexually different forms of the same genus (Catasetum tridentatum, etc.).
Morphine: A bitter white crystalline alkaloid found in opium, possessing strong narcotic properties, and much used as an anodyne; -- called also morphia, and morphina.
Malaysian: Of or pertaining to or characteristic of Malaysia or its people or their culture; as, Malaysian police cracked down hard on drug smugglers; Malaysian poetry.
Maoism: A form of communism developed in China by Mao Zedong.
Mastication: The act or operation of masticating; chewing, as of food.
Malpractice: Evil practice; illegal or immoral conduct; practice contrary to established rules; specifically, the treatment of a case by a surgeon or physician in a manner which is contrary to accepted rules and productive of unfavorable results.
Micrococcal: Of or pertaining to micrococci; caused by micrococci.
Mediative: Pertaining to mediation; used in mediation; as, mediative efforts.
Metonymic: Used by way of metonymy; using the name of one thing for that of another with which it is closely associated.
Mediator: One who mediates; especially, one who interposes between parties at variance for the purpose of reconciling them; hence, an intercessor.
Moschatel: A plant of the genus Adoxa (Adoxa moschatellina), the flowers of which are pale green, and have a faint musky smell.  It is found in woods in all parts of Europe, and is called also hollow root and musk crowfoot.
magnetic recorder: A device for making records (of sound, data, etc.) on magnetic media such as magnetic tape or wire.
Mahovo: A device for saving power in stopping and starting a railroad car, by means of a heavy fly wheel.
modeled: resembling sculpture; as, her finely modeled features.
meanspirited: Of a mean spirit; petty; small-minded; base; groveling; -- of people.
Mareschal: A military officer of high rank; a marshal.
Myodynamometer: An instrument for measuring the muscular strength of man or of other animals; a dynamometer.
Mylodon: An extinct genus of large slothlike American edentates, allied to Megatherium.
Maginot line: A line of fortifications built before World War II to protect France's eastern border.
man of letters: A writer, especially one who writes for a living.
Making: The act of one who makes; workmanship; fabrication; construction; as, this is cloth of your own making; the making of peace or war was in his power.
Municipalize: To bring under municipal oversight or control; as, a municipalized industry.
Mote: A small particle, as of floating dust; anything proverbially small; a speck.
Mantinea: The site of three famous battles among Greek city-states: in 418 BC and 362 BC and 207 BC.
Moth: Any nocturnal lepidopterous insect, or any not included among the butterflies; as, the luna moth; Io moth; hawk moth.
Merrythought: The forked bone of a fowl's breast; -- called also wishbone. See Furculum.
Microcline: A mineral of the feldspar group, like orthoclase or common feldspar in composition, but triclinic in form.
Mordicant: Biting; acrid; as, the mordicant quality of a body.
Musician: One skilled in the art or science of music; esp., a skilled singer, or performer on a musical instrument.
Monophyodont: Having but one set of teeth; -- opposed to diphyodont.
Monthly: Once a month; in every month; as, the moon changes monthly.
Medicable: Capable of being medicated; admitting of being cured or healed.
Melodist: A composer or singer of melodies.
monomer: The basic conceptual building unit of a polymer; a molecule of low molecular weight which may combine with other molecules to form a molecule in a chain or branched form having high molecular weight; as, amino acids are the monomer units which are combined to form proteins; vinylic plastics are formed from monomers having a vinyl group.
Magnify: To have the power of causing objects to appear larger than they really are; to increase the apparent dimensions of objects; as, some lenses magnify but little.
Megalops: A larva, in a stage following the zoëa, in the development of most crabs. In this stage the legs and abdominal appendages have appeared, the abdomen is relatively long, and the eyes are large. Also used adjectively.
moderated: having elements or qualities mixed in proper or suitable proportions; especially, made less severe.  Contrasted with harsh.
Muscovy duck: A duck (Cairina moschata), larger than the common duck, often raised in poultry yards. Called also musk duck.  It is native of tropical America, from Mexico to Southern Brazil.
mainstream: TO place (a student) in regular school classes; -- used especially of mentally or physically handicapped children.
Mower: One who, or that which, mows; a mowing machine; as, a lawn mower.
Monoclinal: Having one oblique inclination; -- applied to strata that dip in only one direction from the axis of elevation.
Mancus: An old Anglo Saxon coin both of gold and silver, and of variously estimated values.  The silver mancus was equal to about one shilling of modern English money.
mesotartaric: Pertaining to, or designating, an acid called also inactive tartaric acid.  It is an optically inactive stereoisomer of tartaric acid due to internal compensation of the rotatory activity of the two asymmetric centers; it has a plane of symmetry in the molecule.
machine-made: made by a machine.  Contrasted with handmade.
Managership: The office or position of a manager.
Mischief-making: Causing harm; exciting enmity or quarrels.
malice: Enmity of heart; malevolence; ill will; a spirit delighting in harm or misfortune to another; a disposition to injure another; a malignant design of evil.
Micropyle: An opening in the membranes surrounding the ovum, by which nutrition is assisted and the entrance of the spermatozoa permitted.
&Verbar;Modius: A dry measure, containing about a peck.
&Verbar;Morosaurus: An extinct genus of large herbivorous dinosaurs, found in Jurassic strata in America.
manna gum: A tall tree (Eucalyptus viminalis) yielding a false manna.
Melodic: Of the nature of melody; relating to, containing, or made up of, melody; melodious.
machine gun: A fully automatic rapid-firing rifle, which continues to fire bullets repeatedly as long as the trigger is depressed; lighter versions may be carried in the hands, and heavier versions may be mounted on a tripod, vehicle, or other mount.  The lighweight versions are sometimes called a submachine gun.
Mobbish: Like a mob; tumultuous; lawless; as, a mobbish act.
minor-league: Of or pertaining to a minor league.
Mobilize: To assemble and organize and make ready for use or action; as, to mobilize volunteers for the election campaign.
Morose: Of a sour temper; sullen and austere; ill-humored; severe.
Mysidae: A natural family of small shrimplike crustaceans.
Moton: A small plate covering the armpit in armor of the 14th century and later.
murdered: killed unlawfully; as, the murdered woman.
Motor: Causing or setting up motion; pertaining to organs of motion; -- applied especially in physiology to those nerves or nerve fibers which only convey impressions from a nerve center to muscles, thereby causing motion.
&Verbar;Mero: Any of several large groupers of warm seas, esp. the guasa (Epinephelus guaza), the red grouper (Epinephelus morio), the black grouper (Epinephelus nigritas), distinguished as Me"ro de lo al"to (&unr_;), and a species called also rock hind, distinguished as Me"ro ca*brol"la (&unr_;).
-mere: A combining form meaning part, portion; as, blastomere, epimere.
Magnolia: A genus of American and Asiatic trees, with aromatic bark and large sweet-scented whitish or reddish flowers.
Malassimilation: Imperfect digestion of the several leading constituents of the food.
Monomyarian: Of or pertaining to the Monomya.
Misfit: The act or the state of fitting badly; as, a misfit in making a coat; a ludicrous misfit.
Mutilation: The act of mutilating, or the state of being mutilated; deprivation of a limb or of an essential part.
MVP: most valuable player; the player judged to be the most important to the sport, also the name of the award given to that player.
